fields.headline: Breathless bewitcher
fields.standfirst:
Dee Dee Bridgewater
Barbican, London ***
fields.trailText:
Dee Dee Bridgewater
Barbican, London ***
fields.body:
If ever someone missed out on the silent movie era, it was Bridgewater. She would have been a star with those wonderfully expressive, surprised eyes, suggestive walk and fondness for tableaux.

But it is hard to imagine her keeping quiet for long. Song was just one of a range of vocal gears she employed in her tribute to Ella Fitzgerald; she frequently zoomed from whisper to scat to roar to chuckle in seconds. It was a hair-raising ride that left Bridgewater gasping, not to mention the audience.

"Are you feeling more relaxed now? Just let me know if there's something you need," she purred with a sultry hip-wiggle, having slammed through Gillespie's Night in Tunisia and a couple of Ella numbers, including a Let's Do It, during which she serenaded a listener in the front row.

It was hard to tell whether her band was keeping her in check or egging her on. Thierry Eliez, her musical partner for 10 years, vaulted between piano and organ, sometimes sitting on his foot to give himself greater leverage as he jack-hammered the keys, looking at times like a DJ scratching a track and then, wonderfully, exploding into vaudeville on Basin Street Blues. Bridgewater's own rendition of this Ella standard was playful, gutsy, but too clean to match her heroine's tearing growliness.

Vampiric in her floaty dress and kittenish in her walk, she showed herself a mistress of quick changes, from Eartha Kitt animality to sentimentality (Dear Ella) to a stylish bit of Herbie Hancock-style scat on Love for Sale. The bluesy numbers gave rein to her energy as she trampo lined off vibrant organ sounds, but particularly fine was a quieter new track, Kurt Weill's My Ship.

It seemed at first that the bowed bass accompaniment was too fragile to sustain her resonance, but when Eliez's piano released the tension with cascades of high notes, the audience held its breath at the magic of the moment.

fields.headline: Focus:  Dairy Crest
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Dairy Crest has just become Britain's largest dairy company - but "milk" seems to be a taboo word around the business.
fields.body:
Dairy Crest has just become Britain's largest dairy company - but "milk" seems to be a taboo word around the business.

As the group announced a £1m fall in annual pre-tax profits to £44m, the only things the management wanted to talk about were butter, cheese and yoghurt.

The chief executive of Dairy Crest, John Houliston, is still basking in the success of winning a fierce bidding battle with Robert Wiseman Dairies to snatch Unigate's milk and cheese businesses for £250m last month.

That deal has sparked a 20% revival in the value of the company's shares.

The acquisition means Dairy Crest processes a quarter of Britain's entire milk production, with more than 9,000 employees in 23 factories.

The only problem is that milk is a declining industry - Britons have been buying less and less for years.

So Mr Houliston prefers to dwell on Clover spreads, stilton cheese and Petits Filous desserts - which are growing, albeit at rather meagre, single-digit levels.

Dairy Crest has some decent brands - Cathedral City cheddar, for instance, managed 20% growth in volume sales in a market which expanded just 1%. Clover is doing well as a happy medium between "unhealthy" butter and low-fat spreads.

However, the bulk of the business still revolves around selling billions of litres of milk.

Instead of getting a pint from the milkman every day, Britons have switched to buying several pints a week from the local supermarket.

The dairy industry has been in no state to respond to this problem, having been through big changes with the break-up of the Milk Marque co-operative.

This summer, however, the industry is planning to begin a major advertising campaign promoting the virtues of milk. But this is unlikely to be enough to inject much excitement into the sector - Dairy Crest's shares slipped 5.5p to 177.5p yesterday.

fields.headline: Branson lays into BA again
fields.standfirst:
Virgin joins EasyJet in attack on KLM merger

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson yesterday led the charge against the proposed merger between British Airways and KLM, the Dutch airline, claiming it would be a blow for European consumers.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson yesterday led the charge against the proposed merger between British Airways and KLM, the Dutch airline, claiming it would be a blow for European consumers.

Low-cost airline EasyJet joined the fray by demanding an inquiry into the proposed merger by the European competition authorities.

The criticism came as BA and KLM confirmed that they had started negotiations on a "possible combination of their businesses". Sir Richard, a long-time BA rival as head of Virgin Atlantic, blasted the proposals, which could create Europe's largest airline in terms of flights, as a "merger too far".

The European talks come amid reports that American Airlines, the second largest airline in the US, had discussed a possible merger with Delta, America's third largest airline.

Neither company would comment on the talks yesterday. American Airlines, which has an alliance with BA, is also understood to have approached Northwest Airlines, a KLM partner, about a possible combination.

Such an industry merry-go-round has been prompted by last month's announcement by United Airlines, the world's largest airline, that it wanted to buy rival US Airways. This merger is expected to provoke extensive regulatory scrutiny as airlines seek to cut costs by pooling resources.

Several analysts said yesterday that the rash of merger discussions by American and other US rivals may be intended to scare regulators into derailing the proposed merger of UAL and US Air. Sir Richard Branson said yesterday that a combination of BA, AA, Northwest and KLM "would destroy competition on the north Atlantic and at Heathrow and in the UK regions".

Regulators are expected to focus on landing slots at both Heathrow and Schiphol in Amsterdam. The UK landing slots are already a significant bone of contention for negotiations between the US and British governments over so-called "open skies" talks set to restart next week.

Sources close to BA stressed that the talks with KLM were unlikely to result in any deal within the next few days.

fields.headline: Vodafone in £500m tax row
fields.trailText: A complex tax avoidance plan involving the transfer of the German telecoms group Mannesmann to an offshore tax haven after its takeover by Britain's Vodafone AirTouch is believed to have triggered the much publicised row between chief executive Chris Gent and chancellor Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
A complex tax avoidance plan involving the transfer of the German telecoms group Mannesmann to an offshore tax haven after its takeover by Britain's Vodafone AirTouch is believed to have triggered the much publicised row between chief executive Chris Gent and chancellor Gordon Brown.

International tax experts say Vodafone appears to have been relying on a controversial mechanism to gain tax breaks running into hundreds of millions of pounds per year through the use of controlled foreign companies, or CFCs, a tax loophole which was closed in the Budget.

Previously, it was assumed that a threat by Mr Gent to relocate Vodafone abroad was sparked solely by budget changes affecting the operation of "mixer companies", which are used by multinationals to smooth the flow of profits from their international operations before the money enters Britain and is taxed.

Vodafone, Britain's biggest company - which claims it will lose £500m from changes to mixers and CFCs announced in the Budget - bought Mannesmann for £107bn earlier this year.

It is thought the British company was aiming to hold the German firm in an offshore haven rather than keep it as a direct subsidiary in order to avoid tax payments.

Tax experts say that by doing that, Vodafone would have been able to reduce its tax bills in Germany and Britain, paying only at the preferential rate in the haven.

"It [Mannesmann] was bought without a holding company," said one industry source familiar with the takeover. "However over a period of time - to maximise tax efficiency - it would not remain as a direct subsidiary of Vodafone."

Since 1984, there have been rules designed to stop British multinationals avoiding tax in this country by diverting income to CFCs in tax havens. Genuine business transactions escape these rules.

However, multinationals have been attempting to get around the regime by creating artificial streams of income between their various corporate entities.

In Vodafone AirTouch's case, it is thought the company wanted to set up an offshore holding company, probably in Luxembourg, Ireland or Switzerland, which it would have been able to use to pump debt into Mannesmann, which is based in a high tax country.

Mannesmann would then be able to reduce the tax bill on its German profits because the "loan" from the holding company would generate interest payments - which are tax deductible.

At the same time, because the interest payments from Mannesmann to the offshore holding company would not have entered Britain, they would have avoided UK tax.

"The company could avoid tax in the high tax country simply by paying the interest to the UK," said a tax source. "Tax would then be payable at the UK rate on the interest.

"But by choosing to divert the interest to the holding company it is able to avoid UK tax and so reduce the tax rate on the interest to below the UK rate."

Gordon Brown's proposed budget legislation, heavily criticised by the big business lobby for undermining British competitiveness, is designed to prevent this kinds of practice. As before, the new rules would only apply in cases of British tax avoidance.

The Inland Revenue, Treasury and Vodafone, who have held discussions over the new tax rules on CFCs, refused to comment. A Vodafone spokesman said: "This is a matter for Vodafone and the government that is strictly confidential. We are not going to comment on this at all."

fields.headline: Abbey looks deeper into cyberspace
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Yet another internet bank will take to the small screen this weekend as the race for cyberspace banking customers gathers pace. This time the advertiser will be Cahoot, Abbey National's internet venture which aims not to be just a bank but also a shopping experience.
fields.body:
Yet another internet bank will take to the small screen this weekend as the race for cyberspace banking customers gathers pace. This time the advertiser will be Cahoot, Abbey National's internet venture which aims not to be just a bank but also a shopping experience.

Last night, ahead of Monday's launch, Cahoot was being coy about the interest rates it would offer other than to say that the rates would be customised for customers.

The key to the idea is to be low cost - it employs just 56 staff - and grab a 5% share of the internet banking market by 2003. At about the same time it should start to make a profit. Abbey spent £50m on Cahoot last year, as well as £30m on its own-brand internet bank and a further £20m on various online projects.

Its own-branded retail internet bank, launched four weeks ago, is already claiming to have 120,000 customers, putting it on track for 1m customers in 12 months.

Abbey yesterday tried to impress the City with its next generation of e-credentials by announcing a mobile phone deal with Carphone Warehouse and Orange.

It also wants to be big in the world of digital TV, where it sets itself the target to be the dominant player. In a sad reflection of the TV viewer, the first 75,000 or so registrations for digital banking show that most activity takes place at 7.59pm each evening, the gap between Coronation Street and The Bill.

As with its closest rival the Halifax, the internet is also the avenue for Abbey to try to break into the business of banking to small businesses, where the dominance of the "big four" is already being investigated by the competition commission.

But despite all the hype surrounding yesterday's announcements, the City was left cold as Abbey's shares drifted down 5% to 867.5p.

One thing that did emerge from yesterday's presentations is the fact that by getting customers to use the net, Abbey can manage accounts at 60% of the cost of traditional equivalents in branches. That kind of statistic is likely to be true for all the banks, and it remains to be seen whether they will pass the lower costs on their customers or please the City by boosting their profits.

fields.headline: Carphone king worth £1bn
fields.standfirst: The founder built a chain of 800 stores with a loan of £6,000; now flotation will give him data market firepower
fields.trailText: Charles Dunstone, founder of Carphone Warehouse, will soon be worth almost £1bn after the mobile phone retailer yesterday confirmed plans for a stock market flotation.
fields.body:
Charles Dunstone, founder of Carphone Warehouse, will soon be worth almost £1bn after the mobile phone retailer yesterday confirmed plans for a stock market flotation.

A far higher valuation has been put on the business than previously, with the highest new estimate giving it a price tag of some £2bn.

Mr Dunstone and fellow directors David Ross and Guy Johnson will sell part of their stakes and bank £200m cash between them. The rest of Mr Dunstone's wealth will be held in shares. Mr Ross, a childhood friend who is chief operating officer, owns a third of the business - giving him personal wealth of £660m.

Mr Dunstone, who founded the business with a £6,000 loan in 1989, described yesterday as emotional. "We had no idea how enormous this market would become when we started the business back then, and anybody who says they did is a liar."

Carphone Warehouse has more than 800 stores in 14 countries across Europe and is buying a further 98 in Germany. Sales last year were almost £700m, and it employs more than 4,000 staff.

The sale of new shares will raise another £200m for further acquisitions while the shares will give the company paper currency for deals.

Mr Dunstone, 35, said he had to be convinced of the merit of putting the company under the City's gaze. The board had been considering the move for five years.

"The opportunity out there is so enormous that we have to get into Europe and be ready for the data revolution on mobile phones," he said. "We have had this fantastic market based on voice services which is about to restart and we want to be as fit as possible."

The flotation will see 20% of the company on the market, although that figure will be nearer 25% if strong demand means a "greenshoe" is used to make more shares available. The offer will be open to institutions, retail investors and staff who will also enjoy a handout of share options.

Mr Dunstone, who is paid a relatively modest salary of £170,000 said he had not tempted fate by drawing up a shopping list. "None of us live particularly flamboyantly and that won't change."

The western Europe market has 173m mobile phone users - 45% of the population - up from 102m a year ago. High speed internet access, video phones and other new services lead analysts to believe the market for replacement handsets will dwarf new subscribers in coming years.

Mr Dunstone shrugged off the threat from supermarkets and the four networks which have been buying shops and selling direct to consumers. The grocers, he said, were selling entry level pre-pay phones while Carphone Warehouse remained independent.

He said he was unconcerned by recent market turmoil. "Nobody argues that wireless is a fast growing market, but with us you also have a solid real business with profits. We could be seen as a good compromise for investors."

The prospectus will be published later this month with pricing, allocation and trading of shares due in July.

webTitle: Manufacturing breathes sigh of relief over rates

fields.headline: Manufacturing breathes sigh of relief over rates
fields.trailText: Hopes that borrowing costs may have reached their peak were raised yesterday after the Bank of England left its key interest rates on hold at 6% for the fourth month in a row.
fields.body:
Hopes that borrowing costs may have reached their peak were raised yesterday after the Bank of England left its key interest rates on hold at 6% for the fourth month in a row.

The decision was greeted with relief by industry and homeowners as new figures underlined the fragile state of Britain's manufacturing sector. Government figures showed firms cut output by 0.2% in April, completing a month of weak data which had led many City economists to predict that the Bank would make no change to rates yesterday.

"Not only is manufacturing back from the brink of a technical recession, but consumer activity also appears to be easing, while the housing market is coming off the boil," said Dharshini David at HSBC.

The office for national statistics said the fall was the result of a bad month in the car industry. Output fell almost 10% as uncertainty over the future of Rover's Longbridge plant and the impact of the pound's strength took their toll.

"We believe that from here the arguments may start to switch toward when the Bank will look to cut rates," said Neil Parker, senior European economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland.

But he warned there was still a danger that the pound could plunge, forcing the Bank to raise interest rates.

The pound took a tumble immediately after the Bank's monetary policy committee announced their decision. It fell to fresh five month lows against the euro, trading at above 63p for the first time since January 6th, equivalent to DM3.10, and was also down against the dollar.

The pound has now lost more than 7% against the currencies of Britain's major trading partners since the monetary policy committee last met and is now below the Bank's forecast.

However, industry leaders cautioned the Bank against reacting too rapidly to the pound's recent bout of weakness. "The Bank is right to avoid a knee-jerk reaction to initial signs of a weaker pound," said Dr Ian Peters, deputy director general of the British Chambers of Commerce. "Sterling remains above a level at which UK manufacturers and exporters can compete effectively and this is having damaging knock-on effects across the wider economy." The BCC would oppose another rate rise unless the pound dropped below the equivalent of DM3.

fields.headline: Human face of musicals
fields.standfirst:
Hard Times
Theatre Royal Haymarket, London
***
fields.trailText:
Hard Times
Theatre Royal Haymarket, London
***
fields.body:
It may not be good Dickens. It may not have the pizzazz of Oliver! But after so many musicals that seem to be written by computers and performed by androids, this show at least is the work of recognisable human beings and has the ever-amiable Roy Hudd to nudge it into our good graces.

Even though Chris Tookey and Hugh Thomas co-wrote this musical when they were Oxford undergraduates, no one could accuse them of approaching the novel with Leavisite seriousness. In fact, they frame the action as if it were being presented by Mr Sleary's Circus which creates several problems. The main one is that it undercuts the social anger that underlies Dickens's portrait of heartless Gradgrind utilitarianism and of the suffering of Coketown's industrial workers.

The novel offers a running battle between a rigidly statistical view of human beings and the claims of imagination. But, since the story is here being presented by circus performers, cheerfulness reigns throughout.

What the device does do is enable Tookey and Thomas to tap into the world not just of circus but of music hall, melodrama and panto. Indeed their 27 songs range over the whole entertainment spectrum including romantic ballads, G and S patter and even, anachronistically, 40s Hollywood.

Students of Dickens may wince at his transformation of the mysterious Mrs Pegler into a comic, rural fussbudget. But Hudd acts as the evening's jovial master of ceremonies, bringing a wonderful whiff of Archie Rice to the proceedings.

No one could claim that this show pushes out the boundaries of the musical and Tookey's own production could usefully do with a bit of Joan Littlewood's improvisatory freedom. But this tuppence-coloured tuner reminds us of the days when the musical was a source of innocent delight.

 Until August 5. Box office: 020-7930 8800 .

fields.headline: Berlioz with words
fields.standfirst:
Beatrice et Benedict
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
Beatrice et Benedict
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
Berlioz's last opera is a problem, dramatically if not musically. It is a divertissement more than a fully rounded stage work, which pares away Shakespeare's Much Ado About Nothing to leave just the essential relationship between Beatrice and Benedick, counterpointed against the romantic love of Hero for Claudio.

In the tradition of the French opéra comique the musical numbers are connected with dialogue, and that nowadays presents the main problem in performance - do you keep all of Berlioz's text, and have a probably polyglot collection of singers struggling through the speech in bad French, or find some alternative?

For the latest instalment of his Berlioz Odyssey with the London Symphony Orchestra, Colin Davis came up with a curious hybrid. With singers to the left of him and actors to the right, he conducted a performance in which the score was threaded through with chunks of the original Shakespeare selected by the director Elijah Moshinsky. It provided a (sometimes not very convincing) continuity but little conviction; there was always a massive change of gear when text (spiritedly delivered by a line-up headed by Barbara Flynn and Hilton McRae) gave way to music. Far better to have dispensed with the spoken words altogether.

Certainly the musical performances were more than good enough to stand alone. Guided by Davis the LSO is masterly in Berlioz; they make the music dance and take wing, while their hushed string playing at the end of the first act could only have been achieved by an orchestra of the very highest possible class. Perhaps the Albanian mezzo Enkelejda Shkosa was miscast as Beatrice (a gorgeously velvet voice, but a bit weighty for a work that Berlioz described as "a caprice written with the point of a needle"), but Kenneth Tarver's Benedict was nimble and elegant, Susan Gritton's Hero impassioned and commanding, and Sara Mingardo a luxury piece of casting as Ursule. David Wilson-Johnson nearly stole the show, and all the dramatic plaudits certainly, in his single number as Somarone.

 Repeated at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), tonight; and broadcast on Radio 3.

webTitle: MPC proves itself for third year running

fields.headline: MPC proves itself for third year running
fields.standfirst: Whether by skill or sheer luck, the interest rate setting body has met with success
fields.trailText: There was no birthday cake and no celebration yesterday when the Bank of England marked the end of its third full year of setting interest rates. Instead it was business as usual, with a simple statement announcing that borrowing costs had been left at 6% for the fourth consecutive month.
fields.body:
There was no birthday cake and no celebration yesterday when the Bank of England marked the end of its third full year of setting interest rates. Instead it was business as usual, with a simple statement announcing that borrowing costs had been left at 6% for the fourth consecutive month.

Operational independence for the Bank was Labour's first big decision following its victory in May 1997, coming just five days after the election. Gordon Brown set interest rates himself only once before coming up with a system under which the government would set an inflation target and charge the Bank's nine-strong monetary policy committee to hit it.

Some of the concerns expressed about the MPC when it was set up remain. There are some who argue that it is undemocratic to leave the main tool of economic policy in the hands of technocrats; others who say that independent banks inevitably err on the side of deflationary policies; still others who say that it is asking for trouble to have different hands on the monetary and fiscal policy levers.

All that said, however, the Bank's record in conducting monetary policy over the past three years has been good.

The economy is in its ninth year of growth, unemployment - measured by the claimant count, admittedly - is the lowest in the G7 at 3.9% and inflation - on a harmonised basis - is the lowest in the European Union. The government's target measure of inflation - which excludes mortgage interest payments - has remained close to its 2.5% target, and has been slightly below it for the past year.

No bed of roses
Not everything in the garden is rosy. While the economy has continued to expand, growth has been slower under Labour than it was under the Conservatives, and exporters have been rightly alarmed at the difficulties they have been caused by the strong pound.

But the fact remains that the gyrations of the economy have been much less pronounced in the most recent cycle than they were during the booms and busts of the 1970s, 1980s and early 1990s.

This may be the result of changing economic circumstances, with globalisation helping to keep the lid on inflation. It may be that the MPC has just been lucky, and has yet to be tested in a real recession. However, it is also the case that the government's decision to make the inflation target symmetrical - with an undershoot considered to be as serious as an overshoot - was a crucial factor in ensuring the MPC worked effectively.

The outside members of the committee have been well chosen, and have acted with sensitivity and no little skill. DeAnne Julius and Sushil Wadhwani have both made their presence felt on the committee, challenging the orthodox view.

The MPC began by increasing interest rates at each of its first three meetings. It believed that there had been a build-up of inflationary pressure in the run-up to the election and that this was likely to be exacerbated by the windfall gains for consumers from the demutualisation of building societies and insurance companies in the summer of 1997. The tightening continued into 1998, when the MPC made its one real blunder by pushing rates to 7.5% in June on the back of unreliable figures which appeared to show an acceleration in wage inflation.

With the global economy weakening rapidly, the Bank was guilty of overkill - and this became apparent when the Russian crisis blew up two months later.

The MPC then reacted swiftly and decisively, cutting rates seven times between September 1998 and June 1999. The easing of policy meant that although the economy was perilously close to recession in the winter of 1998/9 it did not actually tip over the edge, and by the summer of last year growth had recovered so quickly that the Bank felt the need once more for a touch on the brakes. As a result, rates were raised four times between September and February, but since then they have been left on hold at 6%, exactly where they were on election day in 1997.

Hyperactive
Only once - between November 1997 and June 1998 - has the MPC left rates unchanged for longer than in the most recent four-month period. The fact that it has moved rates 17 times in three years - double the eight changes in the three years leading up to May 1997 - has drawn accusations that the Bank has adopted a hyperactive stance, and is trying to do the impossible by fine-tuning the economy with minuscule base-rate variations.

Most of the moves have been justified either by the state of domestic and global economic conditions or by the remit laid down by the government, which means that the MPC has a single target - inflation - and a single policy instrument for hitting it - interest rates.

The argument that the government should change the remit to take into account the exchange rate is likely to fall on deaf ears. A more likely fate is that the MPC's reward for its success will be its abolition when Britain joins the euro.

There may not be many more birthdays to come.

fields.headline: Politics taken out of statistics
fields.standfirst: Chancellor clings on to control of retail price index
fields.trailText: Ministers are to cede control over sensitive political statistics relating to health, education and crime to an independent auditor in an attempt to overcome public mistrust of official figures.
fields.body:
Ministers are to cede control over sensitive political statistics relating to health, education and crime to an independent auditor in an attempt to overcome public mistrust of official figures.

After a decade in which the reputation of government statisticians has been tarnished by political manipulation of unemployment figures and errors in the compilation of earnings figures, a new statistics commission will be charged with ensuring the independence and integrity of official data.

The commission - to be staffed by leading economists and statisticians and headed by Sir John Kingman, a former president of the Royal Statistical Society - will warn ministers if it is concerned about the quality of their department's figures. Sir John said yesterday that their advice would be made public. "You will know everything we are up to."

Announcing the biggest overhaul of Britain's official statistics in 30 years, Melanie Johnson, the economic secretary to the Treasury, said: "Our aim has always been to raise the public's confidence in official statistics."

The commission's brief had been expected to be restricted to checking the work of the office for national statistics. But after fierce lobbying by senior academics, the government yesterday announced that it will also cover the output of other government departments including politically contentious areas like hospital waiting lists, likely to be scrutinised in the run-up to the next election.

Opposition MPs were angered when the Treasury confirmed that the new watchdog's brief will not include one of the most important official figures, the retail prices index used to calculate inflation rates. The chancellor Gordon Brown will remain personally responsible for the scope and definition of the index.

"Mr Brown's control freakery has championed again," said Edward Davey, the Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman and a member of the Treasury select committee. "The RPI is of crucial importance to the UK economy and to things like the pensions uprating which affects millions of people. I think they would rather that the statistics were guaranteeed by an independent body and not by Mr Brown."

The Treasury said the RPI "is of crucial importance and it is right that the accountability reflects that".

The new head of the ONS, Len Cook, promised yesterday to restore public faith in official statistics. "My wish for national statistics is that it will become the trusted source of the accurate and up to date knowledge we all need for the advancement of the government, business and people of the UK," he said.

The ONS promised a monthly index of services output along the lines of the industrial production index by the end of the year. It would be a "world beater", as no other leading economy measures the sector on a monthly basis.

fields.headline: Calling time
fields.trailText: 8 June: My company charges over the odds when I use my work mobile for personal calls. Can they do this?
fields.body:
The problem

I get a mobile phone with my job for the times when I work away and need to contact the office. When the mobiles are used for private calls we must pay the price of the call plus 30p regardless of whether the call connected or not.

To add insult to injury there is an allowance to spend up to £2.00 per day on private calls when in hotel accommodation. My colleagues and I feel we are being treated badly and are looking to pay only the actual cost of the call.

The solution

Unfortunately, there is no right that I know of for an employee to be able to make private phone calls at all. Your employer can charge you what s/he likes if you do so, whether on a mobile or office-line.

However, it does sound like your company is being somewhat unreasonable. You have two options. The first is to accept that your employer simply does not want you to use their mobiles for personal calls. This means that you either pay up, get a personal mobile of your own (seems daft to carry two around, but, hey, they are cheap enough, so why not?) or use the payphone (using your £ 2.00 hotel phone allowance).

If you want to try and fight this unfair rule, get together with others who are similarly cheesed off and make a case to the powers that be. Prepare a written argument - you could include some written statements of previous bills, showing how you have ended up paying more than the total phone bill. Make sure that you make it clear that you are not trying to get out of paying for your calls, just out of paying over the odds. Hopefully, they will see how unreasonable they are being.

Having said all that, I wonder why they are so keen to discourage private use of their phones? Maybe they want to avoid the phones being seen as a perk, and thus something that other employees will demand even though they don't need one.

After all, they might argue that they are providing you with a mobile phone, rent free, so any personal calls you make, would be without the overheads that your colleague who has to provide his own mobile would incur. Such a colleague would then feel they were missing out just because they didn't work away from base.

At the end of the day, it is down to negotiation between you and your employer, but as they may have good reasons for such draconian measures, you may just have to accept the situation.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: Building societies still offer mortgages facing ban

fields.headline: Building societies still offer mortgages facing ban
fields.standfirst: Tie-in insurance deals expected to embarrass mutuals at the start of conference
fields.trailText: Building societies with more than half a million mortgage customers between them are continuing to offer products banned under laws about to come into force, an investigation by the Guardian shows.
fields.body:
Building societies with more than half a million mortgage customers between them are continuing to offer products banned under laws about to come into force, an investigation by the Guardian shows.

Among the mortgages which remain in their product range are those that offer lower borrowing rates for customers who buy insurance along with home loans - a practice the government wants to prevent.

The so-called tie-ins, where insurance and mortgages are linked together, are being targeted by the Department of Trade and Industry, which along with the Treasury is trying to clean up the mortgage industry. The ban will be contained in the consumer protection bill, expected to be included in the next Queen's speech, and should become law by the end of the year.

The discovery that building societies - which often claim their mutuality allows them to offer better products than listed banks - are using tie-in insurance deals is expected to embarrass the dwindling mutual sector at the start of the annual Building Societies Association conference this morning in Edinburgh.

The major mortgage lenders in the banking sector have already stopped offering such tie-ins and compulsory products and some of the smaller building societies which would have featured on the list as recently as April have with drawn their range of insurance-mortgage deals.

Industry sources believe that by continuing to offer tie-ins, some of the building societies may be featuring too prominently in "best buy" charts.

While many of the building societies contacted by the Guardian insisted they not do make it compulsory for customers to take the insurance, many of them continue to offer a preferential rate of interest to those customers who take the insurance product.

Philip Dearing, chief executive of Market Harborough, said it offered a better deal if a customer took the building society's insurance.

Mr Dearing said a customer could take out a mortgage with a two-year fixed interest rate at 4.8% but this carries a three year lock-in penalty and compulsory insurance. If the customer decides not to take up the mutual's insurance the rate rises to 6.49%.

Many building societies also fall short of the government's charges access and terms standard mortgages as they can charge penalties to break out of cheap, fixed-rate mortgages. Some of the bigger lenders are still cleaning up their acts in this area: as recently as yesterday Barclays agreed to waive redemption penalties for fixed-rate customers.

Who offers what

Compulsory tie-ins
Teachers

Tie-ins or alternative products
Barnsley, Clay Cross, Darlington, Earl Shilton, Lambeth, Leeds & Holbeck, Market Harborough, Newcastle, Norwich & Peterborough, Principality, Progressive, Skipton, West Bromwich Universal

Recently scrapped tie-ins
Buckinghamshire, Chesham, Chorley, Melton Mowbray

Unclear
Leek

Source: Moneyfacts and The Guardian

fields.headline: A toast to the wasted
fields.standfirst:
Dandy Warhols
Leeds Cockpit
**
fields.trailText:
Dandy Warhols
Leeds Cockpit
**
fields.body:
As Iggy Pop would testify, you can always rely on the British public to take a drug-frazzled American wacko to their hearts. The Dandy Warhols are a whole band of them, so it is unsurprising that they have enjoyed considerable success here while their homeland (hardly short on drug-frazzled wackos) has failed to share the appeal. The Warhols blitzed these shores in 1998 with goofy songs about heroin, and interviews espousing narcotics and free love. All good cartoon rock'n'roll outrage, but the band seem equally convinced they are one of the last bastions of the rebel rock n'roll flame.

Even now, their biography describes them as "counter-culture". This amount of baggage can end up in the back seat when a band has good tunes, and on their new Thirteen Tales from Urban Bohemia album, the Warhols still have several. But they seem to be incapable of playing them.

Without speculating too much on the difficulties (technical problems with both the equipment and players), the gig is like an extended rehearsal. Gaps between songs seem longer than the songs themselves; singer Courtney Taylor goes off into nonsensical drawled monologues. Some of the droning psychedelia played is so slow I half expect a doctor to rush on to check the band haven't expired.

Some of this is, admittedly, very funny. There are at least 15 minutes of pleasure to be gained from staring at the drummer's Afro. When drunken oafs demand that keyboardist Zia McCabe bare her breasts (it has been known in the past), they are stunned when Taylor takes his top off and starts teasing them. Musically, though, the new single Get Off is the best moment but collapses, prompting McCabe to wonder aloud why Radio 1 refused to play the song, which scraped into the Top 40.

fields.headline: Judge orders Microsoft breakup
fields.standfirst:
Gates says US ruling is unjustified and plans appeal
The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: A US judge ordered Microsoft, the world's largest software company, to be broken into two separate corporations last night, in a historic ruling expected to reverberate through the technology industry.
fields.body:
A US judge ordered Microsoft, the world's largest software company, to be broken into two separate corporations last night, in a historic ruling expected to reverberate through the technology industry.

In a judgment sharply critical of Microsoft's behaviour during the landmark anti-trust trial, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson gave the company four months to come up with a detailed blueprint for a break-up into two separate companies. One would own and market the Windows operating system, and the other would handle the other software, such as its Word program and Internet browsers.

Judge Jackson's final ruling agreed with the remedies put forward by the justice department and 17 US states which launched the prosecution more than two years ago.

Yesterday's order followed an earlier judgment that Microsoft had broken US anti-trust laws by abusing its stranglehold over the personal computer industry. Janet Reno, the attorney general, welcomed the judgment. She said it would "have a profound impact, not only by promoting innovation in the software industry but by reaffirming the importance of anti-trust provisions as well as the importance of competition".

As well as ordering the most significant corporate restructuring for more than 20 years, Judge Jackson agreed with the government's proposals to impose drastic curbs on the software giant's behaviour while the case is under appeal. He said Microsoft "had proved untrustworthy".

Among other things, these proposals would force it to share more information about its software with rivals and to offer them uniform pricing. The company would also be prevented from taking "adverse action" against any rival.

The ruling was contemptuous of Microsoft's appeals for more time and of its behaviour during the 79-day trial. He said the company could have pre vented such a radical restructuring if it had worked harder at reaching a settlement.

More critically, the ruling stated that Microsoft "continues to do business as it has in the past". It was found guilty of using its monopoly in the personal computer industry to break into the internet browser market.

Microsoft immediately confirmed its intention to appeal against both the interim measures and the break-up order.

Bill Gates, its founder, said the ruling was an "unwarranted and unjustified intrusion into the software marketplace", and suggested that the judge had failed to understand the dynamics of the industry.

Judge Jackson said a break-up was necessary because the company "has shown no disposition to voluntarily alter its business protocol in any significant respect... Following a full trial Microsoft has been found guilty of anti-trust vio lations, notwithstanding its protests to this day that it has committed none," he wrote.

"A structural remedy has become imperative: Microsoft as it is organised and led is unwilling to accept the notion that it broke the law or accede to an order amending its conduct." Under the terms of yesterday's decree, the company must appoint a committee of external directors to ensure its adherence to the ruling.

Microsoft's first step will be to ask for a postponement of the conduct restrictions, which could come into effect within 90 days. It will also appeal against the entire ruling, set to last 10 years. The justice department is expected to ask for the case to go straight to the US supreme court rather than the court of appeal.

fields.headline: Williams celebrates a long century
fields.standfirst:
Essex 263
Gloucestershire 5-0
fields.trailText:
Essex 263
Gloucestershire 5-0
fields.body:
It is generally thought to be the most frustrating job in county cricket - that of the No2 wicketkeeper. In moments of understandable ambition he is never quite sure whether to move on. But he knows there are only 18 counties and no guarantee of regular first-team employment elsewhere.

In Reggie Williams's case he takes an uncomplaining place in the queue behind Jack Russell. Everyone agrees he is rather better than average himself, though he shrugs with the resignation of the definitive trooper, accepting that for him it is always going to be a long wait. And it is not quite the same knocking off the bails for the second XI or helping his village team Lodway under the shadow of the Anchor on free Saturday afternoons.

He made his debut in 1990 and this was only his 38th first-class match. It was marked with some style: two dismissals particularly adept, and the next giving him his 100th catch.

Williams quickly curtailed Stuart Law's stay with a one-handed catch and was equally agile down the leg side to dismiss Darren Robinson, who left with an expression of disbelief, directed more at the umpire than the athleticism of the 'keeper.

Gloucestershire bowled out Essex just before the end for 263 but by late afternoon they seemed to be struggling to polish off a stubborn tail that featured Barry Hyam with a career-best 53.

Gloucestershire had rested Ian Harvey, Kim Barnett and Mike Smith, in addition to Russell, ahead of Saturday's Benson & Hedges Cup final. That allowed Mike Cawdron to return to the side, grasping his chance with a pacy early spell that included three for seven in 25 balls. But his later stint was less impressive. Essex reached 52 without much trouble before Cawdron dismissed Paul Grayson, an introspective Nasser Hussain and Law.

Ronnie Irani, with nine boundaries, went after Jon Lewis, who conversely did not make out a strong case for a place on Saturday. But the misfortune within the Essex innings belonged to Paul Prichard, sixth to go after a solid contribution of 170 balls.

His judgment was singularly sound; strange, therefore, that when on 96 he drove comfortably to mid-off and went for a single. Tim Hancock tumbled yet still hurled in the ball for a direct hit on the stumps.

There was just time, after Essex's laborious approach, for Gloucestershire to face one over.

fields.headline: Warne's head stays above water
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 95
Lancashire 54-3
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 95
Lancashire 54-3
fields.body:
Hampshire may have thought that a trip to Aigburth, with its traditionally batsman-friendly surface, would be just the tonic they needed for their run-shy upper order.

However a number of this Lancashire team still have nightmares about the last first-class game played here, against Glamorgan three years ago, when Neil Fairbrother negotiated a last-day run chase of 273 in 56 overs only to see his team hustled out for 51 in 14 on a pitch that had sweated under the covers.

So John Crawley had little hesitation in choosing to bowl on the first morning of this First Division fixture after heavy rain had added extra moisture to an already damp square, and the devastation wrought on the Hampshire batting was only marginally less spectacular than when Waqar Younis and Steve Watkin had had ball in hand in 1997.

Yet there was no hint of the collapse to come as Jason Laney and Giles White survived the first 11 overs virtually without alarm. Then Joe Scuderi found some outswing into the wind from the Pavilion end and Mike Smethurst started hitting the pitch with the breeze and the River Mersey behind him.

Hampshire, who had been playing cards in the 120-year-old pavilion before lunch, folded so dramatically that all 10 wickets fell for 69 runs in 31 overs. In fairness they did not enjoy much luck: the ball seemed drawn magnetically to the edges of their bats. Warren Hegg took acrobatic catches to dismiss White and Derek Kenway and five batsmen were snapped up in the arc between wicketkeeper and gully.

Smethurst, a tall 23-year-old from Oldham who took a career-best seven for 50 at Durham last month but had been left out of the two subsequent championship matches, also had Robin Smith caught at short leg and trapped Will Kendall lbw pushing half-forward in an often hostile spell of 11-3-15-4.

He did not get the chance to add a fifth wicket as Andy Flintoff, who took over for the last over before tea, dismissed Adrian Aymes with his second ball and had John Stephenson well taken low down by Crawley at third slip with his sixth.

Flintoff worked off more of his Trent Bridge frustration by removing Simon Renshaw's off-stump and just when he seemed likely to make way for Smethurst's return, Scuderi polished off Alan Mullally and Simon Francis with consecutive balls.

Shane Warne was left unbeaten on 18, the highest score of the innings, and he must despair of ever having a decent total to bowl at. Hampshire average 171 from 10 completed first-class innings this season and Jimmy Cook, who has taken over as their coach this season, must be tempted to strap on the pads himself.

Warne was not used as Lancashire slipped to 54 for three in reply, although their openers, Crawley and Mark Chilton, also seemed to be in full control until Chilton was lbw playing around a Stephenson outswinger.

Crawley and the nightwatchman Chapple followed quickly to complete a 13-wicket toll in less than two full sessions but there seems little danger of Lancashire being punished for the pitch since the Lord's liaison officer, Phil Sharpe, had left before lunch.

webTitle: England go from good to bad via downright ugly

fields.headline: England go from good to bad via downright ugly
fields.standfirst: Atherton and Ramprakash alone rise above team-mates' familiar failings
fields.trailText: Atherton and Ramprakash alone rise above thier team-mates' familiar failings, reports Mike Selvey.
fields.body:
Sergio Leone might have enjoyed the past few months, for with the King Commission into corruption in cricket about to begin and England's Test series against Zimbabwe finished there would have been no better time to revive The Good, The Bad and The Ugly.

The capacity of the England team to teeter between sublime and ridiculous remains unchallenged, even in the new era of Nasser Hussain, Duncan Fletcher and central contracts.

At Lord's, albeit against a side whose knees were knocking so noisily they sounded like Andy Flintoff breaking in a new bat, they were brilliantly efficient in conditions that favoured the seam bowlers.

Andy Caddick and Darren Gough confirmed that on their day they compare with any opening attack in the game, and Ed Giddins took with aplomb the chance offered him. Centuries from Alec Stewart and Graeme Hick emphasised England's superiority, the former clearly settled into his role down the order now and Hick, in his latest reincarnation, justifying the faith of Fletcher in particular.

The innings defeat was one of the heaviest inflicted by England on anyone. Was it complacency that England transported to Nottingham? Were there too many eyes gazing ahead to Edgbaston next week and the first Test against West Indies?

The final two days of the Trent Bridge test plumbed the depths once more, the sort of performance which must make coach and captain wonder why they did not take up something less stressful for a living, such as bomb disposal.

There was Good, of course, and it came in the form of Mike Atherton. The former captain made scarcely a mistake in scoring 172 runs in the match, and there was a less telling but significant contribution from Mark Ramprakash, who needs a decent run if he is to grow into the role of opener.

Graham Gooch, who can tell you more about the techniques and requirements of opening the batting than any man alive, admires Ramprakash's technical ability and believes he can be a class player at the top of the order. The Middlesex man's half-century was well constructed, freer of constraint than for months and ended by a worthy delivery. But centuries are what you are judged by and he knows he has to deliver them.

These two apart, Bad and Ugly reared their heads and the batting at Trent Bridge generally was below the standard required in terms of technique and concentration. Twice now, for instance, Hussain has been caught driving in the air, weight on the back foot, and Nick Knight's footwork was way off beam on Monday when promoted to opening.

Fletcher seems to think that all Flintoff requires is patience, but the statistics of his innings - 62 balls, 16 runs, one six and one four - point to something more than this. He needs to bone up on simple run accumulation, a necessary adjunct to his massive power, and work is needed on his footwork.

"His form is a concern to us," said Fletcher. "He's an attacking player, but you get to the stage where you are thinking whether you should turn him into a defensive player, and destroy this ability he's got, or let him carry on as he is doing."

The England bowling was as poor as it had been good at Lord's, offering scoring opportunities galore to Murray Goodwin, a player brought up in Western Australia where back-foot shots are the name of the game.

Gough did not look 100% fit and Giddins came back to earth with a bump. Caddick appeared unsure of his length, trying to bowl fuller at times but floating the ball into the drive as a consequence.

The leg-spin of Chris Schofield had gone unused at Lord's, and when it was finally unveiled at Trent Bridge it was to reveal a lad full of nerves who received much the same treatment from Goodwin as Hansie Cronje had meted out to Ian Salisbury on the same ground two years ago. We need to see what he is made of next time he bowls.

The performance has provided an interesting test of the merits of central contracts. Between the two Tests, five players - Atherton, Hussain, Stewart, Gough and Caddick - played no cricket. Atherton's response was obvious and Stewart kept wicket immaculately. But the bowlers are more worrying, for it is they who ought to benefit most from the break, the theory being that if they are fit at the end of one match they should be fit for the next, something that all too frequently has not applied to England. It looked at Trent Bridge as if fitness had been traded for efficiency.

Neither Gough nor Caddick has bowled sufficient overs this season and their presence for Yorkshire and Somerset respectively in this next round of championship matches ought to serve them well if they stay fit. And that is the big if.

webTitle: Cullinan to kick off match-fixing inquiry

fields.headline: Cullinan to kick off match-fixing inquiry
fields.standfirst: More about the corruption of cricket
fields.trailText: Cricket's first judicial inquiry into match-fixing produced its first shock yesterday by naming the former Test batsman Daryll Cullinan and the current international all-rounder Derek Crookes among more than 40 witnesses scheduled to appear.
fields.body:
Cricket's first judicial inquiry into match-fixing produced its first shock yesterday, on the eve of the opening session here, by naming the former Test batsman Daryll Cullinan and the current international all-rounder Derek Crookes among more than 40 witnesses scheduled to appear.

Cullinan and Crookes are two of only three South African players, apart from the disgraced captain Hansie Cronje, to have appointed their own legal counsel for the King commission, which could spend months probing allegations of dressing-room corruption.

The so-called Cronjegate affair erupted when the former captain confessed to taking some $10-15,000 (£6-10,000) from an Indian bookmaker, though Cronje insisted the payment was to buy information and not improper influence.

The commission will examine the six months leading up to mid-April, when Cronje made his dramatic admission after Delhi police claimed they had tapes of mobile phone conversations he had had with bookmakers during the one-day series in India in March.

Cullinan shocked many by suddenly retiring from one-day cricket last season, a decision he rescinded shortly after Cronje was sacked on April 11. Cullinan has never confirmed or denied knowledge of match-fixing, but he described Cronje's controversial decision to declare and "make a game" of the fifth Test against England in January as "very out of character". That match, at Centurion, will come under intense scrutiny at the inquiry.

Cullinan will give his testimony today along with Crookes, who said he had been "very surprised" when Cronje asked him to open the bowling with his off-spin in the final March 19 one-dayer against India. He said Cronje had told him earlier in the tour that "I definitely would not be opening".

The pair are expected to provide a blockbuster start to the proceedings. The country has been gripped by speculation that Cronje may plead an equivalent form of the American fifth amendment, refusing to answer questions on the grounds that he may appear to incriminate himself.

However, failure to answer questions properly could lead to criminal charges since the commission enjoys the same status as a South African supreme court hearing.

Cronje's attorney, Clem Drucker, has appealed for him to be the final witness so that he is aware of all allegations against him. Drucker says this would make it less likely that Cronje will refuse to speak.

Cronje and the three other players allegedly implicated by the Delhi tapes, Herschelle Gibbs, Pieter Strydom and Nicky Boje, all deny they have ever acted corruptly.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Andrew Caddick recovered from a disappointing Test performance with six for 57 as Somerset bowled out Kent for 261 in the First Division championship match at Bath.
fields.body:
Andrew Caddick recovered from a disappointing Test performance with six for 57 as Somerset bowled out Kent for 261 in the First Division championship match at Bath.

At 170 for three Kent, having won the toss, looked set for a sizeable total but Caddick took four for 22 in his last seven overs. By the close Somerset were 47 without loss thanks to Jamie Cox and Marcus Trescothick.

Rahul Dravid held the Kent innings together with 90. He only arrived in England on Monday morning after playing for India in the Asia Cup. He stroked 14 fours in his 167-ball innings before falling to a leg-side nick off Graham Rose.

Robert Key, who made 27, helped him add 62 for the second wicket following the early loss of David Fulton but Caddick removed Alan Wells soon after lunch and none of the Kent middle-order batsmen could make an impact.

Shoaib Akhtar, struggling with a side strain, will have a fitness test shortly before the start of play to decide if he is fit to make his championship debut for Nottinghamshire against Worcestershire at Trent Bridge today.

 Waqar Younis, Mushtaq Ahmed and Younis Khan have returned to the Pakistan squad for the three-Test series against Sri Lanka starting in Galle in a week's time.

All three were overlooked for the Asia Cup. The all-rounder Shahid Afridi has been dropped while the 18-year-old batsman Qaisar Abbas has been called up. Wasim Akram also features.

webTitle: Brassed off as summer's rhythm is upset by too much, too soon

fields.headline: Brassed off as summer's rhythm is upset by too much, too soon
fields.trailText: Engel on cricket I have followed every one of England's Test matches rigorously since the age of seven. So why have I found it harder to get enthused about the series against Zimbabwe than about any series of my entire lifetime? Scheduling.
fields.body:
Being an early starter and of an obsessive nature, I have followed every one of England's Test matches rigorously since the age of seven. Many times this has been duty: I have been covering the game for the Guardian. Often it has been pure pleasure (though frequently, England being England, a pleasure of a sexually deviant nature).

I have tried frantically to get the BBC on a short-wave radio in the middle of the Tanzanian bush; I have rung the sports desk to ask the score at a cost of about a dollar a second while flying over the Rockies; I have shouted out the lunchtime bulletin to the rest of the UK press in the media centre at the Barcelona Olympics, causing consternation among nearby foreigners... "Vot haz collapsed again?"

So why have I found it harder to get enthused about the series against Zimbabwe than about any series of my entire lifetime? Why is it that day after day I have got past midday then suddenly remembered that there was a game on?

Is it me? Is the problem, as the establishment consensus had it at least until Sunday, that the Zimbabweans have been uninteresting and unworthy opponents? Is it still a hangover from England's disastrous 1999?

All these are undoubtedly factors. However, it is far more a question of scheduling. The Lord's Test started on May 18, 11 days earlier than any previous Test played in England.

By custom, Test cricket for the summer should start tomorrow. The government gets criticised for making insufficient preparation for global warming. Well, here's cricket setting an example. Lord's has decreed that the climate has been transformed already.

Alas, this is a century or so premature. Predictably the two matches against Zimbabwe have been meteorological disasters. Even more predictably few people wanted to know. Officials of the England and Wales Cricket Board claim reasonable TV ratings, but the attendances have been appalling. The officials are convinced that 2001 and 2002 - when Pakistan and then Sri Lanka will also be playing at Lord's in mid-May - will be better. Well, we shall see.

English cricket has had few successes over the past decade or so. But one of them has been the maintenance of the rhythm of the summer, so that the popularity of five-day cricket dropped off far more slowly than the fall in the team's ability would have suggested it might. The Lord's Test has always been the peak. Now that has been chucked away. By having an earlier, far less marketable game at Lord's, which is going to be a misery more often than not, the cachet of the great occasion is going to be devalued.

It is a decision as wrong-headed as moving the British grand prix to Easter. There has been no buzz about this series whatever. They have spent years tinkering with the county programme to no good purpose; now the fiddling has been transferred to the one part of English cricket that worked, with potentially dreadful consequences.

It is going to get better. The Zimbaweans have been patted on the head and put aside until the one-day games. A week tomorrow the main event of the summer starts. It is five years since West Indies last played here, the longest gap in four decades, and there is an irresistible appeal about the latest on Lara (expert comments from Mike Selvey, Vic Marks and Dr Anthony Clare) and the last hurrah of Walsh and Ambrose.

Advanced sales are decent except for Old Trafford, which Mancunians have forgotten is also a cricket ground. A bit of sun and (whisper this) a fairly early exit for Keegan's lot would help. The series, between two fallen titans, may be a bit like watching two bald men fighting over a comb, as Borges said of the Falklands War. Still, it can hardly fail as cricketing drama.

However, the season is a little tired already and, if the plans for an early-autumn India-Pakistan one-day fiesta go ahead, there will be 48 scheduled days of international cricket in England this summer against an old norm of 33 or 34. This was designed to bump up the TV contract and the cash flow, and to do something to ease international pressure to play more one-day games and for more tests against the newer countries. That pressure will get stronger when Bangladesh are promoted this month.

But it seems to me an unsustainable programme. It will bore various parts of the anatomy off the public, the players, and the brass monkeys - if they aren't actually frozen off first.

fields.standfirst: Microsoft special report
fields.trailText: A US federal judge ordered the Microsoft Corporation to split into two companies today, prescribing the biggest corporate breakup since AT&T while harshly rebuking the global software giant for stifling computer-age competition.
fields.body:
A US federal judge ordered the Microsoft Corporation to split into two companies today, prescribing the biggest corporate breakup since AT&T while harshly rebuking the global software giant for stifling computer-age competition.

Potentially monumental, the ruling by US District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson was not the last word in a case that could define the limits of companies operating in a high-tech economy. Microsoft has promised to appeal in the case, which had been pressed by the Justice Department and 19 states. The case could go to the US Court of Appeals or directly to the Supreme Court.

Jackson, who concluded two months ago that Microsoft had violated antitrust law, ordered the company to be split into these parts:

 One that would oversee the Windows operating system.
 A second that would handle all other Microsoft software, such as its "Word" program.

The Justice Department and 17 of the 19 states recommended that the company be broken into two pieces - one to own and market Windows, source of the company's monopoly position, and another to control other software and the company's Internet business.

fields.headline: Lara's dry run gets drier
fields.standfirst:
West Indians 176
Glamorgan 44-2
fields.trailText:
West Indians 176
Glamorgan 44-2
A lack of form in tour matches can be a misleading guide for when the real thing starts but Brian Lara and the majority of his fellow West Indies batsmen continue to give cause for cautious English optimism.
fields.body:
A lack of form in tour matches can be a misleading guide for when the real thing starts but Brian Lara and the majority of his fellow West Indies batsmen continue to give cause for cautious English optimism.

After a Monday spent frowning at England's inconsistencies, West Indies reminded everyone at Sophia Gardens yesterday that Nasser Hussain's team do not own the patent on abject batting.

Robert Croft's first victim in an unbroken spell of 34 overs used to be the biggest prize in cricket. For the moment, though, Lara is everyone's rabbit. In his three innings on the tour he has made one, one and now nought.

He might be more concerned if, on each occasion, his middle stump had been knocked out by the first straight ball faced. Instead he has found unorthodox ways of being dismissed. At Worcester he was twice caught down the leg side; here he was stumped by Adrian Shaw as he overbalanced after missing a leg-side delivery. He lasted six balls.

England's main concern is that he will soon get bored with endless days of fielding and watching his team-mates bat. They know he is due a score. "He's adopted the right attitude," said the West Indies assistant coach Jeff Dujon "We're hoping that he'll get going pretty soon. After his long break he's just short of time in the middle. We've just got to be patient."

The West Indies captain Jimmy Adams ducked questions afterwards on Lara's form but insisted that panic buttons are not being pressed with nine days to go to Edgbaston.

"There's no problem in our camp," he said. "If people think England will win easily, they could be disappointed. We'll be ready for the challenge, I can promise you that."

However only the 23-year-old Jamaican, Wavell Hinds, demonstrated any conviction. He was assured against the turning ball and drove powerfully when given the chance. His unbeaten century saved his team from embarrassment.

Hussain has urged the counties to field strong teams against the tourists to prevent them building momentum. Glamorgan went one better; they produced a surface that totally suited Croft.

"This is going to be a great education for them," added Dujon. "Some of the players are struggling with the conditions. I don't think they could have got this pitch any drier. It doesn't do a whole lot for our preparations."

Brought into the attack after eight overs, Croft profited from a pitch that offered him considerable turn and bounce. He continued to twirl until the West Indians were dismissed half an hour after tea.

If this summer's tests were at Sophia Gardens his would be the first name on the England teamsheet. It still might be in there somewhere. In this match eight of the first nine West Indians batted left-handed and it will be little different in the test series. An experienced off-spinner could be a more threatening option than the novice wrist spin of Chris Schofield.

"All you can do is throw your name forward and by taking wickets I'll do that," Croft said after collecting five for 26. "I'd like to get back into the test arena. I probably had about 18 months when my form did go backwards, but I'm back to bowling as well as I have done."

So England now know the best way to beat this West Indies team but, in keeping with past hospitality, expect the Edgbaston pitch to be a belter and Croft not to play.

fields.headline: When golf causes grief
fields.standfirst: Kevin's plans; Vegard's depression; the Sepp and Scratchy show; Patrik's furtive fumblings
fields.trailText: Kevin's plans; Vegard's depression; the Sepp and Scratchy show; Patrik's furtive fumblings.
fields.body:
***********************************************************

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

***********************************************************

EUROTALK

"If we reproduce the form we showed against the Ukraine, we have an outside chance, but no more" - Gary Lineker on England's chances. Tomorrow: Des Lynam on how he's going to kick Kevin Keegan in the face.

THE EURO-TORIAL

The reading of runes may not be as popular a hobby as it used to be (say back in 1125), but anyone inclined to extract deeper meaning from Kevin Keegan's utterances on the England team yesterday is likely to draw some tedious conclusions. Aside from revealing (gasp!) that Alan Shearer will start if fit, the England coach's only other remark was to suggest that he will play 4-4-2 and that he's known the XI that will start against Portugal "for a long time".

Which means that for all Nick Barmby and Gareth Barry impressed in the recent friendly matches, they won't be starting next Monday. It would also suggest that Steve McManaman may not just breeze out of Madrid and onto England's left wing. It also makes you wonder why, in the name of Odin, Keegan tinkered around with both formation and personnel in the last three games. Perhaps he wanted to keep all those Portuguese spies on their toes.

Which is what the England players appear to be doing to their coach. Keegan, as is his wont, went on yesterday to talk about the team spirit in camp England. Describing the scene after the Maltese debacle, Keegan said that he was angry, but that he told the players "I'm not going to start throwing teacups at you". To which a player responded: "It's just that we're ready for the tournament." Keegan apparently accepted this as fair comment, which is good news for schoolchildren everywhere: "Where's your homework, Barkham?" "Forget that, mate, I'm waiting for the exam."

WINNING AT ALL COSTS

Cracks are beginning to appear in the Norwegian camp, where Steffen Iversen is at loggerheads with Vegard Heggem after thrashing the Liverpool defender at golf. What's going on, Steffan? "It wasn't much of a competition." Can't you play nicely? You're supposed to be friends. "I decided to give him a chance to get his own back, over a game or two of pool." That's better. That's a really nice gesture.

"I humiliated him." Oh for goodness sake. "After ten wins, I offered to play with one hand." Don't you give a pickled herring for team spirit? "After I beat him with one hand, we went back to the hotel. Vegard was a bit depressed." It doesn't bode well, you know.

***********************************************************

OUR SPONSOR WRITES

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. And £200 behind the bar. Perfect. Win a £200 bar tab for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com

***********************************************************

EURONEWS

Belgium's Euro 2000 spokesman Jan de Grave today jumped out from behind a pillar and bonked Sepp Blatter on the nose with a hammer in the continued debate over the venue for England's Group A match with Germany next week. "We are very determined that it is not going to be moved," de Grave told BBC Radio 4's Today programme this morning. "We feel that every precaution that should have been taken has been taken so that the match can go through there." Blatter is now expected to invite De Grave round to his house so that he can give him a 'nice present'.

The French once again highlighted their terrible difficulties in the striking department by beating Morocco 5-1 in Casablanca last night. French coach Roger Lemerre was said to be contemplating throwing it all in after all of his strike force failed to find the net. Apart from Thierry Henry, Youri Djorkaeff, Christophe Dugarry, Nicolas Anelka and Sylvain Wiltord.

Brazil have withdrawn their bid to host the 2006 World Cup. They are now expected to "throw their weight" behind South Africa, which could have huge implications for the tectonic structure of the earth, not to mention global weather patterns.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hi folks. Patrik Berger here... so this is why Karel never breakfasts with the rest of the squad! Well, he's not the only one with intimate knowledge of the transfer market - after all, it was me, not he, who scored with a scuffed penalty in the 1996 final to seal a glory move to Liverpool while everyone else at Borussia Dortmund went on to win the European Cup. So I think I'll have a go at this Eurorumour business before he gets here. Now, this should be even easier than making a half-arsed challenge to win the ball back...

Paolo Maldini is being linked with a move to Chelsea. Milan may be willing to let the 31-year-old go as they cull their squad this summer, and Maldini's good friend Gianluca Vialli will be first in line to sign him up.

Manchester United want Athletic Bilbao winger Joseba Etxeberria as cover for David Beckham. But the 22-year-old Spanish international could be very expensive - the buy-out clause in his contract is £33m.

Lazio may bid for Czech Republic striker Jan Koller. The lanky Anderlecht striker has been recommended to the Rome club by fellow Czech international Pavel Nedved.

Nick Barmby is up for grabs after turning down a £25,000-a-week contract offer from Everton. Barmby will be available on a Bosman free next summer, and Sunderland, Celtic, Coventry, Leicester and Celta Vigo are all lining up bids, according to the Express.

Aston Villa are prepared to pay Galatasaray £5m for Turkish international Hakan Sukur.

Hold on. I hear footsteps. Cripes! It's Karel! I'm off!

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC1: Three Lions (10.20pm)
The second part of a documentary about the English football team. Narrated by James Bolam, the whole thing is set to the theme tune of Only When I Laugh.

British Eurosport: Road to Euro 2000 (9pm)
How Belgium, Sweden, Turkey and Italy got to this year's finals. Not really interested in the Belgium bit.

European Championship Legends (11pm)
Something about France. As if they've ever won anything.

fields.headline: Class wars in the House
fields.trailText: Class war dominated the battle of the soundbites at Prime Minister's Questions this afternoon, as William Hague sought repeatedly to expose differences on the issue between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
Class war dominated the battle of the soundbites at Prime Minister's Questions this afternoon, as William Hague sought repeatedly to expose differences on the issue between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown.

After cursory congratulations on the birth of the Prime Minster's new son, the Tory leader opened his attack early in the session by pointing to the comments on academic elitism made by the Chancellor while the Prime Minister was on paternity leave.

"We all know how difficult it must have been - sleepless nights, a lot of noise, a refusal to settle down, and that was just the Chancellor!" Hague declared to Tory laughter - and a grin from Gordon Brown.

"Wasn't it a shame that Mr Brown re-ignited class war, plunged the Government into a complete shambles, made statements that he could not back up and exposed a whole catalogue of hypocrisy at the heart of new Labour?" he continued.

He asked the Prime Minister to repeat the Chancellor"s statement that Oxford University"s admission process was "scandalous".

Hague claimed that by speaking out on the issue the Chancellor had exposed a "catalogue of hypocrisy at the heart of new Labour".

With Brown sitting next to him, the Prime Minister took care not to fall into the trap of seeming to differ from his Chancellor, responding by turning on the record of the Conservatives whilst in office.

``It is only the Tories that could be satisfied with the numbers of children going from state schools to university," he said.

Blair could not avoid the Tory leader's trump card, however: the fact that whilst the Prime Minster was educated at a fee-paying selective school, Hague had gone to Oxford from his local state comprehensive.

"Hasn't it occurred to you that when the Chancellor whinges about public school boys getting the top jobs, he"s not just talking about Oxford University," the Tory leader demanded, claiming that "it looks like the Chancellor is being hung out to dry!"

"However many times you re-launch this Government, isn't it now clear they are happy to use opportunity and privilege for themselves, while trying to deny it to others," Hague said.

The Prime Minister sustained his attack on the actions of the last Conservative government, reeling off a string of facts which claimed demonstrated Tory failures.

"In the two years you were in the Conservative Cabinet, education spending as a proportion of national income fell. Under us it has risen. Who cares more about state education - the people increasing spending, or the person that cut it?" he asked Hague.

"We are the government investing £6 billion in school buildings," he ended.

Later in the session, Charles Kennedy brought up the issue of university tuition fees, claiming that their recent abolition in Scotland had led to an increase in the numbers of school leavers going on to higher education.

"If we are going to expand [university numbers] there is going to have to be a balance," Blair answered, before raising the political temperature with an attack on the "piddling little measures" for reducing crime promoted by the shadow home secretary.
