fields.headline: 'I did them all' - nail bomber
fields.trailText: The jury at the murder trial of nail bomber David Copeland, who detonated bombs in three London locations last year, today heard how he told the police officer who arrested him: "Yep, they are all down to me. I did them all on my own."
fields.body:
The jury at the murder trial of nail bomber David Copeland, who detonated bombs in three London locations last year, today heard how he told the police officer who arrested him: "Yep, they are all down to me. I did them all on my own."

Detective sergeant Peter Basnett said he arrested the 24-year-old engineer at his home in Cove, Hampshire, after police received a telephone call identifying Copeland's picture.

Asked if he had any more explosives, Copeland had nodded to a door and said: "Two kilos of ammonium nitrate - but it is safe."

Det Sgt Basnett said there was a Nazi flag on the wall of Copeland's bedsit and several newspaper cuttings showing the aftermath of the Brixton bombings and other incidents in which people had been injured. There was also a picture of Hitler, photographs from Northern Ireland and a picture of the Ku Klux Klan. The officer also found newspaper cuttings showing a car being damaged by the Brick Lane bomb and two knives - one with an eagle and swastika.

Copeland was not in court this morning but returned after lunch. His barrister, Michael Wolkind QC, said the defendant was unwell.

The jury also heard evidence from the husband of Andrea Dykes. She was pregnant when she and two other people died in the bombing of the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho, which the prosecution claims was motivated by Copeland's homophobia.

Copeland admitted at an earlier hearing that he caused the explosion at the pub, and two others - in Brixton and Brick Lane - in April last year. He has also admitted the manslaughter of the three who died in the pub blast on the grounds of diminished responsibility, but his plea was not accepted by the prosecution. He denies their murder.

"I cannot really remember what happened just prior to or after the explosion, but as a result I have obviously lost my wife and future baby," Julian Dykes said in a statement read to the court.

Mr and Mrs Dykes had gone into the pub in Old Compton Street for pre-theatre drinks. Shortly afterwards a pipe bomb exploded in the packed, narrow bar, killing Mrs Dykes and the couple's friends John Light and Nik Moore. Mr Dykes was seriously injured and did not learn of the deaths of his wife and friends until much later.

Mr Dykes said it was his first visit to the Admiral Duncan. "I could see it was packed with people. Nik went to order some drinks. John and Andrea had walked deeper in to find some seats. I remember an enormous rush of air and an orangey flash of light. Then I was on fire. I did not see the other four." Mr Dykes said he had run out of the pub. "I was waving my hands trying to put myself out. I was sitting on the kerb opposite. My bum was wet and I believe someone had poured water over me. A shoe was missing. I cannot remember anything about what was going on after the bomb. I did not know what had happened to the other four." His injuries included a nail in the lung, shrapnel in the stomach, and burns.

The prosecution also alleges that Copeland bombed Brixton and Brick Lane - home respectively to large numbers of black and Asian people - in an attempt to ignite a race war in Britain. The attack on the Admiral Duncan pub was "personal", it has said.

webTitle: How 'Bonkers' launched the battle for Britain

fields.headline: How 'Bonkers' launched the battle for Britain
fields.standfirst:
Liberal elite Hague's attacks on 'establishment damaging the country' echo maverick rightwinger's defence of tradition

Education Unlimited

Education Unlimited: elitism special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's populist attacks on the "liberal elite" carry an uncanny echo of criticism of the same group by a maverick rightwinger nicknamed Bonkers.
fields.body:
William Hague's populist attacks on the "liberal elite" carry an uncanny echo of criticism of the same group by a maverick rightwinger nicknamed Bonkers.

The Conservative leader has read The Abolition of Britain by Peter Hitchens, a very conservative columnist on the very New Labour Daily Express, and has discussed it with the author.

Other opposition spokesmen, including David Willetts and Peter Ainsworth, have also read it.

Mr Hitchens, like Mr Hague, is for marriage, discipline, private schools, institutions, countryside, patriotism and God.

Mr Hague, like Mr Hitchens, is against single parents, welfare, drugs, homosexuality and anybody who can be remotely painted as a liberal do-gooder.

When Mr Hitchens published his book last August, he promoted it with the slogan: "Who stole our country and how can we get it back."

When Mr Hague addressed the Tory conference last October, he declared: "If you believe in an independent Britain then come with me and I will give you back your country."

His aides were anxious to play down the influence of Mr Hitchens on his thinking, but there are clear parallels.

When prodded yesterday, Mr Hitchens said: "It's actually a sign of the dumbing down of the education system that someone like me can even be considered a guru. I got two Bs and a C at A-level."

Mr Hitchens, 48, started out as a Trotskyist but gradually moved to the right of the Tory party.

By his own admission he was a "crazed Dave Spart" in the late 1960s and 1970s after joining the International Socialists, occupying the student union at York university and charging a police line protecting Enoch Powell.

For years he has been in the shadow of his elder brother, Christopher Hitchens, a flamboyant leftwinger who converted him to Trotskyism before losing influence as sibling rivalry grew.

After university Mr Hitchens started work as a journalist in Swindon. He later became a member of Hampstead Labour party, then a disillusioned member and then, in the 1980s, a Thatcherite.

During the 1992 election campaign he hounded Neil Kinnock, and before the 1997 contest infuriated the Labour camp by targeting Cherie Blair's leftwing past.

When Mr Hitchens considered standing in last year's Kensington and Chelsea byelection, some at Westminster thought it was in part a protest at Michael Portillo's gay past.

The Abolition of Britain blamed Thatcher for dismantling much of the beloved past, and its author is now regarded as even to the right of his one time heroine.

Mr Hitchens argued that a cultural revolution had robbed Britain of stability and continuity in education, the church, literature and government to the point where they were fast disappearing.

Labour was organising a slow coup d'état on the back of a collapse of British self-confidence that started in the 1950s with the adoption of an American way of life.

The "great scaly monster of national abolition" was close, he wrote..

He said Tony Blair was hell bent on the destruction of Britain by transforming the monarchy, parliament, the union with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland and Britain's relationship with Europe.

At the Conservative party conference in Blackpool last autum, Mr Hague said the party believed in the traditions, institutions, values and instincts of the British people. "That's what the commonsense revolution is all about."

Mr Hitchens wrote: "A nation is the sum of its memories, and when those memories are allowed to die, it is less of a nation."

webTitle: Labour peers singled out by the Tories

fields.headline: Labour peers singled out by the Tories
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Conservatives picked on three Labour ministers who sit in the House of Lords in launching their attack on the "liberal elite" they blame for Britain's woes. Singled out by central office were Lord Falconer, Lady Jay and Lady Blackstone.
fields.body:
The Conservatives picked on three Labour ministers who sit in the House of Lords in launching their attack on the "liberal elite" they blame for Britain's woes. Singled out by central office were Lord Falconer, Lady Jay and Lady Blackstone.

Andrew Lansley, a rising Tory star who speaks on Cabinet Office issues, was particularly scathing about Lady Jay. "She, like some of her colleagues in government, has benefited from excellence in the past, but they are now more concerned with equality of outcome than with equality of opportunity.

"They are pulling up precisely the ladders of opportunity which have helped people from less privileged backgrounds in the past to achieve opportunity."

Lady Jay
Daughter of the former Labour prime minister Lord Callaghan, she was accused last week of misleading the public over her own education after being dragged into the Laura Spence university elitism row.

She told TV viewers she had attended a "pretty standard grammar school" before going to Somerville College, Oxford.

Blackheath high school in south-east London, where she was a pupil between 1948 and 1957, said it "was and always had been a fee-paying, independent, academic school for girls".

A spokesman for Lady Jay, Labour's leader in the Lords, protested that she had a direct grant place paid for by the state, accusing the Tories in turn of playing with semantics.

Lady Jay, 60, who sent her eldest daughter, Tamsin, to the fee-paying St Paul's girls school in west London, has a reputation for being feisty. She used to be married to the BBC economics editor, Peter Jay.

Lord Falconer
Privately educated at Glenalmond College in Scotland before attending Queen's College, Cambridge, Charles Falconer's decision to educate his four children privately cost him a seat in the Commons. Tony Blair had planned to parachute his old flatmate into the safe seat of Dudley at the last general election.

Aides told him he must tell activists that he would have sent them to state schools if they had been good enough, but Lord Falconer maintained that was not true.

Mr Blair instead rewarded him with a peerage, and he is now his "eyes and ears" as a Cabinet Office minister, sitting on more than a dozen committees and overseeing the Millennium Dome.

A former QC who earned £500,000 a year, Lord Falconer, 48, organised a May ball when at Cambridge.

Lady Blackstone
An education minister, Lady Blackstone went to Ware grammar school before moving on to the London School of Economics where she completed a doctorate.

Her liberal views on issues such as education, race, crime and social disadvantage have made her something of a hate figure for sections of the Tory right.

Lady Blackstone, 57, was a senior official on the inner London education authority, abolished by Margaret Thatcher and is a former master of Birkbeck College, University of London.

webTitle: Blair opens new front in elitism row

fields.headline: Blair opens new front in elitism row
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Education Unlimited: elitism special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today assert that New Labour's drive to modernise outdated institutions is rooted in "the best of old British values", not promulgated by the liberal elite that William Hague is seeking to blame.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today assert that New Labour's drive to modernise outdated institutions is rooted in "the best of old British values", not promulgated by the liberal elite that William Hague is seeking to blame.

As the Conservative party leader refines his main targets in the run-up to the general election, the prime minister will seek to wrest the "opportunity for all" agenda back from what he sees as his rival's old-fashioned Tory defence of vested interests.

But Mr Hague's team is determined to paint the cabinet into a political corner after the attack by Gordon Brown, the chancellor, on "old school tie" elitism - which the Tories say is class warfare, not the classless meritocracy that ministers envisage.

In the wake of Mr Hague's broadside yesterday against a liberal elite that is allegedly ruining education, the Tory leader plans a denunciation of a similar group responsible for welfare policy.

A senior Hague aide told the Guardian that his sights were also on "elites" in charge of health, immigration, social services and adoption. "The liberal establishment, which lives in a secret garden, is highly resistant to scrutiny and needs to be held to account," said the adviser.

Mr Hague hopes to make "culture war" issues between left and right a crucial election battleground, as Tory campaign strategists at central office accept that fighting the election on the economy will be difficult while incomes rise and unemployment falls.

He intends to portray the prime minister and Labour as part of an establishment that is destroying Britain and ignoring the concerns of both working and middle-class citizens - the "aspirational" voters who decide the results of most elections.

Yesterday he spoke of "the elitism of a New Labour government increasingly in thrall to the obsessions of the liberal establishment", and pledged that the next Conservative administration "will not just turn the tide - we will defeat the liberal elite".

In a counter-blast, Mr Blair will today claim that Mr Hague embodies the "forces of conservatism", invoking the keynote phrase in his speech to last year's Labour conference. His speech will be made to a 10,000-strong conference of the Women's Institute at Wembley.

The prime minister is not backtracking from attacks on unjustified privilege launched against Oxbridge and other citadels of Old Britain by Mr Brown and other ministers, but his tone will be more inclusive of middle England. And he will emphasise responsibility as well as rights.

"He will be making clear that the programme of modernisation that the government has embarked upon, and is seeing through the building of a New Britain, is rooted in the best of old British values," the Down ing Street spokesman, Alastair Campbell, told reporters.

"The central purpose of the government is to deliver opportunity for all, but it can only be possible if we recapture the eroded values of responsibility for all," Mr Campbell said, invoking "the revival of civic society" as crucial to Mr Blair's ambition.

It will be founded in "rights and responsibilities, rule and order, rather than a society of hierarchy and prejudice", Mr Blair will tell the WI audience, after first joining them in singing what is both one of theirs and Labour's favourite anthems - Jerusalem.

Mr Blair will invoke a series of Labour reforms of public services, designed to root out "inefficient, old-fashioned systems" in which staff work flat out but need fundamental change to deliver what voters want, he will say.

Health, education, transport and crime will feature in the "opportunity agenda", along with Labour's plans for a drugs bill next winter - trailed tomorrow by the home secretary, Jack Straw - to give greater power to the police.

"True equality is not equality of outcomes but equality of worth", the prime minister will say, a formula that may alarm Labour traditionalists.

Mr Hague will have none of it. "We are speaking up for the silent majority. If politics in the modern era is going to mean more about social policy or cultural factors, politicians are going to have to focus more on these matters," his advisers said last night.

Tory central office said Mr Hague had picked up the public's concern about an "out of touch" elite during his "Save the Pound" lorry tour.

fields.headline: Should you trust a vicar?
fields.standfirst: Are US evangelists having an unhealthy effect on the Church of England?  Stephen Bates  meets a clergyman who claims many parishioners are abused by their clerics
fields.trailText: Are US evangelists having an unhealthy effect on the Church of England? Stephen Bates meets a clergyman who claims many parishioners are abused by their clerics
fields.body:
Like the arrival of the exorcist in the film, you half expect Stephen Parsons to emerge wreathed in swirling smoke, dressed in a large fedora and accompanied by the rumble of thunder. This is, after all, a man with a mission to root out wickedness within the Church.

But the vicar of Lechlade, Gloucestershire, turns out to be a tall, diffident figure, somewhat overwrought by his research. This has nevertheless resulted in a book likely to re-open issues the Church would prefer not to consider - the abuse of church-goers by priests.

The case studies Parsons has detailed in his new book, Ungodly Fear, are hair-raising accounts of vulnerable parishioners manipulated by ministers, accused of demonic possession and homosexuality, sexually abused by priests and made to donate huge sums - in one instance, life savings and the proceeds of a house sale totalling £78,000.

The surprise is not that these incidents should occur occasionally but that Parsons, and others working in the field, believe them to be commonplace, much more widespread than the Church of England has ever admitted. In Parsons's view, much abuse is the responsibility of fundamentalist, Bible-bashing sects, many originating their beliefs and techniques in the US.

"I would say that 50 to 75% of middle-of-the-road clergy have at some point in their ministry had to help someone who has come through an experience of abuse," says Parsons. "Abusive episodes are two a penny."

In his book, Parsons tells the story of Teresa, a parishioner at a large church in the Midlands, who suddenly found herself being progressively shunned by other members of the congregation, including old friends, following the arrival in 1994 of a charismatic but dogmatic new vicar.

She discovered that they had been told to avoid her because she was possessed of a devil, apparently because the priest had discovered she had once been raped. Teresa eventually went to see her bishop: "He said that this vicar had psychological problems. They had been keeping an eye on him since he was ordained, but they weren't sure what was going on. He sort of apologised and said they would keep their eye on him."

In the case of another woman, Rita, the rapist was her own vicar. He told her it had been prophesied to him that God had made her beautiful so that she could sexually appease Christian men. When she tried to complain, other clergymen accused her of being a liar, or a witch.

In the case of Peter, a young and successful minister, church elders at first told him he must be mistaken when he came out as homosexual: "Don't be silly, you're much too hairy," was one comment. They drummed him out of his church flat. They tried to persuade his wife to shun him, wrote to his previous parishes and insisted that all the parishioners he had ever christened should be rebaptised, as if the revelation of his sexuality had rendered the earlier ceremonies invalid.

Parsons identifies common features in every case: the exploitation by those in authority of vulnerable people and the use - and sometimes misuse - of biblical references as a means of exercising that authority.

He points out that evangelical Christians, especially those on the charismatic and fundamentalist wings of the Anglican and free churches, are used to emphasising the infallibility of the Bible and then to selective referencing to bear out their doctrines. In this way, even child-beating can be justified, as American evangelical writers have happily pointed out - Proverbs 13:24: "A father who spares the rod hates his son, but one who loves him keeps him in order," or the improving tale in Deuteronomy in which parents watch as a disobedient son is stoned to death.

This leads some US evangelicals to advise parents to chastise their children from babyhood onwards. Such "experts" unaccountably fail to notice the message of a God of love in the New Testament but their own is much more about control. It leads on to other saws such as that "she [the female child] should never be allowed to argue at all. She should be submissive and obedient. She must obey immediately . . . The parents who require this have done a big favour for their future son-in-law."

If a congregation can be persuaded to believe such rubbish, the possibilities for misusing power are extensive. As in many of the cases cited by Parsons, anyone choosing such a church at a difficult time - after a divorce or a breakdown, the loss of a job or a bereavement - will be open to being impressed by new friends among the congregation and perhaps less likely to question the code by which they live.

As Parsons says: "Members of the congregation are offered belonging on condition that they conform to the rules offered by the leadership. The rules are not just about behaviour but also about their beliefs and attitudes.

"In return for obedience the individual within the congregation is offered assurance that he or she is saved and also enjoys the promise of eternal life with God. Thus, the individual is allowed to feel safe, a sensation they may only have enjoyed before as a very small child and which has been lost in the harsh realities of adult life.

"But the membership is conditional; at any moment that promise can be withdrawn and the individual left to fend for themselves outside the warmth of the family in a spiritual and social wilderness."

Reverend John Smith, UK director of the Evangelical Alliance, which has a membership of more than 1m church-goers of various denominations, says: "We must take our accountability seriously. We try to make sure people are appropriate for their positions of trust but we have an increasing number of independent churches where selection of ministers is decided locally and people may not have sufficient training.

"If we were to suggest a code of good practice, we would be suggesting a Christian leadership model based on the life of Jesus Christ. A manipulative model would be one we would want to be distanced from."

Ungodly Fear by Stephen Parsons is published by Lion Books, price £18

A manipulative model would be one we would want to be distanced from." Ungodly Fear by Stephen Parsons is published by Lion Books, price £18

webTitle: Judge to rule today on Microsoft

fields.headline: Judge to rule today on Microsoft
fields.trailText: The US judge overseeing the Microsoft antitrust case will release his final ruling at 4.30pm (EDT - 9.30pm BST) this evening. It is widely expected to include an order to break up Bill Gates's company.
fields.body:
The US judge overseeing the Microsoft antitrust case will release his final ruling at 4.30pm (EDT - 9.30pm BST) this evening. It is widely expected to include an order to break up Bill Gates's company.

US district judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled in April that Microsoft had broken antitrust laws. He is now believed likely to back the US justice department's plan to divide the corporation into two companies, one making and selling operating systems for personal computers such as Windows and the other containing Microsoft's other software and online businesses.

At a hearing last month, Judge Jackson requested only minor changes to the government plan, leading many antitrust experts to believe he is receptive to the proposed break up.

Microsoft has said a break up would be bad for consumers and has vowed to appeal against any such ruling. The company has predicted that it will prevail on major points.

"A break up of Microsoft, I think, would be an awful thing for consumers and for the industry. The real issue in a possible break up would be the harm it does to innovation," chief executive Steve Ballmer said in Oslo.

"But we'll be fine either way," he added.

fields.headline: The BA-KLM merger
fields.standfirst: British Airways today confirmed that it has begun merger talks with Dutch airline KLM. Mark Tran explains why they should want to merge and the regulatory barriers they face
fields.trailText: British Airways today confirmed that it has begun merger talks with Dutch airline KLM. We explain why they should want to merge and the regulatory barriers they face.
fields.body:
What's in it for BA and KLM?
BA loses money in Europe, partly because its base at Heathrow is too congested. KLM's Schiphol base, on the other hand, has been developed specifically to handle transfer passengers. If they combine, BA would handle the expensive direct flights to and from London, while KLM would handle the cheaper indirect flights.

Would passengers benefit?
Passengers after a bargain might come up short. BA and KLM operate discount carriers, Go and Buzz respectively, at Stansted. If the combination knocks out start-ups such as EasyJet, also based at Stansted, then bargain travellers could lose out. EasyJet has already voiced its strong opposition to the planned merger and this is something the competition authorities would have to consider.

How big would BA/KLM be?
If this deal goes through, the combined company would create Europe's biggest airline and the world's third-largest career, behind United Airlines and American Airlines in the US, with a value of more than $7.5bn and a fleet of almost 600 aircraft. Strictly speaking it would not be a merger if BA buys the much smaller KLM; more of a friendly take-over.

Why have there been so many mergers recently?
It's not just airlines, but across the board and the answer lies in one word: globalisation. As national markets slowly merge with the harmonisation of regulations and globalised communications, including the internet, companies want more resources to compete. In the media world, America Online, the world's biggest online service, is merging with media giant Time Warner. Banking has seen a rash of mergers, including Citicorp in the US, which has acquired a swath of smaller institutions. In the airline industry, United wants to buy US Airways, and BA has been trying for years to form an alliance with American.

Who has the final say on whether BA can merge with KLM?
A merger would face scrutiny in the US and Europe as both carriers have significant operations on both sides of the Atlantic. In the US, the planned merger would be investigated by either the US department of justice or the federal trade commission. In Europe, the EU competition commission in Brussels has the final say, with input from the national competition authorities. If BA and KLM decide to merge, Brussels will consult the UK office of fair trading and the department of trade and industry and their Dutch equivalents.

What powers does the European competition commission have?
The EU commission can investigate mergers of any companies - not just European ones - that will affect European consumers. It is currently pondering whether to begin a full-scale inquiry into the planned $127bn acquisition of Time Warner by AOL. The commission has forced companies to modify their merger plans in the past, most notably in the Boeing-McDonnell Douglas deal of 1997, which provoked a political row between the US and Europe. The EU agreed to the alliance only after Boeing dropped arrangements that would force airlines to buy exclusively from Boeing.

Is the BA/KLM deal likely to be approved?
Yes, Brussels is likely to grant its approval, though the merged group could run into problems over the issue of international route rights, which are governed by official bilateral treaties. This system, dating back to the 1940s, requires a carrier to be majority-owned by nationals where the country is based. So if BA were to buy KLM, some countries might say that KLM was no longer a national carrier, forcing the Netherlands to renegotiate its air service agreements. That would hugely complicate life for the combined company. Until now, airlines have dodged this problem by buying minority shares in each other and establishing international alliances such as Star Alliance, founded by United and Germany's Lufthansa.

fields.headline: Whose league is it anyway?
fields.trailText: There were some heroic failures in the latest round of Championship fixtures. Hampshire, set 265 to beat Surrey at The Oval, came within two runs of the highest tenth-wicket partnership (95) ever to win a county game - but Dimitri Mascarenhas top-edged a pull and was caught and bowled by a jubilant Alex Tudor for 59. And on Monday Notts came within two wickets of becoming only the second team in Championship history to win a game without losing a wicket themselves, after Darren Bicknell (180*) and Guy Welton (whose 200* was also his maiden hundred) had put on an all-wicket county record of 406* in their only innings at Edgbaston.
fields.body:
There were some heroic failures in the latest round of Championship fixtures. Hampshire, set 265 to beat Surrey at The Oval, came within two runs of the highest tenth-wicket partnership (95) ever to win a county game - but Dimitri Mascarenhas top-edged a pull and was caught and bowled by a jubilant Alex Tudor for 59. And on Monday Notts came within two wickets of becoming only the second team in Championship history to win a game without losing a wicket themselves, after Darren Bicknell (180*) and Guy Welton (whose 200* was also his maiden hundred) had put on an all-wicket county record of 406* in their only innings at Edgbaston.

But in the context of the new two-divisional system, what does it all mean? The news that Notts would have gone top of the second division had they beaten Warwickshire is all very nice. And it's the sort of line we now read in most final-day county reports. But for fans reared on a steady 110-year diet of one division and one division only, it still seems a bit surreal to have to worry about staying up or going down.

So here's a challenge: can you name the nine teams in both divisions of the Championship and the one-day National League? (Answers at the bottom - and here's a clue: ten of the 18 counties are in the same division in both competitions.)

Last year, only the one-day league was rent in two, so most of us could get our head round the idea that six teams out of 18 would change divisions in time for 2000 (three relegated, three promoted). But at the end of this season, a total of 12 counties will be swapping leagues in the two competitions. And, because these 12 could be 12 separate teams, we could have a situation where two-thirds of the sides will be on the move. Confusing?

The football Premiership also has an annual turnover of three sides, but because it contains 20 teams and the media indulges it as much as it ignores county cricket, it's relatively easy to follow. It's also easier to survive in: the seventh-best side in the country in football looks forward to challenging for a European place next season; cricket's seventh-best team gets relegated. It's not just the supporters who have to have their wits about them.

Which isn't a bad thing. A format that, give or take the introduction of a few teams and the four-day game, has been largely untouched since 1890 could do with a few surprises. No-one would have predicted in 1992 that new boys Durham would be part of a first-class elite eight years later. And you would have got great odds on the team of the '90s, Warwickshire, winding up in the two lower echelons (sorry to give it away, but you're out of time now anyway). Then there's the competition factor: with one round to go, the 15th-best team in the land could still have its eye on promotion. These are the sort of things that make news.

Fluidity might mean a bit of confusion. But it might just concentrate the mind as well. How many did you get?

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. Click here to read his last County View, on the rise of the Gloucestershire one-day team

Div 2 Essex, Glamorgan, Gloucestershire, Middlesex, Northants, Notts, Sussex, Warwickshire, Worcestershire

National League

Div 1 Gloucestershire, Kent, Lancashire, Leicestershire, Northants, Somerset, Sussex, Worcestershire, Yorkshire
Div 2 Derbyshire, Durham, Essex, Glamorgan, Hampshire, Middlesex, Notts, Surrey, Warwickshire

webTitle: England v West Indies, man by man

fields.headline: England v West Indies, man by man
fields.standfirst: Orin Gordon looks forward to the England-West Indies Test series which begins a week tomorrow at Edgbaston, and finds two sides that should be closely matched
fields.trailText: Orin Gordon looks forward to the England-West Indies Test series which begins a week tomorrow at Edgbaston, and finds two sides that should be closely matched
fields.body:
West Indies

Sherwin Campbell
Doesn't move his feet very well, but he's added a little more aggression to his batting and took on a quality Pakistan attack very well at times. He may have played here with Durham but I think he'll struggle in these conditions. The vice-captaincy should make him more determined to succeed.

Adrian Griffith
Has fallen on lean times and could be the one forced out by Lara's return. The progress he made against New Zealand at the beginning of the year was rudely interrupted by Streak and Wasim Akram. One of the genuinely nice guys of the side, and a good team man. Has no qualms about taking on the role of towel-carrier - may be required to.

Brian Lara
Two runs in three innings is an embarrassing start to the tour. But genius is about really turning it on, and Lara can go from single-figures one innings to a double-century next. It will be tough, and it looks as if he was right when he told one Barbadian radio journalist recently that he hadn't picked up a bat for so long that even he could get him out. Will he be able to fit into the ranks, and which batsman will he (a) replace, or (b) force to open with Campbell?

Wavell Hinds
Could (harshly, some may think) be forced by Lara's return to drop down or open. But, like Madonna's new movie, he's the Next Big Thing. Scoring runs for fun at the moment, and, in unfamiliar English conditions, is beginning to pick up where he left off against Pakistan. The quality of his debut 165 against Moin's men had to be seen to be believed. Tall, upright, with decisive strokeplay, he is equally at home in Tests or one-dayers. Will be examined by an England attack that knows how to use the conditions, but progressing very quickly.

Jimmy Adams
Taken to the captaincy very impressively. Excellent handling of his Jamaican teammate Hinds helped him to blossom, and his 48 not out to win the series against Pakistan is probably the most important innings he's played for the side in eight years. His play reminded me of Larry Gomes - an important and underrated player in the successful West Indies team of the '80s. Could be the Gomes to Lara's Viv.

Shivnarine Chanderpaul
Welcome back. The real determined, adhesive Chandra had gone missing for about two years, but an encouraging end to the Pakistan series and a big hundred at Worcester shows he's rediscovering his good qualities and may be over his chronic fatigue. A crucial member of the side with Lara's form uncertain.

Ramnaresh Sarwan
A sleepy and jetlagged Ted Dexter was jolted wide awake watching him on TV. Comparisons have been made with the great Rohan Kanhai - a Guyanese East Indian like Sarwan. All this stuff can go to a young man's head. Just ask Lara. At 19, he's been around a long time already - he was being spoken of as a star of the future when I left Guyana five years ago. Could be the one to make way when Lara returns, but as one of only two right-handers in the top eight, it makes sense to play him.

Ridley Jacobs
His batting's tailed off sharply. Worrying. It's time for him to remind people that he's actually a good batsman. I would move him up to open with Campbell, and keep Hinds in the position in which he's been scoring runs - No.3.

Curtly Ambrose
There'll be a few tears at The Oval when the great Antiguan takes his cap and sweater from the umpire for the last time. He needs 12 more to make it to 400. Less quick these days, but if the weather stays the way it is, few will be able to exploit it better.

Reon King
King has forced himself into the position as the third choice behind Ambrose and Walsh. Will interest a few counties by the end of the tour.

Franklin Rose
Gets movement both ways, has good control, and will get wickets here. Will keep out the quickest bowler in the side Nixon McLean, and the slowest, legspinner Mahendra Nagamootoo.

Courtney Walsh
449 and counting. Nursing a slight ankle injury at the moment which could be telling because this remarkable man has stayed relatively free of injury in his 16 years playing Test cricket. His record here speaks for itself, and he'll improve his haul by 12 wickets at least. Then, who knows? Maybe he'll stick around a few more years for a crack at 500.

Honourable mentions go to Chris Gayle and Nagamootoo, both of whom are just on the fringe, and could be involved at some point. Gayle showed promise as yet another left-hander. Lost form and place to Sarwan. Aggressive, can bowl a bit. Nagamootoo on the other hand is kind of passive, but can bat some offspin. Neither of the legspinners - him or Chris Schofield - will have a series to remember.

England

Mike Atherton
Will score runs provided the old back holds up. His mental toughness has served him well against the Windies, and will again this series. He'll be severely tested by Ambrose, who's dismissed him more times (16) than any other bowler. Tends to get squared up by away movement. Ambrose in particular will take note.

Mark Ramprakash
The Windies bowlers will indicate to us whether he's a Test-class opener. Will be successful if he decides to be attacking. We know he's got the shots, but the only time he made that side of his game sing in harmony with his sound technical ability was the only time he scored a century - 154 at Bridgetown in 1997-98. He'll do well to remember his debut series in 1991, again against West Indies, when he batted well and defended stoutly but only ended up with a string of 20s. Be enterprising. Besides, England don't need two blockers at the top of the order.

Nasser Hussain
Owes his side some runs, and good enough to get them against this attack. Has improved his strokeplay against quality fast bowling. Who can forget his thunderous hooking against Shaun Pollock? Has tended lately to get himself out to loose shots rather than good balls. Has to be careful that Walsh in particular doesn't have him spooning his slower one to mid-off.

Alec Stewart
Colin Croft tells me Stewart would never have scored against him, Holding and Co., because he doesn't move his feet. True, the Reeboks often look leaden, but he's always had a teriffic eye to go with his flashing blade, is a very good player of short, fast bowling and his record over the past decade speaks for itself. But he'll struggle once West Indies' bowlers pitch it up and move it around. He's a better player against them in the Caribbean. Won't ignite this series, except perhaps at home at The Oval in the final Test.

Graeme Hick
Could be the surprise package of the summer. His old aversion to short, fast bowling is well known, and the Windies quartet will be queueing up for a bowl at him. But am I the only journalist in England who wonders why this player has to keep proving himself? His record over the last three years is actually a good one. Could expose the tourists' thin spin options.

Nick Knight
Would not be in my side. Sorry Nick - you really are just a one-day batsman, but being a specialist is nothing to be ashamed of. One of the greatest Test batsmen, Sunil Gavaskar, just couldn't get his head around the fact that he had a limited number of overs in which to bat. I'd play Graham Thorpe instead, England's best left-hander.

Andrew Flintoff
Heath Streak took Flintoff to school at Trent Bridge, and showed up embarrassing gaps in his education. He'd better learn very fast, or his could be a short summer. Still, has got awesome potential. Should adopt a policy of attack against Adams's left-arm spin and if he plays, Nagamootoo's legbreaks.

Chris Schofield
Needs time to prove himself, and if England's much-mentioned new consistency of selection is to mean anything, he should be given that time.

Darren Gough
The Windies rate him, and if fit he'll get wickets. Has a troubling tendency to disappear from a game for entire sessions, in which time his side could be effectively out of it. I also worry about his batting, which is summed up now by an attempted legs-together heave over extra cover, a shot that gets him out too often. He looks impatient at the crease, as if he's got to catch the 17:15 to Leeds. Once good for at least 20, now a permanent tenant in a longish tail.

Andrew Caddick
Disappointing at Trent Bridge (who wasn't apart from Atherton and to a lesser extent Ramprakash?), but has been a revelation since his return to the side. Also hangs in there for his 15 or so runs, something that will be valuable in what I think will be low-scoring series.

Ed Giddins
Calls for his omission after a poor performance in Nottingham were as premature as they were predictable. Come on guys - you've been demanding consistency of selection, and it's only one match since he took seven at Lord's. Having said that though, it looks as if he'll struggle to be menacing on pitches that are not green-tops, but with his ability to move it both ways he'll trouble this long line-up of lefties.

Honourable mentions go to two Surrey players, Graham Thorpe and Alex Tudor, both of whom could be involved before the series is finished. Apart from Stewart, Thorpe cuts and pulls better than any other England player. That's useful against this attack. Proved he's no Lara by being punished for missing a tour. Tudor's batting for Surrey has confirmed that his 99 not out against New Zealand wasn't a fluke. And his bowling's looked penetrative this season too.

Overall, the ball will dominate, and unless the weather intervenes, I expect results in four of the matches. Two-two is my call.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. Click hereto read his last Anglo-Caribbean View, on Brian Lara: blessing or burden?

His mental toughness has served him well against the Windies, and will again this series. He'll be severely tested by Ambrose, who's dismissed him more times (16) than any other bowler. Tends to get squared up by away movement. Ambrose in particular will take note. Mark Ramprakash The Windies bowlers will indicate to us whether he's a Test-class opener. Will be successful if he decides to be attacking. We know he's got the shots, but the only time he made that side of his game sing in harmony with his sound technical ability was the only time he scored a century - 154 at Bridgetown in 1997-98. He'll do well to remember his debut series in 1991, again against West Indies, when he batted well and defended stoutly but only ended up with a string of 20s. Be enterprising. Besides, England don't need two blockers at the top of the order. Nasser Hussain Owes his side some runs, and good enough to get them against this attack. Has improved his strokeplay against quality fast bowling. Who can forget his thunderous hooking against Shaun Pollock? Has tended lately to get himself out to loose shots rather than good balls. Has to be careful that Walsh in particular doesn't have him spooning his slower one to mid-off. Alec Stewart Colin Croft tells me Stewart would never have scored against him, Holding and Co., because he doesn't move his feet. True, the Reeboks often look leaden, but he's always had a teriffic eye to go with his flashing blade, is a very good player of short, fast bowling and his record over the past decade speaks for itself. But he'll struggle once West Indies' bowlers pitch it up and move it around. He's a better player against them in the Caribbean. Won't ignite this series, except perhaps at home at The Oval in the final Test. Graeme Hick Could be the surprise package of the summer. His old aversion to short, fast bowling is well known, and the Windies quartet will be queueing up for a bowl at him. But am I the only journalist in England who wonders why this player has to keep proving himself? His record over the last three years is actually a good one. Could expose the tourists' thin spin options. Nick Knight Would not be in my side. Sorry Nick - you really are just a one-day batsman, but being a specialist is nothing to be ashamed of. One of the greatest Test batsmen, Sunil Gavaskar, just couldn't get his head around the fact that he had a limited number of overs in which to bat. I'd play Graham Thorpe instead, England's best left-hander. Andrew Flintoff Heath Streak took Flintoff to school at Trent Bridge, and showed up embarrassing gaps in his education. He'd better learn very fast, or his could be a short summer. Still, has got awesome potential. Should adopt a policy of attack against Adams's left-arm spin and if he plays, Nagamootoo's legbreaks. Chris Schofield Needs time to prove himself, and if England's much-mentioned new consistency of selection is to mean anything, he should be given that time. Darren Gough The Windies rate him, and if fit he'll get wickets. Has a troubling tendency to disappear from a game for entire sessions, in which time his side could be effectively out of it. I also worry about his batting, which is summed up now by an attempted legs-together heave over extra cover, a shot that gets him out too often. He looks impatient at the crease, as if he's got to catch the 17:15 to Leeds. Once good for at least 20, now a permanent tenant in a longish tail. Andrew Caddick Disappointing at Trent Bridge (who wasn't apart from Atherton and to a lesser extent Ramprakash?), but has been a revelation since his return to the side. Also hangs in there for his 15 or so runs, something that will be valuable in what I think will be low-scoring series. Ed Giddins Calls for his omission after a poor performance in Nottingham were as premature as they were predictable. Come on guys - you've been demanding consistency of selection, and it's only one match since he took seven at Lord's. Having said that though, it looks as if he'll struggle to be menacing on pitches that are not green-tops, but with his ability to move it both ways he'll trouble this long line-up of lefties. Honourable mentions go to two Surrey players, Graham Thorpe and Alex Tudor, both of whom could be involved before the series is finished. Apart from Stewart, Thorpe cuts and pulls better than any other England player. That's useful against this attack. Proved he's no Lara by being punished for missing a tour. Tudor's batting for Surrey has confirmed that his 99 not out against New Zealand wasn't a fluke. And his bowling's looked penetrative this season too. Overall, the ball will dominate, and unless the weather intervenes, I expect results in four of the matches. Two-two is my call. Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. Click hereto read his last Anglo-Caribbean View, on Brian Lara: blessing or burden?

fields.headline: Jerry Springer, Ricardo Teixeira and Bally Pele
fields.trailText: WAVE GOODBYE TO WRIGHTY
fields.body:
WAVE GOODBYE TO WRIGHTY

Ian Wright has retired from professional football. He'll never spit, make an obscene gesture, serve a three-match suspension, pay a £5,000 fine, be booked, be sent off, call referees incompetent little Hitlers, make a malicious challenge on Peter Schmeichel, call David Pleat a pervert, face a charge of misconduct, barge into a steward, pay a £15,000 fine, get involved in post-match bust-up with Steve Walsh, lean out of a window shouting at his own supporters, trash a referee's room, pay a £17,500 fine, hack down Kevin Muscat, manhandle a fourth official in the tunnel or call Scottish football's judicial system a joke ever again.

Wright announced his decision on, of all places, the Jerry Springer show. "It's a really hard decision," he ruefully revealed in a programme to be broadcast this Friday. "I've got all the people in Burnley, the manager is a close friend and I've made really good friends up there. My family are the major factor in me not playing any more, plus I have had a very good career and it's other people's turn now." Wright then gracefully departed as the residents of a trailer park in Arkansas took the stage for a disturbingly violent fistfight.

The Fiver hopes the player who scored a record number of goals for Arsenal will enjoy his retirement - you'll be forever in our thoughts, Wrighty. Although because from now on we'll only see you when you're hosting your excruciating chat show or prancing around like a drugged-up lunatic in order to sell us chicken, most of those thoughts will sadly be murderous.

IT'S JUST LIKE DODGING BRAZIL

The cream of the English hospitality and cocktail-mixing industry are on standby this afternoon as rumours persist that Brazil are to drop out of the race to host World Cup 2006. Senior officials within the Department for Culture, Media and Sport are already said to be concerned that there will not be enough cream in the country to fill the cakes necessary to persuade the Argentine FA to give us their vote. But, by heck, you can be sure they'll try.

The future wasn't always this rosy, however. Reports in the FT this morning suggested that the totally-upstanding Ricardo Teixeira, head of the Brazilian FA, was off to South Africa next week to offer support for their bid in return for a vote when the 2010 selection process comes around (great! another one!). That looked like bad news for England, especially because Nike's favourites were expected to persuade Argentina and Paraguay, the other two South American countries with World Cup votes, that it would be in their interests to follow them.

But the Fiver wasn't worried, because Alec McGivan wasn't worried. McGivan is the optimistic director of our 2006 bid who always sees a harelip in the face of adversity. "We have had discussions with Argentina and Paraguay on our own," he said today. "We have good reason to believe we will get those votes if Brazil do pull out." Which, as far as he is concerned, would leave England hot favourites. "More than ever, I am convinced that there are only three serious runners in the race and that Germany are in third place," he said. "If England make the final two I am confident we will win." Or we could go out on penalties at the semi-final stage. The Fiver's advice? Just keep making those cakes.

STOP PRESS!! The Duke of York has been named as the new President of the FA! We can't lose now, surely!

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Obviously they are looking at us from their point of view" - Kelvin Koogan certainly knows what those shifty Portuguese types are up to.

FALL IN, IT'S SQUADRON LEADER FIVER!

Sick of all this constant poo-pooing of our glorious England team? Want the media to wrap itself around the flag of St George and swear blind allegiance to Queen and country? Well, Squadron Leader Fiver is here and reporting for duty, sir! And our mission is to find a pundit who reckons England can win Euro 2000. Which should take about five minutes, sir!

Here comes Gary Lineker. Surely Kelvin Koogan's boys are certainties, Lineker? "I believe the quality of Kluivert for the Dutch and Henry for France will mean England cannot win this summer's tournament." What what? "Well, we struggled to qualify for the tournament and only made it through the back door after a poor performance against Scotland at Wembley. If we reproduce the form we showed against the Ukraine, we have an outside chance but no more."

Hrumphh. How are we going to rally our glorious nation with yellow-bellied talk like that? Move aside and let David Ginola through. Ginola, explain to Lineker just who will be the best side in Euro 2000. "I believe France are the quality side in the competition. People may, however, be surprised by the standard of lesser teams who could progress, such as Spain and Turkey." And what about England? "I hope England will be successful. Because I play in England I can see that English people believe their football is among the best in the world."

That's hardly a ringing endorsement, young man! But Squadron Leader Fiver doesn't give up that easily. Who's that standing in his Koogan-style briefs in the pouring Rio rain? It's that bally Pele! And would you believe it? The world-class pundit has just named England, Spain and Holland as the three teams who can win Euro 2000: "I've got great respect for England. They have got pride, which has been there since the start of the history of football." Hrumphh. But wait... France's odds for Euro 2000 are dropping faster than an unwaxed moustache!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Auxerre winger Bernard Diomede has flown into England to finalise a £3m transfer to Liverpool, according to Planet Football.

Christian Karembeu expects to sign for Middlesbrough, after turning down a late bid from Arsenal to sign him as a replacement for Lee Dixon. "My true place is in midfield," he admitted. "Now I have a great chance to play in the Premier League." But Boro's bid for Barcelona striker Dani looks set to be rejected.

Juninho could be set to leave the Riverside after he confessed an interest in joining Benfica. "If an interest from Benfica really does exist then the only thing I can say is that Benfica is a great club, where any player would like to play. It is a hypothesis that pleases me," the Brazilian admitted, rather long-windedly.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Convicted criminals in Belgium will be sent home from prison during the Euro 2000 tournament to make room for football hooligans. Justice Ministry spokeswoman Rosanne Germonprez said that 150 prisoners serving a maximum of three years in jail for minor and non-sexual offences would be sent home for between two and three weeks.

Alan Shearer and Gary Neville both missed England's training session today. Shearer is struggling with the knee injury he picked up against Malta on Saturday, although he will be fit enough to resume tomorrow. Neville is suffering from blisters to his foot, but the problem is "not serious".

Portugal midfielder Paulo Sousa is a doubt for his country's opening Euro 2000 fixture against England on June 12. Sousa is suffering from a strained thigh and missed last Friday's 3-0 win over Wales.

Neil Lennon could soon be following Martin O'Neill to Celtic. "Were Celtic to make a bid for me and Leicester allowed me to talk to them it would become a very serious option," Lennon admitted.

Sheffield Wednesday chairman Howard Culley has admitted the lack of funds at Hillsborough is making it difficult to attract a new manager. "Although we have some cash available to help initially, in the medium term we have to cut our cloth according to our new income levels," he said.

Raul will not play in Spain's final friendly match before Euro 2000 against Luxembourg. But Spanish squad doctor Genaro Borras said: "The injury has improved a lot over recent days but he's still not 100 per cent. In two or three days he should be fine, though."

Jan Molby has signed a new four-year deal with Football League newcomers Kidderminster.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Three Lions (10.20pm)

Something about England. Ooh!

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm)

Something about world football. Aah!

International Football (7pm, 9pm SS2)

Something about the US, Ireland and an offside goal. Erm...

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm)

Something about Roy Bentley, the former Chelsea and Fulham player. Nah.

British Eurosport: Road to Euro 2000 (9pm)

Something about Belgium. Balls!

European Championship Legends (11pm)

Something about France. Actually, that Belgian thing sounds quite good.

fields.headline: No 2: Jan Koller
fields.trailText: Appearance: Jaap Stam's bigger (and badder) brother.
fields.body:
Appearance: Jaap Stam's bigger (and badder) brother.

Nickname: 'Dino', as in Dinosaur, for his towering figure.

So how tall is he? A gigantic 6ft 8ins

Why, he must be the tallest footballer in the world! He's certainly the tallest in Europe. And if that wasn't enough to make him stand out, Koller usually wears white cycling shorts as well.

Cycling shorts? That's a bit 1991 isn't it? Look, he's a Czech. Be thankful he's not got a heavy metal style mullet and a Scorpions T-shirt.

I bet his height makes him a bit of a Kevin Francis on the deck Not according to Paul Doyle of the Irish Times. "Koller is one of my favourite players," he wrote. "He's more powerful than a well-publicised lie, yet has feet so magical he could perform in a sequel to the Wizard of Oz. I tell you, you should have a butcher's at this boy: when the Czechs drew away to Holland before Christmas, he made spam of Jaap Stam and pounced on chances like a rat in an abattoir."

Crikey! But can he score? He certainly can. Last season he scored 27 goals for KSC Lokeren which secured him a move to Anderlecht, and this year he's hit another 20. He also came runner-up in the poll for the Belgian league's player of the year.

Wow! I guess it doesn't come much bigger than that. Surely his record at international level can't be as impressive? How does 14 goals in 14 international matches sound?

Isn't that the best performance by a Czech since the legendary Josef Bican in the 1940s? It certainly is.

So who will Koller partner in Euro 2000? Czech manager Jozef Chovanec will either play with the 6ft 5ins Vratislav Lokvenc (place your bets now on the first commentator to call them the 'Twin Towers') or Vladimir Smicer.

Isn't he the slightly built one who doesn't even get into Liverpool's midfield? Yes - but when he's got a Czech shirt on he's usually pretty good.

Really? Yes, really.

So how does Koller think he'll do in Euro 2000? "We play teams with some of the best defenders in the world, it'll be difficult to score," he admits. "In Anderlecht, it's different. I have a lot of space and a lot of chances. But at the Euro, we will rely more on team spirit than on the individual performances."

If he's 27, why haven't I heard of him before? He was a unknown in the Czech Republic, and it was only after he joined lowly Belgian side Lokeren in 1998 (after being dropped from Sparta Prague's first team for his 'clumsiness' and 'lack of efficiency') that he blossomed.

So now he's made it, I bet he gives it large Very funny. Despite being tipped for a big money move to Lazio this summer, Koller is known for his modesty and congenial personality. "I know what it's like to be down," he says, "I will never forget the times when I was not even on the bench."

Not to be confused with: Jaap Stam, Andre the Giant, Will Self, Dracula, a donkey.

fields.headline: Libby Brooks and Raekha Prassad
fields.standfirst: Guardian women's editor Libby Brooks and her deputy Raekha Prassad were live online on International Women's Day (Thursday March 8) answering your questions. They discussed issues from Afghanistan to Ally McBeal, gave their views on modern feminism and defended the existence of a "women's" section in the paper. This is an edited transcript, but click here to read the full discussion and have your say.
fields.trailText: rubenruben: Do you think it smacks somewhat of marginalisation to title two pages of the Guardian 'women'? Doesn't it imply that the rest of the paper is for/by/about men? How about redressing the imbalance with a men's spread too?
fields.body:
rubenruben: Do you think it smacks somewhat of marginalisation to title two pages of the Guardian 'women'? Doesn't it imply that the rest of the paper is for/by/about men? How about redressing the imbalance with a men's spread too?

LBRooks: Obviously, that's an argument that we encounter a lot, and as editor I'm continually reassessing our pages' place in the paper. I don't believe that the women's pages give out the message that women aren't interested in anything else in the paper. I hope that our readers are far more sophisticated than that. Over three decades since their inception, I feel very strongly that the women's pages continue to serve a valuable purpose, providing a forum for the sort of debate that simply doesn't get airplay elsewhere in the paper, or indeed in any other broadsheet. What we're good at is picking out that line in a news story, that detail of a current event, that every woman is talking about in the pub, and that can be unpicked to provide a real insight into women's place in society at the moment. Take the Shipman case for example. Throughout the trial, the one topic that all the women I spoke to were gripped by was the question of why he'd concentrated on killing elderly women. But the women's page was the only broadsheet section to tackle this. That's the sort of analysis we do best. And additionally, you must bear in mind that a large part of my job involves liaising with other parts of the newspaper and suggesting woman-y ideas to them: comment pages, news, and features in particular. We don't work in a vacuum.

rubenruben: Libby, sorry, I didn't at all mean to diss the women's page. I think it's a great read. What I meant was that some of the under-reported men's issues would benefit from similar treatment - issues such as men's role as parents, paternity leave, those undiscussed male illnesses, the pressure to be macho etc...

john208: While ideally I agree that a women's page shouldn't be necessary, I accept that it probably still is. But I notice a lot more fashion coverage in the news pages these days - or is that just the Guardian's way of having "Page 3" type images while pretending to be above body-consciousness?? Do you complain about this to your male editorial colleagues?? Are all the subs male??

LBRooks: john208, well spotted re: fashion coverage. Actually, I think the argument is more 'why do we use Big Wierdy Pix of the latest hip-lacerating McQueen confection rather than presenting innovative but less spooky couture? It's a problem that fashion editors have right across the board I think ,not just at the Guardian.


pollster: How about positive discrimination? If a publication wants to cater for all of its readers, surely this would help form a more representative view.

And, do you think a man could do your job?

LBRooks: pollster. I don't quite understand your point about positive discrimination. As I said before, often it's about sensibility rather than gender and equally about having the space, confidence and respect to articulate oneself in a working environment rather than a mathematical question of numbers. Could a man do my job? Are you offering? webTitle: Drugs? A carrier bag full, please

fields.headline: Drugs? A carrier bag full, please
fields.standfirst: Trying: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.trailText: Trying: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.body:
I went to get my drugs today. I need so many I'd had to order them in advance. I'd been warned my bulk buy would fill a carrier bag. But when I went to my local chemist, the pharmacist's assistant couldn't find them.

She knew they were somewhere, she was sure she'd seen my name on something. "What are they for?" she said, scrambling amongst the little white boxes. I told her there was a lot of them: Buserelin, Urofollitrophin, Chorionic Gonadotrophin, Progesterone. I felt safe saying them out loud. These were mere technical terms, sounding as if they could be a cure for almost anything, not at all incriminating. And, of course, I knew them by heart as everyone - everyone who's infertile like me, that is - does.

We tend to be hugely researched into our condition. It usually takes a couple of years at least from diagnosis to treatment, so we amuse ourselves, thinking that we're Doing Something, by sending off for vast amounts of literature on infertility drugs and entering their names into our internet search engines. It's not a comforting exercise. Although there is no evidence, there are continual chat room discussions about the high doses of hormones causing cancer.

The names didn't seem to help the assistant. "What're they for?" she insisted. I repeated their names. She repeated the question. Our eyes locked over the throat lozenges, athlete foot ointments, and hayfever remedies. There was already a short queue flapping prescriptions behind me. I leant over the counter. "IVF treatment," I said, as quietly and nonchalantly as possible. Then, emboldened not by bravery but anger, stood up straight and shouted: "THEY'RE FOR IVF."

The young man behind me in the Nike Air baseball cap, all of 18, sniffed. I guessed he'd come in for an extra packet of Durex Gold. He'd never be standing in a queue blurting out anything like that.

He's probably right. Infertility is not as common as you might think: 95% of couples conceive within two years of trying. But if infertility only directly affects a few, fear of infertility is rife; one in seven seek medical advice to help become pregnant. It's as if now infertility has been publicly acknowledged and named, it is a spectre that could fall on any of us. I have a 40-year-old friend who, after a couple of months of a most vigorous sex life, was so distraught that she hadn't "fallen" that she attempted to make an appointment with infertility superstar Professor Sir Winston himself.

When my drugs were eventually placed on the counter, it wasn't a carrier bag full after all. It was two. The assistant now became over-solicitous. "Let us know if there's any news," she cooed. "We had someone in here once, and now she's out here." She stretched her arms to embrace a phantom pregnancy. "You read a lot about how successful it is in the papers."

Indeed you do. The assistant's assumption of intimacy would have been shocking if it hadn't happened before. I'm asked all the time why I haven't had another child, by people I've barely met, who demand an explanation. Although it's at the cutting edge of medical procedures, curiously IVF is not generally regarded as a straightforward medical matter, so us patients aren't afforded the usual discretion and privacy that automatically accompanies any other condition. Can you imagine the woman in your local chemist leaning over the counter as she hands you your haemorrhoid cream and whispering: "Do let me know if that works. Keep me informed how your piles get on."

As I marched out past the queue, an assortment of strangers offered a sympathetic, shallow smile. It was as if I were a woman being sent to her execution for a crime we all knew I did not commit.

But the long walk home hadn't ended. Coming out of the chemist, I spotted a colleague striding up the street in my direction. What the hell was he doing here? I was close to home, far from my office. Did he live hereabouts? How was I going to explain my emerging from the chemist with two full carrier bags? I dipped my head down, pretending not to see him, and wandered off up a side street. By the time I dared raise my head, I was lost in a street I'd never walked along before.

When I reached home, almost 20 minutes later, a builder was putting up a ladder in my next door neighbour's front garden, preparing to paint her window frames. "Been shopping, then?" he said, searching for smalltalk and nodding at the carrier bags. "Yep," I said, nodding back, before entering the safety of my own front door, shutting it firmly behind me.

fields.headline: Katie wears Y-fronts
fields.standfirst: 'She said she felt like a boy inside and if she ever grew breasts she'd pop them with pins.'  Reva Klein on what to do if your child develops a gender identity crisis
fields.trailText: 'She said she felt like a boy inside and if she ever grew breasts she'd pop them with pins.' Reva Klein on what to do if your child develops a gender identity crisis
fields.body:
We all want our daughters to be strong and brave and our sons sensitive and caring. But when - if at all - does "girlish" behaviour in a boy or "boyishness" in a girl become a problem? And whose problem is it anyway?

Tom is eight, and has been playing with dolls since he was old enough to hold one. A quiet child, he shuns the football brigade at playtime in favour of playing and talking to girls, and the one or two other boys who don't like rough and tumble. At home, he still loves playing imaginative games with dolls and animal toys. Sometimes he and his younger sister dress up in sparkly swirly costumes, festoon themselves with their mother's necklaces and paint their faces with make-up.

Tom will never win a popularity contest among his peers. Because he's friends with all the girls, the boys will have nothing to do with him. At home, his parents love and accept him for the rather eccentric child he is, providing him with a range of experiences, like camping, swimming and music lessons, like all good parents do.

Do they worry about his gender identity? "Not at all," says his father Philip. "Tom knows he's a boy and that he's a bit different from other boys, but he's secure and happy being who he is."

Tom is a very lucky child. Many parents would find his behaviour difficult to deal with, says Dr Domenico Di Ceglie, consultant child psychiatrist and director of the Gender Identity Development Clinic at the Portman Clinic in London. Gender is, he says, a psycho-social construct. "You can't dissociate what the child is feeling from what parents feel and from what society's views of conventional behaviour are."

While Tom's behaviour is different to that of most boys of his age, it would only become a problem if it were part of a larger picture. "When a child's behaviour occurs purely in the context of role play and the child retains its identity in the role, it's perfectly normal. It's when children say they want to be the other sex and cross-dress and avoid play stereotypically associated with their own sex, prefer friends of the opposite sex and dislike their bodies that they and their families need to be listened to professionally."

When Jacky Miller heard what her daughter was feeling, she knew she had to take action. Almost from birth, her daughter Katie preferred a "boyish" lifestyle. Jacky has a photograph of her Katie, now nine, taken just before her second birthday. In it, she's sitting in the middle of her smiling family, scowling. Why? Because of the dress she's wearing. She hated wearing dresses.

Shortly after the photo was taken, Katie insisted on having all her curls cut into a short crop. She only played with boys and when they'd come over, she'd always manage to get them to part with their Y-fronts. She even wrote to Father Christmas begging for some.

By the time she started school at four, Katie was wearing boys' school trousers, had adopted a streetwise strut and would only play Barbies with her older sisters if she could be Ken. But she far preferred guns, trains and cars.

Looking back, Jacky says that she didn't yet think that Katie's behaviour was anything to worry about because she was such a popular, happy child. "Even when her friends would sometimes call her 'him', it didn't really worry me."

The crunch only came when, aged seven, Katie told her mum that she wanted to change her name to Dennis, that she felt like a boy inside and that if she ever grew breasts she'd cut them off with a knife or "pop them with pins". It was then that Jacky knew they needed help. "I realised this was more than just being a tomboy," she says. "I felt I couldn't risk not intervening."

A child psychiatrist confirmed that Katie needed specialist help and referred her to the Gender Identity Development Unit. There, Katie and family saw a clinical social worker, a member of the multi-disciplinary team who agreed that she appeared to have a gender identity problem. During five visits, Katie, her sisters and parents talked about how they felt.

Often Katie would sit on the floor playing with blocks or drawing as the rest of the family vented their views. "My oldest daughter would say, 'Oh mum, you're making a big deal out of it. She's quirky and odd but she's fine.' And my middle daughter said things like, 'She'll be whatever she'll be. All you need is love.' After a couple of times, they didn't come any more."

Katie herself was open about how she felt and said that she didn't think she had a problem.

During that time, the Portman Clinic suggested that Jacky contact Mermaids, a family support group for children and adolescents with gender identity problems. She and Katie went a few times but Jacky found that her daughter's boyish behaviour became exaggerated during and after the visits. "I didn't think that was what Katie needed. It clarified to me that she wasn't like the other children there who had genuine gender identity problems. For her, it wasn't all-consuming."

That was a year ago. Today, Katie appears to have forgotten all about Dennis, has let her hair grow out and has a new friend who happens to be a girly sort of girl. She has even worn dresses.

So what was it all about? Jacky doesn't know and neither does she understand why Katie was the way she was. "I've often asked myself if I encouraged this on some level. I don't think so. At first I was delighted to have a girl who wanted to play with cars instead of dolls. I was a feminist mum. But it clearly was something else and when people would say to me, 'Oh yeah, I was a tomboy when I was young', I'd think, 'This is different.' The fact is that for the first nine years of her life, she wanted to be a boy."

Some names have been changed. The Gender Identity Development Unit sees children up to the age of 18 and their families. Write to them at: The Gender Identity Development Unit, Portman Clinic, Tavistock and Portman NHS Trust, 8 Fitzjohns Avenue, London NW3 5NA. Tel: 020-7794 8262. Email: GIDU@Tavi-Port.demon.co.uk. Mermaids' helpline: 070-71 22 5895. Email: mermaids@freeuk.com

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: It's official - children watch too much TV, according to the British Heart Foundation. So should parents simply get rid of the TV?
fields.trailText: The Question: It's official - children watch too much TV, according to the British Heart Foundation. So should parents simply get rid of the TV?
fields.body:
Michael Forte: Children and Young People's Programmes, Carlton, father of five

The idea of stopping children from watching TV, with ever more channels appearing, is impractical. The best we can do is monitor what they watch. Too many kids experience TV purely passively; many satellite channels provide "moving wallpaper". This is a shame, as dedicated children's services, especially on the two main terrestrial channels, offer quite proactive TV. The best of ITV and BBC encourage other activities. We undervalue the quality of bespoke TV for kids. Parents don't play an active enough role in their children's viewing. If they took the time to watch children's TV, they'd find a rich and varied diet. Don't watch less, just watch more quality.
Verdict: No

Iona Kenrick: Mother of John, four, and Guy, two; TV-less since Easter

We hid the TV after a blissful week's holiday without one. John hadn't watched loads; but once you turned it on, that was it for at least half an hour. Now he looks at books and he plays, and seems happier. There's been no whingeing. They're more mentally active, interacting with their own imaginations and playing games. Also, if they're at home with someone else while I'm at work, I know they're not just sitting in front of the TV. Keeping them occupied when I get home isn't a problem; after a day's work I want to be with them. John sees TV at friends' houses and knows all about Pokémon and things like that. The pay-off is that we're going to buy a computer.
Verdict: Yes

Dr David Lewis: Child psychologist, did TV survey for www.planet4kids.com

Our research found that the longer kids spend staring at TV or computer screens, the less physically and mentally active they are, and the less well they do at school. When kids watch TV, they sit down and switch off. There are three risks. First, kids are not physically active enough and generally don't play outside. Second, they're not interacting with each other and developing social skills. Third, they become inattentive due to TV used as "visual valium". In terms of actually banning it, you can't cold turkey it. Children are most vulnerable during their first five years so, depending on their age, no more than an hour a day is acceptable on average.
Verdict: No

Kim Leys: Spokeswoman, Michael Hall Steiner School

Steiner schools believe children develop through play while keeping mentally and physically fit. Children should also participate in activities with families and extended families to cultivate their community sense. Being continually "entertained" by things like TV, they lose out on developing their own skills. If your child is at a Steiner school, we ask that they don't watch TV. In our opinion, TV can really damage imaginary skills, and sight and hearing. The older children do media studies, so it's not kept from them all their lives. Most of our converts have never gone back. The children have stopped wanting it and started to play.
Verdict: Yes

John Bowmer: Father of Alexander, six, and Mattie, four; TV-less since 1984

We got rid of the TV because of me not the kids. I used to waste hours. I find it mesmerising even now. If we're at a friend's house and the TV is on, I feel like saying: "Please be quiet, you're interrupting my viewing." We are slightly out of the loop. In fact, the Amish are probably ahead of us when it comes to knowldege of popular culture. But it's worth it. Alex and Mattie see TV sometimes at a friend's house. Mattie finds it weird and would prefer something he can relate to; Alex is indifferent. Both benefit - their emotions are not deadened by the screen. I think they are more sensitive. But if either expressed a great desire to have a TV, we'd get one.
Verdict: Yes
