fields.headline: Give me a break, Cherie
fields.standfirst: Hilly Janes is 46 and her baby is due in October. The PM's wife used to ge a great role model. But not any more . . .
fields.trailText: Hilly Janes is 46 and her baby is due in October. The PM's wife used to ge a great role model. But not any more . . .
fields.body:
The wobble started when I saw the picture of Cherie Booth entering the high court just before her baby was due. No, I tell a lie. It was when I realised that perhaps she wasn't going to have a Caesarian, as I had blithely assumed. Well you would at 45, wouldn't you? But Caesarian babies are often delivered early, and there was no sign of Cherie arriving at hospital at an appointed hour: the opposite - there was the false alarm a couple of days before the birth. The QC, PM's wife, mother of three teenagers was planning to do it all by herself.

Oh yes, I've been keeping a close eye on Cherie, because I'm having a baby too, and I'm even older than she is. Cherie is four months younger than I am (I said I was obsessed). By the time my baby is due, in October, I will be 46. So as my already swollen bosom swells a little more with pride in the geriatric motherhood stakes, I confess that Cherie Booth has been something of a role model. I'm afraid all that's beginning to change.

When I first heard the news (hers not mine) I felt apprehensive. I had three miscarriages in between having my first child, now five, when I was 40, and this trouble-free pregnancy. Would the same happen, inevitably all too publicly, to Cherie? And what about tests? The choices and their implications are bewildering but none, apart from amniocentesis for Down's syndrome, which carries its own slight risk of miscarriage, is conclusive. As a devout catholic, for Cherie these choices and their outcome if, for example, she was carrying a Down's baby, would be made even more fraught by the moral debate her reaction would inevitably create. Worried? I was frantic.

But by early February, when I knew I was pregnant again and Cherie blossomed, she became a great comfort to me. Only a few people have the nerve to reassure you that you'll be able to have another baby in your mid-40s. Doctors, having done their best to establish there is nothing clinically wrong, sit on the fence, wanting neither to raise nor dampen your hopes. My mother, who had me at 40 (we're late developers in our family), was the most cheering. "I don't know what all the fuss is about," she said one day as we were talking about Cherie's pregnancy. "What do you think used to happen before? Nobody would have batted an eyelid."

Statistics prove her point. US research shows that in the 1920s, the average age at which women had their last child was 42. I'm old enough to remember what changed all that: the hard-won right to control your own fertility and combine a job with motherhood. Now I can tell by the look on some people's faces - especially the clever ones who neatly dropped a couple in their early 30s while continuing to climb up the career ladder - that they find the idea of having a baby in middle age positively yucky. Yet things could be turning full circle. About 11,000 babies a year are born to women over 40, double the number 10 years ago. Statistics are all very well, but there is nothing as reassuring as knowing somebody your age really is having a baby, and that everything seems to be going fine. Three cheers for Cherie!

But then I began to find my role model a little daunting. She worked up to the last minute and gave birth naturally, even though her previous deliveries hadn't all been plain sailing. After only one disastrous attempt at doing it naturally, I'm certainly not about to have another go, thank you. Pass the epidural.

I read that in September she'll go back to her cool old job at her hot new chambers, albeit part-time. I gave my proper job up to a) spend more time with my family; and b) try to make said family bigger.

Well, it looks as if I've managed that, so far at least, and nothing is more important or joyous for all of us, but I have to admit I do envy her in that respect. And I know she couldn't be seen to be clogging up the dreaded waiting lists, but even so, only four hours in hospital? And all that lip gloss in the photo with Tony - although when I saw the picture of him carrying little Leo a week later and looking rather pale, I confess to punching the air and hissing: "Yessssss! He's knackered!"

Go on Cherie, have the double extra nanny portions you deserve, instead of asking your Mum to help look after the baby. I feel tired enough already at the moment, but all this is making me positively exhausted. So plucky, so glamorous, so politically correct. Come on girl, give me a break.

fields.headline: Summer of love
fields.standfirst: Joanna Moorhead  was 18 when she worked in a kids' summer camp. She drank a lot, fell in love, and vowed she would never send a child of hers to a place like  that . Now, 19 years later, her daughter has seen the brochures . . .
fields.trailText: Joanna Moorhead was 18 when she worked in a kids' summer camp. She drank a lot, fell in love, and vowed she would never send a child of hers to a place like that . Now, 19 years later, her daughter has seen the brochures . . .
fields.body:
It's 19 years since I went to summer camp, but boy do I remember it. In fact, the boy is what I remember best. The rest of it, to be perfectly honest, is a bit of an alcoholic haze, punctuated with wild all-night parties and occasional trips up to London for a spot of shopping.

Fear not: I wasn't a camper. On the other hand, fear more: I was a camp counsellor, one of the supposedly responsible grown-ups charged with the care of children like yours and mine. I was 18, straight out of my fresher year at university. I'd rarely looked after kids, I wasn't interested in a child-related career, and what was in it for me was a good time. Thankfully, the youngsters survived - though the company that employed me seems to be no more - but the memory of what a hopeless counsellor I was does make my hair stand on end. Put it this way: you won't catch me sending my daughter to summer camp.

Or you wouldn't have done. Alas for me, Rosie, aged eight, has been mesmerised by the pile of summer camp brochures I've requested as research for this article, and she's rather got the wrong end of the stick. It's not so much, "Would you send me there, mummy?" as "When will I be going?" And she's only asked about 100 times in the past 24 hours. She keeps pleading to watch one company's promo video, but I know if she does there will be no turning back. Rosie will be off to summer camp for a week ("Just a week? I wanted to stay for the whole of my holidays!" scream the quotes in the brochures), and I'll have stumped up £300-odd for a nail-biting seven days wondering if she's paralysed with homesickness or risking life and limb learning to abseil with some hungover undergraduate holding the safety rope.

On the other hand, I too have waded through the brochures - and secretly watched the video - and I can see that summer camps in Britain have come a long way in 19 years. "Facilities" at the place I worked meant an unheated outdoor swimming pool and a playing field; the setting was a minor public school, and the children slept in huge, smelly dormitories with bizarre names like "Wildebeest" inspired by the hunted animals whose skeletal heads grinned down from above the bunkbeds. In many ways, the whole experience - for the children - differed little from that of the youngsters who occupied the same space in term time, minus any formal teaching. In reality, it was boarding school by another name: from our camp leader, who spent the rest of his working life as a headmaster, to the matron, who worked at a nearby prep, most of the senior staff were drawn from the school environment, and the emphasis was on containment and discipline, with fun a poor second.

Fast forward a couple of decades, and Fun, with a capital F, has become the name of the game. I can't imagine many of the inmates from our dreary little camp went home pleading to go back, but these days parents are allowed no rest from their returning offspring until the deposit has been mailed for next year. And not just any time next year: it seems the little darlings spend their last night plotting to meet up again - same time, same place, a year from now - so God help you if you fail to secure that booking for 2001. "Meeting your friends again is definitely the best bit," says Ellis Knight, 13, due to return for the fourth year in succession to the 3D adventure camp on the Isle of Wight this summer. "That and the quad biking, the go-karting, the swimming, the climbing, the football, the computers, the watersports, the orienteering and the canoeing. Oh yes, and the disco."

Strewth, Ellis, isn't it all a bit, well, overwhelming? "Well, you can have a quiet sit-down if you want," he says politely. "But the point is, most of us don't want to. We like all the action. If you want to know, it's fantastic. I can't wait to go back."

For professional, medium-to-high income families (especially city dwellers with two working parents) a few weeks at a rural camp for the kids is as much a seasonal norm as a fortnight at the beach for the whole clan.

Many camps are infused with a sense of mission, with the character-building, back-to-nature, adventure-in-the-forest experience one of the hot favourites. "The tents have no electricity, though there is a lightbulb in the wash-house down the path. Some would want more comforts, but my daughter views it as a fun adventure. For her it has been a wonderful experience - going swimming, sailing and canoeing in a beautiful lake every day."

"Fat camps", which promise to slim down those overweight couch potato teenagers we've been warned about yet again this week, are already blossoming here after taking off Stateside, and it can only be a question of time before we see whole five-a-side teams and rounders squads booking en masse into team improvement camps as they already do in the US. British summer camps may still be in their childhood, but they have the potential to grow up fast.

The only downside to the whole thing I can eke out of the children who've been to camp is the risk of bad weather. "If it rains, the whole thing can be a bit boring," says Camp Beaumont veteran Antony Onipko, 15. And the naughtiest thing any of them will admit to having got up to is an occasional illegal cigarette - though they're hardly going to spill the beans, are they, given that they're all so desperate to go back?

I confess to being reassured by a phonecall to the market leader PGL (named after the initials of its founder Peter Gordon Lawrence, incidentally, though most of the kids who've been there will tell you it stands for Parents Get Lost). They are adamant there's no way they'd employ anyone like me at any of their camps in the year 2000: applicants for jobs as counsellors ("group leaders" in PGL parlance) must demonstrate real commitment to working with kids, and definitely shouldn't just think of it as a holiday for themselves.

I'm inspired, too, by Madeleine Knight, Ellis's mum, who regales me with stories of how some parents drop their offspring off at camp en route to the airport, where they jet off for a week à deux in the Caribbean. Now there's an idea. OK, Rosie, you win: here's that video . . .

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: Report cards from teachers evaluating students - that's not news. But report cards from teachers grading parents on their parenting - that's news guaranteed to generate headlines and fierce protests.
fields.body:
Report cards from teachers evaluating students - that's not news. But report cards from teachers grading parents on their parenting - that's news guaranteed to generate headlines and fierce protests. And it has, ever since Paul Vallas, Chicago Public School System CEO, announced last month that, from autumn, Chicago parents would receive a report card every five weeks assessing their fitness as caregivers.

The report card, the first of its kind in the US, will let moms and dads know if their children are falling asleep in school, going to bed at inappropriate times, failing to complete homework, arriving late, and dressing incorrectly. Parents who score low marks will be referred to a parent training academy.

Vallas, responsible for 591 schools, 431,000 students and $3.3bn (£2.2bn), said the card was to communicate with parents, not intimidate them: "The objective is to [send] home a checklist that can serve not only as an instructive instrument, but also as a reminder of what they should be doing."

The idea is not going down well in a city where reading scores are low and the divide between private and public schools is a huge problem. Outraged, parents have launched a protest. "The idea is an invasion of privacy, insulting and doomed to fail," says Johnny Homes of Pure, Parents United for Responsible Education. He says it is an attempt to shift the blame for a failing school system from state to parent: "What they need to fix is the public education system. We need more money, computers and teachers.

"You have three types of parents here. First, parents who don't care. The report won't change them. Second, parents - particularly single mothers - who are doing the best they can. If they haven't time to monitor homework, when are they going to have time for parenting classes? Finally, you have parents who are on top of their kids already."

But Patty Yoxall, of the National Parent Teachers Association, calls it "an intriguing idea. We look at anything favorably that will improve parent-teacher communication. However, the wording should not be critical of parents, just informative. And we would like there to be provision for parents to respond, instead of just being dispatched to parenting classes. We know some parents are outraged, but we think there is value in parents discovering their children are arriving late or falling behind in their homework."

Homes argues that Chicago teachers already call parents if their children are troublesome: "They want to hold our feet to the fire instead of addressing their own failings. And we won't stand for it."

webTitle: Be a man of the people Tony

fields.headline: Be a man of the people Tony
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair must develop his own brand of populism to stay in power and that means no more holidays in Tuscany, says columnist Madeleine Bunting
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 3.45pm: Tony Blair must develop his own brand of populism to stay in power and that means no more holidays in Tuscany, says columnist Madeleine Bunting
fields.body:
For the first time, William Hague is really hitting home. His latest salvo has the potential to be the most damaging yet. He has conjured up a plausible hate figure - the liberal establishment - against which he can rally the Tory troops. Tony Blair hasn't grasped yet quite how dangerous this could be; today's speech attempts to head off the attack with soothing words about traditional values. But that won't be enough.

"Elitist" is one of the most dangerous labels in politics; it means that "the politician down there in London has lost touch with me the voter, is only thinking about his own interests and doesn't care about my pension or my kids' school". That emotional reaction spells electoral disaster.

The problem is that firstly, elitism is an occupational hazard of politics. All politicians are members of a tiny elite - by definition; add to that the fact that they all group together in central London and mix with members of other elites such as business and media.

Secondly, being in an elite invariably blinds you to the fact. Recently, a senior member of New Labour asked rhetorically, "What is the liberal elite? Where is it?" To anyone else, it was obvious that their family background of media and politics made them a central pillar of the liberal elite.

Thirdly, the "elitist" label is sticky - it's very hard to get rid of. What Mr Blair has to worry about is that the Tories had more than a decade of government before they faced accusations of elitism while it has taken New Labour only three years. There is a crucial issue here for Mr Blair to ponder: the secret of conservative electoral success in the 20th century lay in the ability of an elite to mask itself with a powerful populism.

Mr Blair has made it clear that he wants the 21st century to be dominated by the centre-left New Labour and for that, he needs also to develop an authentic populism. And this is where it gets personal. Baroness Thatcher made much of her Grantham shopkeeper father and even managed to project herself as the dutiful housewife and mother (it didn't matter that some of this was mythologised fact.)

This is where Mr Blair is weak. He is a member of the group which is probably the most disliked in the country - the do-gooder middle classes. They are variously accused of being hypocritical about their drive for power, patronising about knowing what is best for everyone else and arrogant because at heart, they want everyone else to be like them.

There are some grains of truth in these criticisms, and the hard task for Mr Blair is to reposition himself as not so much the blush tomato-eating Islington liberal and a bit more the ordinary family man. That was his selling point at the election.

It's coming round to summer holiday time; the loaned villa and private beach saga in Tuscany last year didn't help, so how about following the example of Mrs T (and millions of his voters) and head for Cornwall, or if he wants something quieter, the Isle of Mull?

fields.headline: Top of the range
fields.standfirst: Whitbread Volunteer Action awards
fields.trailText: Regional winners from over 1,000 entries in the three categories in this year's Whitbread Volunteer Action awards assemble in London today, when the national winner in each category will be announced, writes Malcolm Dean. More than 700 people were nominated for the individual volunteer of the year. They range in age from Michelle Lewis, a 17-year-old student who has raised almost £1m for charity, to Win Wyatt, an 80-year-old breast cancer care campaigner.
fields.body:
Regional winners from over 1,000 entries in the three categories in this year's Whitbread Volunteer Action awards assemble in London today, when the national winner in each category will be announced, writes Malcolm Dean. More than 700 people were nominated for the individual volunteer of the year. They range in age from Michelle Lewis, a 17-year-old student who has raised almost £1m for charity, to Win Wyatt, an 80-year-old breast cancer care campaigner.

Michelle was born with a muscle wasting disease, and her parents were told she had little chance of walking. At the age of seven, she was admitted to Alder Hey hospital, Liverpool, for the first of 28 operations. At eight, she was rewarded for her courage by being officially chosen as mascot by the hospital. She decided to devote her spare energies to fundraising for the hospital and, later, other charities. Now aged 17, she no longer sits in her wheelchair but walks with the aid of callipers - although she won her wheelchair section in last year's London marathon.

Win Wyatt was first diagnosed with breast cancer at 39 and had her second mastectomy at 63. Her nominees pay tribute to the energy and goodwill she generates through her voluntary activities publicising Breast Cancer Care's services in London. She is described as a brilliant outworker, a sensitive counsellor and wonderful publicist for the cause. Her other work has included volunteer recruitment, training and network organiser. Her nominees add: "At 80, Win is still an absolute dynamo, completely dedicated to ensuring women with breast cancer receive help."

 Other regional individual winners: Keith Bedford, Harlow, Essex - 26 years' service to the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds; Keith Bowen, Leeds - advocacy work for people with learning difficulties; Joanne Carson, Belfast - community work in Northern Ireland; Bridgett Crowther, Aldershot, Hampshire - work with the homeless; Audrey Gow, Currie, Midlothian - work with Brownie pack and church groups; James Hawker, Bridgend - youth leader; Ruth Johns, Warwick - 30 years of community work; Jenny Lorigan, Newcastle upon Tyne - work with a cancer support group; Jenny Marshall, Chippenham, Wiltshire - work with a disability group. There are also 11 winners in the annual voluntary organisation category and this year there is a third category for companies which have encouraged voluntary action. Five have been short-listed.

fields.headline: Volunteers week: Perfect partners
fields.standfirst: Guardian/National Centre for Volunteering photographic competition
fields.trailText: The image of young Chloe Rowe with a fistful of purple paints at a play scheme for children with complex medical needs wins this year's Guardian/ National Centre for Volunteering photographic competition
fields.body:
The image of young Chloe Rowe with a fistful of purple paints at a play scheme for children with complex medical needs wins this year's Guardian/ National Centre for Volunteering photographic competition.

The picture of Chloe and volunteer Hannah Buckley was taken at the Hamlet Centre in Ella Road, Norwich, by Michael Askew, of Norwich. He wins two British Airways Club World return tickets to the US.

The judging was done by Eamonn McCabe, picture editor of the Guardian, Sean Risdale, head of development at the National Centre for Volunteering, and Ruth Lewis, senior manager, community relations, at British Airways. McCabe explained why he picked the winner: "I love the vibrancy, colour, interaction and joy, and the fact that they are not self-conscious in the photograph. They are not aware of the camera."

Two entrants were joint runners-up: John Hunt, of Hawkhurst, Kent, with a picture of a Scout abseiling with a young person with special needs; and Michele Boham, of Acton, west London, with her picture of a volunteer escorting an elderly man whose vision is impaired. Both win a £50 voucher from WH Smith.

McCabe said: "Boham's picture is a very sensitive image and you can feel the empathy between the man and the volunteer. The photograph doesn't quite have the strength of the winner because the background is a bit loose. The abseiling picture shows how ambitious disabled people can be, and the warmth between the carer and the disabled child is obvious."

The quality of this year's entrants impressed Sean Risdale. "There were some very, very good photographs," he said. "A lot of them reflected unusual aspects of volunteering. There were photographs of volunteers involved in domestic care, which isn't normally an area which is featured in high-profile photographs - it can be a monotonous task. Photographs showed a very strong and happy relationship between the volunteers and the person being looked after, and a great feeling of enjoyment in the volunteering that was going on. Also, the photographs showed inter-generational volunteering, bridging gaps of age and attitude."

The competition is held to celebrate Volunteers Week - now in its 15th year - which is run by the National Centre for Volunteering and which ends today. The idea behind Volunteers Week is to "recognise, reward and recruit" volunteers. Last year 15,000 organisations took part and 105,000 volunteers were presented with certificates to thank them for the work they had done over the year.

For information on Volunteers Week, call the National Centre for Volunteering on 0207-520 8932. The website is: www.volunteersweek.org.uk

fields.headline: Who is Kenny?
fields.standfirst: We hear of babies being abandoned, but a 14-year-old boy?
fields.trailText: We hear of babies being abandoned, but a 14-year-old boy?
fields.body:
We're all familiar with the headlines: "Newborn baby abandoned... hospital authorities urgently want to talk to the child's mother... nurses have named the baby." We all shake our heads, sigh at the unimaginable loneliness and fear that could have driven a scared teenage mother to such an act of desperation. Well, here's a different twist on that familiar theme: "Fourteen-year-old boy with severe learning difficulties abandoned in London... social services urgently seek any information about the mystery boy, whose name is Kenny."

It hardly seems possible in our age of databases that a child's past could be so impossible to trace, but that is the case with Kenny, who, for the past six months, has been in the care of a team of social workers in the London borough of Southwark.

Last autumn, Kenny, who has severe learning difficulties and epilepsy, was brought to their offices by a man who claimed to be his uncle Victor. fields.headline: New world, old struggle
fields.standfirst: Most of Romaina's gypsy population live in grinding poverty, surviving persecution by forming tight-knit tribal groups. Kate Connolly reports on their plight
fields.trailText: Most of Romaina's gypsy population live in grinding poverty, surviving persecution by forming tight-knit tribal groups. Kate Connolly reports on their plight
fields.body:
Heavily pregnant, Borca Sorina is frying a lunch of potato strips in pig fat on an open fire for her four children. One, pale and sick, lies asleep on a mattress on the concrete floor of the family home, a tarpaulin covered one-room shack. Two others play with sticks beyond the dusty back yard. The fourth wanders barefoot in the sand, digging his teeth into a raw onion.

Suddenly, Borca drops the wooden spoon and gasps. Her waters have broken. The translator uses my mobile phone to call for an ambulance to come to Lumga Noua, "New World" - the Gypsy, or Roma, community in the industrial zone on the outskirts of the east-central Romanian town of Alba Iulia. The line is bad. "Where did you say?" asks the hospital receptionist. When she finally grasps that we want them to come to the Gypsies, she slams the phone down. We bundle Borca into our hire car and send her to hospital.

Meanwhile, the screams of a dying pig belonging to Borca's next door neighbours, Adriana and Josif Roja, fill the street like the cries of a hysterical toddler. Adriana, a diabetic, concentratedly pulls out its steaming intestines. "The doctor told me I must eat three times a day," she says. "Slaughtering the pig is a last resort, but I've run out of insulin so what else can I do?"

For around 90% of Romania's estimated 1m to 1.5m Roma who live in varying degrees of poverty, death is never very far away. Members of the "New World" community gather round and spit out their problems as if no one has ever listened to them before. One woman's six-month-old boy was born with club feet and she needs 5m Lei (£166) for a simple operation that would change his life. Her husband is out collecting scrap metal for which he will get the equivalent of 1p per kilo.

Although now a part of the "new Europe", the 2,000-strong Lumga Noua community seems closer to the favelas of Rio or the shanties of Jakarta and Manila. It has no water supply. Single low-watt light bulbs cast a yellow hue in the wattle and daub-style shacks, powered by electricity from a man up the road who has allowed them to tap into his line. Debilitating illnesses long-banished in the west, such as TB, hepatitis and typhoid, are well-known to the residents. "We cannot send our children to school," says one mother, "because we can't afford the books or to clothe them properly."

Yet a few hundred miles to the south, the lifestyle of the 250 Gypsy families in the village of Buzescu, outside Alexandria, could hardly be more different. Huge aluminium, oriental-style tiered roofs, or "turlas", dominate the skyline. Adjacent garages house Mercedes and BMWs, and the three-storey homes boast marbled entrance halls leading to dozens of (largely empty) rooms filled with expensive kitsch, such as plastic lemon trees and large porcelain statues of Michael Jackson and Princess Diana. Mobile phones abound.

The old traditions die hard though. In Buzescu, almost every house has its kitchen in a tent in the back garden, harking back to the days when every minute of the day was spent outside. Italian-tiled bathrooms lie unused in preference to privies decorated with flowery curtains in the backyards.

Buzescu's bulibasha, or Roma leader, Marin Grinea Stoica, parks his oil tanker outside the Italian-style villa he shares with his wife and four generations of his family. Like all the men in the street, he describes himself as a businessman, but refuses to elaborate. "We've always been upwardly mobile, even under communism - although we couldn't be ostentatious about our wealth in those days," he says. "My family has continually upgraded - from a caravan to a Dacia and now to a Mercedes."

The oil tanker serves the oil-pumping plant he has set up just down the road. He casually drops into the conversation that he also owns 10kg of gold. Asked how he would explain the gaping divide between his lifestyle and that of Lumga Noua's impoverished Roma, Stoica offers a reply Norman Tebbit would be proud of. "The trick which they haven't grasped is to put your mind into action all the time," he says. "When I was young I would lie awake all night thinking of ways in which I could feed the children next day, while others slept until 10 in the morning. So how can they expect to be on the same level?"

He cannot, he says, understand the couples from Tanderei, three hours' drive east of Bucharest, who recently went to England to earn money from begging and earned those back home such a bad press. "But Roma will always go where the work is," he says. "That's the bottom line, and that's the basis on which decisions are made."

Talk to almost anyone from the Roma community and they will tell you that it simply makes economic sense for them to run the risks of travelling through Europe (Germany is the country most often mentioned.) And as an outsider looking into the poor communities, the risks seem quite reasonable.

A few days spent among them quickly dispels the myths spread in the British press that sees them as "scroungers". Rich, poor, entrepreneurial, beggars, small-time merchants, olive-skinned, fair, black-haired and blonde, they defy stereotyping. They seem to be still trying to make sense of their position in the post-communist new world order which appears to have decided it has no place for Europe's fastest-growing ethnic group.

Romania's Roma, which make up around 10-15% of the population, have survived by retreating into tight-knit tribal groups. They have become frequent targets for organised violence from the police. Racially-motivated murders have increased since 1990. The European Roma Rights Centre in Budapest has documented several cases of arson attacks where Romanian Roma have been burnt out of their homes. Now debate rages because many Romanians don't like the fact that "Roma" looks and sounds too much like "Romanian" and insist on using a new spelling to distinguish them from the dark-skinned citizens: Rroma.

Despised in their own country, the Roma are largely psychologically detached from the modern world. The Kaldaras community of Sarulesti, 30 miles south-east of Bucharest, are poor but happy, living in their muddy, lilac tree-lined streets. Their community functions to its own rules. The bulibasha leads court sessions in cases of dispute and adjudicates when marriages are being arranged. A woman down the road checks that potential brides are virgins. The boys spend the day collecting scrap metal which they will sell for a decent price in Bucharest.

The men wear "designer" labels - cheap fakes picked up at wholesale markets on the outskirts of the capital. The women, unsteady on bright green and orange platforms, don the traditional flowing flowered skirts, headscarves and wear their heavy gold-coin "dowries" woven into their plaits.

Their aspirations appear to be modest. Talk to them about what motivated some Gypsies to travel to England and there is no mention of roads paved with gold. Lenuta, hobbling on pink platforms, squelches through the mud towards us. "Take me to England! It must be a beautiful country with asphalt streets, because your shoes are so clean!"

Returning with his family from a horse-drawn scrap-metal search, Robert Mihai concentrates on smashing a brake pump with a hammer to extract the valuable ball-bearings. "Where's England?" he asks. "Do you have mountains and sheep?" I sketch a crude map of Europe and walk my fingers across the Channel. "And where's Romania?" he asks. He has no knowledge of the origins of Roma peoples, of the US president, the European Union (which his country hopes to join), or of the internet. On mention of the word computer, his brow furrows still further. "Calculator?" he says. "I don't need a calculator. I can count my money in my head and that's all that matters."

Others in the village who are lucky enough to go to school say the most important thing they'll ever learn there is maths. "And reading," shouts 27-year-old Mihai Buzdugan, who never went to school. "I have to send for my brother whenever there's an American film I want to watch, because I can't read the subtitles."

The bulibasha, Florea Gogu Mihai, welcomes us into his home after we hand him an entry ticket: three bottles of tuica, or plum brandy. He remembers the days when he used to travel around with his parents in a horse and cart, before the communists forced them to settle. "We're sorry we unlearnt how to travel," he says.

Florin's community has clearly felt the forces of globalisation in its local form and he sees migration as a necessity for future generations. As a bulibasha, he says, he would have no problem encouraging it if it was the only way to survive. "It's to do with the breakdown of our tradition," he says. "Under communism we'd sell our buckets, pots, brandy distilleries and gold for wedding rings to non-Roma who were keen to buy them because they couldn't get them anywhere else. Our products are still the best, but there is a lot of cheaper stuff on the market now and we are being forced to travel where the work is."

He recently met with the bulibasha from Tandarei, where the Britain-bound beggars came from. They discussed Britain's tightening of its policy against asylum seekers, which appears to have reached Roma leaders throughout the country. Then Florea shows me a copper coffee pot made by a villager. "Do you think they'd buy those in England?" he asks. "If so, I can imagine the young people will be off there soon."

fields.headline: Tales of the city
fields.standfirst: Have we got to grips with urban decay? Malcolm Dean reports
fields.trailText: Have we got to grips with urban decay? Malcolm Dean reports
fields.body:
Where does regeneration move in the fourth year of a Labour government? The government's long delayed urban white paper is now not expected until the autumn. Urban specialists meeting recently in London concluded there was correction needed to Labour's myriad initiatives. They spoke of an excess number of partnerships - one local authority having more than 70 multi-agency partnerships - and a widespread sense of the need to reduce "zoneitis". Fatigue was setting in with the energy expended on bidding for funds.

Two new reports from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation on regeneration and regionalism were presented at the conference. The first, by a team from Heriot Watt and Glasgow Universities, suggested partnerships were still not "joined up enough". Professor Michael Carly, who presented the findings from a study of 27 partnerships, wanted to see a reduction in their number but the emergence of stronger projects. There was a disappointing level of commitment from business.

The ingredients for success were relatively straightforward: strong political and executive leadership at senior level; vision; and a real sense of where the city ought to be in 20 years' time.

He noted the danger of regeneration chasing "problem families" from one area to the next and the risk of urban renewal squeezing the most disadvantaged families into the worst housing areas. The extent of deprivation in our major cities was indicated by the fact that a majority of wards in Liverpool, Glasgow and Manchester could be defined as deprived and faced an uphill struggle to improve.

Carly noted the relatively new partnership recipe in the UK had been tried earlier on the continent, where researchers discovered one serious problem was the danger of local government using partner ships to avoid taking strategic decisions.

He went on: "Despite 30 years of regeneration, we have not cracked the problem of deprivation in neighbourhoods, and cities hit hard by industrial job losses. What is needed is joined-up action at all levels. We need a development strategy that links the objectives of key departments, promotes northern cities as much as London, and provides a modern transport and educational infrastructure."

Among the conclusions of the report were a need for:

 more active involvement of health trusts, the employment service, the benefits agency and police in regeneration partnerships;

 community development work as a key part of regeneration schemes to enable local people to make their voices heard;

 better co-ordination between government offices for the regions and the new regional development agencies.

Presenting the second report on regional development agencies, Professor Brian Robson, of Manchester University, noted that although the RDAs had identified their principal task as sharpening economic competitiveness, their budgets were primarily made up of ring-fenced regeneration subsidies. They were in danger of being squeezed between central and local demand.

Many regeneration partnerships felt that local voices - from the voluntary sector and community groups - had been able to exert only marginal influence on RDA strategies.

 Urban Regeneration Through Partnership: a study of nine urban regions in England, Scotland and Wales, by Michael Carly and others, The Policy Press, £14.95. Regional Agencies and Area-based Regeneration, by Brian Robson and others, The Policy Press, £13.95. Add £2.50 for p&p. Available from Marston Book Services, PO Box 269. Abingdon, Oxon OX14 4YN.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Two years ago, I attended a meeting of academics interested in developing research into what they called the information technology revolution. The first topic for discussion was mobile telephony and how it was transforming business. What efficiency gains could be credited to the mobile phone? What was the impact of the mobile phone on people's readiness to abandon fixed office space?

At this moment, the most junior member of the committee erupted. Didn't we realise, she said, that the most significant aspect of mobile telephony was how it was transforming the nature of sociability? Mobile telephones may have initially been a business device, but their massive success was almost entirely due to their adoption by young people, who found them essential for ordering and amplifying their social lives.

"I sometimes feel," she said in a final flourish, "that the world is now moving too quickly for traditional academic research in social science. A typical research project takes a year to devise, another year to secure funding, and another three years to complete. By that time, life has moved on."

How interesting to find Anthony Giddens making a similar point in his recent lecture on the future of social science to the London School of Economics' Centre for Philosophy of Natural and Social Science .

Universities, he observed, no longer have the type of monopoly on the production of social scientific knowledge that they enjoyed a generation ago. Other hats are in the ring. "If you look back to the 1970s, there were only three or four think-tanks," he said. "Now there are about 30. Think-tanks are not only quicker on their feet but they find it easier to get their ideas represented in the media than universities. I know it's an aggressive analogy, but you could regard the think- tanks as little Spitfires and the universities as Lancaster bombers."

But Giddens, unlike my committee colleague, did not go on to suggest that academic social scientists should throw in the towel. There was still a place for thoroughgoing academic research, but this must be complemented by a readiness on the part of academics to take a more active part in public debate. Academics had a duty to communicate. We need more "public intellectuals", people from within the academy who are "able and willing to communicate findings to a wider public and engage in a dialogue with that public". People, he might have added, not altogether unlike myself.

 Laurie Taylor talks to Anthony Giddens about the future of social science on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Swept aside
fields.standfirst: Allan Brigham knows the paths are only paved with gold for some in a hi-tech world
fields.trailText: Allan Brigham knows the paths are only paved with gold for some in a hi-tech world
fields.body:
It was 6am. Above loomed the turrets of King's College chapel. On the ground, the orange chunks of diced carrot stared back at me. They lay in the centre of a lurid pool of pink, sticky vomit. Littering the surrounding pavement were half-eaten hamburgers, shredded cabbage and discarded packaging. Along the deserted street, the early morning light reflected off broken glass. We began to clear up the debris deposited after closing time the night before.

10am. Break time. We sat in the cafe. Opposite me, Paul tucked in to his poached eggs. His son had woken in the night and he was tired. Their one-bedroom flat is the size of some people's living rooms. With a failed business start-up behind them, they are now stuck - as owner-occupiers not eligible for social housing and unable to afford anything larger. What will happen when Tom is a teenager?

We'd left the city centre spotless, a stage prepared for another day of shoppers, tourists and revellers. With 3m visitors a year, it is one of the most sought-after high street locations in the UK. Now it boasts the largest pub in the country, capable of holding 2,000 customers on a Saturday night, all of whom appear to make a beeline for the nearest takeaway once they are ejected on to the street.

It was different when I started as a sweeper 20 years ago. The pub used to be a cinema, there was one chip shop in a back street, and hamburgers were only eaten in America. Cambridge was just a university town, with low wages and low costs. Jobs were plentiful at Chivers, making jam from soft fruit. Now Microsoft is here, recruiting staff on starting salaries of £35,000. It joins biotechnology firms promising a brave new world.

Cambridge has been transformed in front of our eyes. The government sees it as "its champion in a cut-throat new world economy". Nick Raynsford states that it is "the leading edge of the new technology", and the same theme is echoed by journalists: "The e-volcano at the end of the M11 that's about to erupt", or "the British version of the American dream".

It's a welcome transformation if it brings prosperity for all. But it is a threat if local people who provide the basic services that sustain the city, like we do, can no longer afford to live here. To many of my colleagues, the hi-tech recruits commanding London salaries are part of the problem, pushing up house prices to London levels. Local wages have not kept pace and local people are being forced out.

We are lucky. Since we bought our home 20 years ago, the cost of housing has risen tenfold while a road sweeper's wages have only risen fourfold. There's little "luck" for others starting afresh today. A mortgage for the cheapest house requires an annual income of £30,000. Nor is renting property an option. Social housing is scarce and landlords are asking £1,000 a month for a Victorian terrace.

A regular headline on the local news is "A14 chaos". Maybe the problem is not traffic but the fact that too many people have been forced to live too far from jobs and facilities. Projects such as Cambridge Futures, an initiative to investigate the consequences of rapid growth, have begun to look at this issue. But it needs addressing soon if Cambridge is not to become a city of the very rich, the very poor and students serviced from distant fenland ghettos.

10.30am. Paul wipes the egg yolk off his plate and we leave the cafe. The rest of the day is spent cleaning residential streets. A review of the green belt that surrounds the city is promised. More a mud belt than a green belt. But an emotive subject. Yet most of these streets we are cleaning were fields only 50 years ago. "Belts" are important, but boundaries can change without destroying the city. If the review can help to provide decent and affordable housing for those who want to live here then it is to be welcomed.

What is really important is how a sustainable and diverse urban environment can be created for those who live in this champion of the new world economy. It is a challenge for the 21st century - not a threat.

fields.headline: Payback time
fields.standfirst: Stopping fraud and waste of public funds is important, but accounting procedures for community and voluntary organisations are over-bureaucratic, argues Kevin Hyett
fields.trailText: Stopping fraud and waste of public funds is important, but accounting procedures for community and voluntary organisations are over-bureaucratic, argues Kevin Hyett
fields.body:
There is now a strong push from the government for neighbourhood renewal and social inclusion, but it seems that the government's financial systems are perversely designed to exclude community groups from becoming actively involved. Much of the recent funding debate has been about the trend from grants to contracts. But perhaps the more pressing issue for community groups is the trend from funding organisations with core grants to just reimbursing project costs.

In recent years, community and voluntary organisations in the UK have increasingly relied upon project-specific grants from public funds, both from the government and from the EU institutions. However, these project-specific funds have brought with them a new volume of accounting requirements, unlike any grants in the past. Previously, the monitoring of a grant would include, for example, sending the funder a copy of the annual audited accounts and of the annual report. Whereas now, we have reached the point where itemised quarterly claims for every receipt have to be inspected and accounted for. Is this really necessary?

Within the UK, civil servants are keen to repeat their requirement that the proper financial control environment must be established. Partly, this need for a "control environment" comes from the years of sleaze when private gain from public funds was getting out of hand. It also comes from the EU institutions who have had a bad press in terms of fraud, and are very keen to show that they run the tightest system of all. Although senior civil servants are being told by ministers to find out what works, to take risks and be entrepreneurial, this new approach seems not to change how community groups can be funded.

In the desire to be squeaky clean, have we forgotten our other objectives? Particularly when we have the strong suspicion that the smallest groups are given the hardest time. We can read how the Jubilee line in London overspent with millions of pounds of public funds, yet a community project will spend days putting together another claim or monitoring report for travelling costs, and has to justify to officials whether each training course was strictly necessary for their staff.

Stopping fraud and waste of public funds is important - we would lose public support otherwise. But we now have a control culture which will reimburse the most ineffective but bureaucratically-correct project, yet take to task the inspirational project manager who forgets that childcare is to be counted under "beneficiary costs" and not under the "other costs" heading.

So, if the only reason we have to live with this degree of control is to protect public funds from fraud, the key question should be - does it actually work in terms of detecting fraud without hindering good work? At best, we can say that the jury is still out on this question. There are many examples of slick organisations which have provided plausible spreadsheets and information to claim a grant. But, although we all agree that the system is not perfect in detecting fraud, the key choice is should we add even more detail, or should we think it through afresh?

One of the key weaknesses of the reimbursement culture is that it asks the funder to audit the expenditure, but seldom talks to the community group's own auditor. This is particularly true for revenue grants, though less so for capital grants. Indeed, it is sometimes surprisingly straightforward to get a massive capital grant, often only verified by formal certificates from an auditor and from a quantity surveyor.

The treasurers of community groups already know how much detail they have to cope with. The charity commissioners have set out their own rules for the accounts, which it is commonly agreed would not kick in for the private sector until the company's turnover was into millions of pounds a year. These rules make it quite hard for community groups and voluntary organisations to find skilled finance staff, and now groups find they have even more work to do to meet project funding requirements. Groups set out with energy and a strong agenda to improve an aspect of life, only to be overwhelmed by horrendous financial systems.

Within the Greater Manchester Coalition of Disabled People, of which I am treasurer, we have seen the steady drip of ever more short-term project funding and more financial red tape, with our core grant from the local authorities frozen since the mid-1990s. We have to juggle budgets to cover administrative costs and fixed overheads, with horrible consequences. There are many other organisations in the same position, and not just in the north of England, where the absence of new core grants makes it now the hardest time to establish or build a new group, no matter how essential its work would be.

We think core grants are important because they fund groups in the best way possible by letting groups concentrate their energy and commitment on achieving the purposes of the group.

So perhaps we can hope for this issue to come full circle. It should be possible to respect the role of the auditor, and come back to funding bodies receiving copies of audited accounts which cover the project concerned. If cashflow is an issue, it can be addressed with an audit during the year which then results in an auditor's certificate to justify large advance payments. Smaller payments in advance should just be good practice.

The government has committed to supporting active communities and to reducing red tape. The degree of detail over the project funding of community groups is overdue for change. The task is now for politicians to drive this understanding much deeper into the civil service reimbursement culture across the country in the real life of real groups.

 Kevin Hyett is treasurer of the Greater Manchester Coalition of Disabled People.

fields.headline: On the road to nowhere
fields.standfirst: Forced out of their homes by racists who threatened to kill them, Gypsies are still not considered genuine refugees by the government, reports Jake Bowers-Burbridge
fields.trailText: Forced out of their homes by racists who threatened to kill them, Gypsies are still not considered genuine refugees by the government, reports Jake Bowers-Burbridge
fields.body:
Lucky heather! Come and buy some lucky heather. It's a call still used by Gypsies plying their age-old trades. But while Gypsies may be used to dealing in fortunes, they have rarely possessed them. As such, they are always seen as perpetual scam artists, and the ultimate embodiment of the economic migrant. They are a people without a state, or even an effective international organisation to defend them. And they are the ultimate scapegoats to be abused with impunity as "bogus" asylum seekers.

Beneath the image of a people who move when the economic winds starts to blow in a different direction, there is a story of racial persecution that is unrecognised by the governments who now find themselves dealing with a people defined by the Czech president, Vaclav Havel, as "the litmus test of civil society". But how well is Britain standing up to that test?

Ladislav Balaz is a Romany refugee under siege. The electricity in his north London home stopped working days ago, his sister-in-law has died from cancer after being refused treatment because of her race, and he's just heard that skinhead gangs are rampaging through the home town he fled in the Czech province of northern Moravia.

Most British people, passing him in the street, would not even know he is a Gypsy. He's never owned a caravan in his life and you get the feeling he wouldn't know one end of a horse from the other. His olive skin might have betrayed his origins in a much whiter Britain 100 years ago, but nowadays it just helps him fit into the multicultural crowd.

He enjoys the new-found anonymity he has gained on the streets of north London. "In my home town, Orlova, my colour marks me out," he says. "We never ventured on to the streets at night. You see, in the Czech Republic there are only two kinds of people, the 'white' Czechs and the 'black' Roma. Skinheads have killed 32 Roma in the last 10 years. My friend Milan was one of them. A gang of them beat him to death outside my home because, to them, he was just a filthy Gypsy."

Outraged by the attack, Balaz sought justice for his friend, only to witness a conspiracy you might think was more at home in apartheid South Africa than an aspiring member of the European Union. "The coroner told me that he had been run down by a truck," Balaz says, "but we saw them kill him with our own eyes."

Six weeks later, in June 1998, Balaz received an anonymous letter signed by the "Satanic sect, k.k.k, S.S" and a swastika. It said, "God warns you, quickly get going. Hitler should have lived two more years, then there would not be any more gypsies. We want a Moravia clean of black gypsies". Ladislav fled with his wife Marta and his six children to Britain, where his life is now in limbo. He is one of the thousands of supposedly "bogus" refugees reviled by the tabloid media.

The 1951 UN convention relating to the status of refugees supposedly guarantees protection to any person who has fled their country "owing to a well-founded fear of persecution due to their race, religion, nationality, membership of a social group or political opinion". But Home Office guidelines to magistrates refuse to recognise Romany persecution, despite its continuing documentation by Amnesty International, the Council of Europe, the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the US state department.

"The Home Office says that you are not a genuine refugee because you are a Gypsy," says the magistrate in a refreshing dose of honesty at Taylor House, where immigration appeals are heard in London. The woman she is addressing has no legal representation and it's clear that this is the end of the line for her. Dr Donald Kenrick is there as well, giving testimony on Romany persecution in Poland, after recognising the defendant's name as Polish Romany on the list of cases to be heard in the court that morning.

Kenrick has been a tireless fighter for Romany rights for the last 30 years. At the age of 70, he spends many of his days voluntarily helping refugees fight for their claims to asylum. "There's at least 10 cases every day," he says. "I come along when I can, find a case and do my best to get the government to see that these people are genuinely persecuted because of their race. We've won a few."

But the few cases that have been won are a mere drop in the ocean. Of the 5,000 Romany asylum seekers to have arrived in this country, only three have been granted leave to stay - dramatically lower than for other asylum seekers. Figures from the Refugee Council state that 54% of asylum applications are granted on their first hearing. The disparity between the treatment faced by the Romany people and other persecuted groups is something Kenrick has made a point of experiencing all over the world.

Valeria Bockova tells me about the Czech Republic in her tiny flat in suburban Clacton-on-Sea, Essex. Her mantelpiece, adorned with family photos, looks just like any mother's enthusiastic collection of family portraits - until she starts explaining why she is here. In the light of what she tells me, it becomes a chilling shrine to Romany suffering and a family torn apart by racial violence and government hostility.

"The skinheads grabbed him and shoved poison down his throat," says Valeria while looking at the worn portrait of her brother. It was 1983 and he was just 17. But it was a horrific indication of things to come. Britain is the fifth country she has come to looking for sanctuary. She hasn't found much.

On arrival at Stansted airport, her husband, Villem Bock, was arrested and was detained at Tinsley House, near Gatwick, after three days of interrogation.

Valeria clutches a letter about the detention like a left luggage receipt. In a language she can't understand, the reason for the detention is given thus: "I am detaining you for examination because I have further inquiries to make and more questions to ask you." The £87.30 she and her daughter are given every week to live on barely covers her food and utility bills. She simply cannot afford the £37.35 cheap day return to Gatwick to see her husband. "I want to eat meat, not biscuits," she says as she shows us her near empty fridge. Seeing your husband, it seems, is a luxury for a refugee.

Only one of Valeria's four children, Mary, is with her. Her son Stefan is in Norway, daughters Berta and Valeria are in Canada. At the age of 10, and after only two months in this country, Mary has a command of English and a stoical understanding of humanity that can only have been learnt the hard way. "Some people good, some people bad," she says about the people of Clacton. She explains that the children in her street have been told not to play with her, but some of the kids at school are interested in why she is here.

Valeria is crying after getting off the phone with her son Stefan. I think of telling her that everything is going to be all right and that her family name, Bock, actually means "luck" or "fortune" in English Romani. But I don't. Somehow I don't think she'd appreciate the irony of it.

 Jake Bowers-Burbridge has spent the last three years on the road tracing his Roma ancestory.

But Home Office guidelines to magistrates refuse to recognise Romany persecution, despite its continuing documentation by Amnesty International, the Council of Europe, the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the US state department. "The Home Office says that you are not a genuine refugee because you are a Gypsy," says the magistrate in a refreshing dose of honesty at Taylor House, where immigration appeals are heard in London. The woman she is addressing has no legal representation and it's clear that this is the end of the line for her. Dr Donald Kenrick is there as well, giving testimony on Romany persecution in Poland, after recognising the defendant's name as Polish Romany on the list of cases to be heard in the court that morning. Kenrick has been a tireless fighter for Romany rights for the last 30 years. At the age of 70, he spends many of his days voluntarily helping refugees fight for their claims to asylum. "There's at least 10 cases every day," he says. "I come along when I can, find a case and do my best to get the government to see that these people are genuinely persecuted because of their race. We've won a few." But the few cases that have been won are a mere drop in the ocean. Of the 5,000 Romany asylum seekers to have arrived in this country, only three have been granted leave to stay - dramatically lower than for other asylum seekers. Figures from the Refugee Council state that 54% of asylum applications are granted on their first hearing. The disparity between the treatment faced by the Romany people and other persecuted groups is something Kenrick has made a point of experiencing all over the world. Valeria Bockova tells me about the Czech Republic in her tiny flat in suburban Clacton-on-Sea, Essex. Her mantelpiece, adorned with family photos, looks just like any mother's enthusiastic collection of family portraits - until she starts explaining why she is here. In the light of what she tells me, it becomes a chilling shrine to Romany suffering and a family torn apart by racial violence and government hostility. "The skinheads grabbed him and shoved poison down his throat," says Valeria while looking at the worn portrait of her brother. It was 1983 and he was just 17. But it was a horrific indication of things to come. Britain is the fifth country she has come to looking for sanctuary. She hasn't found much. Valeria clutches a letter about the detention like a left luggage receipt. In a language she can't understand, the reason for the detention is given thus: "I am detaining you for examination because I have further inquiries to make and more questions to ask you." The £87.30 she and her daughter are given every week to live on barely covers her food and utility bills. She simply cannot afford the £37.35 cheap day return to Gatwick to see her husband. Her son Stefan is in Norway, daughters Berta and Valeria are in Canada. Somehow I don't think she'd appreciate the irony of it.  Jake Bowers-Burbridge has spent the last three years on the road tracing his Roma ancestory.

fields.headline: Nest eggs
fields.standfirst: The government is listening to new ideas from the US to invest money for each newborn baby as a way of helping people on low incomes save for the future, says Gavin Kelly
fields.trailText: The government is listening to new ideas from the US to invest money for each newborn baby as a way of helping people on low incomes save for the future, says Gavin Kelly
fields.body:
It is often said that the inspiration for the government's big ideas on welfare reform have come from the US. Tonight, Michael Sherraden, a leading US social policy expert, is speaking alongside David Blunkett at an Institute for Public Policy Research lecture. He will offer a new policy agenda that ministers might want to import.

Over recent years, much of cutting edge US and UK policy has focused on finding new ways of boosting the incomes of disadvantaged groups - particularly the working poor - through a range of tax credits. It is Sherraden's willingness to stray beyond this emphasis on "income" and focus on the distribution of financial assets - such as savings and investments - that makes him distinctive.

At the moment, individual development accounts (Idas) are the most prominent form of "asset-based welfare" in the US. These are savings accounts into which contributions from individuals are more than matched by those from government. For every dollar saved by an individual the state may add another two, three, or more dollars (it varies across schemes). The funds accumulated within the Idas can help low-income people - those from households with income less than 80% of median income - to buy their first home, undertake post-compulsory education and training, or start their own company.

The early evidence from Idas is that it can encourage people with modest incomes to acquire the saving habit and to plan ahead. These promising beginnings have led 27 states to pass legislation in the last few years allowing them to set up Ida schemes and it is estimated that well over 200 community-based Ida schemes are in existence. But it is important to keep this growth in perspective. The number of individuals benefiting from Idas is still limited. Despite the hype Idas are still small beer in terms of public spending.

Their small scale is only one of the reasons why Idas are currently a policy without an enemy. Leftish Democrats are delighted to find a new way of supporting disadvantaged groups and relish the opportunity of rekindling the New Deal project of democratising wealth. Meanwhile, most Republicans purr with pleasure when Idas are sold to them as a way of promoting individual responsibility and spreading private ownership. Idas are one of those rare policies which allow both sides in politics to use their favourite rhetoric. The resulting bi-partisan support is evident in the savings for working families bill, currently under consideration in Congress.

If and when asset-based policies start to have major implications for the public purse this consensus is likely to come under serious pressure. The signs are this may happen sooner rather than later. Some states are already drawing up plans for more ambitious asset policies such as Kidsave, which involves the state paying $1,000 into the account of each newborn child and making additional contributions over subsequent years. The cost implications of these proposals are of a different magnitude to those of Idas.

The presidential race is also having an impact. Bill Clinton has fired some valedictory shots in the debate on the future of social security by restating his support for the creation of millions of universal savings accounts which would help low income individuals save for retirement as well as homes, learning and business start-ups. This has triggered Republican candidate George Bush to counter with his plan to convert the generous pay-as-you-go state pension into a funded pension system in which individual citizens take control of their own retirement accounts. Suddenly, everyone in American politics is adopting a position on the merits of different asset-based welfare strategies.

All this makes Sherraden's visit to the UK a timely moment to consider the case for asset-based polices in the UK. The government's raft of measures aimed at boosting the incomes of disadvantaged groups can be contrasted with the absence of any serious measures aimed at promoting asset-building for those on low incomes. There is very little by way of substance behind the regular calls for "wealth for the many" and "savings for all".

This is of greater concern due to the growing body of evidence which suggests that asset-ownership can have a powerful independent effect on a number of key social outcomes, such as labour market performance and health. Part of this simply reflects the fact that some life-choices - such as starting a new firm - require capital. But it also reflects the finding that owning capital appears to enhance people's sense of control and well-being. Add to this the fact that the ratio of households without any assets doubled between 1979-1996 and that 50% of people still have under £500 disposable financial wealth - and the case for a new policy agenda hardens.

The answer cannot be to promote asset-building among low income groups through the traditional route of granting tax reliefs - the evidence from Peps, personal pensions and Isas suggests that this approach benefits the comfortable and does next to nothing for those with few or no assets.

A bolder approach would see a second-term Labour administration committing itself to a range of asset-based policies. Here are two it could start with. First, it could set up a savings account for every newborn child - a "baby bond" as the IPPR has called it - with special endowments and matching contributions made for children from poorer families. The account would build up in value until the young adult accesses it when they reach 18. Second, Idas run by local community and voluntary groups could be targeted at adults in localities where there are particular problems with obtaining credit, starting businesses, and accessing training and learning. Both of these measures would go with the grain of the government's commitment to ending the spread of poverty across generations and attacking concentrated pockets of disadvantage.

Proposals for other forms of asset-based policies will follow. As the government continues to search for new ways of making a reality of the promise of "opportunity for all" Michael Sherraden should find that his ideas receive a warm welcome. Perhaps it is time for a New Deal for savers.

 Gavin Kelly is senior research fellow at the IPPR and is author, with Rachel Lissauer, of Ownership for All (published by IPPR; ISBN 186030 114 2; price £4.95; available from Central Books, tel: 020-8986 5488).

fields.headline: Fast forward
fields.standfirst: Alan Travis talks to immigration minister Barbara Roche about tackling a huge backlog
fields.trailText: Alan Travis talks to immigration minister Barbara Roche about tackling a huge backlog
fields.body:
After two months in which decisions have been made in more than 20,000 cases, the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, believes that Britain's stricken asylum system is finally on the road to recovery.

Extra staff will arrive in July, and if a new Treasury bid succeeds then Roche holds out the possibility that by this autumn the Home Office will have the capacity to make 15,000-16,000 decisions on asylum cases every month.

Roche says this compares with an average last year of only 3,000 decisions a month - the result of a botched computerisation programme and an ill-timed move of headquarters' offices. The scale of the recovery is impressive and offers the prospect that a mountainous backlog - at one time, more than 100,000 cases - could be reduced to what is officially termed "frictional" levels by the end of next year.

Roche is in no doubt that the asylum backlog has been one of the key reasons why 1999 saw a record 79,000 applications to Britain. "A major pull factor - especially if you are talking about organised crime - can clearly be that you go to the back of a very long queue," she says. "Well, the message is getting out that 'No you don't now'. The backlog continues to fall and is now 94,540."

Applications from Poland and the Czech Republic have fallen sharply as a result of a widespread media campaign in eastern Europe about Britain's new tougher asylum law. And the opening of the Oakington rapid processing camp, near Cambridge, has ensured that applying for asylum doesn't mean joining the end of that long queue. In its first two months, 300 asylum seekers and their families were sent to Oakington. Some 205 have been refused asylum, three have been given refugee status and three allowed to remain in Britain on exceptional grounds. Some 172 applicants have appealed, and the appeals, if they are certified, will be heard within three weeks. So far, all those appeals heard to completion have been dismissed.

Roche says that this initial record disproves the claims of those who argued such a fast-track procedure would be unfair. "It was said that if you had a quick decision-making process that would affect the quality of decisions," she says. "The fact that cases were taking ages before a decision was made wasn't because case workers were poring over them; it was because they were sitting on a dusty shelf somewhere, which was doing nobody any good."

As MP for the north London constituency of Hornsey and Wood Green, Roche says: "I am unique among immigration ministers in that I have one of the highest immigration and asylum caseloads in the country," she says. "When I do a surgery, 80% of the cases are about immigration and asylum."

Roche also makes clear that contingency plans, leaked to the Guardian last month, for the mass detention of asylum seekers in army camps in the event of a sudden surge this summer no longer exist. The theory is that the fast-track decision-making process, the civil penalty fines on smugglers, and the introduction of vouchers will all combine to deter any fresh surge in applications.

She believes that the new national asylum support service (Nass), with its system of dispersal and vouchers, has worked well since it became operational on April 1. A lot of the problems which had emerged, she says, were the result of London boroughs, such as Westminster and Wandsworth, and Kent councils placing asylum seekers with all sorts of landlords in all sorts of places.

Roche says: "It was done in a completely uncoordinated way, with no thought for language groups, and it had a knock-on effect in terms of shortage of facilities." Among the problems are poor landlords and difficulties getting refugee children into schools.

The minister says that contracts with the local authority regional consortia to provide accommodation outside London will be signed soon and the dispersal scheme - currently operating for only 40% of asylum seekers after its full introduction was postponed in April - will be fully implemented this autumn.

The immigration and nationality directorate of the Home Office reckons that, after all appeals and other procedures are taken into account, about 34% of all asylum seekers are given some sort of official status to remain in Britain.

Roche says that she wishes more attention was paid to the problems of integrating those who are recognised as refugees. She insists: "What Jack Straw and I keep saying is that we want to welcome people who are genuinely fleeing persecution, to give them asylum and, once they are here, to make the best use of their skills and qualifications."
