fields.headline: Breathing space
fields.standfirst: We invited Reclaim the Streets to reply to the criticisms levelled at it in the Guardian. This is their response, by Graeme Chesters
fields.trailText: We invited Reclaim the Streets to reply to the criticisms levelled at it in the Guardian. This is their response, by Graeme Chesters
fields.body:
What must the few thousand people who gathered in Parliament Square on May Day to plant seeds, erect a maypole, discuss with friends and enjoy the sunshine be thinking? Classified as, at best, "inchoate herbivores" by the Guardian's political columnist, Hugo Young, and at worst as "May Day mobsters" by the director of Friends of the Earth or "incoherent vigilantes" by George Monbiot in these pages, what do we find beneath this opprobrium?

Is such comment justified outrage at the graffiti adorning the Cenotaph, or due to the brief, ritual violence between police and a small group of young people outside McDonalds?

Maybe, the level of outrage reflects something entirely different, something deeper which the actions of the "guerrilla gardeners" has brought to the surface. My fear is that, amid the moral pontificating of politicians and the shrill respectability of mainstream greens, the debate will be reduced to a competition as to who can make the loudest condemnation.

What appears to some commentators as incoherent and disorganised can equally be understood as purposeful and reasoned. The actions of occupying and cultivating Parliament Square are entirely consistent with the explicit rationale of Reclaim The Streets, which has been clearly articulated since its formation in 1995, and which involves "taking back those things which have been enclosed within capitalist circulation and returning them to collective use as commons".

Behind this elaborate language is a biting critique of the way in which public spaces have become increasingly privatised: colonised by advertising; criminalised if used for enjoyment or protest; stolen for needless development; or enclosed by politicians.

Hugo Young, however, believes the actions of the guerrilla gardeners to be little more than a form of "anti-politics", providing cover for "anarchists" to exercise the violent "dictatorship of the individual", to use the phrase of FoE director, Charles Secrett.

Equally, George Monbiot feels able to unilaterally decree that RTS "can never again be anything but a threat to the environmental and social justice movements".

These critiques have been levelled at every other movement which has chosen non-institutional methods of engagement with a powerful political and economic elite.

Instead, under the guise of advocating a more nuanced and intelligent approach, commentators such as Young, Secrett and Monbiot reveal an impoverished notion of the possibilities for meaningful human interaction and its expression in creative forms of collective action. Secrett lauds the possibilities of a "regulated market economy", and Young highlights "a gap in the market for serious radicalism", while at the same time arguing that "capitalism . . . is the best system anyone can think of" - a state ment that epitomises the lack of imagination which currently passes for political commentary.

Monbiot believes that RTS has a responsibility to elucidate a workable alternative to capitalism or to be classified as failures. But that task is already inherent in the ongoing and collective process of struggle undertaken by individuals, groups and social movements who, through their practices, explore and refine opportunities for expressive, participatory and radically democratic forms of politics.

This is what RTS and the broader radical environmental and social justice movement is already involved in - the process of exploring how we might resist and survive. They don't expect to have the answers; what they have is the leverage to open space for the discussion and practice of alternatives, to open space for instrumental action against polluters and profiteers, and sometimes just to open space so we can remember what open spaces look like.

Parliament Square was, for a brief period, an experiment in possibilities - not all of them thought through, or taken up. The guerrilla gardening action, which had been trailed extensively as not being "a protest", was audacious and symbolic. It required people to work together in a situation of significant threat to their liberty- a threat heightened by newspaper articles declaring the inevitability of violence.

It was, by definition, utopian and romantic, but this is what many miss in politics, as in everyday life: a vision which moves beyond the "inevitability" of the market place and the "triumph" of transnational capital. Throughout the day, open microphones allowed participants to debate and discuss a range of issues, including GMOs, the anti-terrorism bill, permaculture and composting. When the square was finally sealed by riot police, who refused to allow anyone in or out without being searched and photographed, a mass meeting was called to debate how to respond.

Led initially by activists, it quickly became a forum for people to vent their fear and frustration at the police tactics and to make demands of the day's organisers.

Eventually, a decision was made to march through the lines of riot police at the exit closest to the Commons and, despite a tense period of pushing and shoving, when a great deal of discipline was shown by those confronted by shields and batons, the police relinquished their blockade and the crowd was able to samba towards Lambeth bridge.

It should be remembered that many of the people in the square were the same people who fought the roads programme to a standstill, with imagination, creativity and the occasional burning bulldozer. They began by being denounced, before latterly being applauded for their vision and persistence. This doesn't mean they cannot be wrong or that their tactical acumen cannot go astray. It does mean, however, that those so quick to dismiss their actions should remember that such events were illegal and unimaginable only a few years ago. Now they are only illegal.

Further information

www.indymedia.org.uk/
www.reclaimthestreets.net
www.freespeech.org/mayday2k/

 A longer version of this article appears in the forthcoming edition of ECOS magazine. Graeme Chesters is a research fellow in the Centre for Local Policy Studies at Edgehill College, Lancashire, and is also active in Lancaster Reclaim the Streets.

It was, by definition, utopian and romantic, but this is what many miss in politics, as in everyday life: a vision which moves beyond the "inevitability" of the market place and the "triumph" of transnational capital. Throughout the day, open microphones allowed participants to debate and discuss a range of issues, including GMOs, the anti-terrorism bill, permaculture and composting. When the square was finally sealed by riot police, who refused to allow anyone in or out without being searched and photographed, a mass meeting was called to debate how to respond. Led initially by activists, it quickly became a forum for people to vent their fear and frustration at the police tactics and to make demands of the day's organisers. Eventually, a decision was made to march through the lines of riot police at the exit closest to the Commons and, despite a tense period of pushing and shoving, when a great deal of discipline was shown by those confronted by shields and batons, the police relinquished their blockade and the crowd was able to samba towards Lambeth bridge. It should be remembered that many of the people in the square were the same people who fought the roads programme to a standstill, with imagination, creativity and the occasional burning bulldozer. They began by being denounced, before latterly being applauded for their vision and persistence. This doesn't mean they cannot be wrong or that their tactical acumen cannot go astray. It does mean, however, that those so quick to dismiss their actions should remember that such events were illegal and unimaginable only a few years ago. Now they are only illegal. webTitle: Amnesty accuses Nato of war crimes

fields.headline: Amnesty accuses Nato of war crimes
fields.standfirst:
Amnesty International
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Nato today dismissed accusations by Amnesty International that it committed war crimes during its air war against Kosovo and Serbia.
fields.body:
Nato today dismissed accusations by Amnesty International that it committed war crimes during its air war against Kosovo and Serbia.

Jamie Shea, Nato's chief spokesman, said that cases when civilians were killed were due to technological failure or "the accidents of conflict" - not because Nato had failed to take all necessary precautions.

"Each target that Nato struck was approved by a team of government lawyers and we attacked in such a way as to minimise the prospects of civilian casualties," he said.

"We never said we would avoid casualties. It would be foolhardy to say that, as no military operation in history has been perfect.

He argued that the costs of the conflict had to weighed against the thousands of Kosovan Albanians who would be dead without Nato intervention.

Pressed on the bombing of a Serb TV station in which several civilians were killed, Mr Shea said: "The television station was attacked because it was not the BBC or CNN, it was being used to push out propaganda and to create a climate of hatred in which the persecution of Albanians could be accepted as normal by the greater majority of the Serb population."

In its 60-page report, Amnesty said allied commanders should have taken greater precautions to avoid civilian deaths.

Brendan Paddy of Amnesty said: "Our conclusion was that in a number of incidents they did not take sufficient precautions to prevent civilian casualties. As a result there were inevitable and unlawful civilian deaths."

The attack on the Serbian state television station was a "grave breach of the laws of war" and Nato "therefore committed a war crime", Mr Paddy said, adding: "What they have done was deliberately target a civilian facility and 16 civilians were killed as a result."

The report also criticised the Nato attack on a civilian convoy at Djakovica on April 14 last year.

"We are saying that Nato did not take necessary precautions and did not positively identify the target before firing on it," Mr Paddy said.

"In particular that was a result of flying at 15,000 feet in order to ensure pilots' safety. That, of course, compromised the safety of civilians on the ground."

Most cases discussed in the 60-page report contravened the first protocol of the Geneva Convention, which prohibited attacks on civilians, he said.

Amnesty said that in some other attacks, such as on the rail bridge at Grdelica on April 12, Nato did not suspend bombing after it was evident that civilians were struck.

Mr Shea said the Amnesty report was less authoritative than that of the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, which concluded that Nato had committed no violations of international law.

"I have great respect for Amnesty, but their usual business is conducting inquiries into prisoners of conscience, and I think they have strayed a little bit beyond their turf in investigating military actions by Nato," he added.

In another report released today, the Labour-controlled foreign affairs select committee concluded that Nato's bombing of Kosovo was of "dubious legality".

The cross-party committee said Operation Allied Force was contrary to the "basic law of the international community" - the United Nations Charter.

However the committee said that the Nato action was justified on moral grounds because of Mr Milosevic's repression of the Kosovan Albanians.

It accepted that the alliance went as far as possible to make its military intervention comply with international law, faced with the veto of Russia and China in the UN Security Council.

The report also queries whether the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade was a genuine mistake as Nato claims.

The committee received evidence that the Americans deliberately targeted the embassy on the grounds that it was a telecommunications post passing on information to the Serbian regime about Nato's bombing campaign.

fields.headline: Time on our hands
fields.standfirst: Nicola Hill on radical plans to attract more people into volunteering
fields.trailText: Nicola Hill on radical plans to attract more people into volunteering
fields.body:
Over the next 10 years the role of volunteering is set to change. It will reduce loneliness, give retired people a purpose, increase company profits and bridge the gap between young and old. These are the predictions made in a report published today by the think-tank, Demos, and Community Service Volunteers. It looks at demographic trends - the ageing population, more single person households and teleworking, and assesses the challenge ahead for voluntary organisations.

The report's author, Gavin Mensah-Coker, of Demos, says that in an increasingly diverse and atomised society, volunteering could help to reduce social exclusion. But to achieve this, he says, "the image of volunteering needs to be addressed. The perception of a volunteer is very narrow - white, middle-class women - and this must be broadened to attract more people."

The scope of volunteering also needs to become less formal and institutionalised, Mensah-Coker argues. Virtual volunteering with people offering advice and support via the internet will take off. Employers will use volunteering as a way of developing staff skills and expect a return on time invested. And through the introduction of citizenship in schools young people will play a more active part in their communities.

The report states: "New volunteers will take the lead in cultivating their own opportunities that fit their lifestyle and interests and incorporate other leisure activities." For example, volunteering for the environment will be seen as a way to keep fit and improve the community.

CSV president, Lord Levy, says: "One of the toughest challenges ahead will be in persuading institutions to change their attitudes to volunteers." So what can organisations do to attract more volunteers?

One age group that is surprisingly under-represented in the volunteer workforce is 50-65 year olds. The policy director at the National Centre for Volunteering, Fiona Dawe, says voluntary organisations need to advertise in magazines catering for this market. Charities should also become involved in pre-retirement programmes and work with employers to find mutually beneficial ways of using the talents of staff.

One charity which has just moved premises to accommodate the number of volunteers it attracts is Weston Spirit set up by Falklands war veteran, Simon Weston, to help disaffected young people in inner cities. Communications officer, Helen Brennan, says organisations need to harness the skills and knowledge of people who are retired or unemployed. "You benefit from their experience and they don't feel left on the scrapheap," she says.

One of the volunteers, Ken Whittaker, aged 51, helps out on courses for young people, and with fundraising and IT support. He worked on building sites for most of his life, but when he became unemployed decided to take a degree in business information systems.

His motivation to volunteer for Weston Spirit was two-fold: he needed work experience in an office as part of his degree and wanted to help motivate young people in Liverpool. "You see them start a course introverted and full of apathy, and it's great when they come out chatting and enthusiastic. It's helped me too. I'm learning a lot of theory at univer sity, but here I get down to the nitty-gritty. Volunteering has really increased my own confidence and communication skills."

Dawe points out another area where the needs of volunteers and charities could converge. "Voluntary organisations shouldn't avoid asking people who have retired on sickness benefit," she says. "They may not be able to continue with their employment, but they could easily be retrained to do voluntary jobs."

Yesterday, Age Concern England published a report recommending an "active citizen's income" to recognise the contribution volunteers make to their communities.

Dawe takes this a stage further by calling on the government to implement a system of credits towards a person's pension in return for the time they give. Rory Hegarty, of Age Concern, says: "Rather than relying on goodwill, organisations are going to have to think of innovative ways of attracting older people to volunteer."

Today marks the end of a week in which volunteering has been celebrated with tea parties and coffee mornings. In 10 years' time, volunteers might expect a bonus paid into their volunteer credit accounts.

webTitle: Kinnock tells of dramatic Solomon's escape

fields.headline: Kinnock tells of dramatic Solomon's escape
fields.trailText: Glenys Kinnock today described her dramatic flight from the Solomon Islands after a "surreal" confrontation with the leader of an armed coup.
fields.body:
After a three-hour flight to freedom in a chartered light aircraft, the MEP and wife of former Labour leader Neil Kinnock said she was relieved to be safe after "a surreal kind of experience", but she remained deeply concerned over the threat of civil war in the islands.

Ms Kinnock, accompanied by fellow MEP John Corrie, was in a party of six which flew to Papua New Guinea - the first people to leave the islands since the coup began on Monday. Both MEPs will return to Britain via Australia this weekend.

It took the pilot of their twin-engined Otter plane two attempts to leave because of gunfire from marauding armed rebels on the airport perimeter, near the capital city of Honiara on the islands, 1,600 miles north east of Sydney, Australia.

"We started to take off and then headed back to where we started. The pilot said there was a faulty light on the panel. The second time everything was all right," said Labour MEP Mrs Kinnock.

"Only later did John tell me the pilot was concerned the first time round in case the plane had been hit. I had heard gunfire but I assumed it was coming from the bay, where the armed militia had commandeered a navy patrol boat. In fact they were firing from the edge of the airport."

Mrs Kinnock and Conservative colleague Mr Corrie, who had abandoned plans to visit Fiji because of the coup there, were invited to the Solomon Islands to act as EU mediators as tension mounted in the long-running violent inter-island feud between natives of Guadalcanal and Malaita.

But soon after they arrived, lawyer Andrew Nori led a coup, placing prime minister Bartholomew Ulufa'alu under house arrest.

"We arrived and we were just ambling around, although I was very concerned that things were clearly close to getting out of hand. There was a real threat," Mrs Kinnock said. Then the coup started and the MEPs were confined to their hotel.

"It became completely lawless. The police just seemed to concede to the gunmen of the Malaita Eagle Force under Andrew Nori. There were armed men roaming around with home-made weapons and the streets were blocked and the airport closed."

Nevertheless, both MEPs insisted on meeting the prime minister in an attempt to fulfil their "mediation" role.

"Although he was under house arrest he was brought to our hotel. In came this benign man, guarded by two awful armed guys. We assured the prime minister of our support for the democratic process," she said.

"Then we met the coup leader Andrew Nori, a very plausible man. We told him our views and warned him that EU aid to the Solomon Islands will stop unless they lifted their deadline for the prime minister to resign and allowed the due democratic process to determine the future through a vote of confidence in parliament.

"If the aid stopped it would be a complete disaster for the Solomons, they don't seem to realise that."

"I am very relieved to be out, but still very concerned at the potential for the crisis escalating. This is an ethnic conflict rooted in poverty and a sense of grievous injustice," she said. "It is important that we in the EU should do more than we do in these situations and do it faster."

Both MEPs are on the European parliament's development committee, and will be pressing for the about £40 million in EU aid - worth 25% of GDP to the Solomon Islands - to be put on hold if the conflict carries on.

Mrs Kinnock also reported that the deadline for the prime minister's resignation had been lifted, and there were increasing hopes that Mr Nori would halt his action until the parliament had time to discuss the crisis.

"It is important that we in the EU should do more than we do in these situations and do it faster." Both MEPs are on the European parliament's development committee, and will be pressing for the about £40 million in EU aid - worth 25% of GDP to the Solomon Islands - to be put on hold if the conflict carries on. Mrs Kinnock also reported that the deadline for the prime minister's resignation had been lifted, and there were increasing hopes that Mr Nori would halt his action until the parliament had time to discuss the crisis.

webTitle: British Airways in merger talks with KLM

fields.headline: British Airways in merger talks with KLM
fields.trailText: British Airways and the Dutch carrier KLM are to discuss a possible merger that would create Europe's biggest airline, it was announced today.
fields.body:
British Airways and the Dutch carrier KLM are to discuss a possible merger that would create Europe's biggest airline, it was announced today.

The two airlines, which together operate 500 aircraft, are to have discussions "on a possible combination of their businesses". The move was immediately condemned by the Virgin Atlantic airline chairman, Sir Richard Branson, as "a merger too far".

Sir Richard said that any BA-KLM alliance would raise huge competition issues in Britain, in Europe and on transatlantic routes.

BA, with 321 aircraft, flies to 233 destinations and also has its own low-cost carrier, Go, based at Stansted airport, Essex. KLM has 207 aircraft and flies to 137 destinations, and also operates a Stansted-based no-frills carrier, Buzz.

A merger between BA and KLM would create an airline with a market value of about £5bn.

News of the talks comes just two weeks after BA reported its worst financial results, with losses hitting £244m before one-off gains. The talks also mark the first major strategic step by BA's new chief executive, Rod Eddington, who took over at the helm of the company in May after his predecessor, Bob Ayling, was ousted.

BA's strategy for recovery focuses on business passengers, who provide higher profit-margins. But it has emphasised that it does not wish to alienate budget travellers. KLM, which has been seeking a possible merger partner since its talks with the Italian carrier Alitalia collapsed earlier this year, is understood to have initiated the talks with BA. A merger would give the enlarged group a second major travel hub in Europe at Amsterdam's Schiphol airport to add to BA's strong position at London's Heathrow. It would also allow the two companies to merge Go and Buzz.

The KLM talks, the focus of BA's European ambitions, come soon after the UK airline announced that it was cutting back its business interests in other continental carriers.

A combined BA and KLM would be twice the size of Europe's next biggest airline German group, Lufthansa, in terms of passenger miles.

Any deal would require the approval of competition regulators and attention would focus on landing slots at Schiphol. BA and KLM were close to a merger eight years ago when talks collapsed over a failure to agree on the price.

fields.headline: Blair urges return to 'traditional values'
fields.trailText:
Tony Blair today urged a return to traditional British values and promised opportunities for all as he attempted to move on the elitism row.
Special report
Quiz: What elite do you belong to?
fields.body:
Tony Blair today urged a return to traditional British values and promised opportunities for all as he attempted to move on the elitism row.

In his first speech since the birth of baby Leo two weeks ago Mr Blair told 10,000 delegates at the annual Women's Institute conference in London that community was at the heart of his beliefs and the government needed to "trust people more".

"In the last few weeks I've done a lot of reflecting. It is not just that life is in better perspective. There is a renewed sense of purpose," he said.

"The idea of community is as old as time. What makes it tick are the values of responsibility to, and respect for, others. These are traditional values, good old British values.

"A meritocratic society is the only one that can exploit its economic chances to the full and that means exploiting the talent of all its people."

Mr Blair dismissed the criticism over Gordon Brown's attack on Oxford University's admissions procedure. "Let's hear no more rubbish about class war, as if we had to choose between caricatures of Little Lord Fauntleroy or Karl Marx," he said.

Education was still the most important thing in the country, he said. However the prime minister attracted heckles from the 10,000 strong audience when he said the government was working to improve the NHS.

The Women's Institute gave a warmer reception to the government's plans to take driving licences away from fathers who do not support their children financially. Mr Blair summarised his approach as respect for others, honour, self-discipline, duty, obligation and the essential decency of the British character.

"Let us take these old values and blend them with the challenge of the new world to fashion a Britain able to take on the world," he said.

fields.headline: Far from reality
fields.standfirst: Plans to link social housing rents to property prices will create huge anomalies between the north and south, argues Bill Payne
fields.trailText: Plans to link social housing rents to property prices will create huge anomalies between the north and south, argues Bill Payne
fields.body:
As Sir Humphrey might have said in response to the housing green paper proposal to link local authority and housing association rents to house prices, "A very bold decision, if I may say so minister."

These social landlords charge affordable, below-market rents for low-income households. Unlike private sector landlords, they do not seek to maximise rents to market levels. Nick Raynsford, the housing minister, is well informed on his subject, but it is hard to believe that this proposal has been properly thought out.

Linking rents to house prices makes very little sense for a national housing strategy. House price rises in the south are headline news and cause the Bank of England to increase interest rates; at the same time, good quality homes in former coal mining communities in South Yorkshire can still be bought for well below £5,000.

The government intends to restructure rents so they are set on an objective basis - which tenants and landlords must welcome as being fairer than the current system, which can lead to considerable anomalies, with tenants often paying significantly different rents for similar properties in similar locations. At first sight, linking rents to property values appears to be a reasonable policy. But there are two flaws which may make this proposal unworkable.

First, it will increase the differentials in rents between the south and north. Rents in the south - already far higher than in the north - will be forced up, while there will be substantial falls in northern rents. Initial inquiries from the Chartered Institute of Housing suggest that housing association rents based solely on capital values could increase in London by more than a third; but in Yorkshire and Humberside, they could fall by more than a fifth. Substantial rises in rents in London could make it even harder for schools to find teachers and leave inner city hospitals unable to find cleaning staff for love nor money.

Second, housing associations will be dramatically affected: some may not survive the proposed changes. Running costs between north and south do not vary as much as property values, so housing associations in the south would make significant surpluses, while those in the north will find their viability threatened.

To deal with this problem, the minister has suggested that southern housing associations should take over those in the north. But would our southern cousins, with their higher property values and rents, be keen to merge with their poorer northern relatives just to keep them viable?

Tenants might not be keen on this suggestion either. A leading tenants' group member in Rotherham told us that "a big southern landlord wouldn't have any interest in the slightest in what we want in our area. It'd all be about figures on the balance sheet. At the moment, there's a local focus - that's why we're called South Yorkshire Housing Association. We like it because that's where we live: South Yorkshire - not in London or anywhere else."

Housing associations are key organisations in tackling social exclusion; this needs local strategic partnerships, increased accountability and sensitivity to local needs for regenerating deprived communities. No minister! The regeneration of Sheffield or Newcastle simply cannot be directed from Notting Hill.

We think that the government will ultimately recognise that capital values are far less helpful than a more sophisticated relationship with tenant incomes. A link with capital values alone would have serious consequences. There would be a massive rent rise - and corresponding increases in housing benefit - for housing association tenants in the south. While in the north, vulnerable housing associations would be unable to deliver the green paper's objectives and the government's social exclusion agenda.

It is early days for detailed responses to the green paper, but the red herring of linking capital values to rents needs to be consigned to the bin. Delivering good quality homes at a price people can afford should be the focus of these deliberations. We believe that the temptation to use an easy index like house prices, which would lead to adverse outcomes, cannot be allowed to happen. The key issue is what people on low incomes can afford to pay. Even concocting a formula linking rent levels both to incomes and capital values will only modify the nonsense. Please think again, minister.

 Bill Payne is chief executive of the Yorkshire Housing Association.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your answers to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer them.
fields.trailText: Can anybody tell me when the dug-out was invented? Was it during the famous Christmas ceasefire football game in World War I? wondered Mario Kerssens.
fields.body:
Can anybody tell me when the dug-out was invented? Was it during the famous Christmas ceasefire football game in World War I? wondered Mario Kerssens.

Hats off to Donald Jamieson, who emailed us from Venezuela to tell us that the first dug-outs were in Pittodrie in Aberdeen. He was right - although his suggestion that they first occurred in the late 1930s was slightly wide of the mark.

According to Simon Inglis's excellent Football Grounds of Great Britain, "the most unusual addition to Pittodrie came in the 1920s. Apparently the Dons trainer, Donald Colman, was a boxing and dancing enthusiast obsessed with his players' footwork. Because he also made meticulous notes during games, he needed a dry notebook. Thus he had built a sunken, covered area by the touchline, soon termed 'the dug-out.' A few years later Everton visited, liked the idea and built one at Goodison, and it was not long before every ground had to have one."

How many opposition players have scored hat-tricks at Old Trafford? And who were they? asked Marc Beauge last week.

So far the roll of honour stands at three. Stephen Martin is one of many who remembers Dennis Bailey's brilliant hat-trick during QPR's 4-1 New Year's Day demolition of United in 1992. (And apparently he's still banging them in for Forest Green.)

Another player to accomplish the feat is Kevin Mabbutt, who John Scotchmer says scored a hat-trick at Old Trafford for Bristol City when they were in the old First Division (late 70s to early 80s).

But surely no-one else has managed to match Martin Peters, who, as Jez Simmonds points out, once bagged all four goals as Tottenham walloped United 4-1 at Old Trafford early in 1973.

How many trophies have Spurs won when the year has ended in 'one'. Is this a coincidence and is it likely to be repeated next season? writes Alan Sheridan

For once Cockney musical jesters Chas 'n' Dave are spot on - because Spurs really do win the Cup (and the League for that matter) when the year ends in one.

Out of the 13 trophies they've won, a whopping eight have occurred in the second year of the decade. Just for the record, Spurs were league champions in 1951 and 1961, FA Cup winners in 1901, 1921, 1961, 1981 and 1991 and the League Cup in 1971.

As for the probability of it happening again next season - any mathematicians out there?

Do you know why the nutmeg manoeuvre is so called, and if so, who coined the term? enquired Paul Stearn.

"According to none other than popular Sky pundit and former Fulham favourite Jimmy Hill, the expression nutmeg is little more than dodgy rhyming slang," writes Jez Simmonds.

"Nutmeg equals leg, apparently, and was thus coined during the 1940s to describe the skill of placing the ball between an opponent's legs before retrieving it t'other side.

"Although I wasn't hugely convinced by this explanation, Jimmy generally knows his stuff - and, like me, is a Balham SW12 boy."

Well that's settled it then. Anyone know different?

I would be interested to know how many teams, if any, have the chance to become the first to win the FA Cup in three different centuries? I know Sheffield United are one of them but I am not sure of any others or if Chelsea won in the 1800s enquires Robert Ansell.

There are eight teams still in with a chance of accomplishing the feat. They are Blackburn (who've won the FA Cup in 1884, 1885, 1886, 1890, 1891 and in 1928), Aston Villa (1887, 1895, 1897 and 1905, 1913, 1920, 1957), West Bromich Albion (1888, 1892 and 1931, 1954, 1968), Preston North End (1889 and 1938), Wolves (1893 and 1908, 1949, 1960), Sheffield Wednesday (1896 and 1907, 1935), Nottingham Forest (1898 and 1959) and Sheffield United (1899 and 1902, 1915, 1925).

Chelsea didn't win their first FA Cup until 1970.

Can you help?

Bradford City have been on a constant accent in terms of league position for the past five years, having gone seven years with an upward tend in the 1980s. What is the record for the greatest number of seasons finishing higher in the league than the previous year? wonders Michael Wood

I'm having an argument with someone at work and it's come down to a tenner, but neither of us can get proof. It could come to blows soon. What formation(s) did Terry Venables use for the England Team in Euro 96? wonders Kim Ulrich.

After hours of heated debate my friends and I are still in disagreement on this one. Who was the first East German to represent the unified team? I think it may be Thomas Doll but a lot of people tell me that it's Sammer and others have been mentioned. Can anyone help? asks Martin Widdicks.

Send your answers to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to answer them.

webTitle: 7 June: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: 7 June: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.standfirst: Not even Battlefield Earth is as bad as Honest, former Disney boss launches Revolution, big screen stardom for Britney Spears, and on the casting couch Jason Lee and DMX
fields.trailText: Not even Battlefield Earth is as bad as Honest, former Disney boss launches Revolution, big screen stardom for Britney Spears, and on the casting couch Jason Lee and DMX
fields.body:
 In the battle of the film flops, the universally panned Battlefield Earth has still not done as badly as the All Saints mega-flop Honest. The sci-fi flick, based on the book by Scientology guru L Ron Hubbard, has been dubbed "the worst film of this century" and took just £207,832 during its opening weekend in the UK. However, it still outshone the Honest, which took just £111,309 and was dropped by many cinemas when it took only £500 per screen in its first three days.

 Joe Roth, former chairman of Walt Disney Studios, finally unveiled his long-awaited plans for a new movie and internet company yesterday. Revolution Studios, to be backed by $3bn from Fox Entertainment, Sony Pictures and TV content provider Starz Encore, will make six movies a year over a six-year period. It will combine big blockbusters such as the forthcoming Pearl Harbor with smaller low-budget films, such as the recent comedy Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo. Revolution already has 25 movies in development and deals with major stars like Julia Roberts and Adam Sandler. Roth has called Revolution "a dream come true". Along with film-making, Revolution will focus on internet content via its media division.

 Teen singing sensation Britney Spears is preparing for a film career. The virginal princess of pop, who was recently offered over $7m to give up her virginity to a mystery businessman, has signed with the agency Endeavor who will represent her film and TV projects, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

Casting news

 Jason Lee has been cast in Barry Sonnenfeld's ensemble comedy Big Trouble, based on the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by Dave Barry. The film also stars Tim Allen, Rene Russo and Katie Holmes in a story about a group of people whose lives are interrupted when a nuclear device inside a suitcase is rigged to go off in a Miami airport.

 US rapper DMX has been lined up to star opposite Steven Seagal in the forthcoming feature Exit Wounds. The singer, who made his film debut in Hype Williams' Belly, is up for "a very big role", according to Exit Wounds producer Joel (The Matrix) Silver.

fields.headline: Interest rates remain at 6%
fields.standfirst: More about house prices
fields.trailText: More about house prices
fields.body:
The Bank of England has left interest rates unchanged at 6% for the fourth month in succession.

The decision, widely expected by City analysts, comes amid signs that the pace of economic growth is slowing, underlined by official figures today showing another fall in manufacturing output.

Manufacturing output fell 0.2% in April, with a 12.5% slump in car production, the worst performance in over a decade, according to the Office for National Statistics.

Manufacturing output has fallen for four of the last five months and is just 1.6% higher than a year ago. The overall trend for both manufacturing and industrial production remains weak, with annual rises running at only around 0.5%.

While manufacturing accounts for less than a quarter of Britain's economic output, many service industries depend upon thriving factory activity.

Previously the Bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) has refrained from raising rates because of concerns that the strength of sterling was making it difficult for exporters to compete in overseas markets.

Despite the pound's recent slide on the foreign exchanges, analysts believe it has not fallen far enough for the Bank to start putting up rates.

Instead they believe the Bank is more likely to be concerned about unexpectedly weak figures for gross domestic product in the first three months of the year and a recent CBI survey suggesting that manufacturers remain pessimistic.

Recent evidence has also suggested that the booming housing market in south east England may finally be cooling, strengthening the case for the MPC not to put up rates.

Britain's borrowing costs are well above the 3.75% level set by the European Central Bank for euro zone countries. They are also high in real terms, as inflation is running at just 1.9%, well below a government target of 2.5%.

While manufacturing accounts for less than a quarter of Britain's economic output, many service industries depend upon thriving factory activity. Previously the Bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) has refrained from raising rates because of concerns that the strength of sterling was making it difficult for exporters to compete in overseas markets. Despite the pound's recent slide on the foreign exchanges, analysts believe it has not fallen far enough for the Bank to start putting up rates. Instead they believe the Bank is more likely to be concerned about unexpectedly weak figures for gross domestic product in the first three months of the year and a recent CBI survey suggesting that manufacturers remain pessimistic. Recent evidence has also suggested that the booming housing market in south east England may finally be cooling, strengthening the case for the MPC not to put up rates. Britain's borrowing costs are well above the 3.75% level set by the European Central Bank for euro zone countries. They are also high in real terms, as inflation is running at just 1.9%, well below a government target of 2.5%.

fields.headline: Net movie makes distribution history
fields.trailText: Film distribution history was made yesterday when 20th Century Fox became the first distributor to send a movie over the internet from one side of the US to an audience on the other side. The new animated sci-fi blockbuster, Titan AE, was sent from a studio in Burbank, California, to an audience at the Supercomm trade show in Atlanta.
fields.body:
Film distribution history was made yesterday when 20th Century Fox became the first distributor to send a movie over the internet from one side of the US to an audience on the other side. The new animated sci-fi blockbuster, Titan AE, was sent from a studio in Burbank, California, to an audience at the Supercomm trade show in Atlanta.

Although a number of films, including Star Wars Episode 1 - The Phantom Menace, have been digitally projected by cinemas, this is a landmark in movie disbribution as it is the first time a film has been distributed digitally.

It also showcased the new technology that could replace the traditional analogue distribution systems that date back 80 years. "It's a small step toward looking at the future," said Tom Sherak, chairman of the Fox domestic film group. "It's a one-time test to show it can be done and see if we can move forward."

He admits however that it could take years before it becomes common place, with issues such as cost and copyright protection still unresolved.

The film will be shown using a digital projector and a specially made screen and sound system - but only after it has been fully downloaded, which should take around four hours.

The 90-minute film, set 1,000 years in the future, features the voices of Matt Damon and Drew Barrymore as teenagers trying to save mankind after an alien attack. It goes on general release in the US on 16 June, and in the UK on 28 July.

 Read a first review of the film on Ain't It Cool News.

webTitle: More asylum seekers to be deported

fields.headline: More asylum seekers to be deported
fields.trailText:
The immigration service is to deport tens of thousands more asylum seekers as the number of people claiming refuge in Britain and being held in detention centres quadruples.
Special report
fields.body:
The immigration service confirmed last night it is to deport tens of thousands more asylum seekers as the number of people claiming refuge in Britain and being held in detention centres quadruples.

Almost a third of those who are refused asylum in Britain are vanishing in an attempt to stay in the country, according to Home Office figures. Of the 10,685 asylum seekers refused permission to stay last year, 7,645 people left voluntarily or were deported, leaving 3,040 missing, according to official figures.

Ian Boon, the immigration service's director of enforcement, said last night that officials aim to increase the number of deportations from 9,000 last year to 12,000 this year, rising to 30,000 in 2001-2 and eventually to 57,000 each year.

A Home Office spokesman confirmed it intends to tighten the system. The move reflects the government's anxiety not to be seen as a "soft touch" on asylum seekers.

"It is important to the integrity of the asylum system that while we speed up the decision-making process it is clear to people whose claims are proved to be unfounded that they are very likely to be removed at the end of that process," the spokesman said.

The number of asylum seekers held in detention centres - a policy espoused by the Conservative party - will increase from 900 to 2,700 over the next year, with the building of new detention centres at Thurleigh, Bedfordshire, and Manston, Kent. Eventually 4,000 asylum seekers will be held while their applications are processed.

The 100,000-case backlog in decision-making on asylum has been cut in recent months, with an increasing proportion of applicants turned down.

fields.headline: Copycat coup
fields.standfirst: Now it is the turn of the Solomon Islands
fields.trailText: The coup attempts and resulting violence in Fiji and the Solomon Islands are, in a broad sense, a product of the colonial era dislocations which still bedevil a large swath of Far East and Pacific territories once ruled by 19th-century Europe's great powers and, in the case of the Philippines, by the United States.
fields.body:
The coup attempts and resulting violence in Fiji and the Solomon Islands are, in a broad sense, a product of the colonial era dislocations which still bedevil a large swath of Far East and Pacific territories once ruled by 19th-century Europe's great powers and, in the case of the Philippines, by the United States. A generation or two after most of these countries obtained independence within often arbitrary, oddly defined borders, the present instability is attributable to many different causes. Some see religion at the root. In Aceh, a northern province of Indonesia, and in the Moluccas, pressure for East Timor-style independence has conflated with confessional tensions. Mindanao, in the southern Philippines, is the scene of a lengthy conflict between Muslim rebels and the Catholic majority which dominates in Manila.

Some say an as yet unformed, elusive national identity lies at the heart of the matter. In Papua (formerly Netherlands New Guinea, then West Irian, then Irian Jaya, and not to be confused with the old German Kaiser-Wilhelmsland or British Guinea), Jakarta's distant embrace is questioned, and no wonder: by any measure, the Javanese association is as confusing as those which preceded it. In Bougainville, an island situated beyond the portentously named Bismarck archipelago, disaffection produced a vicious separatist war with Papua New Guinea in the 90s. This again was an echo of that vainly waged by the Kanaks of New Caledonia against fly François Mitterrand and other heirs to Napoleonic ambition.

Yet others, nearer the mark, believe the common cause of this widespread instability is economic deprivation. The crisis in the Solomons (formerly run in turn by the British, Germans and Japanese) is microcosmic, even by nearby Micronesian standards. But in pitching the inhabitants of Malaita against those of Guadalcanal in a battle for jobs and pre-eminence, it mirrors Fiji's ethnic confrontation. Peaceful, political solutions are rightly sought to the challenges posed by Andrew Nori and George Speight; but the unifying problem is poverty, neglect and outside meddling. After centuries of imperial power games, Europe's nations have a particular responsibility of redress. Punitive sanctions are no answer for such peoples, washed up at the edge of our world. The flotsam of our lost empires, of our dog-eared, Maughamian dreams, they are the ultimate victims of our vainglory.

fields.headline: MEPs trapped on coup island
fields.standfirst: Airport closed as rival militias clash near Solomon Islands capital
fields.trailText: Airport closed as rival militias clash near Solomon Islands capital
fields.body:
Glenys Kinnock and a fellow member of the European Parliament, John Corrie, were yesterday trapped in a hotel less than a mile from fighting between rival ethnic militias on the Solomon Islands, as the chaos from Fiji continued to sweep through the region.

Fighting involving more than 1,000 people wielding home-made guns, spears and axes erupted around the airport, stranding the MEPs on the final day of a week-long fact-finding mission. Three people were taken to hospital with minor injuries.

Mrs Kinnock, sheltering with other Europeans in a hotel in the capital Honiara, said yesterday that the situation was becoming tense. "The airport is closed. We have no option of going anywhere at all except our hotel. Maybe reality will set in. The rival ethnic leaders appear to be talking, but it's very difficult to rein them in, because nobody knows to whom they are answerable."

In Brussels, Nicole Fontaine, the European Parliament's president urged island authorities to guarantee the safety of the two members of parliament. And a spokesman for the EU's executive commission said: "This action and the taking into custody of the prime minister represents a grave threat to democracy in the Solomon Islands."

Mrs Kinnock said law and order had largely broken down on the Pacific Island state. There is no army or reliable police force and the armoury, a repository of weapons left by the US army after the second world war, has been raided by the militias.

To her surprise, she found herself being used as an interlocutor between the rival groups, the Malaita Eagles and the Isatabu Freedom Movement and the captured prime minister.

Mrs Kinnock was allowed access to the ousted prime minister, Bartholomew Ulufa'alu, who has been held incommunicado under house ar rest since the coup on Monday.

"We were surprised when they delivered him to our door. Rambo-style gunmen, touting huge world war two guns took him to our hotel, stayed outside the room while we talked to him, and then took him back to his house," Mrs Kinnock said.

The wife of the former Labour leader said that Mr Ulufa'alu offered to resign as the price for peace on the Solomon Islands. He still hoped that this could be done constitutionally. Later, one of his government ministers, minister of state Alfred Sasako, said that this could be done by convening a meeting of parliament.

Mr Sasako said Mr Ulufa'alu had reached an agreement with the leader of the one of the militias that par liament would meet on June 16 and he would resign, possibly after a vote of no confidence and a secret ballot to choose a new leader.

The ethnic dispute between the residents of the main island of Guadalcanal and Malaitans has simmered since the second world war. In the past 18 months 60 people have been killed.

The EU is waving a big financial stick at the rival factions. The commission yesterday ruled out an immediate suspension of a $62m (£37m) annual aid package, but it would review it unless democracy was restored. Up to one quarter of the islands' economy depends on the package.

In a statement, the MEPs said: "The country is already facing economic collapse. In our dealing with the main players in this crisis, we have made it absolutely clear that the international community will not tolerate the use of force against a democratically elected government.

"Our strong view at this time is that the legitimate government of the islands needs support. The prospect of civil war is real."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: A bumper crop of transfer rumours, harvested, exported and seized by customs
fields.trailText: Nick Barmby has rejected a £25,000-a-week contract offer from Everton. The Sun believes that the England midfielder has "put himself in the Euro 2000 shop window", while the Daily Mail believes Sunderland, Celtic, Coventry and Celta Vigo would be keen to snap up the 26-year-old when his contract runs out next summer.
fields.body:
Nick Barmby has rejected a £25,000-a-week contract offer from Everton. The Sun believes that the England midfielder has "put himself in the Euro 2000 shop window", while the Daily Mail believes Sunderland, Celtic, Coventry and Celta Vigo would be keen to snap up the 26-year-old when his contract runs out next summer.

Aston Villa are to move for Turkish superstar Hakan Sukur, who is surprisingly available for transfer under the Bosman ruling. The Sun believes that John Gregory was ready to pay £5m for Sukur before he realised the striker's contract had run out. They quote Sukur as saying: "I want to further my career playing abroad and England would be my first choice."

Planet Football expects Christian Karembeu to sign for Middlesbrough, after he turned down a late attempt from Arsenal to sign him as a replacement for Lee Dixon. "My true place is in midfield," he told the site. "Now I have a great chance to play in the Premier League."

Planet Football also suggests that Juninho could be set to leave the Riverside after he confessed an interest in joining Benfica. "If an interest from Benfica really does exist then the only thing I can say is that Benfica is a great club, where any player would like to play. Everything is possible, I have to talk and I am available to do this. It is a hypothesis that pleases me," the Brazilian was quoted as saying, rather long-windedly.

Liverpool are on the verge of signing French international Bernard Diomede in a £2m deal, according to the Mirror. The paper believes that the 24-year-old winger will arrive on Merseyside today.

Didier Domi has confessed that he is tempted by a return to his native France. "Newcastle has been a good experience for me," the Daily Star quote him as saying, "but I would love to go back to France." The young full-back is tipped to return to his former club Paris St Germain.

If The Sun is to be believed, Newcastle could use some of the money from Domi's sale to further strengthen his strikeforce. The paper reports that Bobby Robson is hopeful of signing Atletico Madrid Spanish international forward Kiko for £5m.

The Mirror also suggests that Craig Hignett will become George Burley's first Premiership signing for Ipswich. The talented midfielder would only cost £1m from Barnsley.

The Daily Star reports that Chelsea will not allow Gianfranco Zola to leave the club for anything less than £3m. The diminutive Italian is expected to join Napoli this summer.

webTitle: Jonathan Tulloch wins lucrative Betty Trask Prize

fields.headline: Jonathan Tulloch wins lucrative Betty Trask Prize
fields.trailText: After all the excitement of last night's Orange Prize, the literary world has hardly had time to draw breath before the announcement of another eight prizes
fields.body:
After all the excitement of last night's Orange Prize, the literary world has hardly had time to draw breath before the announcement of another eight prizes. Awards worth over £80,000 have been given out tonight by the Society of Authors at London's Kensington Roof Gardens. Unlike the better-known Orange and Booker prizes, there is no single winner and it seems that almost everyone nominated has come away with something.

The Betty Trask prize was the most lucrative of the fiction prizes. Given to a first-time novelist under 35 who writes in a 'romantic or traditional, but not experimental, style', Jonathan Tulloch won the top prize and £10,000 for The Season Ticket (Jonathan Cape). Called 'a Kes for our times' it is a story of two unemployed friends whose sole purpose in life is to raise enough money to buy season tickets for Newcastle United. Read a review

In addition, three other authors were presented with Betty Trask awards. The largest award went to Australian-born Julia Leigh who won £7,000 for her novel The Hunter. Picked by the Observer as a writer to look out for in the new millennium, Leigh also appeared on the long list for the Orange Prize. The Hunter tells the tale of M, who arrives in an isolated community in the Tasmanian wilderness determined to track down and kill the Thylacine, the last-remaining Tasmanian tiger. Read a review

Susan Elderkin, a graduate of Malcolm Bradbury's highly successful MA in Creative Writing at the University of East Anglia, received £4,000 for her tale of a father and daughter's decision to leave London to start a new life, Sunset Over Chocolate Mountains (Fourth Estate). Read a review

Awards of £2,000 were also given to Nicholas Griffin for The Requiem Shark (Little Brown), and to Galaxy Craze for By the Shore (Jonathan Cape), a touching and perceptive novel of bohemian family life seen through the eyes of a bright but stroppy 12-year-old, which was longlisted for the Guardian First Book Award. Read a review of By the Shore

The Somerset Maugham Awards for writers under 35 have gone to Bella Bathurst's The Lighthouse Stevensons (HarperCollins) - a history of Robert Louis Stevenson's family, which was also shortlisted for last year's Guardian First Book Award - and to Sarah Waters's story of spiritualism and seduction in Victorian London, Affinity (Virago). Read a review of The Lighthouse Stevensons

The big money in terms of poetry lay with the Eric Gregory Award for poets under 30. This was awarded to Eleanor Margolies and Antony Rowland, who each received £6,000. The Cholmondeley Awards of £2,000 each (given in recognition of a poet's whole body of writing) were awarded to Alistair Elliot, Michael Hamburger, Adrian Henri and Carole Satyamurti.

webTitle: Return of the Pretty Woman? Maybe

fields.headline: Return of the Pretty Woman? Maybe
fields.trailText: It was one of the most successful films of the decade. It made Julia Roberts an international star. Its fairy-tale plot bore almost no relation to reality. And it's just the kind of movie Hollywood loves. So the only surprising element of news that plans are afoot to make a sequel to Pretty Woman is that it has taken 10 years.
fields.body:
It was one of the most successful films of the decade. It made Julia Roberts an international star. Its fairy-tale plot bore almost no relation to reality. And it's just the kind of movie Hollywood loves. So the only surprising element of news that plans are afoot to make a sequel to Pretty Woman is that it has taken 10 years.

Syndicated US columnist Liz Smith reported yesterday that the stars of the original - Roberts and Richard Gere - and its original director Garry Marshall have indicated that they are interested in a sequel.

But, reports Smith, the obscenely large budget that would be needed to reunite the trio is something of a stumbling block.

Roberts is now Hollywood's highest paid actress, with an asking price of $20m. Gere apparently wants the same (surely some mistake?). Marshall would need $10m plus 2% of the gross to helm Pretty Woman 2. That's $50m just to kick-start the production.

Still, there may be some cash flow in a repeat performance. Pretty Woman made more than $178m back in 1990, and Julia Roberts' latest movie, Erin Brockovich, had grossed over $122m to date.

However, what seems to have escaped the attention of Pretty Woman 2's backers is that Marshall, Roberts and Gere reunited only last year for the making of Runaway Bride - which set neither the critics or the box office alight. Enough said.

fields.headline: Myers ditches Dieter
fields.trailText: Mike Myers has been issued with a breach of contract lawsuit after allegedly walking out of his latest film. The Austin Powers star is being sued by Universal Pictures who claim he abandoned the big-screen version of Dieter, a film based on the antics of one of the comic characters he created for cult American series Saturday Night Live.
fields.body:
Mike Myers has been issued with a breach of contract lawsuit after allegedly walking out of his latest film. The Austin Powers star is being sued by Universal Pictures who claim he abandoned the big-screen version of Dieter, a film based on the antics of one of the comic characters he created for cult American series Saturday Night Live.

Myers has hit back, blaming an "unworkable script", reports E! Online.

Myers, who was set to earn around $20m from the film, said in a statement: "I cannot in good conscience accept $20m and cheat movie-goers who pay their hard-earned money to see my work by making a movie with an unacceptable script."

The lawsuit has banned the Canadian-born actor from working on any further projects until he completes Dieter and also demands he foot the legal bill and compensate the studio for the £2.5m pre-production costs. They claim he walked away from the project on May 30.

webTitle: Economics of truth MPs attack rewriting of wartime history for box office gain

fields.headline: Economics of truth MPs attack rewriting of wartime history for box office gain
fields.trailText: A Hollywood film which swaps British sailors for Americans in portraying the real-life wartime capture of the German Enigma coding device was yesterday attacked by MPs as a distortion of the truth for financial gain.
fields.body:
A Hollywood film which swaps British sailors for Americans in portraying the real-life wartime capture of the German Enigma coding device was yesterday attacked by MPs as a distortion of the truth for financial gain.

U-571, which opened in Britain last week, tells how the US Navy recovered the Enigma Nazi code machine, changing the course of the second world war.

In reality the device was captured by the crew of the British destroyer HMS Bulldog, who disabled and seized German submarine U-110 and then risked their lives to retrieve the machine.

In a Commons motion, MPs led by the Labour MP for Chorley, Lindsay Hoyle, expressed regret about the film, which they said had "detracted from the valour of the British sailors concerned".

The men, who were later decorated for their heroism, had "risked their lives to board the stricken submarine, facing the danger that it might sink at any time", the MPs said.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, has said it was "a little galling" that the Hollywood film portrayed British wartime actions being conducted by the Americans.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: The veteran Romanian midfielder Gheorghe Hagi is set to swap the midfield for the dugout at the Uefa Cup winners Galatasaray next season.
fields.body:
The veteran Romanian midfielder Gheorghe Hagi is set to swap the midfield for the dugout at the Uefa Cup winners Galatasaray next season.

According to his agent Ioan Becali, the 35-year-old is in negotiations with the Turkish champions, whose current manager Fatih Terim is leaving for Fiorentina. Hagi, who joined the Istanbul club in 1996, may be installed as coach next week. "Everything is possible," he said.

 The Spanish striker Raul is struggling to be fit for his side's first game against Norway having failed to recover from a thigh strain.

The 22-year-old Real Madrid attacker has been carrying the injury since last month's Champions League final and had been expected to play against Luxembourg in tonight's final warm-up match. "He's still not 100% but in two or three days he should be fine," said Spain's coach Jose Camacho.

 German officials have outlined measures to combat hooligans planning to cause trouble at the tournament. They have implemented travel bans on 60 known troublemakers and will require 40 others to check in with police during games.

"If necessary we'll lock the troublemakers up," said the chairman of the state conference of interior ministers, Fritz Behrens. "The police have enough cells and whoever doesn't obey this ban will be prosecuted."

 The Italian prime minister Giuliano Amato wished the Azzurri luck yesterday as Dino Zoff's side set off for the Low Countries. "I've heard that when you start in pole position you're cursed," he said. "Well you won't be, since you're not."

 Chelsea's Jes Hogh is a major doubt for Denmark's opening fixture against France on Sunday having suffered an Achilles injury in training. And Holland's Sander Westerveld is suffering from an ankle problem. "It really needs rest so all the blood can get out of it, but Euro 2000 makes that impossible," said the Liverpool player.

 The Yugoslav defender Nisa Saveljic has been released by police in Belgrade after he was questioned about allegedly failing to perform his obligatory one-year military service.

The 30-year-old, who plays for Bordeaux, claimed he had been treated "like a common criminal. I have never felt more humiliated in all my life. I am not a criminal but a professional soccer player."

 The Scottish referee Hugh Dallas has pledged to let the players rather than the officials take the limelight at the tournament. "Hopefully it will be a low-key approach from the referees," said Dallas, one of the 12 officials in the tournament. "But the referees won't be any tougher than they normally are at this level."

 Germany's Lothar Matthäus will win his 147th cap against Liechtenstein in Freiburg tonight having recovered from a thigh strain. Erich Ribbeck welcomes back Jens Jeremies to his midfield, and Oliver Bierhoff will start on the substitutes' bench.

 The former Nottingham Forest striker Pierre van Hooijdonk is set to move from Vitesse Arnhem to PSV Eindhoven after the tournament. The 30-year-old is seen as a replacement for the Aston Villa-bound Luc Nilis.

webTitle: Major mocks 'seditious' calls to quit EU

fields.headline: Major mocks 'seditious' calls to quit EU
fields.trailText: John Major last night edged towards support of British membership of the European single currency with a speech which mocked as "more seditious than seductive" the Thatcherite plan to leave the EU and join the US trade bloc, Nafta.
fields.body:
John Major last night edged towards support of British membership of the European single currency with a speech which mocked as "more seditious than seductive" the Thatcherite plan to leave the EU and join the US trade bloc, Nafta.

The former prime minister, whose post-1992 government was riven by conflict over Europe, avoided the temptation to personalise his remarks as criticism of William Hague. Instead he called for "a sensible debate, an informed debate, that can acknowledge differing views with the respect that they deserve, a debate that looks at opportunities as well as threats".

Such even-handed language will be recognised by Hague allies and Euro-sceptics for what it is, a coded attack on their style of debate.

Mr Major came as close as a self-styled "reluctant European" could to saying that the euro is Britain's ultimate des tiny, an option he sidestepped in office. In a speech in London Mr Major rejected isolationism and what he called "the concept of wicked foreigners out to do us down". But he conceded that entering the euro - or not - is now central to the future European debate.

"Be in no doubt about the importance of this new giant. Forget for the moment its current difficulties.

"The new currency is far bigger than the pound or the yen. It is big enough in time to rival the dollar. It has huge gold re serves to back it. It will end exchange risks in Europe," he warned.

He went on to agree that membership of the eurozone will exact a price: it would bring about more centralisation of policy making and would bring pressure for more tax harmonisation, for more communal law and regulations, more standardisation.

"The single currency crossed a rubicon. It is a giant step and Europe will never be the same again - although I do not myself see the formation of a single European superstate that is the nightmare of some," Mr Major declared. He called himself : "No visionary, no romantic convert, no idealist, in some ways, a reluctant, but certainly a convinced European. I believe a strong EU is in the interest of my children and their children."

"Some convinced Europeans - and here I number myself - feel such a tug to our present way of doing things that they would only go in when and if it becomes undoubted that we will be economically damaged if we do not. And we might be - though that is not yet proven."

 Black and Asian Britons will get the same protection against racial discrimination they have in Britain when they travel, work or study in the rest of Europe under a directive agreed in Luxembourg yesterday. Mike O'Brien, the Home Office minister, and Tessa Jowell, the employment minister, signed up to the directive at a meeting in Luxembourg, where it was agreed by all 15 EU member states.

fields.headline: Disgraced surgeon faces new inquiry
fields.trailText: Disgraced former surgeon Rodney Ledward is facing a fresh inquiry into his conduct, this time by The Royal Pharmaceutical Society, after it was reported that he has been working as a pharmacist in Ireland.
fields.body:
Disgraced former surgeon Rodney Ledward is facing a fresh inquiry into his conduct, this time by The Royal Pharmaceutical Society, after it was reported that he has been working as a pharmacist in Ireland.

The RPS said it would need to examine the case of the former gynaecologist, who was struck off in 1998 after being found guilty of botching numerous operations on women and abandoning patients.

The RPS said it had contacted the Department of Health "to seek access to the enquiry report concerning the case of Rodney Ledward. The society will want to consider what bearing his previous conduct as a surgeon, and the findings of this report, have on his registration as a pharmacist in Great Britain."

Under European Union freedom of movement legislation Ledward is free to work as a chemist in any EU country as long his RPS certificate is in order. He registered as a pharmacist in 1960, the year after qualifying from Manchester University.

Last year he was given a "good standing certificate" by the RPS which would entitle him to work in Ireland.

Speaking from his new home in Mallow, Co Cork, Ledward, 62, who denies that he has done anything wrong, said: "I am a registered pharmacist here and in Britain and I've no problem finding work if I want it."

Ann McGee, the Pharmaceutical Society of Ireland's registrar said: "The society is naturally very concerned about the situation but is quite powerless to act."

Despite the ruling against him and the complaints of hundreds of women who have come forward since he was struck off, Ledward has had no complaints made about his work as a chemist.

"The case proven against Dr Ledward related to his acts as a gynaecologist and specifically as a surgeon and that is quite distinct from his ability to act as a pharmaceutical chemist," Ms McGee said.

A shortage of pharmacists in Ireland means Ledward would not struggle to find work as a locum chemist there. He is unlikely to work in Britain because he has no recent experience here.

"We are not aware of Mr Ledward having recently practised as a pharmacist in Great Britain - serious issues would arise if he did," the RPS statement said, referring to Ledward's lack of recent training or experience.

After a year-long inquiry the report into the Ledward affair, which was published last week, detailed horrific accounts of women left maimed, scarred and emotionally damaged while he was working as a gynaecologist.

The independent inquiry, headed by Jean Ritchie QC, also exposed a climate of fear and intimidation in the NHS where consultants were considered "gods" and managers ignored the concerns of other doctors.

Compensation for all of Ledward's victims could reach £1.2m, which would be a record amount against an individual surgeon.

webTitle: One dead, 25 hurt in coach crash

fields.headline: One dead, 25 hurt in coach crash
fields.trailText: One person was killed and 25 were injured, one seriously, when a passenger coach collided with a car near Newmarket, Suffolk, last night.
fields.body:
One person was killed and 25 were injured, one seriously, when a passenger coach collided with a car near Newmarket, Suffolk, last night.

Several people were cut from the wreckage by firefighters after the crash on the B1506 road at Kentford. The injured were taken to hospitals in Cambridge and Bury St Edmunds.

The National Express coach, which had 27 passengers and was travelling towards the A14 dual carriageway, left the road after the collision and hit a tree shortly after 8pm last night. The dead man was the driver of the coach, which was travelling from London to Great Yarmouth.

Suffolk police spokesman Simon Stevens said: "A car was involved in the accident and the coach ended up hitting a tree. We believe most of the passengers have minor injuries - cuts and bruises rather than broken bones."

webTitle: The best rehearsal scene: The girl on the bridge

fields.headline: The best rehearsal scene: The girl on the bridge
fields.trailText: Intinerant knife-thrower Gabor (Daniel Auteuil) has talked his way onto a line-up of circus acts, but only by promising that he throws "blind".
fields.body:
Intinerant knife-thrower Gabor (Daniel Auteuil) has talked his way onto a line-up of circus acts, but only by promising that he throws "blind".

Unfortunately, he has neglected to inform his assistant, Adele (Vanessa Paradis). As Gabor stands in a corridor talking to another of the acts, a woman of around his own age, Adele confronts him.

"Excuse me, but what does 'blind' mean?"

"It means", explains Gabor without so much as a pause, "we'll wow them."

Cut to the pair rehearsing, with Adele strapped to her board.

"Shoulders out", Gabor tells her. "Chin up."

"Was that your wife?"

"Feet apart."

"Did you bring her luck?"

"No, I caught her. She was Miss Cannonball. She flew a hundred yards. She fell on me - I saved her life."

"Like me. You save everybody."

Gabor scowls."Not like you."

"So, blind", exclaims Adele. "Do you shut your eyes?"

"Stand straight", instructs Gabor, trying to ignore her. "Breathe deep. Leave the rest to me."

"You've done it before."

"Not completely. I lacked the right target. You."

See also: The Producers, Funny Bones, Waiting For Guffman

Don't see also: Fame

Pointless trivia: Daniel Auteuil has a daughter with Emmanuelle Beart, whom he met while working with her on the 1985 romantic comedy L'Amour en douce.

webTitle: College failure deals new blow to fresh start policy

fields.headline: College failure deals new blow to fresh start policy
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's drive to revive failing schools received another blow last night when inspectors ordered emergency rescue measures at one of its fresh start schools.
fields.body:
The government's drive to revive failing schools received another blow last night when inspectors ordered emergency rescue measures at one of its fresh start schools.

East Brighton arts and media college is the first fresh start school to be taken back into "special measures". It is looking for a permanent head following the resignation of "superhead" Tony Garwood in March. In its report, published last night, Ofsted criticised Mr Garwood's leadership.

The Department for Education defended its fresh start policy and put the blame in Mr Garwood's court.

"There was a problem with leadership at the school and we are trying to resolve that following the departure of the head. This was more a failure of management within the school than of our fresh start policy," a spokesman said.

In its report on East Brighton, Ofsted said the school was "failing to give its pupils an acceptable standard of education". Pupils made satisfactory progress in only 18 of 31 lessons observed. Leadership was weak, attendance and punctuality poor and staff morale low.

"There is too much unsatisfactory teaching. Teaching was satisfactory or better in only two thirds of the lessons," the report said.

"There is a core of hard working teachers who provide sound and sometimes good lessons, but in many classes the teachers have low expectations, or have difficulties managing pupils' behaviour."

In the few months since the college opened, eight pupils have been excluded permanently and 47 temporarily. Mr Garwood preferred not to comment on the report, which he had not read in detail. "I think people need to focus on the future, on what is being done now," he said.

Under "special measures", Ofsted will visit the school every term and the school and LEA will follow a joint action plan.

Clive Frost, director of east Brighton's education action zone took over as acting principal on May 1. "There has been a lot of change for staff and students here, but there are many good things going on now," he said last night.

fields.headline: Search for new teachers widened
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is to cast its net wider in the search for new teachers in an attempt to exploit the increased job mobility which sees people switching careers several times during their working life.
fields.body:
The government is to cast its net wider in the search for new teachers in an attempt to exploit the increased job mobility which sees people switching careers several times during their working life.

Ralph Tabberer, chief executive of the teacher training agency, announced yesterday that it was looking to recruit teachers from among the 45% of the population who were saying they might consider entering the profession.

The first step was to study the reasons why people were deterred from teaching, he said.

The agency will also redouble its efforts to convert inquiries from prospective trainees into applications for places and then jobs. A record number of phone calls, more than 10,000 a week, have been logged by the agency since its latest advertising campaign.

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, said yesterday that more than 4,500 graduates, a 32% rise on this time last year, had applied to become teachers since plans for "training salaries" of £6,000 were announced in March in a £70m incentives package.

She said the system of performance-related pay being introduced in September, which would give good teachers the chance to earn up to £30,000, was also attracting more of the best graduates into teaching.

Mr Tabberer denied critics' claims that there was still a recruitment crisis: "Vacancy rates are running at less than 1%."

 A Labour-supporting businessman, Bryan Sanderson, was named yesterday as chairman of the learning and skills council, which will be at the heart of the government programme for those aged over 16.

Mr Sanderson, group managing director of BP Amoco and chief executive of BP Amoco Chemicals, will take up the part -time post in October, in charge of an annual £6bn budget.
