fields.headline: Being Liberal with the truth
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown is proud to be a liberal but rails against William Hague's attempts to lump him in with Tony Blair.
fields.trailText: Derek Brown is proud to be a liberal but rails against William Hague's attempts to lump him in with Tony Blair.
fields.body:
There is an interesting whiff of mania around William Hague these days, as he pursues the blue rinse vote of middle - or should that be little? - England.

Thrashing around for issues which will mark him out as less liberal than the illiberal Labour government, he has seized on the word 'liberal' itself as a term of abuse.

Nothing new in that of course. Like most ideas in contemporary British public life, it has been imported unaltered from America, where liberals are objects of vituperative rightwing, redneck scorn.

Liberals like high taxes and bureaucracy. They threaten individual freedom and undermine tradition. This conservative mantra has a powerful appeal in the USA, where government itself has ever been an object of suspicion.

In Britain, with its very different political tradition of venerating the established order, it is decidedly odd for a Conservative like Hague to attack what he calls a 'liberal elite'.

Elitism, for goodness sake, is what the Tories have been in the business of promoting for 300 years, ever since they evolved as the party of King and Church. As for the supposedly liberal establishment against which Hague feebly rails, there is nothing remotely liberal or Liberal about it.

Here I declare an interest: I am a card-carrying Liberal Democrat. I am very happy to be called a liberal, with or without a capital. But I don't care to be associated by Hague, or anyone else, with a governing clique which has proved less liberal than any other in my regrettably lengthy lifetime.

Indeed both big parties, having abandoned their own traditions, seem intent on a contest of illiberalism.

They both defend our rotten voting system and other clapped out institutions, they both use disgraceful language about asylum seekers and other immigrants, they both are scared witless of Europe, they both bang the law 'n' order drum, and they both have no time for freedom of information.

Most importantly of all, they are both in thrall to big business.

The Liberal Democrats, with their unfortunate instinct for caution and incremental change, may be tarred to some extent with the same brush.

But real liberals, or Liberals, have no truck with the squalid current order.

Real liberals believe in liberty.

In a truly liberal society, people would not just be free to make pots of money, which is our crabbed and narrow modern interpretation of freedom.

They would be free of want and ignorance and injustice.

Those who believe in such things should, on balance, be happy that Hague attacks them.

For as his own party disintegrates, and the ruling clique transforms itself, Animal Farm-like, into the new Tory establishment, there is at least a glimmer of opportunity for the reassertion of liberal values.

Among them is the far from radical notion that government should reflect the wishes of the electorate.

Another is that parties which aspire to govern, should believe in governing rather than handing over power to unaccountable financiers and corporate tycoons.

And yet another is a fundamental respect for human rights and the dignity of freedom from fear, exploitation, and inequality.

If that is liberalism, than I for one am for it. And if Hague is against it, he should tell us why in his next sound bite.

The Liberal International
Liberalism in America
Anti-liberalism in America

fields.headline: Nato got it right
fields.trailText: Today's Amnesty International report on the conduct of the war in Kosovo last year, makes a number of criticisms of Nato's conduct. The most important are that:
fields.body:
Today's Amnesty International report on the conduct of the war in Kosovo last year, makes a number of criticisms of Nato's conduct. The most important are that:

 Nato bombers flew too high to protect themselves and could not discriminate between bombing Serb civilians and bombing the Serb military;

 Nato did not abandon key bombing raids on passenger trains and refugee convoys when it realised the victims were civilians;

 The bomb attack on a television station - even one that was used for war propaganda purposes - was a war crime.

Yes. These are valid criticisms.

Amnesty International points out Nato's failures. Nato needs to acknowledge and explain, for example, its decision to fly at 15,000ft, making it impossible for pilots to see if they were targeting civilians. This policy helped bring the death toll among Serb civilians to between 1,000 and 1,500 - and that does not include the thousands of conscripted soldiers blasted by Nato's bombs.

But that does not mean that then history of the war has to be rewritten as a failure. The aim of Nato intervention was to bring the refugees home. That was a success. Perhaps the price was too high but the world has already paid a preposterous price for not standing up to the Serbia president, Slobodan Milosevic, eight years ago in Bosnia.

Nato belatedly reversed the consequences of a diplomatic disaster and brought hundreds of thousands of Kosovan Albanians home from the mountains. Milosevic's position is much weakened by the defeat and some analysts suggest that he may be gone in a year.

There are always, and there should always be detractors when it comes to war. It is always the weakest, the poorest and the innocent who suffer most. Among the anti-war voices raised over Kosovo were Harold Pinter's and John Pilger's. But I would like one of them to explain how else the world could have forced Milosevic to allow the Kosovans home? What do you do with a million and a half refugees banished by foot and by cattle trucks to the mountainside or into neighbouring countries that do not want them?

If the Kosovo issue had not been swept under the negotiating table in 1995 at Dayton, Ohio, it would have not descended into the hell it did last year. But equally, those who spent weeks at the Dayton air base trying to bring peace to Bosnia insist that to try and solve the problem at that moment would have meant an end to the peace talks for Bosnia.

Kosovo was a failure of diplomacy - war always is. Force appeared to be the only option - not just to bring the Kosovans home but for the world to finally say to Milosevic: "You can't go on destroying. If you do, you will be destroyed." As Amnesty has rightly pointed out, the use of that force was sometimes flawed.

The other stick that the detractors use to batter Nato is the suggestion that the whole basis for the war was fabricated.

It is true that the Kosovo Liberation Army provoked the Serb police and military, but dismissing the Kosovo repression as Serbia trying to control a few murderous paramilitaries is to ignore ten years growing tension and repression of in Kosovo. It was inevitable that after the years of repression, the Kosovans would eventually hit back - drawing Nato in as their final tactic and only strategy of for survival. Nato finally stood up to the Milosevic. The Kosovan people paid a terrible price for it in the backlash that followed the bombing - and the Serb people also paid dearly as Nato made sure its priorities were for its pilots to be safe and bombed civilians.

It is wrong of Nato to suggest the bombing did not unleash a new and much more ferocious attack on the people of Kosovo. It did, and those of us who spoke to the people left behind as the Serbs withdrew know that things got far worse when the bombing started.

But six months before Nato bombed, Serb paramilitaries had been in Kosovo organising the "cleansing" of Kosovan civilians from certain areas. Mr Milosevic was preparing to use the suppression of Kosovo as another desperate crutch to stay in power.

And finally, who created the Kosovo Liberation Army? It is like the Boston judge who was removed from the bench for asking a battered woman: "What did you do to make him beat you?"

Just months after the war, the revisionism began in earnest. The Spectator published a long article arguing that Nato propaganda exaggerated the numbed of dead to get the war going. The war crimes tribunal digging in Kosovo expects to find at least 5,500 bodies.

What is this brutal numbers game? Tell the mothers I interviewed in the coffee shop in Suva Reek, who had their children shot dead in front of them, that enough of their children were not dead. Does it take 10,000 to make a genocide charge stick? Does 5,500 not suffice?

The then-defence secretary, George Robertson, claimed that 100,000 people were missing. It is now clear that it was part of the military hype in the run-up to the bombing campaign. Nato was attempting to garner international public support for the military action. Yes, he was exaggerating. You could even call it lying - the sort of lying that involves stretching an unlikely possibility into fact.

He used the same tactics that General Colin Powell used to help build public support for the war against Iraq when he produced fake photographs of an Iraqi tank build-up poised to invade Saudi Arabia. These propaganda excesses should be curbed. But Nato's excessive spinning and cowardly tactics do not mean that its reasons to go to war should be dismissed.

As you read this, the Serb general Radislav Krstic is on trial in the Hague for the alleged murder of 7,000 Muslim men in a three-day massacre at Srebenica in July 95. So perhaps Robertson could be excused some creative rallying.

What puzzles me most is what drives our dissenters? Colleagues such as Robert Fisk of the Independent accuse the media of being mouthpieces for Nato. Yet they cannot answer the question of how else the "ethnic cleansing" was to be reversed. How else did the world finally stand up to Milosevic.

In the sixties the anti-war voices of Kosovo were anti-bomb and anti-imperialist; in the seventies they were anti-Vietnam and in the nineties and today they are anti-Nato. Is it a question of always having to shout at teacher? Always being the kid to stamp their feet in class?

Are they so insecure about their own journalistic identities that they have become knee-jerk anti-consensus voices, without even examining the consensus?

Sometimes, blasphemous as it might seem, to the Angry Young Men, governments can occasionally try to get things right. Britain and the rather grudgingly the U.S. did lead the stand against Milosevic. There were many things wrong with the way they chose to do it and too many Serbs suffered. But at least after 10 years of bullying he was finally taken on.

The press pastes governments for getting it wrong. We also have a duty for acknowledging when they try to get it right.

webTitle: MPs say Kosovo bombing was illegal but necessary

fields.headline: MPs say Kosovo bombing was illegal but necessary
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Nato's bombing of Kosovo last year was illegal under international law, the Labour-controlled foreign affairs select committee is expected to report today.
fields.body:
Nato's bombing of Kosovo last year was illegal under international law, the Labour-controlled foreign affairs select committee is expected to report today.

After an inquiry into the foreign policy implications of the Kosovo crisis, the select committee has concluded that Nato is a defensive alliance and has no powers under its treaty to conduct a humanitarian operations war without the specific authority of the United Nations.

Russia repeatedly promised to use its veto to prevent the UN backing military action.

After an inquiry lasting several months, the committee calls for the Nato treaty to be rewritten and a new code for humanitarian interventions.

The controversy over the proper legal basis for the bombing campaign was one of the many sources of tension with Russia. There were also reports during the conflict that the then attorney general, John Morris, questioned the legality of the bombing.

The report also queries whether the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, traditionally seen as one of great errors of the bombing campaign, was a genuine mistake.

The committee was given detailed evidence suggesting that the bombing of the embassy was not a great strategic blunder, but a deliberate move by the Amercians aimed at knocking out one of the telecommunications posts.

Critics have claimed the Chinese were passing intelligence to the Serbian regime about the direction of Nato's bombing campaign. Diane Abbott, a Labour MP on the committee, was persuaded the bombing was deliberate.

The overwhelming mass of academic evidence given to the committee ruled that the bombing of Kosovo was illegal under international law. Emyr Jones Parry, the Foreign Office political director, insisted the action was legal, but admitted in evidence to the committee that normally a country has one of three legal justifications for action - "one, United Nations Security Council resolution specifically authorising it; two, being invited in to do it; three, in self-defence. None of those actually pertained in this case".

The committee is under stood to have rejected a move by some Conservative MPs on the committee to suggest that the bombing campaign led to the mass ethnic cleansing inside Kosovo.

The members conclude that the Contact Group, led by the Americans, placed some unreal demands on the Serbians during the negotiations at Rambouillet, near Paris, including the requirement that Nato troops be allowed free movement inside Serbia.

Overall, the committee will conclude that even with hindsight it was necessary to undertake the bombing campaign, even if more could have been done to send serious signals earlier to Milsovic that any attempt to purify Kosovo would be met with a fierce bombing campaign.

The Foreign Office has estimated that the Serbs murdered as many as 10,000 Kosovans.

The US chapter of Amnesty International said yesterday that Nato forces had unlawfully killed civilians in Kosovo. It condemned one attack in which 16 people died as a war crime.

"Nato forces violated the laws of war leading to cases of unlawful killing of civilians," the human rights group said in a statement accompanying its 60-page report.

"Nato did not always meet its legal obligations in selecting targets and in choosing means and methods of attack."

Nato immediately released a statement saying the allegations were "baseless and ill-founded".

webTitle: Hain blasts Mugabe ahead of election

fields.headline: Hain blasts Mugabe ahead of election
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: With less than three weeks to Zimbabwe's crucial parliamentary elections, the British government launched an unprecedented attack on President Robert Mugabe, charging that he is determined to hold unfair elections and to ruin the country's economy.
fields.body:
With less than three weeks to Zimbabwe's crucial parliamentary elections, the British government launched an unprecedented attack on President Robert Mugabe, charging that he is determined to hold unfair elections and to ruin the country's economy.

"Neither Britain nor the international community can make this election fair. Only Robert Mugabe can do that, and he seems determined not to," the Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, said. "Neither Britain nor the international community can solve the land problem or reverse Zimbabwe's economic decline. Only Robert Mugabe can do so, and he shows no sign of wanting to."

Mr Hain's criticism was contained in a faxed statement released by the British high commission in Harare yesterday. It came as international observers arrived to monitor the elections.

In the run-up to the elections on June 24-25, Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party has unleashed a widespread campaign of violence against the opposition that has taken 30 lives. Thousands more opposition supporters have been beaten, raped and tortured.

In the latest incident, ruling party militants attacked teachers and health workers, forcing many to flee their schools and clinics, an independent monitoring group and Zimbabwe's main opposition party said yesterday.

Many of those injured in the violence last month in northeast Zimbabwe were also barred from entering medical clinics, the Community Working Group on Health said.

Mr Mugabe's relations with Mr Hain have been strained ever since his outspoken criticism in March, when customs officials in Harare opened and inspected the contents of several British diplomatic bags. At the time, Mr Hain described the move as "not the action of a civilised country", remarks that many in Zimbabwe found deeply offensive. Mr Mugabe has since launched numerous outspoken attacks on Tony Blair's government.

The president refused to allow Britons to participate in the EU and Commonwealth observer teams. The British government decided it was more important to get international observers on the ground than insist on its right to participate. In any case, Britons are in the senior administration of both the EU and Commonwealth teams.

"We are not going to pre-empt the observers' verdict or the verdict of the people of Zimbabwe. To pre-empt would be to play Robert Mugabe's game," Mr Hain said. "He wants to run this election with Britain as the opposition and we are not going to oblige.

"We are in close contact with partners from the Commonwealth, European commission and the United Nations. We have expressed our concerns and we will be monitoring closely reports from the election observers," he added.

Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party is facing its strongest challenge since coming to power 20 years ago. The Movement for Democratic Change has fielded candidates in all 120 constituencies, the first time an opposition party has done so since 1980.

fields.headline: Pinochet immunity reversed
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The Spanish judge who sought unsuccessfully to extradite Chile's Augusto Pinochet from London gave a cautious welcome yesterday to a Chilean appeal court decision to strip the former dictator of his immunity from prosecution.
fields.body:
The Spanish judge who sought unsuccessfully to extradite Chile's Augusto Pinochet from London gave a cautious welcome yesterday to a Chilean appeal court decision to strip the former dictator of his immunity from prosecution.

Judge Baltaser Garzon, who secured Gen Pinochet's arrest in 1998 only to see him freed 16 months later when the British government found him medically unfit to stand trial, expressed "respect" for the ruling, which could pave the way for a trial on human rights charges. But court sources said Mr Garzon realised that Gen Pinochet's fate ultimately rested with Chile's supreme court, where an appeal will be lodged.

Monday's decision has been hailed as a victory for international human rights. "This is a undoubtedly a triumph of justice," a Madrid-based lawyer, Carlos Slepoy, told CNN.

"It shows that the [Chilean] government was sincere when it guaranteed that Pinochet would be returned to his country to be judged," the Spanish newspaper El Mundo said in an editorial.

fields.headline: Window of opportunity
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British companies have only 18 months to break into the Chinese market before other nations grab the lion's share, according to Jack Ma, chairman of the country's largest business-to-business website, Alibaba.com.
fields.body:
British companies have only 18 months to break into the Chinese market before other nations grab the lion's share, according to Jack Ma, chairman of the country's largest business-to-business website, Alibaba.com.

He believes the net will allow thousands of small Chinese companies to build networks with western suppliers, manufacturers and retailers. But within the next year and a half most relationships will be sealed and latecomers will be shut out.

"With the US two years ahead in the highly prosperous B2B market, there is a very real danger of UK businesses being closed out of China," he said. Engineering and design skills "that we understand are very strong in the UK", were in demand.

"China is still considered an archaic country which only makes cheap plastic toys. In reality, like other countries in the Far East, China is becoming more service-oriented."

Firms that build ties with the many family-run manufacturers in China could avoid head-to-head battles with US multinationals investing heavily in the country.

fields.headline: IRA blamed for drugs murder
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Security sources in Northern Ireland last night said a Catholic drug dealer shot dead 10 days ago on the outskirts of Belfast was murdered by the IRA in a sanctioned operation.
fields.body:
Security sources in Northern Ireland last night said a Catholic drug dealer shot dead 10 days ago on the outskirts of Belfast was murdered by the IRA in a sanctioned operation.

Ed McCoy, 28, was shot three times at point blank range as he drank in the Motte 'n' Bailey pub near south Belfast. His assailants wore wigs and false moustaches as they singled him out.

The IRA tried to muddy the waters, unusually dumping the car used in the attack in a nearby loyalist area. But it had been spotted in republican Twinbrook in west Belfast 30 minutes before the attack.

The revelations will cause problems for first minister David Trimble, who refused to comment on the murder last week as he was preparing to return to government with Sinn Fein. They will exacerbate unionist fears over IRA proposals on decommissioning. John Mullin

fields.headline: Tehran rubbishes defector
fields.trailText: Iran's intelligence minister said that a defector claiming Iranian involvement in several anti-American operations was only trying to get asylum in the west, denying that any such person had ever worked for the secret service, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Iran's intelligence minister said that a defector claiming Iranian involvement in several anti-American operations was only trying to get asylum in the west, denying that any such person had ever worked for the secret service, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported yesterday.

The defector, who identified himself as Ahmed Behbahani, told the CBS news programme 60 Minutes that he was involved in Iranian terrorism operations for more than ten years before his defection to Turkey. He is currently seeking asylum in the US.

"Since the establishment of Iran's [intelligence] ministry, no person named Ahmed Behbahani has been working with the ministry," Irna quoted the intelligence minister, Ali Yunesi, as saying.

Mr Behbahani claimed he was the mastermind behind the 1988 bombing of Pan Am 103, but Turkey said the defector was only 32 now, and at 20 would have been too young to lead such a complex operation. The Mujahedeen Khalq, an Iraq-based opposition group, claimed Mr Behbahani was in his mid-40s.

webTitle: Malaria hits UK troops in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Malaria hits UK troops in Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: At least 13 British troops and aircrew serving in Sierra Leone have contracted malaria, the Ministry of Defence said last night. A further three are suspected of having the disease.
fields.body:
At least 13 British troops and aircrew serving in Sierra Leone have contracted malaria, the Ministry of Defence said last night. A further three are suspected of having the disease.

The MoD explained the cases by saying that British troops were deployed at very short notice.

The medical advice to troops going to countries where malaria is prevalent is to take the drug, meofloquine, three weeks in advance to see whether it causes any side effects.

Of the 13 cases confirmed, six were among aircrew who did not take the drug because of the possible indications, the MoD said.

They took chloroquine and proquamil which are not so effective.

The ministry confirmed the figures after parliamentary questions were tabled by Paul Keetch, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman.

fields.headline: Home truths
fields.standfirst:
As Londonderry elects the first republican to run an Irish city since the 20s, Esther Addley returns to the home she left 13 years ago to discover how much has changed in the town that has always straddled the front line of Ireland's Troubles

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: As Londonderry elects the first republican to run an Irish city since the 20s,  Esther Addley  returns to the home she left 13 years ago to discover how much has changed in the town that has always straddled the front line of Ireland's Troubles
fields.body:
The first time I was sure that I was about to die was when I heard the Catholics coming for us from the other side of the river. It wasn't unusual to hear the occasional gunshot from the Bogside or the Creggan, the two big Catholic estates on the "city side" of Derry. We were used to things going bang in the night, the odd dull thud of a bomb or a crackle of gunshots echoing across the river Foyle to the nice middle-class Protestant area where my family lived.

But this was different. The sounds of imminent massacre were unmistakable, weapons being fired in the air in gleeful bloodlust. I clung to my bunk bed, sick with terror. It was only when I finally scrambled downstairs to my mother's cool, comforting laughter that I realised I had been listening to a firework display.

Childhood terrors were of a different scale when you grew up in Derry in the late 70s. As well as bogeymen and bed bugs, we had the Catholics to keep us awake at night. No one really lived their life in a state of permanent fear, apart from those whose dads were in the police (and we all knew who they were). But even as I approached my teens, there was a feeling that the only way the "Troubles" could be resolved would be through one side slaughtering the other. Everyone knew the Catholics were going to outbreed us at some point, but the British, we trusted, would never let Northern Ireland go back to the Irish. The IRA would be forced to massacre us in our beds.

Thirteen years after I left Derry at the age of 14, I am bewildered by the opinions I held as a child. My parents, good Protestant folk who were as liberal as it was possible to be in those times, had raised us without the smallest trace of animosity towards the Catholic people who shared the city with us. But despite their best efforts, we were inevitably infected by sectarianism. It was part of the air you breathed in Ulster, it hung in the soft, drizzly rain. Casual slaughter was part of the routine rhythm of life, after all: even today many of my childhood memories are bound up with atrocities. I went to Omagh the day that Lord Mountbatten was blown up. A friend's mother died the day two soldiers were battered to death at a Belfast funeral. I had my last cello lesson the day a loyalist gunman killed three at another funeral.

It is this mad little world that observers have to try to enter if they want to understand Northern Ireland's tentative progress towards peace. How, I wondered, had the Ulster Unionist party's narrow vote to re-enter Northern Ireland's executive government played in Nelson Drive and in Lincoln Courts and in Irish Street? What would my friend Andrea McDaid, who had talked with me late into the night about the coming massacre, make of it? What about the girls who taught me songs about burning the Pope in the back of the minibus on the way to hockey matches?

I wanted to go back to Derry, to talk to the people I had grown up with and who, unlike me, had stayed. I had moved to a school in Belfast, decided I was really a nationalist, and taken off to university in England, looking over my shoulder with the mix of romanticism, guilt and disgust that characterises Irish exiles the world over. It was a philosophical conversion rather than one based on any experience - I made my first real Catholic friend at university in England. But as the ties of fearful religion loosened, I realised that identifying with Ireland rather than Ulster had its own attractions. The devil did have the best tunes after all. But what about those who stayed?

If Northern Ireland is a weird little place, Derry must be one of its weirdest corners. Tucked up in the north-west corner of the province, right on the border with the Irish republic, it is the second biggest city in Ulster, but still fits neatly into a chest-tighteningly beautiful lough valley under the soft hills of Donegal. The ancient Irish town of Doire became Londonderry in the early 17th century, when several wealthy London trades guilds invested heavily in the new Protestant citadel. (The fraught issue of how to refer to the city still exercises the minds of the country's brightest and best. This paper's style is to call it "Londonderry", Protestants all over Northern Ireland insist on nothing less, but almost everyone in the city, from both sides, refers to it as "Derry".)

The guilds built a handsome cathedral and an impressive set of city walls to ring-fence God's own people. The walls are one of the sacred symbols of Protestant inviolability, the "Maiden city" whose boundaries were never breached by Catholicism. But 300 years after the Protestant city saw off a Catholic siege, the Prods again find themselves under assault. The city is now about 75% Catholic, a fact which on Monday ensured the election of ex-IRA man Cathal Crumley as the city's mayor - the first republican to run any Irish city since partition in 1922.

The old "Derry side" of the city has been all but abandoned by Protestants who fled during the Troubles to the east bank and the reassuring road to loyalist north Antrim. I went to school on the city side, to the only Protestant grammar, established when that side of town was a less alien environment. Northern Ireland's education system is still based around the 11-plus exam, when children feed into grammar or secondary schools, largely divided along class lines. The religious division happens much earlier, when you start primary school at the age of three or four. Both Catholic and Protestant schools are state funded, but the two are run along parallel - separate - systems.

My old schoolmates were difficult to track down. I phoned five or six people; everyone's parents still lived where I remembered. "I know that name well! How is your mum?" But none of the kids was still in Derry. They were in Glasgow, or in Edinburgh, or "across the water" in England, the names of the remote cities pronounced as if they were foreign words. I tracked Andrea McDaid down to a telecom company in Belfast. She had moved back to Ulster after university in England, but hadn't been able to bring herself to come back up over the Sperrin mountains to Derry. She told me she had come up to the city for a work function, and had gone out with some colleagues on the city side of the river. It was the first time she had been out socialising on the west bank in her life.

I had more luck with people I had known from church. John Thompson had also been to study across the water, but had come back to teach at the primary school 100 yards from where we both had gone to church as children, tucked into a labyrinthine Protestant estate with murals so menacing the Guardian's photographer refused to get out of the car. "I wanted to come back because this was where I was from," Johnny says. "But most people had gone, most of my friends had left Derry. They went to university in England or Scotland and got used to not having the hassle. They were sick of the things they had seen here, and in England it didn't matter who you were."

He is in favour of the assembly, he says, and even welcomes Martin McGuinness's reinstatement to the post of education minister, the most contentious appointment of the new executive. "You can only judge him on what he does, not on what he has done." Trimble has worked wonders, he thinks. "If things hadn't gone well with that vote I might have thought we were going down the same road again. It was really important, because I don't think there would have been any way back if it hadn't gone well."

This determined hope is something you see again and again among young Protestants, however much their political leaders may shout when placed in front of a microphone. Darren Graham has had one of the more remarkable conversions. He grew up on a big Protestant working class estate in Derry, where we went to church together, and where his mother still lives, but he doesn't go back to see her much. He got in with a bad crowd, got involved "with drugs, with the paramilitaries, with buying drugs for the paramilitaries". They would run round the estate causing trouble, lighting fires, intimidating people.

"I can't really go near the estate," he says now. "I get the feeling that I'm regarded as a 'fenian lover' because I don't have that hatred that I thought I had. A lot of that stuff was generated by your peers, we all fed off each other." He is hopeful about Northern Ireland's fledgling parliament. "The best thing about the agreement is that once we had two sides, and you had to belong to one of them, because if you sat on the fence you would get it from them both. Now we have got four - you have pro- and anti-agreement Catholics, pro- and anti-agreement Protestants. If they just keep on splitting us up more and more, that's how it's going to work."

His friend William Docherty was disgusted with the vote to re-enter the Executive, however: "And for the record I voted 'no' in the referendum. My dad didn't have to say anything. He knew I would vote no." Docherty is proud to assert the views of the stereotypical hot Prod, to the extent that his mates in the small sports club refer to him jokingly as "the bigot". But he denies he is bigoted. He just doesn't understand how anyone can have fallen for what he calls Sinn Fein's pro paganda. "I just can't see how people can be sympathetic to them. The IRA hasn't given up a pound of Semtex. And then there's the prisoners. And what about the police? If we let out all the prisoners you are just having thugs run around with guns." The British, he says, are so desperate for peace they want to brush the real issues under the carpet and give the IRA anything they want.

Docherty personifies many of the tensions that Protestantism is currently trying to keep in equilibrium. His parents, he says, would discourage him as much as possible from having Catholic friends. "The way I'm brought up I'm just taught that even their religion is evil, that being a Catholic is wrong, and they worship idols. My dad thinks that if I run about with them I might be brainwashed." But then, he concedes, he has probably been brainwashed from birth anyway.

And if this is bigotry, it's been watered down a lot since the rough boys at my school used to dig up the sports pitches to throw clods of mud at the black taxis, which we all knew were "run by the IRA". "I do run about with a lot of Catholics and I have a few good enough mates," says Docherty. He even went out with a Catholic girl for a few months, though he never took her home. "I told her why. My dad would have gone mad."

It is only when I get home that I realise we haven't spoken at all about "religion", the thing that supposedly unites us. Docherty still goes to church, but often it is with a hangover. And this is what is responsible for Ulster's slow sea change, as much as political concessions or American intervention. For as long as the killing was going on, young Protestants and Catholics socialised in their own areas, and rarely met anyone from the other side. But drink, ecstasy and a creeping secularisation of society have brought them into contact with the other side in a way that even their parents, who grew up in more peaceful times, probably never experienced. The old suspicions remain, but young people in Northern Ireland are more interested now in getting drunk and getting laid than getting even.

Across the river, in Derry's historic centre, the Bloody Sunday inquiry is sitting in the Guildhall, right in the middle of the main shopping promenade. It's a surreal and disturbing experience to sit in the public gallery and hear bored English lawyers intone details of grotesque and startling slaughter carried out by nonchalant British soldiers in 1972. A girl of about 14 sat on her own in the gallery, another man had brought his toddlers.

I went for a walk on Derry's walls, the first time I have ever gone all the way round, since the army had closed off a section for most of the Troubles. It was a muggy afternoon, and the children going home from school had slung their school blazers over their shoulders as they took the 300-year-old shortcut home. Perched on a battlement overlooking the river, a couple of teenagers snogged as if their futures depended on it. Her uniform was that of my Protestant school, his of the new Catholic college in the city. A small but significant image of hope for the new Derry.

Some of the names have been changed

But as the ties of fearful religion loosened, I realised that identifying with Ireland rather than Ulster had its own attractions. The devil did have the best tunes after all. But what about those who stayed? If Northern Ireland is a weird little place, Derry must be one of its weirdest corners. Tucked up in the north-west corner of the province, right on the border with the Irish republic, it is the second biggest city in Ulster, but still fits neatly into a chest-tighteningly beautiful lough valley under the soft hills of Donegal. The ancient Irish town of Doire became Londonderry in the early 17th century, when several wealthy London trades guilds invested heavily in the new Protestant citadel. (The fraught issue of how to refer to the city still exercises the minds of the country's brightest and best. This paper's style is to call it "Londonderry", Protestants all over Northern Ireland insist on nothing less, but almost everyone in the city, from both sides, refers to it as "Derry".) The guilds built a handsome cathedral and an impressive set of city walls to ring-fence God's own people. The walls are one of the sacred symbols of Protestant inviolability, the "Maiden city" whose boundaries were never breached by Catholicism. But 300 years after the Protestant city saw off a Catholic siege, the Prods again find themselves under assault. The city is now about 75% Catholic, a fact which on Monday ensured the election of ex-IRA man Cathal Crumley as the city's mayor - the first republican to run any Irish city since partition in 1922. The old "Derry side" of the city has been all but abandoned by Protestants who fled during the Troubles to the east bank and the reassuring road to loyalist north Antrim. I went to school on the city side, to the only Protestant grammar, established when that side of town was a less alien environment. Northern Ireland's education system is still based around the 11-plus exam, when children feed into grammar or secondary schools, largely divided along class lines. The religious division happens much earlier, when you start primary school at the age of three or four. Both Catholic and Protestant schools are state funded, but the two are run along parallel - separate - systems. My old schoolmates were difficult to track down. I phoned five or six people; everyone's parents still lived where I remembered. "I know that name well! How is your mum?" But none of the kids was still in Derry. They were in Glasgow, or in Edinburgh, or "across the water" in England, the names of the remote cities pronounced as if they were foreign words. I tracked Andrea McDaid down to a telecom company in Belfast. She had moved back to Ulster after university in England, but hadn't been able to bring herself to come back up over the Sperrin mountains to Derry. She told me she had come up to the city for a work function, and had gone out with some colleagues on the city side of the river. It was the first time she had been out socialising on the west bank in her life. I had more luck with people I had known from church. John Thompson had also been to study across the water, but had come back to teach at the primary school 100 yards from where we both had gone to church as children, tucked into a labyrinthine Protestant estate with murals so menacing the Guardian's photographer refused to get out of the car. "I wanted to come back because this was where I was from," Johnny says. "But most people had gone, most of my friends had left Derry. They went to university in England or Scotland and got used to not having the hassle. They were sick of the things they had seen here, and in England it didn't matter who you were." He is in favour of the assembly, he says, and even welcomes Martin McGuinness's reinstatement to the post of education minister, the most contentious appointment of the new executive. "You can only judge him on what he does, not on what he has done." Trimble has worked wonders, he thinks. "If things hadn't gone well with that vote I might have thought we were going down the same road again. It was really important, because I don't think there would have been any way back if it hadn't gone well." This determined hope is something you see again and again among young Protestants, however much their political leaders may shout when placed in front of a microphone. Darren Graham has had one of the more remarkable conversions. He grew up on a big Protestant working class estate in Derry, where we went to church together, and where his mother still lives, but he doesn't go back to see her much. He got in with a bad crowd, got involved "with drugs, with the paramilitaries, with buying drugs for the paramilitaries". They would run round the estate causing trouble, lighting fires, intimidating people. "I can't really go near the estate," he says now. "I get the feeling that I'm regarded as a 'fenian lover' because I don't have that hatred that I thought I had. A lot of that stuff was generated by your peers, we all fed off each other." He is hopeful about Northern Ireland's fledgling parliament. "The best thing about the agreement is that once we had two sides, and you had to belong to one of them, because if you sat on the fence you would get it from them both. Now we have got four - you have pro- and anti-agreement Catholics, pro- and anti-agreement Protestants. If they just keep on splitting us up more and more, that's how it's going to work." His friend William Docherty was disgusted with the vote to re-enter the Executive, however: "And for the record I voted 'no' in the referendum. My dad didn't have to say anything. He knew I would vote no." Docherty is proud to assert the views of the stereotypical hot Prod, to the extent that his mates in the small sports club refer to him jokingly as "the bigot". But he denies he is bigoted. He just doesn't understand how anyone can have fallen for what he calls Sinn Fein's pro paganda. "I just can't see how people can be sympathetic to them. The IRA hasn't given up a pound of Semtex. And then there's the prisoners. And what about the police? If we let out all the prisoners you are just having thugs run around with guns." The British, he says, are so desperate for peace they want to brush the real issues under the carpet and give the IRA anything they want. Docherty personifies many of the tensions that Protestantism is currently trying to keep in equilibrium. His parents, he says, would discourage him as much as possible from having Catholic friends. "The way I'm brought up I'm just taught that even their religion is evil, that being a Catholic is wrong, and they worship idols. My dad thinks that if I run about with them I might be brainwashed." But then, he concedes, he has probably been brainwashed from birth anyway. And if this is bigotry, it's been watered down a lot since the rough boys at my school used to dig up the sports pitches to throw clods of mud at the black taxis, which we all knew were "run by the IRA". "I do run about with a lot of Catholics and I have a few good enough mates," says Docherty. He even went out with a Catholic girl for a few months, though he never took her home. "I told her why. My dad would have gone mad." It is only when I get home that I realise we haven't spoken at all about "religion", the thing that supposedly unites us. Docherty still goes to church, but often it is with a hangover. And this is what is responsible for Ulster's slow sea change, as much as political concessions or American intervention. For as long as the killing was going on, young Protestants and Catholics socialised in their own areas, and rarely met anyone from the other side. But drink, ecstasy and a creeping secularisation of society have brought them into contact with the other side in a way that even their parents, who grew up in more peaceful times, probably never experienced. The old suspicions remain, but young people in Northern Ireland are more interested now in getting drunk and getting laid than getting even. Across the river, in Derry's historic centre, the Bloody Sunday inquiry is sitting in the Guildhall, right in the middle of the main shopping promenade. It's a surreal and disturbing experience to sit in the public gallery and hear bored English lawyers intone details of grotesque and startling slaughter carried out by nonchalant British soldiers in 1972. A girl of about 14 sat on her own in the gallery, another man had brought his toddlers. I went for a walk on Derry's walls, the first time I have ever gone all the way round, since the army had closed off a section for most of the Troubles. It was a muggy afternoon, and the children going home from school had slung their school blazers over their shoulders as they took the 300-year-old shortcut home. Perched on a battlement overlooking the river, a couple of teenagers snogged as if their futures depended on it. Her uniform was that of my Protestant school, his of the new Catholic college in the city. A small but significant image of hope for the new Derry. Some of the names have been changed

webTitle: Battle royal down the years between the pragmatist and the romantic

fields.headline: Battle royal down the years between the pragmatist and the romantic
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: "He's a romantic and I'm a pragmatist. That means we do see things differently  and because I don't see things as a romantic would, I'm unfeeling," the Duke of Edinburgh told a Sunday paper a year ago in what seemed to be his first comment publicly about his relationship with his son.
fields.body:
"He's a romantic and I'm a pragmatist. That means we do see things differently and because I don't see things as a romantic would, I'm unfeeling," the Duke of Edinburgh told a Sunday paper a year ago in what seemed to be his first comment publicly about his relationship with his son.

That Prince Philip and the Prince of Wales have had a strained relationship has been known for years. The two have much in common - a stiff formality, a naval background - but their views on most other matters, from children to GM organisms, diverge considerably. So do their interests.

Prince Charles's biographers make little secret of what they see as his resentment towards his father. Prince Philip is routinely described as having "bullied" his son to try to instill some backbone for his role as king.

The duke, who played squash on the night his son was born, reputedly continued to be a distant and often absent father. He chose Gordonstoun for his son's education, a school that Charles hated and which he ruled out for his own sons. Charles is also said to blame his father for pushing him into marrying Diana. And it was Philip whom Diana blamed for the coldness she experienced as the marriage broke down.

Charles told his biographer, Jonathan Dimbleby, that he was emotionally estranged from his parents, finding them unable or unwilling to offer affection. Anthony Holden, once close to the prince, said of Philip that his "wrathful disapproval could still, even as [the prince] approached 50, reduce him to tears".

The duke, who likes to appear as a bluff, practical sort, appears to have little time for the prince's ethereal concerns - such as his professed spirituality. He himself has a reputation for gaffes in off-the-cuff comments, and his laborious attempts at wit have often backfired. A long-term president of the World Wide Fund for Nature, he stays keen on fishing and shooting, activities that have earned sharp criticism - like Charles's fox hunting

webTitle: French to hold mobile beauty contest

fields.headline: French to hold mobile beauty contest
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The French government is likely to reap £12.9bn from the sale of four third-generation mobile telephone licences after announcing yesterday that it would conduct the sale through a beauty parade - but that successful applicants would have to pay a hefty entrance fee.
fields.body:
The French government is likely to reap £12.9bn from the sale of four third-generation mobile telephone licences after announcing yesterday that it would conduct the sale through a beauty parade - but that successful applicants would have to pay a hefty entrance fee.

The government set the entry fee for each licence at £3.22bn, a figure immediately criticised as "unreasonable" by Vivendi, the French telecommunications and media corporation.

The price for each licence is, however, comparatively less than that paid by telecoms companies for similar licences in Britain. The cheapest British licence was auctioned for £4bn, raising a total of £22.48bn for the exchequer.

Jean-Marie Messier, Vivendi's chief executive, said the entry fee amounted to an extra tax but the company would sell 3% of its 24.5% stake in BSkyB to fund the purchase of a licence.

The three incumbent operators, France Télécom, SFR and Bouygues, are already favourites to win licences.

Successful bidders will be required to pay half of the 15-year non-renewable licence fee in the first two years and the remainder over 13 years.

Unlike the chancellor, Gordon Brown, ministers in Paris decided not to take the pure auction route. They made the decision on the recommendation of the French telecoms watchdog, ART.

ART said an auction could lead to telecoms companies passing on the higher costs to customers. The French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, said yesterday: "It seemed to us to be desirable to follow the procedure recommended by the ART regulatory body."

However, the government ignored ART's recommendation to set the entry fee at £1.24bn for each licence.

Analysts suggested there could have been elements of nationalism in the French government choosing a beauty contest. This would allow se lection of successful bidders to be influenced by "non-commercial" factors and might ensure that local operators will not be outbid by foreign competitors.

The French government intends to use the funds to increase the reserves of the state pension fund and cut debt.

Bidders are expected to receive the "beauty contest" criteria by June; they are expected to include quality of service, geographical coverage and ability to pay the fee. Candidates then must tender bids by the end of the year. Licences are likely to be awarded in the first half of next year with a third generation service available to customers from 2002.

Vodafone AirTouch, which paid the top price for a UK licence, is not expected to bid directly for a French licence. It holds 20% of mobile phone group SFR, with the remainder owned by Cegetel.

Vodafone has relationships with Vivendi through Vizzavi, the multi-access portal jointly owned by both companies. Vivendi also a stake in SFR in directly through its controlling shareholding in Cegetel.

"We have made no comment on this, but clearly we would be looking to our French partners," said a Vodafone AirTouch spokesman.

BT, which also has a stake in Cegetel, said it would review the criteria to decide whether it would rely on its relationship with French partners or bid directly. Sir Peter Bonfield, the BT chief executive, has said it will pursue third-generation licences in the key European markets.

webTitle: At odds, two princes and a princess

fields.headline: At odds, two princes and a princess
fields.standfirst:
GM debate: special report
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles, May 17:"Opposition to the development of Frankenstein foods is wrongly dismissed as a sign of weakness or even a wish to halt progress. If literally nothing is held sacred what is there to prevent us treating our entire world as some great laboratory of life with potentially disastrous long-term consequences?
fields.body:
Prince Charles, May 17

"Opposition to the development of Frankenstein foods is wrongly dismissed as a sign of weakness or even a wish to halt progress. If literally nothing is held sacred what is there to prevent us treating our entire world as some great laboratory of life with potentially disastrous long-term consequences?

"It is because of our inability or refusal to accept a guiding hand that nature has come to be regarded as a system that can be engineered for our own convenience, or as a nuisance to be evaded and manipulated, and in which anything that happens can be 'fixed' by technology or human ingenuity.

"If a fraction of the money currently being invested in developing genetically modified crops were applied to understanding and improving traditional systems of agriculture , which have stood the all important test of time, the results would be remarkable."

Princess Anne, June 3

"It is a huge oversimplification to say all farming ought to be organic or there should be no GM foods. I'm sorry, but life isn't that simple. Man has been tinkering with food production and plant development for such a long time that it's a bit cheeky to suddenly get nervous about it when, fundamentally, you are doing much the same thing."

Prince Philip, June 5

"Do not let us forget we have been genetically modifying animals and plants ever since people started selective breeding. People are worried about genetically modified organisms getting into the environment. What people forget is that the introduction of exotic species - like, for instance, the introduction of the grey squirrel into this country - is going to,or has done, far more damage than a genetically modified piece of potato. The real point is, where are the limits to what we do?"

webTitle: US hurries along Middle East talks

fields.headline: US hurries along Middle East talks
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, yesterday announced a change of scenery to try to quicken the sluggish pace of Middle East peace talks, summoning Israeli and Palestinian negotiators to Washington to search for a settlement before the Clinton presidency enters its twilight.
fields.body:
The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, yesterday announced a change of scenery to try to quicken the sluggish pace of Middle East peace talks, summoning Israeli and Palestinian negotiators to Washington to search for a settlement before the Clinton presidency enters its twilight.

Next week's talks will try to narrow the gaps between the Israelis and Palestinians sufficiently so that President Clinton can preside over a three-way summit.

If all goes according to an immensely ambitious plan, that summit would produce a final agreement before September 13.

With that aim, Ms Albright announced in the West Bank city of Ramallah that the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, will travel to Washington to meet the US president a week from today.

Mr Clinton is expected to amplify the message that Ms Albright has been trying to get across during her visit to Israel and the West Bank: that both sides will have to make deep concessions on such emotional issues as the final status of the holy city of Jerusalem and the right of return for Palestinian refugees.

"I think as we go through all these negotiations, it is evident that it is impossible for both sides to get 100% of what each side wants," she said yesterday. "But they will not succeed unless both are satisfied with what they have got."

However, Mr Arafat and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, have been losing room for compromise. Despite the fillip to his popularity following Israel's withdrawal from south Lebanon, Mr Barak is under siege at home and today his opponents are almost certain to pass a bill to hold fresh elections.

Although the bill must have at least three more readings, it ushers Mr Barak into increasingly precarious terrain.

Mr Arafat too must stare down his domestic opponents. With the Hizbullah guerrillas of Lebanon claiming victory from Israel's retreat, he is going to find it increasingly hard to sell an agreement that leaves large parcels of the West Bank under Israeli control.

Despite Mr Barak's charges that he was "dragging his feet", Mr Arafat said yesterday: "Our position is very clear. We have demonstrated our flexibility over and over."

There has been progress, however, in back channel negotiations that began in Stockholm several weeks ago. According to press reports, Israel is contemplating the surrender of a far larger portion of the West Bank than previously offered - some 92% of the territory occupied since 1967.

Mr Barak has also hinted that Israel is considering the evacuation of up to 60,000 Jews from West Bank settlements - although some 150,000 people, would continue to live on lands permanently annexed by Israel.

US officials are exploring other, more creative formulae for dealing with West Bank settlements, including a plan in which Israel would give up pieces of land inside its 1967 boundaries in return for annexing areas occupied by Jewish settlers in the West Bank.

There is also a proposal that Jewish settlements in the West Bank could remain under long-term leases from the soon-to-be-born Palestinian state.

webTitle: Dead but refusing to lie down

fields.headline: Dead but refusing to lie down
fields.standfirst: Cars are in reverse, telecoms boom. Managers in the ailing sectors fail to spot the difference
fields.trailText: Industries are born, grow, mature and die, and for investors the most spectacular gains are to be had when an industry breaks through from immaturity to growth. This may seem a simple-minded truism to rank alongside "buy low, sell high" but, according to research by the investment bank Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, plotting the position of each sector on the growth/decline curve is fiendishly tricky.
fields.body:
Industries are born, grow, mature and die, and for investors the most spectacular gains are to be had when an industry breaks through from immaturity to growth. This may seem a simple-minded truism to rank alongside "buy low, sell high" but, according to research by the investment bank Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, plotting the position of each sector on the growth/decline curve is fiendishly tricky.

The reason? Industries simply do not behave as they should.

On paper it looks straightforward, with the life-cycle of an industry resembling a motorway flyover. There is an up ramp (immaturity and growth), a flat stretch (maturity) and a down ramp (decline). Salomon is too delicate to include the final stage, but, as Edward G Robinson said in Double Indemnity: "The last stop's the cemetery."

At least, it ought to be. But Mark Howdle of Salomon, author of the report, highlights an exception or two. Or three. In fact, the exceptions threaten to outnumber the rule, with industrial mummies refusing even to enter their tombs let alone stay in them.

A 'political' industry
Take cars. Salomon puts "autos" firmly on the down ramp. This is an industry that grew until the 1970s, stabilised and ought now to be sliding. At this point, Mr Howdle said, there is still good money to be made, provided managements concentrate on sweating the assets to produce income.

But they don't. Instead, according to Mr Howdle, they are "over-investing", a fact reflected both in the 20% overcapacity of European car manufacturers and in statistics showing the motor industry to have one of the lowest pay-out rates to shareholders when, at this stage of its life, it ought to have one of the highest.

As seen in the Rover debacle, cars are a "political" industry. The same goes for steel, airlines, civil aviation, the railways and defence manufacture, not to mention shipbuilding.

But even outside this state-erected ring fence, human nature prevents company directors accepting the unpalatable facts of commercial mortality. As a result, they continue to hog capital that ought to have been liberated for new industries in the growth phase.

Or, as Mr Howdle put its, they resemble "the very old lady who's squandering the family fortune on anti-wrinkle cream". He added: "It's very difficult to persuade a chairman or CEO that they are in a declining industry and that they should shrink gracefully."

As a result, such industries - with cars providing the most graphic example - are stuck in a prisoner's dilemma in which none dare cut back for fear of giving rivals a free ride. This results in heavy overproduction and falling profits.

In 1998, Robert Brenner, a professor at the University of California at Los Angeles, described this as the result of the "unplanned, uncoordinated nature of capitalist production", with firms refusing to drop out of declining markets at the point where classical economics suggest they ought to.

Professor Brenner and Salomon make strange bedfellows, but they seem at one on this issue.

Investors agree, too, according to Mr Howdle; they assume that "management will continue making sub-optimal decisions", and downgrade the companies' securities accordingly.

But the refusal of some industries to make the stately progress off the flyover is not always the fault of stubborn managements.

Sometimes it is entirely justified by developments that, according to Mr Howdle, give that industry a "top-up dose". Indeed, it is possible for a sector actually to engage the reverse gear and experience the exhilarating "up" phase all over again.

No guarantees

One example is telecoms, which was rated as a "utility" sector 10 years ago and now is deemed a roaring go-go play. Another might, in future, prove to be pharmaceuticals, at present cresting the "growth" phase prior to joining the long, flat "mature" section.

A final word of warning. Telecoms, as noted above, is currently in the "growth" phase, but Salomon notes this is no guarantee of healthy returns.

In fact, with an astronomical £200bn being sunk into licences and infrastructure for Europe's third-generation mobile telephones, Mr Howdle suggested wise investors might prefer to buy shares in those receiving the money (telecom equipment companies) rather than those spending it (the telecom operators).

Some truisms always bear repetition.

The reason? Industries simply do not behave as they should. On paper it looks straightforward, with the life-cycle of an industry resembling a motorway flyover. webTitle: Duke challenges sceptics over GM food

fields.headline: Duke challenges sceptics over GM food
fields.standfirst:
Debate divides royal family as Prince Philip and Princess Anne rebuff 'nervous' opponents - such as Prince Charles

GM debate: special report
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Duke of Edinburgh has intervened in the GM debate to bolster supporters of the new biotechnology against doubters such as his son, the Prince of Wales. In a blunt challenge to sceptics, he said that "foreign pests" such as the grey squirrel had done far more damage to the environment than genetically modified crops would ever do.
fields.body:
The Duke of Edinburgh has intervened in the GM debate to bolster supporters of the new biotechnology against doubters such as his son, the Prince of Wales. In a blunt challenge to sceptics, he said that "foreign pests" such as the grey squirrel had done far more damage to the environment than genetically modified crops would ever do.

The duke's off-the-cuff remarks at a function at Windsor Castle on Monday night came just days after the Princess Royal delivered a sideswipe at opponents of GM food in the industry magazine, the Grocer.

But suggestions of a rift over GM issues or family criticism of Prince Charles were strongly denied by sources last night and Buckingham Palace insisted the "different emphases and opinions" within the royal family merely "reflect the diverse opinions of people generally across the board".

Prince Philip was responding to a lecture by Jonathan Sacks, the chief rabbi, which touched on GM crops while discussing the wider issues of genetics.

Prince Philip said: "Do not let us forget that we have been genetically modifying animals and plants ever since people started selective breeding. People are worried about genetically modified organisms getting into the environment. What people forget is that the introduction of exotic species - like, for instance, the introduction of the grey squirrel into this country - is going to, or has done, far more damage than a genetically modified piece of potato. The real point is, where are the limits to what we do?"

Princess Anne had declared it was an "oversimplification" to say that there should be no GM foods. "Man has been tinkering with food production and plant development for such a long time that it is a bit cheeky to suddenly get nervous about it."

Last month Prince Charles, in a BBC Reith lecture, had warned against creating conditions in which "genetic manipulation seeks to transform the process of biological evolution into something altogether different".

Supporters of all three royals were last night stressing their credentials for the right to voice their opinions. They have all been involved in environmental issues to a lesser or greater extent. Prince Philip was a past president of the World Wide Fund for Nature and has a strong interest on conservation issues. Princess Anne is president of Save the Children, and she has seen conventional crop failures in developing countries. This year she is president of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

Meanwhile, Prince Charles has long been a standard bearer for organic farming methods and a champion of less intensive agriculture. All three were keen "hands-on" farmers at their estates, Balmoral and Sandringham, Gatcombe Park, and Highgrove.

Prince Philip's comments were welcomed by pro-GM scientists. Jim Dunwell, a professor at Reading university, said: "It is useful that everybody is getting involved in the debate. Just because they are members of the best known family does not mean they should not have a view."

The Cabinet Office, which is masterminding the government's GM policy, said that Prince Philip's remarks were "an interesting contribution to the debate". The food standards agency will be looking at the GM food debate during its next public board meeting in Glasgow on June 22.

Tim Yeo, the Conservatives' agriculture spokesman, while not wanting "to get involved in a family row", suggested that Prince Philip was "slightly confused about this issue".

He added: "Of course, it is right that the introduction of some exotic animals into an island like Britain has done great damage, but that should make him more cautious, not less cautious, about the consequences of genetic modification. Genetic modification goes much further than selec tive plant breeding or gradually improving horses so they can run faster.

"It does involve taking genes from one species such as a fish which is normally confined to the Arctic and sticking it into something like a tomato to make [that plant] more frost resistant."

A similar criticism was made by Friends of the Earth, although Pete Riley, the campaigns spokesman, said: "I bet there are plenty of arguments going on around the country's dinner tables. It would be entertaining to eavesdrop on the next royal family dinner. We've been calling for a public debate on this for the past three years, perhaps at last we are going to get it."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: London shares ended the session just about back where they started, with the FTSE 100 having moved through a 130-point range during the session. The overall trend was one of weak drugs and media stocks tempered by some firmness in banking and oil sectors.
fields.body:
London shares ended the session just about back where they started, with the FTSE 100 having moved through a 130-point range during the session. The overall trend was one of weak drugs and media stocks tempered by some firmness in banking and oil sectors.

The Footsie ended just 0.1 points higher at 6,546.8, and trading was pretty average by recent standards.

Uninspiring performances by some of the Top 100 stocks facing demotion to the FTSE 250 saw Psion drop from 635p to 608p, although Kingston Communications managed to add 23p to 670p and Thus moved up from 317.5p to 331p. Meanwhile Hanson , holding steady at 501p, and Scottish & Newcastle , off 14p at 524p, are ex pected to make their return to the blue chip index, with Bookham Technology - up 50p at £37.25 - joining just a couple of months after its flotation and Ocean Group , up 5p at £11.99, also making its first top 100 appearance.

There was some modest buying among the banks - helping the likes of Lloyds TSB, Royal Bank of Scotland and HSBC, who together added about 14 Footsie points.

But against this BSkyB shed 86p to £12.85 after American investment bank Lehman Brothers placed part of German media group Kirch's stake.

Leading the FTSE 100 ad vancers was Anglo-Dutch publishing group Reed International , whose shares gained 36p to 500p after it reported better than expected revenues at its American information unit Lexis and announced plans for six Internet portals in place by the year's end.

Among mid cap issues, Royalblue finished top of the pack, up 212.5p at £15.25, apparently buoyed by a single 30,000-share buy that accounted for more than two-thirds of its trade volume.

Guardian IT was also a feature, gaining 135p at £15.22 after Teather and Greenwood reiterated its "buy" rating, viewing the services com pany as "the only pure play on the strategic growth area of business continuity in London".

Other risers included Alba , up 70p at 617.5p, NXT , up 117.5p at £11.75, and Vocalis - which advanced 12.5p at 227.5p- while the fallers included Fibernet , down 197p at £16.87, and Scipher , down 55p at 525p.

In the small caps Feedback jumped 25p to 102.5p as it announced its intention to list on Germany's Neuer Markt, while Digital Animation added 23p to 120p on expectations that a planned trip to the US may result in an announcement on acquisitions or strategic partnerships.

fields.headline: Grid considers $4bn US bid
fields.standfirst: British power group eyes ailing GPU
fields.trailText: British power group eyes ailing GPU
fields.body:
National Grid, the British electricity group, is understood to be considering a takeover bid for GPU in a deal which could value the US power company at more than $4bn.

The group has considered bidding for several US companies as part of its strategy of expanding international assets and increasing its presence in the US.

Its attention is understood to have turned to GPU because shares in the Massachusetts-based utility company have fallen to a 12-month low. The Grid and GPU declined to comment.

Analysts said a merger would make strategic sense for both sides. However, the Grid might still be tempted to approach a smaller company in the US such as Energy East, a Connecticut-based company, or N Star in Boston.

Any bid for GPU is likely to be some way off. The US firm would bring National Grid several valuable assets as well as doubling its American customer base. The US company owns British distributor Midlands Electricity and a transmission operation in Australia.

Shares in GPU were trading close to $28 yesterday, well below a 12-month high of almost $45 and valuing the company at $3.5bn. Analysts believe any buyer would have to pay a 25% premium.

GPU's shares have fallen because of its failure to sell its Australian transmission business last month as well as general concerns about the lack of movement on an asset disposal programme prompted by a review last October.

It might also face electricity shortages if this summer is hot in the US. GPU is reviewing all businesses outside its core utility unit in order to reduce its debt burden.

Jeff Dennard, head of corporate communications at the company, said yesterday that everything except the core business which serves 2m customers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania was "under constant review". He refused to talk about a potential offer from National Grid. "We make no comment of any kind about any mergers and acquisitions speculation."

This view was echoed by Susan Stevens, head of corporate affairs at National Grid.

David Jones, chief executive of National Grid, told analysts and investors at the company's annual results report last month that he continued to look for acquisitions of a similar size to the New England Electric System or larger.

The company bought NEEC for $3.2bn two years ago.

Barry Abramson, utility analyst with PaineWebber in New York, said GPU "would fit their plan of adding size and scale in the region". He added: "They seem to be thinking about acting early to add another company and start consolidating."

National Grid is thought unlikely to run into regulatory difficulties in the event of a bid.

Earlier this week, a US judge ruled that individuals affected by the Three Mile Island nuclear accident in 1979 could bring lawsuits against GPU. The company says any liability is covered by insurance.

webTitle: Threadbare Textile industry leaders dismiss Byers' jobs initiative

fields.headline: Threadbare Textile industry leaders dismiss Byers' jobs initiative
fields.trailText: Business and union leaders yesterday branded a £15m government package to stem job losses in the textile and clothing industry as too little, too late.
fields.body:
Business and union leaders yesterday branded a £15m government package to stem job losses in the textile and clothing industry as too little, too late.

Stephen Byers (pictured), the trade and industry secretary, said the package was an immediate response to a report on the industry prepared by industrialists, retailers, union officials and academics.

The report says the industry is being hit by the strong pound and overseas competition from low-labour cost suppliers, some of which receive state aid.

Mr Byers, who was wearing a South African-made suit at a students' fashion show in Northumbria, said he would take further action when a new unit within the DTI had looked at the report in detail.

The industry, which has lost more than 40,000 jobs in the past year, had a future if it built on its strengths. "Government support is essential to this process but not an exercise in propping up lame ducks."

He urged young British designers not to leave for jobs in Italy or America.

Berwin and Berwin, the suit maker which yesterday announced 160 job losses in Yorkshire, said the government package was "too little, too late".

fields.headline: Durex maker halts aid work
fields.standfirst: US contract proves unprofitable
fields.trailText: Durex condoms maker SSL International is to stop supplying contraceptives for aid projects in developing countries because the activity is insufficiently profitable.
fields.body:
Durex condoms maker SSL International is to stop supplying contraceptives for aid projects in developing countries because the activity is insufficiently profitable.

The healthcare company has put up for sale a factory in Alabama which makes 300m unbranded condoms a year for the US government to distribute in its international aid work.

The move is part of chief executive Iain Cater's strategy of concentrating on the Durex brand and shifting manufacturing to cheaper facilities in Malaysia and Thailand.

He said: "We weren't making any money out of the US factory."

Part of the problem was that under US government rules SSL had to prove it could produce double the usual annual order for condoms leading to machinery being idle.

SSL made a full-year loss of £26.5m in the 13 months to March, against a £33m profit last year, because of exceptional costs of £143m. The costs related to the group's creation last year from a merger of condoms company London International, and medical equipment and footwear specialist Seton Scholl.

Underlying sales rose 8.1% in core categories, excluding the recently sold chain of Scholl footwear shops.

Growth was driven by strong sales of surgeons' gloves - SSL makes a new type of powder-free gloves.Condom sales were up 4.3%. Most manufacturing has been shifted to Malaysia, where Mr Cater said workers were typically paid £30 to £40 a week, against £200 in Britain.
