fields.headline: Minding the pennies pays off
fields.trailText: Protecting other people's money sounds as dull as the Securicor share price has been lately. But yesterday the company showed there is cash to be made from this worthy business: especially on special occasions such as the millennium.
fields.body:
Protecting other people's money sounds as dull as the Securicor share price has been lately. But yesterday the company showed there is cash to be made from this worthy business: especially on special occasions such as the millennium.

Strong first-half figures triggered a 5% revival in Securicor's stock price.

Until now the only thing that had titillated investors since the new year was takeover speculation and that died out in early April. Securicor lost much of the glamour it did have through the sale of its stake in the Cellnet mobile phone company last autumn.

Now it is again up to Roger Wiggs, the managing director, to generate interest. He tried to do so yesterday by pointing to a myriad of opportunities. "We have lots to do with our money and we will do it," he said. Acquisitions are near the top of the agenda, with the purchase of a leading continental cash-moving company expected before the end of this week.

But management also plans to sort out other parts of the group where business has not been so positive.

In the first six months of the year group pre-tax profits rose from £14.7m to £20.4m on a like-for-like basis. Securicor celebrated by offering a second interim dividend of 0.6p per share, a 25% rise on last year.

The security guard service produced a 21% increase in profits to £24.5m but the distribution arm, halved in size since a sale to Deutsche Post last year, had profits of only £3.5m. The communications business performed better with losses cut by half to £3.9m.

Along with security acquisitions, Mr Wiggs' strategy is to bring communications into profit and to sort out the disappointing road services business. A good start has been made on distribution by bringing in John Brotherton, a former executive at rival operation Swift.

But he will not be able to tackle external problems such as a 20% fuel price increase and falling demand for retail wares.

Securicor's share price has wobbled from 190p to 117p but even at last night's 130p looked cheap for a company that seems to have stopped interesting the predators, at least for now.

The communications business performed better with losses cut by half to £3.9m. Along with security acquisitions, Mr Wiggs' strategy is to bring communications into profit and to sort out the disappointing road services business. A good start has been made on distribution by bringing in John Brotherton, a former executive at rival operation Swift. But he will not be able to tackle external problems such as a 20% fuel price increase and falling demand for retail wares. Securicor's share price has wobbled from 190p to 117p but even at last night's 130p looked cheap for a company that seems to have stopped interesting the predators, at least for now.

webTitle: Still an exotic lure for a few, for others it is paradise lost

fields.headline: Still an exotic lure for a few, for others it is paradise lost
fields.standfirst:
Commonwealth targets the military as island is partially suspended and loses vital tourist trade
The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Commonwealth targets the military as island is partially suspended and loses vital tourist trade
fields.body:
The scene at the Sheraton Fiji hotel yesterday was many people's image of paradise as a hot tropical sun beat down on a palm-fringed, white sand beach.

What was surprising was how busy it was for a resort on an island under martial law.

But this is Nadi, a three-hour drive from Suva, where there is none of the inter-racial conflict that has been a source of so much of the tension around the capital.

Holidaymakers aware of what is going on in Suva seemed unconcerned. "As far as I can make out, there's no threat to any foreigners," said David Marks from London. "The only people with guns outside the parliament are the soldiers and they are protecting us. There's been no trouble here and no one says there's going to be any."

Honeymooners Mandy and Andrew Nicklin from Yarm in Cleveland arrived in Fiji last week, a fortnight after Mr Speight seized more than 30 hostages. Their decision to come was in blatant violation of the Foreign Office's travel advice, which discourages "all but the most essential travel to Fiji" and recommends all Britons in the country, of whom there are more than 500, to leave.

The British high commissioner in Fiji, Michael Dibben, said: "We can't afford to see anyone put in harm's way. It's impossible to predict what's going to happen and we do not want to see any holidaymakers get hurt so we are erring on the side of caution."

But the Nicklins have been more affected by the coup in the Solomon Islands than events in Fiji. "We should be on our way to Vanuatu now," Andrew said. "But because of the coup in the Solomon Islands the flights have been cancelled so we've had to stay in Fiji."

They are going back for a second trip on the cruise ship they had just disembarked from. The ship, which has room for 170 passengers, has only 14 bookings.

As a result of what Andrew described as "the most gentlemanly coup I have ever come across", the economy is in freefall. Tourism, one of the three main earners of foreign currency in Fiji, is drying up.

"We should be running just about full at the moment," said Mark McWhinnie, the manager of the Sheraton Fiji. "But we're running at 30%."

Staff at the hotel have seen many other hotels close, leaving thousands of their friends and relatives unemployed.

"It is all because of Mr Speight and the people in the east," one employee said. "They are ruining our lives and those of our families.

"To begin with, the only disruption to us was the evening curfew. Now many of us have no jobs and can't afford to send our kids to school."

The situation is equally bleak in the sugar industry, one of Fiji's main exports.

To show their opposition to Mr Speight, the country's tens of thousands of farmers in the west are refusing to harvest their crop.

Yesterday was the first day in more than a week that the rebels did not talk with the military authorities, demonstrating the force of the stalemate between the two sides.

While people accept that international pressure is needed to show Mr Speight he is isolated, they are desperate for economic sanctions to be avoided and for Fiji to stay in the Commonwealth.

"If we are left alone we will have nothing," said Wasake Ratuva, a sugar cane farmer. "We will just end up slowly starving to death."

fields.headline: Softbank buys 80% Nippon Credit stake
fields.standfirst:
name
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Masayoshi Son, the president of the internet group Softbank, bounced back yesterday from a series of recent setbacks by clinching the purchase of one of Japan's most prestigious financial institutions.
fields.body:
Masayoshi Son, the president of the internet group Softbank, bounced back yesterday from a series of recent setbacks by clinching the purchase of one of Japan's most prestigious financial institutions.

After months of delays and several breakdowns in negotiations the government gave a Softbank-led consortium permission to buy an 80% stake in the Nippon Credit Bank for ¥101bn (£630m).

The purchase of NCB is a much-needed boost for Mr Son, who is having a bumpy ride on the Japanese internet rollercoaster. In recent weeks Softbank has been hit by sharply falling profits and share prices. Last Thursday itsbid for NCB was also thrown into doubt after a negotiating deadline was missed and the government said it would consider offers from rival bidders.

Yesterday, however, it was all smiles from Mr Son after his consortium - which also includes Orix, a leasing company, and the Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company - secured the deal by dropping demands for more public funds to clear up the bank's bad loans.

The government has pumped more than ¥3 trillion into NCB, which was nationalised after it went bankrupt in December 1998. It has agreed to inject another ¥240bn, while the Softbank consortium will provide ¥100bn in capital.

webTitle: Simply B2B for Jack the giant killer

fields.headline: Simply B2B for Jack the giant killer
fields.standfirst:
Fairytale rise of Chinese high school teacher behind Alibaba

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Dedicated net freaks who want to undermine big business often consider their stance a moral duty, or even a crusade. But to Jack Ma the mission to steal away the lifeblood of multinationals and ultimately marginalise them is simply part of his business.
fields.body:
Dedicated net freaks who want to undermine big business often consider their stance a moral duty, or even a crusade. But to Jack Ma the mission to steal away the lifeblood of multinationals and ultimately marginalise them is simply part of his business.

Mr Ma runs China's largest collection of business to business websites. His slight frame belies the sleeping giant who keeps US presidents awake at night.

Under the catchy umbrella Alibaba.com, Mr Ma has established an online marketplace that boasts thousands of buyers and sellers trading everything from teddy bears to computers, metals and minerals.

Buyers can sign on as members and source goods that previously they would have needed to attend a trade fair to see. Sellers can post messages when it would cost thousands of pounds to meet. "Only the big players can do this kind of thing at the moment," Mr Ma says.

He believes his site will be a treasure island for small businesses. For the first time they can afford to talk to each other rather than rely on trade from bigger firms further up the food chain. The website allows buyers and sellers to register free and there is an absence of add-on fees once they make contact or complete deals.

Mr Ma has chanelled his marketing effort at smaller firms - an untapped market, he says. He is now touring Europe to attract customers on the same basis and the OECD confirmed his view last week when it said only the US could be said to have an online business-to-business economy of any significance.

So far Mr Ma has steered clear of the US for that very reason. It is a mature market dominated by big players, he says, many of which have moved into China in a big way like IBM, Hewlett Packard and Coca Cola. It is companies like these that Alibaba is supposed to help small companies skirt round. Once they have built up business alliances through the site, the idea is that they can confront them on a more equal footing.

Mr Ma can also count on the backing of some heavyweights of his own. US investment bank Goldman Sachs and Japanese internet investor Softbank are his two biggest investors. Adding more weight, Softbank's chairman Masayoshi Son is on the Alibaba board along with Peter Sutherland, former director general of the World Trade Organisation.

Mr Ma began his business five years ago after a trip to the US convinced him the net was more exciting than teaching in high school. He witnessed the first internet connection to China when he got back and immediately began web hosting and designing. He says it was obvious that e-tailing would be slow to take off in China because of conservative consumers and the delicate sensitivities of the Chinese authorities. Business-to-business (B2B)ventures, which are actively encouraged by the government, were always likely to prove more profitable.

Five years later, however, and Alibaba.com has yet to make a bean. Mr Ma says he is careful with his investors' money, most of which goes on 100 staff to look after the site.

"The editors check all the postings," he says. "They don't polish the language, but they check everything fits the right category. For instance, companies don't qualify if they exaggerate their status. In the end we accept 1,500 out of the 2,000 postings we get every day."

That doesn't mean there is any kind of due diligence going on. Once buyers spot something they want, they contact the other party and from that point on its a standard business relationship.

The cash will begin to flow Mr Ma says, when he starts to offer add-on services like shipping and insurance to members involved in a deal. Next month he is launching a scheme that allows members to send samples via the site.

"We are targeting the $6.7 trillion market in imports and exports. At least 5% of that figure is service charges, which is where we come in."

webTitle: Synstar profits alert after trio sold shares

fields.headline: Synstar profits alert after trio sold shares
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in computer services group Synstar plummeted by 27% yesterday following a profits warning issued just two months after three senior directors reduced their holdings in the company by one third.
fields.body:
Shares in computer services group Synstar plummeted by 27% yesterday following a profits warning issued just two months after three senior directors reduced their holdings in the company by one third.

Chief executive Richard Ferre, who sold £1.8m worth of shares at 213p in March said he was deeply embarrassed after Synstar shares fell by 38.5p to an all-time low of 137p. "We didn't know this [warning] was going to happen at the time and obviously we would never have sold had we known," Mr Ferre said.

The other directors who disposed of shares were group human resources director Alan Coles and chief operating officer Steve Bolton. They reduced their holdings to around 1m shares each by selling 500,000 at 213p.

Mr Ferre blamed the profits warning on a slowdown in short-term contracts after the Y2K shutdown, a longer than expected turnaround in its Italian business and continued investment in its business continuity division which will depress margins in the short term.

Synstar now expects to make operating profits in line with last year's £12.8m. Profits of £16m had been forecast but Mr Ferre was at pains to emphasise that the underlying tenets of the business remained unchanged. "We will have lost a year going forward but next year we will be back on the growth curve," he said.

fields.headline: Mandelson yields on police reforms
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, last night announced a series of concessions designed to persuade nationalists not to boycott the reformed Northern Ireland police service.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, last night announced a series of concessions designed to persuade nationalists not to boycott the reformed Northern Ireland police service.

Nationalists have threatened to renege on a plan to put forward nominations to the proposed new police board. They are warning that the bill as published by the government, after pressure from unionists, is in danger of emasculating the original Patten proposals on the future of Northern Ireland policing. They claim the Police (Northern Ireland) bill strays at least 70 times from the proposals originally set out in Chris Patten's report.

Mr Mandelson told MPs he would be able to meet many of the concerns of the nationalists and said he had an open mind about many of their complaints, the bulk of which he insists can be met through clarifications and rewording of the bill.

If Mr Mandelson fails to secure the right balance between reform and reassurance to the unionists, the intricate peace framework could fall apart and the IRA might even renege on its commitment to open its arms dumps to independent inspection.

In the revisions announced yesterday, Mr Mandelson made it clear during the bill's second reading that the police board, the new political body to which the chief constable will be accountable, will have real powers to mount inquiries into aspects of the police service. He agreed he had set too many limitations in the bill on the board's powers to mount such inquiries.

Nevertheless, Mr Mandelson said he would still protect the police from the "risk of vexatious, repetitive or capricious behaviour" by the board.

He said the new board would have more powers than the existing police authority in terms of planning and objective setting for policing, monitoring police performance and holding the force to account.

Mr Mandelson also told MPs that the police ombudsman, due to become operational by October, would have full access to the major papers. Although her main role was to investigate individual complaints, she would be free to raise wider issues. There had been fears that the chief constable would severely restrict her access to sensitive operational papers.

Mr Mandelson made it clear that the process of trying to achieve a police service staffed equally by Roman Catholics and Protestants would not be halted after 10 years. He said: "I accept the time limit of 10 years will be unnecessary if the system is being regularly reviewed," Mr Mandelson said.

He also walked a political tightrope by saying that all police officers - serving officers and new recruits - would be required to sign up to a code of ethics that would reflect full respect for human rights.

Existing officers will not be required to swear a separate proposed new oath because this would breach their conditions of service and be unlawful under employment law.

In private, his officials also reaffirmed that all democratically elected politicians, even if they have been convicted of terrorist offences, would be allowed to serve on the board.

The Tories' Northern Ireland spokesman, Andrew Mackay, described the changes as crass and stupid. He said only a minority of a minority wanted a change in the name of the RUC.

webTitle: A dose of nastiness from doctor with no patience

fields.headline: A dose of nastiness from doctor with no patience
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: I 'm glad Alan Milburn, the health secretary, is not my consultant. He's scary. "Doctor, I've a bit of pain in my leg."
fields.body:
I 'm glad Alan Milburn, the health secretary, is not my consultant. He's scary. "Doctor, I've a bit of pain in my leg."

"Pinn in yir lig? Ah'll show ye what a pinn in yir lig is abou'," followed by a savage kick to the thigh. He is very aggressive. He seems to think that the best way of sorting out the NHS's problems is to abuse the Tories, and when they abuse him, shout back even louder. The Hippocratic oath is possibly the only oath he doesn't use.

The first who thought he was hard enough was David Amess, who used to be Tory MP for Basildon, and would offer extravagant praise to the voters of that town up to the moment he realised that they were about to throw him out, when he shifted to Southend where, miraculously, it turns out that the voters are blessed with even more pluck, wisdom and plain British common sense than those of Basildon.

He asked about the weird and confused NHS consultation exercise, and decided to end on a Cromwellian note - as ever, a mistake. "What would make the NHS better for people and their families would be for you and this rotten government to go !"

But with his floppy hair and air of an injured basset, Mr Amess resembles a schoolboy shouting pathetically at the bully who has just nicked his football.

Mr Milburn jeered back: "You thought so much about the opinions of the people of Basildon that you went off to Southend!" he yelled.

A Labour MP asked a patball question. "The Tories didn't consult patients, doctors, or nurses. They did consult the Adam Smith Institute!" Mr Milburn barked, referring to the thinktank that would happily privatise the army, the church and our beloved, still public sector, Queen.

Liam Fox, the Tory spokesman, tried to be as cross as Mr Milburn. Fat chance. No one could be. The consultation leaflets were badly distributed. One GP had been sent six; another, with only 1,200 patients, had been sent 2,500 to dish out.

"You shouldn't be coy about this, but we're told the prime minister has spent six hours a day thinking about these things. Will you take all the credit for this fiasco, or will you be sharing it with him?"

Mr Milburn snarled, furiously. "Kipp tekking the midicine, is my advice!"

"A pathetic excuse, all spin and no substance," Mr Fox replied. "Who will carry the can for this absurd and pathetic fiasco?" he inquired once again. But Mr Fox is too nice, too amiable, a smooth man who is, perhaps, more at home drinking cocktails in trendy bars with Australian soubrettes. Mr Milburn, by contrast, has metaphorical tattoos all over his political credentials. He squared up to his opponent, possibly about to inform him that he knew where he lived.

He launched into a tendentious account of the government's achievements in the field of health. Abolition of the internal market, "which your party opposed"; primary care groups, which the same party had opposed; reduction of the waiting lists, which the Tories opposed; the biggest hospital building programme in the history of the NHS, "which your party opposed".

Steady on, I thought. They didn't actually oppose these things, merely questioned their miraculous provenance. What next? "The cure for cancer, pioneered by New Libber, opposed by the Tories. The resurrection of the dead, fought tooth and nail by the party opposite ..."?

Gordon Marsden, the thoughtful Labour MP, mentioned "diet and lifestyle challenges", which is a bit hopeful coming from the member for Blackpool, a city which in my long experience presents one vast, permanent, ongoing diet and lifestyle challenge.

Abolition of the internal market, "which your party opposed"; primary care groups, which the same party had opposed; reduction of the waiting lists, which the Tories opposed; the biggest hospital building programme in the history of the NHS, "which your party opposed". Steady on, I thought. They didn't actually oppose these things, merely questioned their miraculous provenance. What next? "The cure for cancer, pioneered by New Libber, opposed by the Tories. The resurrection of the dead, fought tooth and nail by the party opposite ..."? Gordon Marsden, the thoughtful Labour MP, mentioned "diet and lifestyle challenges", which is a bit hopeful coming from the member for Blackpool, a city which in my long experience presents one vast, permanent, ongoing diet and lifestyle challenge.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Euro reaches new dollar high

The euro reached a seven-week high against the dollar after strong data from the euro zone convinced traders that interest rates in the single currency area are likely to rise this week. The euro rocketed higher on early trading in New York, bursting through 96cents against the dollar at one point - a rise of more than a cent on the day.
fields.body:
Euro reaches new dollar high

The euro reached a seven-week high against the dollar after strong data from the euro zone convinced traders that interest rates in the single currency area are likely to rise this week. The euro rocketed higher on early trading in New York, bursting through 96cents against the dollar at one point - a rise of more than a cent on the day.

Analysts said euro's recovery, which began two weeks ago, hinged on a string of weak data from the US which convinced some traders that US borrowing rates could stay on hold this month.

"People are thinking the US may be near the end of its interest cycle while Europe remains in the middle of its," said Eric Nickerson, chief currency strategist at Bank of America.

World Bank in Chad oil row
The World Bank's executive board, meeting in Washington, yesterday approved loans worth around $200m in support of a new oil pipeline between Chad and Cameroon despite objections from environmentalists. The project, which is expected to cost $3.7bn (£2.4bn), will be run by a private sector consortium led by US group ExxonMobil.

Nationwide profits up 4%
Nationwide Building Society edged up profits by 4% to £423.7m in the year to April 4 - compared with double-digit gains at rival high street banks.

But the mutual savings and mortgage group says the moderate rise was because it paid out £370m in "members' benefits" - that is, lower borrowing rates and higher savings returns - compared with £305m last year.

SmithKline poison threat
Drugs firm SmithKline Beecham has been targeted in Australia by an extortionist threatening to put poison in its Panadol painkiller capsules. The threat, received on Wednesday, has prompted the group to withdraw the product in Australia. Several million pounds' worth of the headache medicine is likely to be destroyed.

Panadol is a big seller in Australia: the company is believed to sell up to £5m of capsules a year. SmithKline's total sales in Australia amount to about £150m a year.

US bank faces sex bias charge
US investment bank Morgan Stanley has been accused of sexual discrimination in a judgment that could lead to settlement costs of several million dollars.

The US equal employment opportunity commission criticised the bank after finding in favour of Allison Schieffelin, a senior female broker, and other women who argued that they were passed over for promotion and paid less than their male counterparts.

webTitle: Cook calls for boycott of war zone diamonds

fields.headline: Cook calls for boycott of war zone diamonds
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Britain yesterday called for an international embargo on the sale of Sierra Leone diamonds, which has fuelled the civil war in the west African country by enabling the rebels to build up their arsenal of weapons.
fields.body:
Britain yesterday called for an international embargo on the sale of Sierra Leone diamonds, which has fuelled the civil war in the west African country by enabling the rebels to build up their arsenal of weapons.

The ambitious proposal was announced in the Commons by Robin Cook, who also told MPs that most British troops will leave Sierra Leone next week after achieving the short-term aim of securing Lungi airport to allow a build-up of UN peacekeepers.

The foreign secretary, who is to have talks with President Ahmed Kabbah in Freetown tomorow, wants a UN resolution banning the trade in diamonds from Sierre Leone "except where they are certified as legitimate by the government".

Foreign Office officials conceded yesterday that an embargo on smuggled diamonds would be difficult to police and require the voluntary cooperation of bankers, brokers and buyers in the world's three main diamond centres -Antwerp, Tel Aviv, and Bombay - as well as de Beers, which manages the world's biggest market for rough diamonds from London.

It will also require the cooperation of Charles Taylor, the president of Liberia, who has been supplying arms to Sierra Leone's rebel Revolutionary United Front in return for diamonds. The United States has been pressing Mr Taylor to stop the trade without success.

Of an estimated $70m worth of diamonds exported from Sierra Leone last year, just $1.5m were "legitimate", according to industry sources.

One proposal, FO officials said yesterday, was for the Sierra Leone government to seal official diamond exports in forge-proof sealed packages. They took comfort from a similar scheme in Angola, where diamonds have funded Unita rebels.

In Sierra Leone, the rebel RUF still controls the diamond mines in the east of the country neighbouring Liberia. The objective, Mr Cook said yesterday, was to bring the diamond area under the control of government and UN troops.

"Diamonds have fuelled this war. And the people of Sierra Leone remains among the world's poorest while the wealth of its diamonds goes to rebels", Mr Cook added.

The foreign secretary described a "much improved" security situation in Sierra Leone with all 500 UN personnel seized by the rebels released and the RUF leader, Foday Sankoh, in custody. He shed no light on the whereabouts of the British UN adviser Major Andrew Harrison and the aid worker Alan Smith.

Mr Cook said 600 Royal Marines would leave Sierra Leone next week. However, the Ministry of Defence yesterday announced a new deployment of British troops to Sierra Leone: 180 soldiers from the Royal Anglian regiment will train 1,000 raw recruits to the Sierra Leone army in a camp at Benguema, 25 miles south-east of Freetown.

A British-led 90-strong military training team will not be fully in place until the end of the year, the MoD said.

fields.headline: Danger signals
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

"The wild deer, wand'ring here and there/Keeps the Human Soul from Care," wrote William Blake. Two young deer step from the hedge where it corners away from the woods. They stand, heads and ears up, their sides dappled with spots like flecks of sunlight. But it's a grey, mizzly day - a wet mist pattering through leaves, spraying across the open fields, soaking. Visibility is down to a mile or two at best. The landscape, fluid and hazy, is like a greenhouse with the sprinklers on.

The deer are watchful, sensing everything. Their sight, scent and hearing get more intense until all that stimulus boils into the red and the world suddenly becomes too potentially dangerous to hang around any longer. With a regal swing of head and lift of chin the deer take off - straight into a field of oil-seed rape. They plunge into the field, stand and watch again.

The crop finished flowering weeks ago and is now setting its pylons of thin green seed pods. The leaves are towards the base of each plant: it's only the chlorophyll in the pods and stems that really feeds these plants. This wet green mass is only occasionally broken by a splash of scarlet, as a few lone poppies struggle through the rape canopy - survivors of seeds maybe decades old, cast when these fields blazed with them. Oil-seed rape fields are becoming increasingly barren and anything but the crop is herbicided-out. Is this one of those rogue GM seed fields? My own danger signals register now.

The deer, almost completely submerged in the rape, turn and bound through the field. If they kept their heads down they could cross the field invisibly. But no. They leap above the crop, crashing through it towards the wood at the far end. Their white striped backsides and black tails must shout "chase me" to such predators as the wolf: for animals that blend in so well with their surroundings it seems daft that they should advertise their vulnerability in retreat. Still, Blake is right. The wild deer do keep the soul from care - and it lifts my spirits to think how much damage they are doing to this ugly crop.

webTitle: Security fear over invasion by fans

fields.headline: Security fear over invasion by fans
fields.trailText: Security fears surrounding Euro 2000 increased yesterday when it was estimated that up to 50,000 England fans - 40,000 of them without tickets - could descend on the small Belgian town of Charleroi for the game against Germany a week on Saturday.
fields.body:
Security fears surrounding Euro 2000 increased yesterday when it was estimated that up to 50,000 England fans - 40,000 of them without tickets - could descend on the small Belgian town of Charleroi for the game against Germany a week on Saturday.

Such numbers would threaten segregation and cause massive headaches for the police at a game that has already been pinpointed as the most likely flashpoint for English hooligans to cause trouble - and at a small ground that has been criticised as unsafe.

The National Criminal Intelligence Service has informed Belgian and Dutch authorities that about 1,000 known hooligans could be making for the competition, which begins on Saturday. This includes 416 people banned by courts from attending games in the UK.

The ease with which English fans can travel to Belgium has fuelled fears that thousands will travel to the match in the hope of buying black-market tickets.

Official FA travel club supporters have received the bulk of England's ticket allocation for the game with Germany on June 17, just under 5,000 - 16% of the 30,000 capacity at the Charleroi ground.

It is estimated that another 2,000 tickets have been sold via the internet or postal applications to people giving British addresses.

fields.headline: Fiji penalised by foreign ministers
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Commonwealth foreign ministers punished Fiji yesterday with a partial suspension from the organisation as the hostage standoff after the seizure of the ethnic Indian prime minister moved towards the end of its third week.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele , and  John Aglionby in Suva
fields.body:
Commonwealth foreign ministers punished Fiji yesterday with a partial suspension from the organisation as the hostage standoff after the seizure of the ethnic Indian prime minister moved towards the end of its third week. It also decided to send an urgent mission to the islands to press for a timetable for a return to democracy.

The action against Fiji was less than the full suspension Nigeria received some years ago but similar to the move against Pakistan when an army coup overthrew its elected government last year.

Describing the moves as a "loud and clear signal", Britain's John Battle, a junior Foreign Office minister, emphasised that they were directed mainly at Fiji's army commander, Commodore Frank Bainimarama, for giving in to the hostage-takers' demands by imposing martial law and suspending the island's constitution.

"This is not the right way to act with hostage-takers," he said after an emergency meeting of the Commonwealth's ministerial action group in London. The Commonwealth had no option but to suspend Fiji after martial law was declared and the constitution was abrogated, he argued.

But a spokesman for the commodore said: "We are very disappointed by this announcement. The republic of Fiji military forces only took executive control and declared martial law with the greatest reluctance. It is not us who staged the coup . We are working as hard and quickly as we can to restore stability and normalcy."

The ministers decided not to take any economic or trade sanctions against Fiji. Alexander Downer, the Australian foreign minister, said that to bring pressure on the military, his country would implement a range of diplomatic sanctions as soon as the hostages were released by George Speight, who is holding them in Fiji's parliament building.

Mr Downer, who will be on the Commonwealth mission to the island, said: "To impose significant economic sanctions would destroy Fiji's economy. The islands would take years and years to rebuild and the people who would suffer wouldn't be the organisers of the civil coup but ordinary people." Australia is Fiji's largest trading partner.

The Commonwealth ministers took some comfort from the fact that the military appears to be gaining the upper hand over Mr Speight and his men. Three officers, including a colonel, who were with Mr Speight, defected back to barracks yesterday after Cdre Bainimarama threatened to withdraw their commissions.

Timoci Silatoliu, one of Mr Speight's advisers, reacted angrily to the Commonwealth action. "This is another form of blackmail," he said. "They're not looking at the problem of the indigenous people. They're looking at it from a different perspective, from their own western perspective. They're just being unfair. Everyone is trying to blackmail the indigenous Fijian people.

"What you have to realise is that this is a problem about Indian domination in Fiji. No one seems to understand that this is a problem that we have to sort out internally."

fields.headline: Now wash your hands
fields.standfirst:
The new independent food standards agency will have to resist pressure from politicians if it is to satisfy consumers' demands

What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: The new independent food standards agency will have to resist pressure from politicians if it is to satisfy consumers' demands
fields.body:
The public is cynical about the pursuit of profits by the food industry and has a low opinion of the competence and openness of politicians over food. So says research commissioned by the new independent food standards agency.

This is only to be expected after a string of crises - listeria in cheese, salmonella in eggs, BSE and now genetic modification - in which the government has failed to give any impression of management or regulatory supervision. After all, distrust of the UK agriculture ministries, especially the English one, lay behind Tony Blair's decision to create the new agency in the first place.

Yet the same research shows that people do have confidence in food they eat. They trust the supermarkets more than small shopkeepers, discount stores or markets. The public perception is that people do not generally fall ill and that the regulatory system works.

At the same time, the research, by Cragg Ross Dawson, reveals concerns about the factory farm conditions in which poultry are raised, the content of animal feed for other livestock and the effect of pesticides and chemicals on fruit and vegetables. "The big retailers and established brands are widely trusted, yet people feel many of their anxieties are a consequence of the industrialisation of farming and commercialisation of food distribution."

In other words, the messages are mixed. This ambiguity would be challenge enough for the agency, which has now been in existence for two months. More worrying is the evidence from group discussions just weeks before it began of widespread suspicion about how it will work. "The success of the agency will be judged by many on the impossibly challenging criterion of how many food scares have been averted."

The new agency has been busy. It announced compulsory licensing of butchers, launched a review of labelling standards and declared its readiness to "name and shame" companies which fail to meet those standards. Its board meetings are being held in public, and there are numerous forums planned where the public's worries can be aired. Its chairman, Sir John Krebs, and deputy chairwoman, Suzi Leather, are travelling the country to demonstrate their openness.

Would such energy had been shown when it emerged that farmers had unwittingly planted conventional rapeseed contaminated with GM material. The Cabinet Office, responsible for GM policy and presentation, quickly fled the scene, leaving the flak to be taken once more by the poor old Ministry of Agriculture (MAFF), although the Department of the Environment and the Environment Agency have not been above criticism here.

The food safety agency found out about the mistake weeks after MAFF was informed by the company involved and quickly cleared the crop. It behaved like any old government advisory body. Sir John did warn that consumers needed to have confidence in products described as coming from GM-free sources. But as head of an independent body he ought to have gone in far harder for the poor consumer. One hopes that behind the scenes he was a lot more cross. In future he will need to be more "political" with politicians who will blame future failures of food policy on his agency.

It faces other tests, not least the food industry's reaction to its wish for new codes on television advertising of junk food and on labelling - claims such as "country-style" or "fat-free". The government wants less red tape, more self-policing; Sir John and colleagues do not think such arrangements have been totally successful.

How statistics are used and risks managed are among the agency's other tough assignments. Food poisoning figures, for instance, are notoriously unreliable - we cannot be sure how real is the reported increase. Salmonella infections, now apparently under control thanks to improvements in poultry rearing, may be more than twice as prevalent as reported. And campylobacter, a more worrying problem, may be nearly eight times worse than reported figures show. Food poisoning is officially "any disease of an infectious or toxic nature caused by or thought to be caused by consumption of food or water", an incredibly wide definition that could include cases of the human form of BSE.

A row similar to that over beef on the bone may soon erupt over E coli 0157, the vicious bug that can kill children, elderly people and those with weak immune systems. Scientists are worried at the number of outbreaks connected with land recently used for pasturing animals. Some have even suggested bans on rock concerts, fairs, markets, picnics or scout camps on such land, which can harbour the bug for months. Should young children be stopped from going on farm visits? Though often food-borne, E coli may spread without food being involved at all. A hand that touched animals, their dung or even simply soil might be enough. Should the food agency get involved? Perhaps public health warnings by event organisers and more washing facilities (imposing a cost that could scupper events anyway) will be enough.

The agency's success depends on how it resolves such issues. As Suzi Leather put it last week: "We have to get across the message that science progresses through disagreement. If no one challenges anything, we don't move forward. We have to be prepared to say 'We don't know'."

James Meikle is our agriculture correspondent. james.meikle@theguardian.com

webTitle: He only wanted to end his wife's pain. He ended up in court, at 84

fields.headline: He only wanted to end his wife's pain. He ended up in court, at 84
fields.trailText: Raymond and May Bouldstridge would have celebrated their diamond wedding anniversary in a fortnight. Instead, Mr Bouldstridge, 84, will spend Thursday June 22 alone, contemplating not only the death of his wife, but the failed mercy killing that led to his conviction for her attempted murder.
fields.body:
Raymond and May Bouldstridge would have celebrated their diamond wedding anniversary in a fortnight. Instead, Mr Bouldstridge, 84, will spend Thursday June 22 alone, contemplating not only the death of his wife, but the failed mercy killing that led to his conviction for her attempted murder.

Yesterday Mr Bouldstridge, of Milford-on-Sea, Hampshire, was sentenced to a year's probation at Winchester crown court after pleading guilty to a charge that the judge, Mr Justice Turner, said should never have been brought.

The court heard that for the last six years of her life Mrs Bouldstridge had suffered from Alzheimer's disease, gradually deteriorating to the point where, doubly incontinent and completely immobile, she required assistance from two carers three times a day, seven days a week.

In March, however, Mr Bouldstridge said Hampshire social services told him that unless he had a hoist installed to help lift his wife, her carers would be withdrawn.

His fear that she would be left without sufficient care was "the straw that broke the camel's back", according to his solicitor, David Lawrence.

Distraught with anxiety and "out of his mind", Mr Bouldstridge decided to end his wife's suffering and his own. Attaching a hose to the exhaust of his car, he started the engine, jammed the accelerator open with a small cane, led the other end of the hose into the couple's bedroom and lay down beside his wife to die.

The couple only survived because a neighbour, hearing the car engine running, followed the hosepipe and found the couple still breathing.

Beside them on the bed was a typed note in which Mr Bouldstridge blamed a social worker and the owner of a private care company for his actions. He wrote: "They are responsible for our deaths and are two of the most evil people I have encountered in recent years. I was warned services might be withdrawn.

"Between them these two evil people deemed my darling wife should be left unattended," the note said.

Mrs Bouldstridge was admitted to a care home where, a month after the incident, she died of an unrelated chest infection. Mr Bouldstridge was arrested and charged on his release from hospital, and told police that the threat from social services had driven him to attempt to kill his wife and himself.

On Saturday March 11, Mrs Bouldstridge's carers refused to lift her manually, leaving him unable to feed or clean his wife.

"I broke down and was distraught with anxiety. I thought I just cannot stand it any more and that's why it happened. I bitterly regret it now, but it overwhelmed me," Mr Bouldstridge told police.

Christopher Parker, defending, said: "There was in what he did not a shred of malice directed towards his wife. He could not bear to see her suffering and he could not bear to live without her."

Mr Justice Turner condemned the crown prosecution service's decision to bring a case that was not in the public interest, and accused the CPS of seeking refuge in legalese when trying to explain its decision to prosecute.

He told Mr Bouldstridge: "I am quite satisfied that you are a victim of cruel and long-standing circumstances. You found yourself at your wits' end, and did something which was morally indefensible although humanly very understandable. I am quite satisfied that you do not merit punishment in any form for what you did. You punished yourself by what you did. I am putting you on probation for you to re-establish yourself and get used to life without your wife who had been your constant companion."

The decision to prosecute was condemned by Harry Cayton, chief executive of the Alzheimer's Society.

"[This case] highlights the extreme stress that people with care responsibilities experience, and that social services clearly have not got the level of service right." Mr Cayton said the Alzheimer's Society would be supporting a complaint by Mr Bouldstridge against the social services.

The CPS defended the decision to prosecute, and confirmed that the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, had been consulted about the decision.

"Attempted murder is a serious offence to which Mr Bouldstridge pleaded guilty and there was evidence that showed the offence was premeditated. Sentencing is properly at the discretion of the judge," said a spokesman. Referring to Mr Justice Turner's criticism of the decision to prosecute, the spokesman said he was entitled to his opinion.

A spokesman for Hampshire social services said they regretted the decision to prosecute and were saddened by the circumstances that led to the case, but rejected criticism of individual care workers.

webTitle: How to fix the consultants: give them all a socking rise

fields.headline: How to fix the consultants: give them all a socking rise
fields.standfirst:
The plan is to buy them out of private practice. It could actually work

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The plan is to buy them out of private practice - to separate the NHS from the private sector. It could actually work
fields.body:
The hawks and doves are fighting it out inside the government and the Department of Health. Is there to be all-out war against the God-like consultants, locking horns with the monarchs of the wards? Or is it to be peace, emollience and sweet inducements? The BMA and the Royal Colleges have been outraged by some of the language Milburn, Blair and others have used. But they don't know if it's for real. Indeed the government itself hasn't decided.

Some want a fight. They want consultants under managers' thumbs and properly accounting for every hour of their day. Calmer, wiser heads point to the dismal record of governments who have tried to take on the doctors in the past. Voters always side with doctors (top of the popularity league) against politicians (bottom, alongside journalists). However outrageous the doctors' protection of their Spanish practices, they always make it look as if wicked politicians and managers are "damaging patient care" if anyone lays a finger on their fiefdom. Barbara Castle ran at them headlong - and was trounced. Kenneth Clarke can hardly have felt himself a winner. In an election year, who wants to risk it?

But remarkably radical ideas are in the air. Here is just one startling scheme. It is being hotly debated within the national plan committees and it is hinted at every time Blair or Milburn talk darkly of "perverse incentives" in the system. They are referring to surgeons' perverse incentive to keep their own waiting lists long, deliberately fuelling demand for their private practice. Even the head of the Royal College of Surgeons admitted to me that some consultants "do capitalise on the length of their waiting lists". So the radical idea is to separate the NHS from the private sector for the first time since Bevan was forced to give in on the issue.

All NHS consultants would be barred from doing private practice and would have to choose between the two. They would have to give all their time unequivocally to their NHS work, or leave it altogether. It sounds draconian and terrifyingly socialist. Can this really be the Third Way? But the surprising answer insiders are coming up with is that it could and should be done. Most important of all, and what makes it a Third Way answer, is that it could be done without declaring war on the doctors. It could gain the overwhelming support of most consultants - at a cost.

Here's the plan. Only 6,000 out of the 21,000 NHS consultants have any private practice at all, or any prospect of any. Many of those 6,000 have only a little private work on the side: a smallish handful of big players do a vast quantity. The radical idea is to offer a large salary increase - somewhere between £20,000 and £30,000 - to buy consultants out of their private practice altogether. The argument inside the department is between some parsimonious officials who think the money could be paid just to surgeons and anaesthetists (98% of surgeons have some private practice). But that would be a recipe for full-scale war - and rightly too. Why should the psycho-geriatricians and other Cinderellas with no private practice lose out yet again to the glamorous specialisms? Peter Hawker, head of the consultants committee of the BMA, warns the resentment would be so deep it would spill out onto the wards. "Insane," he rightly says.

No, buying out the consultants has to mean all of them - fat and thin cats alike. Bevan complained about having to stuff their mouths with gold. But by present day standards NHS consultants are not highly paid. The maximum basic salary for an NHS consultant is £63,000, not a fortune considering how hard most work and 10 years of gruelling training. (If the national plan does all it promises, many will be working a lot harder, too.) Some super headteachers now command £70,000 for less training: it's time the public sector, from top talent down to minimum wage, rewarded its people better.

However, some fat cat surgeons threaten that many will walk away from the NHS, as they earn so much more outside it. Waiting lists would soar, despite Milburn's promise of many more con sultants. But could the surgeons walk out? It's an extraordinary sign of the changing times that Barry Jackson, president of the mighty Royal College of Surgeons, does not put himself into immediate opposition to these plans.

Not long ago the college would have exploded with fury. Quite the contrary. It is Jackson himself who points out that any surgeons who abandoned the NHS would find themselves with slim pickings. "I've known many surgeons with excellent private practices take early retirement and expect to continue with their private work. But once they've left the NHS, it dries up quickly and many have been very disappointed men. GPs soon stop referring patients to surgeons not attached to a good NHS hospital."

Peter Hawker, the consultants' trade union leader at the BMA, does not reject the idea either. "I keep hearing about it, but it hasn't been put to us yet. We'd be happy to talk to the government about it," he says. After all, the vast majority of consultants would gain hugely, and only a tiny minority would lose out.

It could be done. Paying £30,000 to all 21,000 consultants would cost £630m - well worth the money. Some officials say that if the national plan succeeds in abolishing all waiting lists in the NHS for ever, private practice will wither away anyway, so why bother to buy the doctors out? But others say the waiting list problem will never be solved until there is absolute separation of private practice from NHS work. The perverse incentive for surgeons to keep their lists long is just too great.

If the government is considering fairness and equal opportunity, demolishing private practice within the NHS would be a good signal to send out. David Hinchcliffe, chair of the commons health select committee, says what upsets patients languishing on long waiting lists is being told they could be operated on by the same man in the same hospital tomorrow, if they have a few thousand pounds.

The select committee is about to launch a raucous and vigorous investigation of the consultants' NHS contract - which is in mid-renegotiation. Hinchcliffe is likely to push for all manner of punitive actions against any "arrogant", "God-like", "king" consultants found lining their pockets while doing less than they might for the NHS. His very old Labour blast will strengthen the government's arm as it proposes many radical changes to the way doctors and nurses work.

Blair and Milburn may yet surprise party critics by being the first Labour government to succeed where Bevan failed. Barbara Castle tried to drive private beds out of the NHS by force and she failed disastrously. Now there's the money to do it, buying out private practice could succeed where brute force failed. The great majority of consultants are likely to welcome it with open arms.

webTitle: Young 'losing faith in NHS' says minister

fields.headline: Young 'losing faith in NHS' says minister
fields.standfirst:
Milburn tells Labour supporters to face up to health changes

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Labour party members were told yesterday to support ministers' plans for radical reform of the National Health Service or watch its popularity sink beyond redemption.
fields.body:
Labour party members were told yesterday to support ministers' plans for radical reform of the National Health Service or watch its popularity sink beyond redemption.

In a stark warning of the high political stakes in play, Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said the alternative to his modernisation strategy was a Conservative plan to make the NHS a safety net service available for life threatening conditions only.

He published figures presented to a Downing Street health summit on Monday showing the UK health service was markedly more popular than counterparts in the US, Canada, Australia and NewZealand.

But he warned that this support for the NHS could not be taken for granted. According to recent surveys, only a third of people aged 18-34 were satisfied with the NHS, compared to over 50% of people over 55.

"It is already clear the younger people are, the more fragile their belief. The NHS has to earn the support of each new generation ... If we fail to do that now, in this generation, with this scale of resources, we would face the very real prospect of losing the faith of the public and thereby losing the NHS as a service for all, paid for by all."

Mr Milburn was addressing a conference in London as his department released the latest waiting list statistics, showing a slight lengthening of the queue.

At the end of April 1,054,000 patients were waiting for NHS treatment in England - 16,600 higher than the figure for March. Departmental sources said the rise was seasonal.

Mr Milburn used his speech to brace his party and the health trade unions for radical change in the service, saying:

"It is no longer enough for the Labour party to believe that because we created the NHS, and believe so passionately in its principles, that it is always necessary for us to defend its practices.

"Perhaps too often in the past the very pride we take in the NHS has prevented us from exposing its weaknesses as much as we have praised its strengths.

"Make no mistake about it, today's Conservative party is waiting in the wings, ready if it ever had the chance, to abandon the principles of the NHS altogether in favour of a reduced safety net service, available for life threatening conditions only, with patients suffereing less urgent conditions forced to go private."

Mr Milburn said reform of the NHS was "a much bigger task than at first we realised". Government intervention would be required to raise standards, but "as modernisation takes greater hold, so devolution will take greater hold. I recognise that government will increasingly have to let go."

A departmental source said this would mean greater discretion for front-line providers rather than any new intermediate tier of control at regional or local level.

The speech included the first public statement of the government's plan to loosen local authorities' grip on social services.

"We need to examine the advantages an integrated health and social care organisation might bring for patients," Mr Milburn said.

The national plan for health to be published next month would include plans for primary care trusts providing the whole range of health and social care for older people.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Turkish quake kills three
fields.body:
Turkish quake kills three

An earthquake registering 5.9 on the Richter scale shook central Turkey yesterday, killing at least three people, injuring more than 50 and sending thousands onto the streets in panic.

The earthquake's epicentre was in Cerkes, about 60 miles north of Ankara. The earthquake struck at 5.40am local time. It was followed by nine after shocks, the strongest measuring 4.5. AP, Ankara

Doomsday cult leader gets life

The doomsday cult leader Yoshihiro Inoue, 30, was sentenced to life in prison yesterday for the 1995 nerve gas attack on the Tokyo underground that killed 12 people and injured thousands.

He was one of five Aum Shinrikyo members accused of being directly involved in the Sarin gas attack during the morning rush hour. The prosecution had asked for the death penalty and called the ruling unexpected. AP, Tokyo

Commonwealth adviser quits

A senior Commonwealth adviser, Moses Anafu, said yesterday he was resigning following allegations that he had close business links with Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe. He denied the allegations but said he was stepping down as the group's special adviser on Africa. Reuters, London

School children on the rampage

Kenyan school children as young as five went on a "drunken" rampage, looting shops, burning a vehicle and consuming the contents of a beer lorry after one of their friends was killed by a minibus.

Hundreds of children barricaded roads and pelted traders and vehicles with stones on Monday after the nine-year-old pupil was run over. Reuters, Nairobi

Rebuff for gun theme shop

New York's city council has urged the National Rifle Association not to open a theme shop and restaurant in Times Square.

The NRA is currently negotiating leasing space. The shop will offer virtual-reality shooting, outdoor clothing and hunting accessories. There are no plans for the shop to sell guns. AP, New York

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers. The trade and industry secretary was caught out wearing a South African-made two piece suit while   announcing aid to the textile industry.
fields.body:
Bad day

Stephen Byers. The trade and industry secretary was caught out wearing a South African-made two piece suit while announcing aid to the textile industry.

Review of day

Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor, revealed what he called a value for money review of lodgings used by judges, which last year cost nearly £5m. The report, due in July, will compare "value for money provided by lodgings ... with alternative forms of accommodation providing appropriate standards of security, privacy and comfort."

Today

Commons: International development questions. PM's questions.

Westminster Hall: Backbench debates include civil war in Sri Lanka and merger of the London stock exchange and the Deutsche Bosse.

Lords: Debates on additional housing in London and south east, problems caused by coastal erosion, and UK relations with Russia.

fields.headline: Neill warns mayor on lobbyists ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's campaign promise to bar staff at the new Greater London authority (GLA) from face-to-face meetings with professional lobbyists would be unfair in practice, according to the standards watchdog, Lord Neill.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's campaign promise to bar staff at the new Greater London authority (GLA) from face-to-face meetings with professional lobbyists would be unfair in practice, according to the standards watchdog, Lord Neill.

In his manifesto, the mayor of London took a strong line against access to GLA staff or assembly members for the kind of lobbyist widely blamed for bringing Parliament into disrepute during the "cash for questions" controversies of the Tory years.

But in a letter to the lobbyists' organisations, Lord Neill, chairman of the independent committee on standards in public life, concedes that it would be wrong to exclude lobbyists when other bodies - including charities and single issue pressure groups - retain access to elected members.

"It is very difficult to define a lobbyist in exact terms and the rules governing contacts between those in government and outside bodies should be framed accordingly to avoid unfairness," Lord Neill wrote.

Mr Livingstone, who is putting together his team and policies during a two-month transition before full powers are granted him on July 3, has called for the GLA to be "open and transparent" - a policy since endorsed by the two lobbyist groups, the Association of Professional Political Consultants (APPC) and the Public Relations Consultants Association (PRCA).

In their letter to Mr Living stone before the election the two groups' chairmen, Michael Burrell of the APPC and the PRCA's Simon Nayyer, say they are "deeply troubled by your suggestion that lobbyists should not be allowed to meet GLA staff".

But they do agree with the London mayor's insistence that lobbyists should not be granted passes which would give them access to the authority's HQ - currently in Romey House, Westminster - as happens when MPs sometimes give researchers passes to pressure group and other campaign staffers.

"We seek no special privileges for our members," say the lobbyists whose members are already forbidden - by mutual agreement - from having access to the Welsh assembly and Scottish parliament other than what is granted to members of the public and other campaigners.

Last night a spokesman for the mayor said that Mr Livingstone has been quizzed on the issue at his first public question time last month. He replied that he remains "opposed to meeting commercial lobbyists" but said he may adopt the Commons code on the issue.

That code controls what MPs can do for lobbyists and other outside interests.

But it also confirms Lord Neill's sixth report which admitted that it would be hard to define or regulate lobbyists as a group.

webTitle: Lifers get chance of sentence reviews

fields.headline: Lifers get chance of sentence reviews
fields.trailText: The hopes of more than 3,000 prisoners sentenced to life, including 26 of Britain's most notorious killers who have been told they will never be released, were raised yesterday after the new lord chief justice signalled they would probably be able to launch fresh challenges against their sentences from this autumn.
fields.body:
The hopes of more than 3,000 prisoners sentenced to life, including 26 of Britain's most notorious killers who have been told they will never be released, were raised yesterday after the new lord chief justice signalled they would probably be able to launch fresh challenges against their sentences from this autumn.

Lord Woolf of Barnes, after being sworn in as the lord chief justice, said he now thought it was inevitable that the role of the home secretary in the setting the terms of criminals sentenced to mandatory life would eventually be transferred to the judiciary.

He said that it was likely that a test case would be brought after the European convention on human rights was incorporated into British law in October which would challenge the right of the home secretary to set the sentences of all 3,400 mandatory life prisoners, including the 26 who have been told that in their cases "life must mean life".

"I do think that it is inevitable that the task in relation to mandatory life sen tences is going to be transferred to the judiciary," said Lord Woolf. "That approach is dictated by the standards expected under the European convention."

The role of the home secretary in setting the term that the Bulger killers must serve has already been declared illegal under the European convention by the Strasbourg court as has his role in setting the sentences of discretionary lifers and Lord Woolf anticipated yesterday that a similar decision is likely in the case of "mandatory lifers".

It would mean that the judges might be asked to reconsider the sentences in all cases where the home secretary set a different tariff than that recommended by the lord chief justice.

Lord Woolf made clear that it would be for the court to decide "on a question of law" at that point whether it was wrong for the home secretary to be involved in such decisions but while his answer was not "on the legal question", it was his view about what was generally likely to happen.

Lord Woolf also went on to raise the hopes of Britain's most notorious killers, including Myra Hindley and Rose West, when he outlined his personal reservations about the use of "life must mean life" sentences imposed for the first time by Michael Howard and then Jack Straw which meant that such prisoners will never be released.

Lord Woolf, who has a reputation as a liberal reformer, said that the range of murders committed was extraordinarily wide. "I have reservations about saying, in advance without being given a particular case, that any case is so lacking in aspects of redemption that one can anticipate that throughout the natural life of the individual concerned it will never, ever be proper to release them.

"I do not think that anybody should take the view that at the minimum they will never, ever be released because so many things can happen that you cannot anticipate," he said.

Lord Woolf also confirmed that the family of the murdered child, James Bulger, would be consulted before he took the decision on how much longer his killers, Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, should serve before they were released.

He said that the director of public prosecutions would report to him on the views of James Bulger's parents and responses on behalf of Thompson and Venables would also be taken before he makes a final decision. He said that he did not think it was necessary for these representations to be heard in public.

But the lord chief justice did say, for the first time, that he would announce the decision, which is expected within the next two months, and his reasons for it, in public and in open court.

He is expected to follow the same procedure as he considers the backlog of 140 other juvenile cases whose sentences are also to be reviewed as a result of the Strasbourg court ruling last December that it was wrong for a politician to be involved in deciding how long they should serve.

Lord Woolf said that one of his main concerns as lord chief justice would be to increase public confidence in the judiciary and said he hoped that when judges took "unpopular decisions" he thought it very important they should fully explain why they had done so in terms that both the media and the public would be able to understand.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: E coli outbreak hits scouts
fields.body:
E coli outbreak hits scouts

A group of six schoolboys have contracted the potentially deadly E coli 0157 bug after they attended a scout camp at New Deer, Aberdeenshire. Two are in hospital and one, an eight-year-old, has been given dialysis after the bug caused kidney problems. A Grampian health board spokesman said more cases could occur.

Move to curb vehicle fumes

Powers to conduct roadside vehicle emission checks could be extended to more than 100 local authorities under government plans announced yesterday after trials in seven areas. Councils could also be given powers to prevent motorists leaving the engines of parked cars running unnecessarily.

Burglary victim dies

A pensioner who suffered a stroke after disturbing a burglar in her home died yesterday. Hilda Marck, 77, suffered the stroke hours after confronting the man, who fled with £100 from her home in Shirley, Southampton, on Saturday.

£11,000 for Churchill sketch

A pen and ink drawing of a boxer by teenage Winston Churchill, which the future prime minister gave to a couple who ran the tuck shop at Harrow in 1892, sold for £11,000 at auction in Chichester, West Sussex, yesterday.

Travolta film flounders

John Travolta's £50m movie turkey Battlefield Earth has only made number seven in the UK cinema top 10 in its opening week. The sci-fi extravaganza has been ridiculed by critics.

webTitle: Bush adviser warns Europe to spend more on arms

fields.headline: Bush adviser warns Europe to spend more on arms
fields.standfirst:
US troops will not police all trouble spots, she insists

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: US troops will not police all trouble spots, she insists
fields.body:
A new Republican administration would press European nations to make massive increases in their defence budgets during the next decade to help free up the United States military from international peacekeeping, George W Bush's top foreign policy adviser says.

Condoleezza Rice, in line to become the first African-American woman to be national security adviser or even secretary of state should Mr Bush take office, said this week that the US must be much more selective in the future about deploying American troops to the world's trouble spots, saying that "doing good" was "not a strategic concept".

She added that the much-vaunted closeness between Bill Clinton and Tony Blair would not make relations difficult if Mr Bush wins the presidency. "The British-American relationship is bigger than any single personal relationship," Ms Rice said.

In a clear warning to European countries that they may soon have to make a highly charged choice between in creased defence spending and existing government social programmes, Ms Rice said there had been a "near collapse" in military spending in some parts of Europe. She specifically excluded Britain from these criticisms.

"When you look at some of the things that Europe needs to be able to do to be a force and a presence in the region, some of them are expensive. Infrastructure, command and control, air support, these are expensive items. So yes, I think spending is probably going to have to increase."

The recent European defence initiative adopted by the EU at Helsinki last year was "in the United States' interests", Ms Rice added. "The greater danger is that European militaries will not do enough, not that they'll do too much," Ms Rice added.

US forces would only be deployed under a Bush presidency when there was a US strategic interest at stake, she said. "It's not that humanitarian issues aren't important. You can't ignore killing in Rwanda or Sierra Leone. But the question is whether these are places into which you would want to introduce American military power."

Ms Rice did not offer an exact definition of US strategic interest, but she said that treaty obligations and the threat of wider conflict would be prime examples.

"It can't be just for social en gineering. It can't be for civil functions that really are police functions. It can't be state-building like we tried in Haiti," she said. "Doing good is not a strategic concept, and it draws you away from the kinds of responsibilities that can prevent a wider war."

Kosovo "clearly fitted into the strategic category", she said, although Mr Bush wanted Europe to take over control there under "a process that puts us in a position to get our forces out".

Ms Rice was fiercely critical of President Clinton's handling of the planned national missile defence system, on which the US and Russia failed to agree this week. Mr Clinton had imposed so many constraints on US missile-testers that "we're not getting our best shot", she said, adding that she "wanted to look at" ship- and aircraft-based anti-missile defence systems as well as the land-based system now under examination.

Ms Rice, who is a former provost of Stanford University in California and who was a White House adviser to President George Bush, welcomed the fact that Mr Clinton and the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, remained at odds on missile defence in their weekend talks in Moscow. "The positive thing about the trip was that there was not a grand bargain about missile defence which ties the hands of the next president," she said.

Mr Bush believes he can persuade Mr Putin that it is time to "move beyond the old cold-war logic" of the 1972 ABM treaty, which bars the development of anti-missile defence systems, even though Mr Clinton failed to do so, Ms Rice said. She called Mr Bush's recent statement that he wanted to make missile-defence systems available to America's European allies and Israel "a commitment to consultation".

A Bush administration "would want to build a system that wouldn't decouple the defence of the allies from the defence of the United States", she said. The Clinton plan, which seeks to protect only the US from missile attack, "clearly decouples", she said.

webTitle: Officials' private offices cost more, say MPs

fields.headline: Officials' private offices cost more, say MPs
fields.trailText: MPs today lambast Whitehall for wasting money on "a fundamentally flawed" private finance deal for new offices which will not provide enough desk space for the 12,000 civil servants who check national insurance payments.
fields.body:
MPs today lambast Whitehall for wasting money on "a fundamentally flawed" private finance deal for new offices which will not provide enough desk space for the 12,000 civil servants who check national insurance payments.

The Commons public accounts committee says the new offices will end up costing £241m - £51m more than the cost of keeping the current offices at the contributions agency in Newcastle upon Tyne.

MPs conclude that the Department of Social Security and inland revenue should have commissioned the new buildings in Newcastle themselves rather than asking a private consortium financed by the Royal Bank of Scotland to build them and rent them to the agency for 31 years.

The cost of handling the tender for the deal increased from £397,000 to £4.4m; legal bills jumped from £70,000 to £2.3m and the cost of financial advice rose from £123,000 to £400,000.

webTitle: Council seeks information on abandoned boy's background

fields.headline: Council seeks information on abandoned boy's background
fields.trailText: The family of a 14-year-old boy, who has a learning disability and epilepsy, is being sought by child welfare officers after he was abandoned eight months ago. His name is Kenny and he is believed to be Nigerian but little else is known about him.
fields.body:
The family of a 14-year-old boy, who has a learning disability and epilepsy, is being sought by child welfare officers after he was abandoned eight months ago. His name is Kenny and he is believed to be Nigerian but little else is known about him.

The boy, abandoned at social services offices by a man who claimed to be his uncle, has been in local authority care ever since.

Southwark council in south London, which is caring for Kenny, has taken the unusual step of obtaining legal consent to publicise his details and release his picture in the hope of getting more information.

A council spokesman said yesterday: "The primary purpose is to find out more about his history, culture and medical condition. The problem for the social workers involved is that they don't know anything."

Although abandoned babies are reported from time to time, it is without precedence, in Southwark's experience, for a teenager to be left in such circumstances.

"We have had cases before where people had said they are at the end of their tether, and they feel like abandoning their children, but we have never had a situation where it has actually happened," the spokesman said.

Kenny was taken to the council's offices last autumn by a man who said he was his uncle, Victor. The man claimed he had been looking after the boy while his mother was in the US. He said she had not returned and he could not cope any longer.

Pretending he was fetching some papers from his car, the "uncle" disappeared and has not been heard of again.

An address given by the man turned out to be false. The only further clue has come from a woman who, a few days later, delivered a letter to social services outlining Kenny's needs and food preferences.

The letter concluded: "I'll be back."

Kenny has been placed in a residential home outside London. He has been found to understand and speak English and Yoruba to the level of an eight-year-old.

A Yoruba speaker who has been employed to visit the boy is sure that he either grew up in Nigeria or has lived in the Nigerian community in Britain.

Social workers say Kenny seems reasonably settled and is suffering fewer fits than when he first arrived, but they are anxious to do more for him.

While the authority is meeting the cost of his care, the spokesman said it was likely that it would have helped fund a care package for him anyway, to assist his family.

A report on Kenny will be broadcast tonight on Channel 4 News. Information on the boy can be given to Southwark council in confidence on 020-7525-4430.
