webTitle: Beith flies home after 'crushing blow' of son's death

fields.headline: Beith flies home after 'crushing blow' of son's death
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat deputy leader, Alan Beith, last night described as a "crushing blow" the sudden death of his son, Christopher, 23.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat deputy leader, Alan Beith, last night described as a "crushing blow" the sudden death of his son, Christopher, 23.

Mr Beith flew home from a parliamentary visit to Germany after learning that Christopher had been found dead at the family home in Berwick-upon-Tweed, Northumberland, on Monday.

Mr Beith, 57, whose wife Barbara died of cancer two years ago, said his son's death would be "felt by his many friends and by all the people who were in contact with him, in sport, his work and his social life".

Christopher, who was diabetic, was adopted by the couple as a baby, and also leaves a sister, Caroline, 20.

Mr Beith said: "We were very proud of Christopher, who had to face real difficulties, both his diabetes and the loss of his mum, both his grandmothers and his aunt in a short time. He was a lovely young man."

The cause of death was not known last night, though a diabetes-linked collapse or suicide have not been ruled out. A spokesman for Northumbria police said a preliminary postmortem had proved inconclusive. Further tests would be carried out.

The Lib Dem leader, Charles Kennedy, said: "I know Alan Beith will have the support of all his parliamentary colleagues in dealing with this terrible personal tragedy."

webTitle: Botched escape Helicopter crashes as sex offender makes daring bid for freedom

fields.headline: Botched escape Helicopter crashes as sex offender makes daring bid for freedom
fields.trailText: Like a Hollywood plot gone wrong, a helicopter lies crashed in an orange grove and two desperate criminals are on the run.
fields.body:
Like a Hollywood plot gone wrong, a helicopter lies crashed in an orange grove and two desperate criminals are on the run.

Police with tracker dogs were hunting yesterday for Steve Whitsett, 28, a sex offender who clambered aboard the helicopter, flown by a student pilot, as it hovered above the recreation yard of a Florida detention centre.

Watched by about 40 inmates and three unarmed members of staff, the helicopter cleared a five metre high razor fence before crashing about 100metres from the perimeter.

"It is out of a Hollywood script, isn't it?" said Jenell Atlas, for the county sheriff's office. "He landed in broad daylight and the inmate ran out like in a movie. But unlike in a movie, they crashed."

fields.headline: Anti-racism rules agreed by EU
fields.trailText: Black and Asian Britons will get the same protection against racial discrimination they have in Britain when they travel, work or study in the rest of Europe under a directive agreed in Luxembourg yesterday.
fields.body:
Black and Asian Britons will get the same protection against racial discrimination they have in Britain when they travel, work or study in the rest of Europe under a directive agreed in Luxembourg yesterday.

The change means that a black British tourist travelling in Austria who faced official harassment could sue the police there for discrimination. Britons holidaying or working in Europe who believe they have been turned away from a hotel or turned down for a job on racist grounds will also have redress.

Mike O'Brien, the Home Office minister, and Tessa Jowell, the employment minister, signed up to the directive at a meeting in Luxembourg, where it was agreed by all 15 EU member states.

The measure, due to come into force within three years, was drawn up in record time by the European parliament in response to the rise of the extreme right in Austria and wider concern that xenophobia and racism were increasing across the continent.

The directive shifts the burden of proof in discrimination cases, with the onus on employers to rebut allegations of racism made against them. Complaints that this could impose new burdens on business have caused alarm in Whitehall. However the complainant will provide a court with prima facie evidence of racial discrimination before a company will be required to respond to the allegation.

The package will also bind new EU members. Many EU states have little or no existing protection against racial discrimination. Labour MEP Richard Howitt, who helped steer the directive through the European parliament, said the unanimous agreement "represents the clearest message to far right extremists that they have no place in a modern Europe".

webTitle: Rich pickings that fuel African wars

fields.headline: Rich pickings that fuel African wars
fields.standfirst:
Dealers scorn sanctions for multi-million pound industry
Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Dealers scorn sanctions for multi-million pound industry
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  in Antwerp  and  David Pallister
fields.body:
In a small, dingy room above the Diamond Bourse in Antwerp, one of the biggest dealers expressed regret over the mutilations and deaths in the African civil wars in Sierra Leone and Angola. But business was business. "Human beings are greedy. I am among them. If you have £100, you want to make it £200," said the veteran dealer.

His assessment was widely shared in Antwerp. In the shadow of the archaic but magnificent central station, dealers, polishers and jewellers are crammed into five streets. Here dealers spill on to their desks diamonds worth not £100 or £200 but millions of pounds.

This is the centre of the world trade in diamonds: it is a crossroads for the gems dug up, often at terrible human cost, in Africa and for the onward journey to the jewellers' shops of the US, Japan, Britain and elsewhere in Europe. The diamond merchants were dismissive yesterday of attempts to regulate the trade and, in particular, yesterday's proposal by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, to extend sanctions already imposed on diamonds from rebel-held fields in Angola to those held by the rebel Revolutionary United Front in Sierra Leone.

In spite of the brash expressions of confidence in their ability to run their own affairs, there is a growing sense of unease within the diamond square mile.

Pressure groups such as Global Witness, which has condemned the way diamonds have fuelled conflicts in Africa, have sought to introduce an ethical dimension. The fear among dealers is that campaigners could undermine consumer demand: dealers react with horror at labels such as "blood diamonds". The diamond as a symbol of eternal love is in danger of being replaced by one identified with lost limbs and death.

Diamonds and arms present a tangled story. The journey to Antwerp begins in the mud of rebel areas in Angola and Sierra Leone, and often from there passes through a third country. The Angolan rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, used Burkina Faso as a staging post and the Burkina Faso government smoothed the way.

Karrica, the nom de guerre of his roving ambassador, Marcelo Moises Dachala, would be met at the airport, cleared through customs and provided with special armed protection for his valuable luggage. A scheduled Sabena flight from Brussels would deliver the Antwerp dealers.

Last year, in meetings like this, as well as at the Rwandan capital Kigali, Unita earned an estimated $150m (£90m) to buy arms, medicines, diesel fuel, mining machinery and other commodities.

Investigators working for the UN sanctions committee on Angola have identified an international network of smuggling, with rebel stones being shifted through half-a-dozen west and southern African countries. Parcels of diamonds were often traded directly for weapons with diamond dealers and arms brokers travelling to Unita areas or friendly capitals.

Overwhelmingly, the arms come from Eastern Europe either directly into Unita territory or via third countries such as Togo and Burkina Faso, whose leaders provide false end-user certificates in exchange for diamonds, according to Unita's former procurement chief, General Jacinto Bandua. Bulgaria has long been the main source, though shipments from Ukraine have been noted.

The pattern in Angola is repeated in Sierra Leone and the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The air cargo companies which fly the weapons into the war zones can be both deliberate sanction busters or mainstream operators taken in by apparently legitimate paperwork.

One of the principal sanction busters for Unita has been a former Russian KGB officer, Victor Bout, who runs a fleet of ex-Soviet Union planes out of Sharjah in the United Arab Emirates. According to the Bulgarian government, his company Air Cess, was responsible for at least one of 19 suspect arms shipments to Togo since 1997.

Another example involved an Antanov 124 operated by the Luton-based Air Foyle. In March last year, it carried a 67-tonne consignment of arms from Ukraine to Burkina Faso which, according to the regional peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone, were transferred via Liberia to the Revolutionary United Front. Air Foyle said it was unaware that the weapons would be transferred.

The number of rough diamonds going to Antwerp from the conflict zones are a matter of dispute. The Diamond High Council insisted it was considerably less than campaigners claimed.

The council also said its import regulations were much tougher than those elsewhere in Europe. In spite of that, it was taking notes of the com plaints by the UN and campaigners.

Campaigners are pressing for some way of unravelling the tortuous journeys made by those trading in diamonds. Proposals include tests to determine the origin of the diamonds as well as marking them as proof they did not come from conflict zones.

Even the dealers admit that diamonds themselves have no inherent value, other than limited industrial use as drill bits. One said: "The value of the diamond is what any fool will pay for it."

webTitle: Mugabe is set on ruining Zimbabwe, says Britain

fields.headline: Mugabe is set on ruining Zimbabwe, says Britain
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: With less than three weeks to Zimbabwe's crucial parliamentary elections, the British government launched an unprecedented attack on President Robert Mugabe, charging that he is determined to hold unfair elections and to ruin the country's economy.
fields.body:
With less than three weeks to Zimbabwe's crucial parliamentary elections, the British government launched an unprecedented attack on President Robert Mugabe, charging that he is determined to hold unfair elections and to ruin the country's economy.

"Neither Britain nor the international community can make this election fair. Only Robert Mugabe can do that, and he seems determined not to," the Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, said. "Neither Britain nor the international community can solve the land problem or reverse Zimbabwe's economic decline. Only Robert Mugabe can do so, and he shows no sign of wanting to."

Mr Hain's criticism was contained in a faxed statement released by the British high commission in Harare yesterday. It came as international observers arrived to monitor the elections, including an estimated 200 from the EU. Others came from the Commonwealth.

In the run-up to the elections on June 24-25, Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party has unleashed a widespread campaign of violence against the opposition that has taken 30 lives. Thousands more opposition supporters have been beaten, raped and tortured.

In the latest reported incident, ruling party militants attacked teachers and health workers, forcing many to flee their clinics and schools, an independent monitoring group and Zimbabwe's main opposition party said yesterday.

Many of those injured in the violence last month in northeast Zimbabwe were also barred from entering medical clinics, the Community Working Group on Health said.

Mr Mugabe's relations with Mr Hain have been strained ever since his outspoken criticism in March, when customs officials in Harare opened and inspected the contents of several British diplomatic bags. At the time, Mr Hain described the move as "not the action of a civilised country," remarks that many in Zimbabwe found deeply offensive. Mr Mugabe has since launched numerous outspoken attacks on Tony Blair's government.

The president refused to allow Britons to participate in the EU and Commonwealth observer teams. The British government decided it was more important to get international observers on the ground than insist on its right to participate. In any case, Britons are in the senior ad ministration of both the EU and Commonwealth teams.

"We are not going to pre-empt the observers' verdict or the verdict of the people of Zimbabwe. To pre-empt would be to play Robert Mugabe's game," Mr Hain said. "He wants to run this election with Britain as the opposition and we are not going to oblige.

"We are in close contact with partners from the Commonwealth, European commission and the United Nations. We have expressed our concerns and we will be monitoring closely reports from the election observers," he added.

Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party is facing its strongest challenge since coming to power 20 years ago. The new Movement for Democratic Change has fielded candidates in all 120 constituencies, the first time an opposition party has done so since 1980.

In the rural areas, where 65% of the people live, Zanu-PF officials have told peasants that their vote will not be secret, and that they will be killed if they vote for the MDC. Many of the subsistence farmers believe the threats and are afraid to vote for the opposition. An international presence in the rural areas is badly needed. A countrywide voter education campaign is also needed to counteract the misinformation, but neither the EU nor the Commonwealth appear prepared to participate in such a move.

Despite the brutality and propaganda, events are not favouring Mr Mugabe. The country's six month-old fuel shortage noticeably worsened this week, with queues of hundreds of cars, taxis, trucks and tractors stretching throughout Harare and the rest of the country. Police had to use teargas to restore order at besieged service stations. Thousands of township households are also affected because the country has run out of paraffin, the main fuel for cooking. The fuel shortage is widely viewed by black and white Zimbabweans alike as the fault of the Zanu-PF government. They blame corruption and disastrous economic policies.

Mr Mugabe tried to blame Britain for the crippling shortages, claiming that a British ship was following tankers bringing fuel to the country and offering them double the price to take it elsewhere.

"The British are interfering with our fuel supplies," he said. "They are trying to divert ships with fuel for this country. That is why we say they are bad."

The British high commission in Harare called the claims "ridiculous".

webTitle: Grant the pick of Orange judges

fields.headline: Grant the pick of Orange judges
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Guardian journalist Linda Grant last night won the £30,000 Orange prize with When I Lived in Modern Times, her novel about a young Londoner who becomes embroiled in the Zionist conflict with the British in Israel after the second world war.
fields.body:
The Guardian journalist Linda Grant last night won the £30,000 Orange prize with When I Lived in Modern Times, her novel about a young Londoner who becomes embroiled in the Zionist conflict with the British in Israel after the second world war.

Grant - best known for her acclaimed memoir of her mother's mental decline and death, Remind Me Who I Am, Again - was the surprise choice for an award which many thought a shoo-in for Zadie Smith's bravura survey of multicultural London, White Teeth.

But the judges, chaired by the Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee and including Ffion Hague, the wife of the Tory leader, were "unanimous" in their choice of Grant's second novel over Smith's debut, the most talked about in a decade.

A spokeswoman for the prize, which is restricted to women writers, said, "There were no rows, this was a happy and unanimous decision."

Smith, 24, had earlier stirred more than the prize's usual surfeit of controversy by attacking Mrs Hague over her husband's "cheap" attacks on asylum seekers, comments she later claimed were taken out of context. "It's so cheap, taking shots at immigrants..." she was quoted as saying in the Mail On Sunday. "If I do win, I intend to give my mother something worth reading. This country that Hague pretends to be so proud of was built on refugee work."

Although not universally liked, When I Lived in Modern Times, which follows the social chameleon Evelyn Sert from dreary post-war Britain to the danger and glamour of Tel Aviv, was described by the Independent On Sunday as a "superb coming-of-age novel... full of sharp humour, complex ironies and an acute eye for cultural clashes".

The Independent praised Liverpool-born Grant's "gift for lyrical storytelling".

The other books on the shortlist were Rebecca Wells's cult bestseller Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood, Judy Budnitz's If I Told You Once, Eilis Ni Dhuibhne's The Dancers Dancing and Amy and Isabelle by Elizabeth Strout.

fields.headline: Women told to remove 'safe' implants
fields.standfirst:
Breast operations could cause cancer and birth defects, medical chief warns

Breast implants on Trial
Breast Implants
fields.trailText: Some 5,000 women who chose soybean oil implants to enlarge their breasts were yesterday advised to have them removed for fear that fluids leaking into the body may cause cancer and birth defects.
fields.body:
Some 5,000 women who chose soybean oil implants to enlarge their breasts were yesterday advised to have them removed for fear that fluids leaking into the body may cause cancer and birth defects.

The government's deputy chief medical officer, Pat Troop, warned women with what are known as Trilucent implants not to get pregnant or breastfeed until they have been taken out. "Although there is no evidence of cancer or damage to unborn babies, these possible risks could not be excluded," she said.

The news that they will have to face surgery will come as a major blow to the women involved, many of whom opted for what was marketed as a safe and more natural implant five years ago, when the controversy over silicone was at its height in the US. The bill, which could total £25m, will be paid by AEI, a company which recently took over responsibility for the implants.

Serious criticism was being levelled yesterday at the regulation system for implants and the Medical Devices Agency (MDA) which oversees it. Implants, unike drugs, do not have to be tested in the human body before being allowed. The Trilucent implants were given a CE "kitemark" in 1995 by a German agency, which permits their EU-wide use. "It is outrageous that implants are not subject to patient trials before being authorised," said Delyth Morgan, chief executive of the Breakthrough Breast Cancer charity.

Yesterday Susanne Ludgate, medical director of the MDA, said the agency would pressure the EU to demand a higher level of proof from manufacturers of the safety of implants, including clinical trials. The system had already changed. "I think it probably is safer than it was five years ago," she said. But asked if a similar scandal could happen again, she admitted: "I can't say for certain, no." The agency said it had "no information" to give women on the safety of alternative implants - silicone or saline-filled.

Dr Troop, meanwhile, said women should discuss the matter with their surgeon. "We're not advising women not to do it. We're giving them information so there is a choice. It will be up to them what they consider is the most important thing in their lives," she said.

Barry Jones, president of the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons and a member of the independent committee set up by the MDA which recommended the removal, said: "One can never say any implant is going to be 100% safe."

Trilucent implants were developed in an effort to overcome the problems of implants blocking x-rays when women have mammograms to detect breast cancer. This turned into a selling-point, however, after thousands of women in the US and later the UK began complaining of leaks and ruptures from silicone implants. A trickle of lawsuits became a flood as women alleged that they were suffering auto-immune diseases, telling of lethargy, tiredness, forgetfulness and joint pains. Silicone implants have been banned in the US and France, but a UK government-appointed scientific committee recently gave them the all-clear.

Trilucent implants were marketed direct to the consumer in radio, newspaper and magazine adverts. Internet websites promoted them to women in the US, where they were not licensed, inviting them to fly for surgery in Europe.

Norman Waterhouse, a consultant plastic surgeon at the Chelsea and Westminster hospital and Wellington hospital in London, said he refused to implant the Trilucent devices. "I had a sample from the manufacturers in my drawer and it went rotten and smelt like an old chip fryer. If that happened in my drawer, what would happen in a woman's body?"

There have been 74 complaints in the UK, where most of the 9,000 implants manufactured were sold. The most wor rying relate to swellings and inflammation caused by leakage and rupture of the implant. The government banned them in March 1999 and asked the Swiss manufacturer Lipomatrix, which has been sold to the US-based Inamed Corporation, to study implants that were removed from women. Those studies found that the soybean oil leaks out of the capsule and can break down in the body to form aldehydes, which may damage DNA and cause cancers and possibly birth defects.

The Department of Health said yesterday that it had no idea how many women had given birth and breast-fed babies with the implants in place. But neither the MDA nor the manufacturers "had received any reports of health problems to mothers with Trilucent breast implants".

Margo Cameron, of Silicone Support UK, said she wrote to the Health Department about the implants after women started complaining about them. The reply from the private secretary to the then health minister, Baroness Jay, dated January 15 1998, admitted that the MDA had been concerned about the CE kitemark in 1995. "However following a detailed review of relevant technical information and a meeting with the company's representatives and academic consultants, MDA concluded that their concerns over safety had been addressed." No challenge to the CE marking and the availability on the European market was felt therefore to be indicated," the letter said.

Ms Cameron accuses the MDA of failing to act. "They were aware of the problems but they did nothing about it," she said.

Inamed, which bought the company manufacturing Trilucent, has set up a separate company, called AEI Inc, to foot the bills of removal. Women are invited to call a freephone helpline on 0800 028 6622 for advice. Information is also available at www.trilucentinfo.com. NHS Direct on 0845 4647 and the Health Information Service on 0800 665 544 can also help.

The news that they will have to face surgery will come as a major blow to the women involved, many of whom opted for what was marketed as a safe and more natural implant five years ago, when the controversy over silicone was at its height in the US. The bill, which could total £25m, will be paid by AEI, a company which recently took over responsibility for the implants. Serious criticism was being levelled yesterday at the regulation system for implants and the Medical Devices Agency (MDA) which oversees it. Implants, unike drugs, do not have to be tested in the human body before being allowed. The Trilucent implants were given a CE "kitemark" in 1995 by a German agency, which permits their EU-wide use. "It is outrageous that implants are not subject to patient trials before being authorised," said Delyth Morgan, chief executive of the Breakthrough Breast Cancer charity. Yesterday Susanne Ludgate, medical director of the MDA, said the agency would pressure the EU to demand a higher level of proof from manufacturers of the safety of implants, including clinical trials. The system had already changed. "I think it probably is safer than it was five years ago," she said. But asked if a similar scandal could happen again, she admitted: "I can't say for certain, no." The agency said it had "no information" to give women on the safety of alternative implants - silicone or saline-filled. Dr Troop, meanwhile, said women should discuss the matter with their surgeon. "We're not advising women not to do it. We're giving them information so there is a choice. It will be up to them what they consider is the most important thing in their lives," she said. Barry Jones, president of the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons and a member of the independent committee set up by the MDA which recommended the removal, said: "One can never say any implant is going to be 100% safe." Trilucent implants were developed in an effort to overcome the problems of implants blocking x-rays when women have mammograms to detect breast cancer. This turned into a selling-point, however, after thousands of women in the US and later the UK began complaining of leaks and ruptures from silicone implants. A trickle of lawsuits became a flood as women alleged that they were suffering auto-immune diseases, telling of lethargy, tiredness, forgetfulness and joint pains. Silicone implants have been banned in the US and France, but a UK government-appointed scientific committee recently gave them the all-clear. Trilucent implants were marketed direct to the consumer in radio, newspaper and magazine adverts. Internet websites promoted them to women in the US, where they were not licensed, inviting them to fly for surgery in Europe. Norman Waterhouse, a consultant plastic surgeon at the Chelsea and Westminster hospital and Wellington hospital in London, said he refused to implant the Trilucent devices. "I had a sample from the manufacturers in my drawer and it went rotten and smelt like an old chip fryer. If that happened in my drawer, what would happen in a woman's body?" There have been 74 complaints in the UK, where most of the 9,000 implants manufactured were sold. The most wor rying relate to swellings and inflammation caused by leakage and rupture of the implant. The government banned them in March 1999 and asked the Swiss manufacturer Lipomatrix, which has been sold to the US-based Inamed Corporation, to study implants that were removed from women. Those studies found that the soybean oil leaks out of the capsule and can break down in the body to form aldehydes, which may damage DNA and cause cancers and possibly birth defects. The Department of Health said yesterday that it had no idea how many women had given birth and breast-fed babies with the implants in place. But neither the MDA nor the manufacturers "had received any reports of health problems to mothers with Trilucent breast implants". Margo Cameron, of Silicone Support UK, said she wrote to the Health Department about the implants after women started complaining about them. The reply from the private secretary to the then health minister, Baroness Jay, dated January 15 1998, admitted that the MDA had been concerned about the CE kitemark in 1995. "However following a detailed review of relevant technical information and a meeting with the company's representatives and academic consultants, MDA concluded that their concerns over safety had been addressed." No challenge to the CE marking and the availability on the European market was felt therefore to be indicated," the letter said. Ms Cameron accuses the MDA of failing to act. "They were aware of the problems but they did nothing about it," she said. Inamed, which bought the company manufacturing Trilucent, has set up a separate company, called AEI Inc, to foot the bills of removal. Women are invited to call a freephone helpline on 0800 028 6622 for advice. Information is also available at www.trilucentinfo.com. NHS Direct on 0845 4647 and the Health Information Service on 0800 665 544 can also help.

webTitle: 'From day one I was in pain and discomfort'

fields.headline: 'From day one I was in pain and discomfort'
fields.standfirst:
Breast implants on Trial
Breast Implants
fields.trailText: When Elaine Coomber had silicone breast implants 24 years ago, she was assured they were safe.
fields.body:
When Elaine Coomber had silicone breast implants 24 years ago, she was assured they were safe.

But after years of discomfort and problems with lumps appearing in her breasts and the implants leaking, she had them replaced.

She had a further operation five years ago to remove the implants and replace them with the so-called safe soya bean oil Trilucent implants.

Elaine had been convinced that soya bean oil implants were safer than silicone. However, the replacement breast implants caused her endless pain.

Four days ago and many thousands of pounds later she had a third operation to remove the implants after the manufacturers withdrew them due to the potential risk of birth defects and cancer.

"I feel shattered by all I have been through," she said. "I had the first silicone implants removed and opted to replace them with Trilucent implants because I was convinced they were totally safe.

"But from day one I was in pain and discomfort with the Trilucent implants. I am angry with the manufacturers because I don't think they were tested enough before they went on the market. These implants need to be properly tested and the procedures for cosmetic surgery need to be tightened up."

Elaine, 54, from Maidstone, Kent, who is a support group leader, had her latest operation in Leeds.

She had the original silicone implants to regain some uplift in her breasts after she finished breastfeeding her four children.

"The silicone implants had been in place since 1976 and had already ruptured," she said. "I also had problems with the implants leaking through my nipples. I wanted something to replace them with and I was assured Trilucent implants were safe.

"When the manufacturers withdrew them from the market last year I decided to have my own removed. It is the fifth year they had been in place and by pure coincidence they were only guaranteed for five years.

"The surgery was uncomfortable but I was not in a great deal of pain. When they were removed they were found to be fine and still intact. There was no problems with them - they hadn't leaked and there was no yoghurt-like substance which had been reported in some other cases. It was a big relief to find out they were okay.

"What I want to get across to people is that help is available and they need not be frightened. The worst thing anybody can do is panic because these things can be sorted out. People need to have their implants checked to see if they should be removed."

Elaine believes that legislation should be used to control cosmetic surgery because she said it was important that people were given the correct information so they could make informed choices.

She has not ruled out having more surgery to replace the implants but she regrets ever having surgery.

"I wish I had never had the original implants because of all I have been through - I am still suffering the consequences."

fields.headline: Bomb killer 'wanted to be famous'
fields.standfirst: Old Bailey hears that man accused of three murders idolised Hitler and Stalin and felt no emotion when he planted deadly device in pub
fields.trailText: Old Bailey hears that man accused of three murders idolised Hitler and Stalin and felt no emotion when he planted deadly device in pub
fields.body:
Nail bomber David Copeland felt a total lack of emotion when he planted the Soho pub bomb which killed three people and injured dozens of others, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Interviewed by police after his arrest, Copeland described walking into the Admiral Duncan pub in April last year to plant the bomb: "I saw the people I was going to maim and kill. I didn't feel joy about it. I didn't feel sad. I just didn't feel anything."

He claimed he was "just like a robot" and felt neither "sadness, sorrow nor joy."

The jury was told how the 24-year-old engineer idolised the dictators Hitler, Stalin, and Saddam Hussein, as well as Henry Lee Lucas, an American serial killer. He said he wanted to get caught because that would make him famous, the court heard.

Copeland told officers that he felt sad about one of his victims, Andrea Dykes, because she had a baby.

Mrs Dykes, 27, four months pregnant with her first child, was killed by the Soho blast along with John Light, 33, best man at her wedding, and their friend Nick Moore, 31. They were among a group of five going to the theatre that night "who had decided to make a day out of it in London". Seventy others were injured.

Destiny

Copeland, of Cove, Hampshire, told detectives: "I did feel sick about that." However, he said: "I just had to do it. It was my destiny." He told police he had also felt sorry for the 23-month-old child who had a nail embedded in his skull by the bomb planted in Brixton two weeks before the Soho explosion.

Nigel Sweeney QC, prosecuting, told the jury: "He said that his heroes were Hitler, about whom he had some books, Stalin, Saddam Hussein, and a man called Henry Lee, a serial killer in the United States. He said he liked the fact that he had terrorised the UK and that was the plan from the start."

Copeland, an engineer's assistant working on the Jubilee Line extension, told police: "I believe what I believe and I took that belief to an extreme."

Mr Sweeney said: "He said he wanted to get caught, to be famous."

Copeland told police: "If no one remembers who you were, you never existed."

Following his arrest Copeland was remanded into custody at Belmarsh prison, where he was kept in the health care unit. While there he told a prison officer: "I'm not mad. I know why I'm in prison. I did plant those bombs. I targeted minority groups for political and religious reasons."

The jury had previously heard how he thought the Bible supported his beliefs and was "against racial mixing".

He told the prison guard: "I'm not mad. I've already worked out how to get out of this cell." Three months ago Copeland admitted three charges of manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility, but the prosecution refused to accept the pleas. He denies murder.

Blame

Yesterday stockily-built Copeland, dressed in a blue shirt and dark trousers, sat impassively in the dock of court one as Mr Sweeney outlined details of the terror campaign which targeted Brixton, Brick Lane and Soho in the space of 13 days last spring. The prosecution revealed how Copeland had tried at one point to pin the blame on extremist group Combat 18. After dumping his bomb in the street in Brick Lane, east London, on April 25, he dialled 999 from a phone box.

Mr Sweeney said: "Copeland, when the operator answered, did not speak to give any warning, but silently pressed the keys 2, 1, 8." The number two was meant to represent a C, in a code where zero was taken to mean A.

In January that year Copeland had joined a far right group called the National Socialist Movement, the court heard. But he claimed to be acting entirely on his own, telling nobody of his plans. Interviewed by police, he described Combat 18 as a "bunch of yobs", and was dismissive of another group, the White Wolves, which also claimed responsibility.

The jury was yesterday shown CCTV footage of the Brick Lane bomb exploding minutes after a passing motorist picked up the bag it was dumped in and threw it into the boot of his car. Replayed in jerky stills, the camera captured the orange bloom of the explosion ripping apart Gerard Lynch's red Ford Sierra, followed by a plume of black smoke.

The smoke cleared to reveal debris scattered across the street, but this was clear of cars and almost clear of pedestrians at the time. Ten people suffered minor injuries in the blast, which caused £50,000 damage in the area, the court heard.

Giving evidence yesterday Mr Lynch, who is in his 50s, told the court: "There was a cardboard box and it was full of screws. I thought it was a workman's bag."

He walked to two nearby police stations to report the "lost property" but found them closed. "It just came into my mind about the nail bomb that went off the previous week, but I still did not believe it was a bomb."

Still away from his car, he dialled 999 on his mobile and discovered from the operator that the bomb had gone off.

Other witnesses described the scenes of chaos when the first bomb, in Brixton, went off. Street trader Miles Macleod, 23, told how he and friends looked inside the bag and saw pink tissue paper, nails, a clock, batteries and wires. Mr Macleod said: "We thought that it was a joke. We started saying things like 'It's a bomb' and then we realised it was a bomb."

Mr Macleod and fellow traders alerted staff at the nearby Iceland store, and police were called. Iceland store manager Paul Maskell told the court how he and security guard Aiah Menjor tried to keep people away.

"No one was taking it seriously at all. We told people don't go down there and they just pushed past. When it went off, everything seemed to go blank, and you felt like you were in a cocoon of yourself. You weren't aware of anything going on around you - just yourself."

Mr Maskell was among the injured. A nail was embedded in his head and another in his chest.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed PM losing common touch, says Sawyer, on page 2 of early editions, June 5, we said that in making critical remarks about Tony Blair, Lord Sawyer, the Labour party's former general secretary, "was backed by the Labour MP Tony Wright". We then quoted remarks by Mr Wright made on the BBC radio programme, The World This Weekend. Mr Wright says that not only did he not back Lord Sawyer, he knew nothing about the latter's remarks and made no reference to them. The quoted remarks by Mr Wright referred to another matter altogether. Apologies for that.
fields.body:
In a report headed PM losing common touch, says Sawyer, on page 2 of early editions, June 5, we said that in making critical remarks about Tony Blair, Lord Sawyer, the Labour party's former general secretary, "was backed by the Labour MP Tony Wright". We then quoted remarks by Mr Wright made on the BBC radio programme, The World This Weekend. Mr Wright says that not only did he not back Lord Sawyer, he knew nothing about the latter's remarks and made no reference to them. The quoted remarks by Mr Wright referred to another matter altogether. Apologies for that.

In a short piece about Carol Morley, whose experiences are recorded in the film The Alcohol Years, page 7 (Women), G2, June 5, we attributed to the author Dave Haslam the view that Carol Morley had been "sexually ill". In fact, that was a remark made not by him but by someone else in the film. Dave Haslam has never believed her to be, or described her as being "sexually ill". Apologies.

In a report, page 13 in early editions, June 1, we said that the Lord Mayor of Cork, Terence MacSweeney, died on hunger strike in Cork gaol in 1920. In fact, MacSwiney, as he appears in The Oxford Companion To Irish History, died in Brixton.

The work for which Susan Loppert is responsible in Chelsea and Westminster hospital, Innovators compete for £200,000 arts prize, page 4, June 5, is not "art therapy" and she is not an art therapist. She is an art historian and consultant. Her project aims to integrate the visual and performing arts into the life of a busy working hospital.

The writer of a letter (Don Mathew), page 19, yesterday, wanted to say that his transport proposals were "child-friendly" and would address "social exclusion issues". This, strangely, became "coal exclusion issues". Sorry.

Homophone corner, from page 16, Weekend, June 3, "The two [male wolves] accelerated at one point into a sprint, their tales wrapped across one another's tawny flanks." And another, from page 16, G2, yesterday, "I bumped into [a member of an animal control team] leaving my neighbour's house holding a possum by the tale."

It is Guardian policy to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: How the neighbouring regime siphons off precious profits

fields.headline: How the neighbouring regime siphons off precious profits
fields.standfirst: Liberia is key to curbing trade and ending war
fields.trailText: Chief Superintendent Tamba Gbeke sighs as he contemplates the safe in Freetown's central police station. In the safe, in little packets wrapped in tissue, are a few of the objects that have made Sierra Leone's war far worse than it might have been - and without which some believe the war might never have happened at all.
fields.body:
Chief Superintendent Tamba Gbeke sighs as he contemplates the safe in Freetown's central police station. In the safe, in little packets wrapped in tissue, are a few of the objects that have made Sierra Leone's war far worse than it might have been - and without which some believe the war might never have happened at all.

"The problem in Sierra Leone is that diamonds are all over the place," he says. A huge swathe of diamondiferous gravel - 7,700 square miles in all - sweeps from the east to the south of the country and the stones can be dug, as another policeman put it, "by anyone with a bucket and spade".

Regulating trade in objects so small, so valuable and so widely dispersed was a headache even in colonial days. The few seized from smugglers which end up in the police safe are a minute fraction of the total.

Mr Gbeke had arrested a man trying to smuggle diamonds which included a 45-carat stone - not the most valuable but still worth a tidy sum - but he knows that most seizures, like this one, follow denunciations by rivals. In any case, the bulk of the illegal trade goes through Liberia, where President Charles Taylor takes a huge cut, with some passing through Guinea and the rest through Freetown.

The diamonds, however, are not the key to the war in the sense that the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) uses diamond income for large arms purchases. The critical fact is that the RUF denies the government any serious income from the diamonds, but without using more than a fraction of that income itself.

The RUF is, in fact, quite badly equipped, and the presumption is that Mr Taylor takes much of the income, while RUF leaders cream off some for personal gain. As one observer put it: "If the RUF got even half of the money from the diamonds it would be flying MiGs."

When diamonds were discovered in Sierra Leone in 1930 they seemed like an extraordinary blessing for a poor colony that had till then been regarded as lacking in resources. But, within a few years, the blessing turned into a curse. Illicit miners proliferated, selling their stones to Lebanese traders who smuggled them out of the country. Neither De Beers, which then had exclusive rights, or the colonial government could cope, and by 1956 there were an estimated 75,000 illicit miners in the main Kono diamond area.

The worst disaster for Sierra Leone came when the neighbouring state of Liberia was transformed from a shambolic one-party state into an essentially criminal polity.

"In 1995, when Liberia lay in ruins and economic activity was almost non-existent, it exported $500m worth of diamonds," says a well-researched report on the impact of the trade on the war by Partnership Africa Canada. Support of the RUF was part of this strategy. The diamond profits sustained both Mr Taylor and the RUF, and the RUF kept much of the diamond area out of the government's control.

Over the years, the Freetown government has fought back, most effectively by giving mining concessions to firms with connections to mercenary outfits like Executive Outcomes and Sandline. Such efforts suggest that unless and until Mr Taylor's influence is curbed by a strong military presence in the diamond area, there can be no end to Sierra Leone's long and terrible war.

Neither De Beers, which then had exclusive rights, or the colonial government could cope, and by 1956 there were an estimated 75,000 illicit miners in the main Kono diamond area. The worst disaster for Sierra Leone came when the neighbouring state of Liberia was transformed from a shambolic one-party state into an essentially criminal polity. "In 1995, when Liberia lay in ruins and economic activity was almost non-existent, it exported $500m worth of diamonds," says a well-researched report on the impact of the trade on the war by Partnership Africa Canada. Support of the RUF was part of this strategy. The diamond profits sustained both Mr Taylor and the RUF, and the RUF kept much of the diamond area out of the government's control. Over the years, the Freetown government has fought back, most effectively by giving mining concessions to firms with connections to mercenary outfits like Executive Outcomes and Sandline. Such efforts suggest that unless and until Mr Taylor's influence is curbed by a strong military presence in the diamond area, there can be no end to Sierra Leone's long and terrible war.

webTitle: Jewels boycott would hit innocent, not warlords

fields.headline: Jewels boycott would hit innocent, not warlords
fields.trailText: For the British jewellery buyer with a conscience, the government's push against the illegal African trade raises an obvious question: is it time to say goodbye to a girl's best friend?
fields.body:
For the British jewellery buyer with a conscience, the government's push against the illegal African trade raises an obvious question: is it time to say goodbye to a girl's best friend?

On a logical basis, the answer is no. For the consumer peering through the shop window, whether in Hatton Garden or the local high street, the chances of that costly, have-to-have piece of personal adornment unwittingly helping to fuel bloodthirsty civil wars in Africa is well below 4%. And should the shopper be using an outlet piloting a "branded" gems scheme from the diamond group De Beers, the probability falls to near zero.

Anywhere in the world, the odds are that any dia mond originated either in southern Africa - South Africa, Botswana or Namibia - or in the Russian Federation.

A general boycott of diamonds would hit blameless Botswana and Bombay in India, a cutting centre employing 800,000 people, far harder than the warlords of Angola, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Sierra Leone.

Escalating sanctions by Britain, the European Union and the United Nations have progressively choked off the supply of "conflict gems" to Europe.

That said, they must be sold somewhere, so the truly war-averse jewellery buyer may prefer to look elsewhere. Pearls, the vast majority of which originate in conflict-free Japan, seem to fit the bill.

fields.headline: Shipman 'invited' to inquest
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: A coroner announced yesterday that he has asked former doctor Harold Shipman, Britain's most prolific serial killer, to give evidence at the inquests into the deaths of three of his former patients.
fields.body:
A coroner announced yesterday that he has asked former doctor Harold Shipman, Britain's most prolific serial killer, to give evidence at the inquests into the deaths of three of his former patients.

John Pollard, the south Manchester coroner, has written to Shipman at Frankland prison in Durham, asking him to say in public what he knows about the deaths of Sarah Ashworth, Alice Kitchen and Elizabeth Mellor.

News of the letter emerged as Shipman, who was convicted in January of killing 15 women patients with lethal injections of diamorphine, was taken to hospital in Sunderland for an operation on a detached retina.

The bodies of Mrs Ashworth, Mrs Kitchen and Mrs Mellor were exhumed in November and December 1998 but Shipman, who practised in Hyde, Greater Manchester, was never accused of killing them. Inquests on all three were opened and adjourned during the murder inquiry.

Their names appear with those of 23 other patients on a list compiled by detectives of people who died in Shipman's care but were later cremated. The crown prosecution service decided against further charges because of difficulties in securing a fair trial.

The inquests will be held in August and September.

fields.headline: Refugees' flats to be improved
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The owners of tower blocks where asylum seekers are living in an allegedly "appalling state" were yesterday ordered to carry out improvements to the buildings.
fields.body:
The owners of tower blocks where asylum seekers are living in an allegedly "appalling state" were yesterday ordered to carry out improvements to the buildings.

Home Office inspectors examined two buildings in Everton, Liverpool, after Louise Ellman, Labour MP for Liverpool Riverside, said the flats were the worst she had seen. A programme of improvements was agreed between officers from the National Asylum Support Service and the owners of the flats, to be implemented immediately.

Ms Ellman claimed conditions in the tower blocks, named the Landmark and the Inn on the Park, left asylum seekers "vulnerable and afraid". Hundreds were forced to live in damp, crowded and sometimes dangerous conditions, she said.

Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, yesterday met Ms Ellman to discuss the arrangements. The Home Office said renovations would include a new lift, wall heaters and safety improvements.

The tower blocks had been sold by Liverpool city council 10 years ago because no council tenants wanted to live in them.

fields.headline: Art and the public purse
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle's random wanderings through the Tate Modern (Inside Tate Modern, G2, June 6) have been intriguing me. Why take this ramshackle approach to a major new gallery?
fields.body:
Adrian Searle's random wanderings through the Tate Modern (Inside Tate Modern, G2, June 6) have been intriguing me. Why take this ramshackle approach to a major new gallery?

On my first visit last Saturday I discovered the reason - the whole is so much less than the sum of its parts. Most of the individual rooms are too small; the hanging is awful; and the lighting is, at its best, flat. In my favourite area, sculpture, some of the positioning is a disgrace. As someone who loves much of modern art, I arrived with an open mind. I left feeling profoundly depressed by the whole experience. If this is the best that Britain's proponents of modern art can manage, have I wasted my time defended it to cynical friends and relatives over the years? The Tate in Liverpool is outstanding, so why not the Tate Modern?

Phil Rimmer
London

 I should like to inform the gentleman who lost his wallet in the top gallery on floor five that my "cred" was nearly lost due to him. I noticed the wallet delicately placed on a wooden seat and had to seriously question how foolish I would look if I asked the nearby security guard if it was part of the exhibition. However honesty prevailed and as I asked him if "it" was a lost wallet. I saw the same questioning flicker in his eyes before he took charge of the lost property with an "I think so".

Delia Hazrati
Dover, Kent
tmri@lodestone.co.uk

fields.headline: A poet at full throttle
fields.trailText: I feel I must intercede in the howling and weeping following the death of Barry MacSweeney (Letters, June 3). Let it be clearly and firmly said that Barry MacSweeney went into no decline. He went out on full throttle. He was not "one of the" nor "amongst the" nor "to be considered one of", the finest poets of his time. He was, by half a head, in front of Tom Raworth, Bill Griffiths, Iain Sinclair and Les Murray, the finest poet writing in English in his time. He went into no recession. He got better and   better and died at his peak. Few people achieve this.
fields.body:
I feel I must intercede in the howling and weeping following the death of Barry MacSweeney (Letters, June 3). Let it be clearly and firmly said that Barry MacSweeney went into no decline. He went out on full throttle. He was not "one of the" nor "amongst the" nor "to be considered one of", the finest poets of his time. He was, by half a head, in front of Tom Raworth, Bill Griffiths, Iain Sinclair and Les Murray, the finest poet writing in English in his time. He went into no recession. He got better and better and died at his peak. Few people achieve this.

The world is full of drunks. His gastronomic life was of no real importance. His work was unique. Let's for God's sake, not make him into a martyr and a victim, nor even a suicide. These things he was not. I was one of the people to be rung up by him late at night over the last few years. He usually gave his reason for ringing me as "wanting to cheer me up a bit". He usually - no, always - did.

Jeff Nuttall
Abergavenny, Monmouthshire

fields.headline: Cross talk
fields.trailText: I recently delivered a lecture at Cranfield Business School, exploring the issues of leadership in politics. I followed this up on Radio 4, discussing how the Labour leadership should change to win a second term. These contributions have been interpreted as a withering attack on Tony Blair (Blair is 'losing common touch of Thatcher', June 5). This is completely at odds with the content, style and language of what I had to say. If we always report political exchanges in adversarial terms we will not achieve the very thing that most people want, which is an open and honest debate.

fields.headline: Sizing it up
fields.trailText: Comparing Wales and Monaco (Letters, June 3), with areas of 20,767sq km and 1.89sq km, means 1 Wales = 10,988 Monacos. The disparity between the sizes makes them impractical units. But it is possible to construct a table of intermediate units. So: 32.5 Monacos = 1 San Marino (61sq km); 3 San Marinos = 1 Liechtenstein (160sq km); 3 Liechtensteins = 1 Andorra (453sq km); 5.5 Andorras = 1 Luxembourg (2,586sq km); 8 Luxembourgs = 1 Wales

fields.headline: Chorus of complaint
fields.trailText: The use of God Save The Queen as a substitute English anthem, even at events where England plays Scotland or Wales, contributes to the Scots and Welsh feeling the English see them as mere appendages to a greater England (Don't save the queen, May 30). Far better that England has its own anthem, God Save The Queen becomes the UK anthem and the Ode To Joy remains the European anthem. It will be clearer we all have multiple levels of identity without one interfering with the other.

fields.headline: Cocaine round her brain
fields.trailText: I am on my rest day after a busy week as a casualty officer in an inner-city hospital. Falls, fractures, epileptic fits, collapses, psychotic behaviours, head injuries ... young and otherwise fit people attend casualty after their busy nights out. In many cases recreational use of drugs is to blame. "Shyness and a low boredom threshold," states Julie Burchill are incompatible with a drugs-free social life (You're gonna die, so you might as well live, G2, June 6); you stop using them when, by magic, you are not surrounded by "bores day and night".
fields.body:
I am on my rest day after a busy week as a casualty officer in an inner-city hospital. Falls, fractures, epileptic fits, collapses, psychotic behaviours, head injuries ... young and otherwise fit people attend casualty after their busy nights out. In many cases recreational use of drugs is to blame. "Shyness and a low boredom threshold," states Julie Burchill are incompatible with a drugs-free social life (You're gonna die, so you might as well live, G2, June 6); you stop using them when, by magic, you are not surrounded by "bores day and night".

I felt hurt and angry reading this article in an influential newspaper. How are we going to tackle real problems if they are minimised and made acceptable? You are bored if you are incapable of walking in a park, listening to music, painting, writing, reading. The world is too vast, too interesting, challenging, diverse to be boring. I can understand the pleasure of a glass of wine; I cannot understand being drunk out of boredom. The use of drugs is a sad, real and serious problem. Let's try to tackle the problem, not to make it acceptable.

Fatou Mbow
London

 Julie Burchill thinks cocaine is harmless, does she? She must be even stupider than most of your readers thought. The cocaine-funded civil war in Colombia kills 20,000 a year and is responsible for 1m Colombians leaving the country in the last two years.

David Holland
Chislehurst, Kent

 So cocaine is responsible for as few as three deaths per year, whereas alcohol and tobacco claim many thousands of lives. Has it not occurred to Julie Burchill that this is because many fewer people are habitual users of cocaine than of alcohol, or has cocaine addled her brain more than she realises?

Jamie McConnell
Cambridge

 Tuesday has long been Education day in the Guardian. This clearly explains why we were treated to Charlotte Raven's view that anyone who studies seriously at school is nerdish and perverted, to Julie Burchill's paean to cocaine (presumably as an alternative to the "dullness" of hard work) and to Matthew Engel's attack on the apostrophe as too difficult for some and therefore elitist and obsolete. As an economist, may I offer you a more obvious way of competing with the Sun? Price works every time.

Peter Daffern
Sunningdale, Berks
peter.daffern@culture.gov.uk

 Julie Burchill found the only way she could cope with her futile life was to take cocaine. What I can't understand is why she gave it up.

Tony Stowell
Tetbury, Glos

 What a lightweight. No missing teeth, septum or soft palette ...

Mark Serlin
London

 Most cocaine users I've met are the dullest, most boring and personality-free human beings alive, who need drugs to become even vaguely interesting. A bit like Julie really.

Richard Avis
Ipswich

 Julie alert: I think regular Guardian users should be warned, there is some low grade "Julie" being touted around certain sections of the paper at the moment. It may give the appearance of top quality stuff, but a quick "toot" confirms this "Julie" has been cut with some hoary old cliches and a fair quantity of filler. However, even if taken in full, there should be no serious after effects save an unpleasant taste in the mouth.

Dave Keighron
Bridgwater, Somerset

fields.headline: Diamonds not for ever
fields.standfirst:
If you buy a ring, will you fund a war lord?

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Diamonds are hugely valuable but very small. They can be hidden and smuggled with far greater ease than drugs, guns or oil, and once they are cut, their origin is impossible to discern; all of which goes to make them the war lord's best friend.
fields.body:
Diamonds are hugely valuable but very small. They can be hidden and smuggled with far greater ease than drugs, guns or oil, and once they are cut, their origin is impossible to discern; all of which goes to make them the war lord's best friend. The entire national diamond output of Sierra Leone can be fitted into one suitcase and yet it generates huge wealth - about $70m a year - for the rebels, funding nine years of civil war. The situation in Sierra Leone is matched by those in Angola and the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

Those who control the world's diamond business are worried and with good reason. They are haunted by the power of consumer outrage; it successfully slowed the fur trade and its next target could well be diamonds. Every day of coverage of Sierra Leone's tragic civil war, with its associations of rape, kidnap and amputation, makes a diamond consumer boycott more possible. The fear that such images could put romantic couples off tying the knot with a diamond ring is prompting traders and producers to devise an effective system of self-regulation. All agree that a consumer boycott would be disastrous for countries heavily dependent on a legitimate trade, such as Botswana, South Africa and Namibia. But the traders sense the noose tightening on them; unless they come up with an answer, they could find themselves lumbered with restrictive legislation, such as the bill in front of the US congress which calls for all diamonds worth over $100 to be certified. Last month in Kimberley, South Africa diamond traders and producers tried to hammer out a global certification system for rough diamonds and to think up ways of having it independently audited.

fields.headline: Burma's not all bad
fields.trailText: When we went to Burma to plead for clemency for our daughter Rachel Goldwyn, imprisoned there last September for demonstrating against the government, we took the Lonely Planet Guide. I believe it is a very fair book. It gives the history and suggests the reader make their own mind up about travelling to a country with a military dictatorship.
fields.body:
When we went to Burma to plead for clemency for our daughter Rachel Goldwyn, imprisoned there last September for demonstrating against the government, we took the Lonely Planet Guide. I believe it is a very fair book. It gives the history and suggests the reader make their own mind up about travelling to a country with a military dictatorship.

People desperately need jobs in Burma. It was sad to see the idle waitresses and to know that the taxi drivers, stall holders and other poor people who rely on the tourist industry are being deprived of a living. Meanwhile tourists rush to China. How many travellers check out the history of torture and repression of the countries they are visiting? What about Turkey, and even Singapore? The US and Europe greedily hurry to do business with the billions in China, while holding up their boycott of the 40m in Burma as an example to appease the human rights defenders. I do not believe in sanctions, they only hurt the poor.

In many countries, Aung San Suu Kyi would have been disappeared long ago. Thankfully she is still there and has recently been released from house arrest. Our daughter was not physically harmed in prison and was liberated to come home with us. Burma is one of the poorest countries in the world. We should encourage the ethical involvement of the west to raise the standard of living and improve the health and education of the disadvantaged.

Charmian Goldwyn
London
chum.goldwyn@virgin.net

fields.headline: Spreading the messages
fields.standfirst: Soon they will take up the whole office day
fields.trailText: Two years ago email users were spending 90 minutes a day on their habit. That has now risen to almost three hours, according to a survey by The User Group and on present trends could rise to four hours a day in a year's time.
fields.body:
Two years ago email users were spending 90 minutes a day on their habit. That has now risen to almost three hours, according to a survey by The User Group and on present trends could rise to four hours a day in a year's time. At this rate it will not be long before the entire working day is spent reading and writing emails, leaving no time at all for the business of actually making things. A variant of Parkinson's Law is happening in which the quantity of emails rises to meet the time available to read them.

Email has become the internet's "killer " application, even though none of the architects of the net ever predicted that it would happen. It soon evolved into a huge spur for business efficiency by breaking down bureaucratic layers in corporations and providing instant communications between and within companies all around the world. But business academics are now worried that information overload will start to make the whole phenomenon counterproductive. According to the TUG survey, the main problems inside companies do not come from externally generated junk mail or "spam" (which can be dealt with using electronic filtering) but from within. Millions of emails are created by employees playing office politics by sending out multiple copies to other people who do not really need them (and blind copies to others), or covering their backs by sending copies to managers who do not want or need to read them. This creates never ending "loops" of emails in transit, often referring to events that have already happened. There is only one thing worse than constantly being sent multiple copies of emails and that is the stress caused by not having any sent at all. ("Was it something I said? Am I out of the loop?"). Few companies have found a solution to email overload. But they had better do so before it starts to have a negative effect on growth - prompting the chancellor to think up a more radical solution: such as an email tax.

webTitle: MEPs face loss of expenses bonanza

fields.headline: MEPs face loss of expenses bonanza
fields.standfirst: The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Euro-MPs should be paid a uniform salary in return for agreeing to justify their notoriously inflated expenses as part of an effort to end their gravy train image, experts recommended yesterday.
fields.body:
Euro-MPs should be paid a uniform salary in return for agreeing to justify their notoriously inflated expenses as part of an effort to end their gravy train image, experts recommended yesterday.

According to an independent report submitted to the European parliament, all 626 MEPs should be paid around £57,000 but adhere to a new system that permits the reimbursement only of costs actually incurred.

Under current practice, some MEPs have been known to claim huge amounts without having to prove they incurred the expenses. Others have employed their wives and pocketed generous secretarial allowances. Daily attendance payments of around £160 have been especially open to abuse.

A key weakness is that MEPs can claim the equivalent of a first-class air fare on official business, even if they hitchhike to Strasbourg or to Brussels, where parliament also sits.

Currently, MEPs earn the same as their fellow national parliamentarians: the Austrians are the best paid, earning around £70,000; the Spanish the worst at just £20,000.

Most MEPs, but especially those from poorer member states, would earn more under the new system, but the recommendation has to be approved both by the parliament and all 15 EU member governments.

Britain's 87 MEPs would end up about £10,000 better off than MPs at Westminster.

MEPs are conscious of the need to end their occasionally sleazy image, especially after their role in bringing down the discredited European commission of Jacques Santer last year. But they insist that they deserve recognition for working long hours and travelling from their homes to Strasbourg and Brussels.

"Euro MPs are dragged into disrepute by a payments system which is outdated, indefensible and in urgent need of radical reform," said the Labour leader, Simon Taylor.

"Euro MPs must seize this chance to regain the respect of a disenchanted public. The taxpayer won't understand if they don't," he said.

The Conservative spokesman, Malcolm Harbour, hailed proposals that MEPs should have to account for other work-related expenses, such as secretarial assistance, office rent, postage and telephone charges, which can add up to £8,000 per month.

The report is based on a detailed comparison of the work of MEPs with national parliamentarians and other public officials.

It will now go to the parliament's legal affairs committee and its findings will be incorporated in a definitive proposal which must then be approved by member governments. So far, however, member states have been divided on their approach.

fields.headline: No: 1651 Arnold Schwarzenegger
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
Arnie In Big Gun Shocker? That's right, but this time he's refusing to carry one.

What's that? Are you saying the big man from Austria with the rightwing tendencies is going soft on firearms? He refuses to pose with a piece to promote his latest thriller, The 6th Day.

Ah, so on the 6th day the Lord decreed that all Hollywood stars stereotyped by appearing in muscle-bound action movies would henceforth unshackle themselves and be reborn as caring, sharing liberals? That's cynical. Be fair to Arnie: he's not a muscle-bound lug any more, he's a hugely versatile actor. He made Twins, for God's sake! And he's upset about all the killing 'n' that: Columbine High and that other shooting - Vietnam, was it? Can't you feel his pain when he says: "If people say movies lead to violence, we should make a concession."

What, by not making violent movies any more? So what do you think he should do then? Go back in time and put right all his gun-toting crimes against celluloid.

Sounds like an idea for a movie: Already in pre-production.

What's it called? Total Refund.

Who's in it? Arnie, Sandra Bullock, of course. And then there's a couple of cameos. Sister Wendy and that nice man who reads the weather - John Kettley.

Doesn't sound very exciting: That's the way the industry's going, darling. Haven't you seen American Beauty?

Don't see Arnie covering himself in rose petals. What happened to his millennial Satanist film? Binned.

So he needs a hit? Could say that.

Ah, it all starts to make sense. So this anti-gun moralising is double-spin? Anti-publicity publicity? Yup.

Surely there's some dirt we can dig on the man? Some wife-beating, coke-snorting secret life? Nope.

Nothing? Well, there was a rumour about under-endowment.

It's not a crime, is it? Not even in Hollywood.

fields.headline: The gift of life
fields.standfirst: Barry Scheck, right, is famous for defending OJ Simpson and Louise Woodward - but his passion is using DNA testing to free innocent people from death row.  Matthew Chapman  reports
fields.trailText: Barry Scheck was waiting to pass through security checks on his way into court when a man confronted him. "Barry," he said as he reached out to shake his hand, "we're going to needle Robert."
fields.body:
Barry Scheck was waiting to pass through security checks on his way into court when a man confronted him. "Barry," he said as he reached out to shake his hand, "we're going to needle Robert."

Scheck was confused. Robert Miller was Scheck's latest death row client, a convicted serial killer he believed to be innocent. What was this man talking about? After a moment's thought he recognised him. It was the lawyer in charge of all prosecutions in the local area. "I'm sorry," Barry said, "I don't know what you mean."

"You know, lethal injection, the needle," explained the prosecution lawyer. "We're going to needle Robert."

Miller eventually won his appeal after DNA evidence showed he was not responsible for a series of murders and was released in 1998. It was another successful case for the Innocence Project, a unique band of campaigning lawyers and students based on the 11th floor of a tower block in downtown Manhattan, New York.

On a crisp spring morning, Scheck, the man best known for defending OJ Simpson and the British au pair Louise Woodward, is burrowing through piles of paper on his desk. A mobile phone pressed to one ear, he is trying to locate a trial file and type out an email at the same time. Scheck is the whirlwind of energy at the heart of the Innocence Project. From their offices within the Cardozo School of Law, he and law professor Peter Neufeld pick cases and plot strategy. Their goal is to locate and release the thousands of wrongly convicted inmates they believe are languishing in America's prisons.

What makes their approach unique is their focus on the use of DNA fingerprinting: they weed through the thousands of begging letters from inmates and lawyers looking for cases where DNA could swiftly prove a prisoner's innocence.

Developed by a scientist at Leicester University, DNA fingerprinting has shifted the odds in favour of those protesting their innocence against a justice system that routinely rejects pleas for cases to be re-examined and that will punish inmates who fail to admit their guilt. "It's the gold standard of innocence," says Scheck. "The fastest way of pointing to someone and saying 'He didn't do it.' "

So far, at least 70 people owe their freedom, and in death row cases their lives, to the Innocence Project. This week one of Scheck's cases made an impact on the presidential campaign when Governor George W Bush granted a rare reprieve to a convicted child killer, Ricky McGinn, hours before he was due to be executed. Having boasted of overseeing 131 executions in Texas - more than any other governor in the nation - and having maintained that he knew none of them could be innocent, he displayed surprising self-doubt in allowing the inmate more time to conduct DNA tests.

Unsurprisingly, Scheck and Neufeld's methods have made them enemies in the legal community as local prosecutors around the country are confronted with their past misdeeds. DNA evidence holds up a mirror to the sloppy proceedings, poor police work, corruption and endemic racism that besets the system.

Scheck inspires adoration and loathing in equal measure. For some prosecution lawyers, like the one who promised to "needle" Robert Miller, it becomes a matter of honour to try to bring this icon of the legal world down a peg or two. His defence of OJ and Woodward earned him the dubious distinction of being voted by one magazine "The most loathed lawyer of the year".

He learned his uncompromising, hard-talking style growing up in the tough New York neighbourhood of Brooklyn, where his father, a former tap dancer, took young Barry along when he went to hang out with his mobster friends. He won a place at Yale, and after graduation spurned the offers of high-paying legal firms and plumped instead for the decrepit offices of Bronx Legal Aid. It was here that he developed a lifelong interest in forensics, which led inevitably to an interest in DNA and a realisation that for the first time the courts were being offered a way to prove once and for all the guilt or innocence of the accused.

There is a palpable sense of urgency in the air at the Innocence Project. Students eat their lunch amid piles of legal documents, phones are constantly ringing, impromptu huddles take place over desks to discuss strategy. All are aware that for many of their clients they are working against time.

"For every seven people executed in the US, one person is exonerated on the grounds of innocence," says Scheck. "Those odds are just terrible. For many people, we're their last hope."

Ronald Jones for one would agree. He is standing on the porch of his clapboard home near Memphis, Tennessee, contemplating a field of grass swaying in the breeze. "Ain't that beautiful," he says. Just four weeks out of prison and the smallest things still fill him with pleasure and wonderment.

Jones contacted Scheck after watching the entire OJ Simpson trial in his cell. "Boy, that man could talk, and I knew if anyone was going to get me a DNA test to prove my innocence, Barry would," he says.

As a small-time ex-con who suffered from partial brain damage, Jones was easy pickings for the Chicago police who pulled him in following the 1985 rape-murder of 28-year-old Debra Smith. Jones says he was beaten into confessing that he killed Smith after she took $10 for sex and then would not perform. The fact that they had no evidence to suggest Smith was a prostitute and that she had only slipped out to buy a chicken dinner for her husband seemed not to bother the police and prosecutors. Jones was heading for execution when the Innocence Project finally forced a Chicago judge to approve DNA testing that showed he was not the killer.

"It's strange," says Jones with a chuckle, "you're talking to a dead man right now. But I can't let myself get bitter - I've been given another chance and I intend to enjoy it."

Scheck has become a passionate advocate for the use of DNA in proving innocence and is surprised that the authorities in Britain do not appear to share his enthusiasm. The national DNA database here contains more than 650,000 profiles and has so far matched evidence found at crime scenes to 75,000 criminals. But, says Scheck, while Britain may be the world leader at putting people in prison using DNA evidence, we have a poor record of exonerating the innocent using the same means.

The fact that the Birmingham-based Criminal Cases Review Commission, which looks into miscarriages of justice, says it has only two or three DNA cases on its books, is particularly puzzling for him. "Frankly, I'm surprised," he says. "I've spoken to them and their docket does not include enough of those cases. I think that solicitors, barristers and families of the inmates who claim innocence, who could use DNA to prove it, should be pushing a lot harder."

Since his release from jail in Oklahoma, Robert Miller has struggled to come to terms with life on the outside. "I never saw the sun go up or down, never walked under the moon at night," he told his lawyer Gavin Isaacs. "Never heard a bird singing, or saw a squirrel running in my path. Never felt the wind on my back or the rain in my face. I never went swimming, got my feet wet, walked up in the mud and felt the mud between my toes."

And the lawyer who bragged to Barry Scheck that he would ensure Miller got "the needle"? A few months after Miller's release, he was elected a judge.
