The national DNA database here contains more than 650,000 profiles and has so far matched evidence found at crime scenes to 75,000 criminals. But, says Scheck, while Britain may be the world leader at putting people in prison using DNA evidence, we have a poor record of exonerating the innocent using the same means. The fact that the Birmingham-based Criminal Cases Review Commission, which looks into miscarriages of justice, says it has only two or three DNA cases on its books, is particularly puzzling for him. "Frankly, I'm surprised," he says. "I've spoken to them and their docket does not include enough of those cases. I think that solicitors, barristers and families of the inmates who claim innocence, who could use DNA to prove it, should be pushing a lot harder." Since his release from jail in Oklahoma, Robert Miller has struggled to come to terms with life on the outside. "I never saw the sun go up or down, never walked under the moon at night," he told his lawyer Gavin Isaacs. "Never heard a bird singing, or saw a squirrel running in my path. Never felt the wind on my back or the rain in my face. I never went swimming, got my feet wet, walked up in the mud and felt the mud between my toes." And the lawyer who bragged to Barry Scheck that he would ensure Miller got "the needle"? A few months after Miller's release, he was elected a judge.

fields.headline: War of words
fields.standfirst: What use is drama if your country has been torn apart by fighting?  Richard Crane  finds out in Serbia
fields.trailText: What use is drama if your country has been torn apart by fighting? Richard Crane finds out in Serbia
fields.body:
It is as if a giant boot had snapped the bridge in two then kicked its rump into the bank. It sits there like a beggar, displaying its deformities, and once in a while an American comes to take photographs to show the folks "what we did", not noticing that barely 200 metres away a new bridge over the Danube has been quietly built in record time.

It is our first sight of the Serbian town of Novi Sad as we arrive for the 10th International Symposium of Theatre Makers, Critics and Scholars. The theme is Theatre and War.

As we pull up at the hotel, we notice a strong police presence. The driver explains: "Terrorists." He is referring to the students from the banned organisation OTPOR who all week have been gathering to protest against the shutting down of the university and Studio B, the independent broadcasting station.

The protest in Novi Sad tonight takes the form of a rock concert in the square. As we cross to go to the National Theatre, a half-naked singer is screaming into the crowd, but no one seems unduly roused. We enter the vast foyer of the theatre. The play Maksim Crnojevic is a Serbian classic about the tragic history of the Balkans. It should be a powerful prelude to the symposium, but the production is stilted, and bears no comparison to the more adventurous Roberto Zucco we saw at the Atelier 212 in Belgrade.

In the foyer we meet Nada, a journalist. She tells us her name means "hope" in Serbian, "nothing" in Spanish. She is part of the symposium, but she wants to help; and talk. She leads us upstairs, through bars, down through understage tunnels in search of the symposium organisers. She talks about the bombing: "Why 20 bombs when the first one did it?"

The next day we return to the National Theatre. The stage is laid out with long tables in "V" formation. There are 37 theatre critics, playwrights, directors and experts from 11 countries (18 from Yugoslavia) gathered to address the question: what can theatre do in a time of war?

The committee president begins by quoting Drodsky: One should never make a choice to be a victim." The theatre's primary task, she believes, is to ask for the impossible. Then the Croatian professor starts.

His thesis is Richard III and the war in Yugoslavia. He talks of the climate of depression that is driving his colleagues into exile or suicide. He calls for a revolt of the "laity" against the dominance of nationalism. Shakespeare is everywhere in the Balkans: Iago manipulating mistrust and self-destruction; Richard III fixing his own succession through assassination and corruption of both government and opposition; Romeo and Juliet shot dead on the bridge in Sarajevo; no place for Hamlet the thinking prince.

The mind wanders to an encounter we had in Belgrade. We were in a fish restaurant by the Danube, when a guy in shorts and T-shirt joined us. "I'm Boris, the fixer," he said. He was in the army in Kosovo last year on the Macedonian border. He sold toy Kalashnikovs (made in China) to the Kosovan kids, and the French K-for troops bought them to take home as souvenirs.

A young playwright, who was a conscript in Kosovo last year, is saying that theatre in a time of war is closer to Chekhov than Shakespeare, the tragedies of small destinies. "We were dealing with day-to-day things: the truckloads, the fridges, the belongings, the families." In his play, he talks about the mentality of his own people who have lost respect for history. His protagonist is crippled by Aids. There is an explosion from another playwright on his left: "People with Aids are not cripples! Rape cannot be used as an excuse for a little tragedy! You can't explain wars by finding reasons in the past." The Croatian professor agrees: "If we overcome the past we shall be able to live in the present." The atmosphere is heating up and there is an uncomfortable nationalistic exchange that turns us into uneasy spectators of a weary struggle for the survival of the spirit.

Later at our hotel the soldier playwright joins us at dinner. He won't eat. He is traumatised by his experiences in Kosovo. He says he didn't kill or rape anyone but he listened as his friends were raping the women next door.

Next day we change our plans, abandon any idea of an academic paper and instead leave the table and the headphones and move into the centre of the V formation to allow theatre to speak for itself. We move from The Trojan Women through plays we have created about the Gulf War and the Balkans. In all these the subject was not the war, but what lay under the war and what was left behind, the detritus, the mess, the jokes in the trenches, the songs.

The closing speeches of the symposium are emotional. It was nearly cancelled last week because of the tension in the streets, but here we all are seeing at first hand what theatre can and cannot do in a time of war. The Serbs are weary, but there is an elation in the air, too. The symposium took place. The isolation was temporarily broken. Maybe theatre can do something.

And then an unexpected last moment. As we are leaving Novi Sad, a fleet of black cars pulls up in front of the government building near our hotel. A grey-haired man steps smartly out of the front car, acknowledges the polite subdued applause, and slips quickly inside. President Slobodan Milosevic has come to this oppositional city, to open the new bridge, but the only protest we hear is a young soldier in uniform swearing under his breath.

fields.headline: It's long. But very strong
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney: Napoleon
fields.trailText: Abel Gance's 1927 epic Napoleon was shown in its latest version, now running at five and a half hours, at the Royal Festival Hall on Saturday, with live orchestral accompaniment composed and conducted by Carl Davis.
fields.body:
Abel Gance's 1927 epic Napoleon was shown in its latest version, now running at five and a half hours, at the Royal Festival Hall on Saturday, with live orchestral accompaniment composed and conducted by Carl Davis. It was magnificent, awe-inspiring, colossal, sublime - all those words you use when you look at a work of art and find your critical reactions defused by its enormity.

A colleague has another word for Gance's film - "oppressive" - and it is hard to disagree. Napoleon is oppressive not just because of the length, but because of the scope of the imagery and the kind of story it tells. The film's famous triptych-screen ending, with Bonaparte leading his armies into Italy and towards the creation of his empire, was followed on Saturday by a standing ovation. Davis and the orchestra deserved it for endurance alone, and yet there is something unsettling about standing to cheer a film that was so manifestly designed to rouse you to just such a response.

Seeing Napoleon "live" is not really like going to a movie, more like going to contemplate the Parthenon. The film, as we have it today, is a phenomenal work of reconstruction, undertaken over many years by Kevin Brownlow (joined on this extended version by Bambi Ballard), and now expanded by 40 minutes from the version shown at the Empire Leicester Square in 1980. That screening at once created a new audience for the major silent works and founded the institution of "live" silent cinema.

Napoleon has been overshadowed in public memory by the ending, in which the single screen expands into a tricolor triptych, a massive animated political banner. But there are so many other types of cinema here: the grotesque comedy of the clerks under the Terror, saving the condemned by eating their files; sentimental melodrama, in the figure of Violine, who worships Bonaparte from afar; luscious debauchery à la Stroheim, with the hordes of bare-breasted revellers at the Victims' Ball. There are battle sequences that prefigure, even outstrip Vietnam cinema in their extremity, partly because they come freshly soaked in echoes of the first world war.

Then there is the commentary on cinema itself. Napoleon is not just a great general, but a great film-maker. As a child, he "directs" a snowball fight; later in life, devising a strategy, he stages the battle in his mind as a montage of maps and diagrams. No wonder the film found special favour with Francis Ford Coppola, who relived the equation when he made Apocalypse Now.

The strangest thing about Gance's film, however, is the insistence with which it invokes destiny. It is less the biography of an emperor than the story of someone fated to be an emperor - not quite the same thing.

The film, in fact, is as much about the icon as it is about the man - when Bonaparte is first acclaimed as a hero, Napoleon dolls go on sale in Paris. You could see Gance's film as an exploration of modern history's first personality cult.

Actor Albert Dieudonné - gaunt, rather stiff in his forbidding severity - has so much become the defining screen image of Napoleon that there is something ghostly in the impersonation. It is as if, through Dieudonné's performance, Bonaparte himself becomes an expert actor, brilliantly impersonating his own legend. Or rather, Bonaparte becomes a sort of monomaniac, obsessed from childhood with the figure that he will one day be. Gance's film, you might say, is the case study of a fixation, of a Napoleon impersonator who performs his act so single-mindedly that he actually ends up leading an army into Italy. It's the story of a man who - quite rightly, as it turns out - thinks he is Napoleon.

webTitle: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: James Brown/Eminem
fields.body:
Spare a thought for the lawyers of James Brown lawyers. In the Los Angeles County Superior Court on May 19, a $1m lawsuit was brought against the Godfather Of Soul for sexual harassment and unfair dismissal. And, frankly, it isn't going be easy convincing a jury that your client is a shy, retiring and abstemious man when they've had it drummed into their heads for three decades that he's a sex machine.

The statement on behalf of the plaintiff - Lisa Ross Agbalaya, who used to work for New James Brown Enterprises - even uses that song as their opening gambit. "It appears that 'Sex Machine' is more than simply a title to one of James Brown's many hit records; it would also appear to be a description for James Brown the man." According to Agbalaya, Brown told her that the government had given him bull testicles so that he could come "harder and stronger than ever".

Of course, Brown is no stranger to the court room, having spent three years inside after threatening a random group of businessmen with a shotgun, and then unsuccessfully trying to speed away from the police down the freeway. He was also sued in 1998 by a woman who claimed that he had held her hostage. It's just as well his lawyers are well paid: for once, they are going to have to earn it.

And so, by a logical progression, to this week's traditional hip-hop story. The ever charming Eminem (Marshall Mathers to the courts) was nicked in the early hours of Sunday morning after a punch-up at a Detroit club. Apparently, Marshall was lounging with some homies - and, oddly enough, the woman he keeps threatening to kill on his records - when some punters thought they'd have a go. Next thing you know, the fuzz have collared four people, including the rapper. Mathers was sprung late on Sunday afternoon, but will face charges.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Quiet Revolution/Frontiers
fields.body:
Bishopton Road in Middlesbrough used to be known as the Beirut of Teeside, its badly battered houses empty and boarded up. The turning point came in 1993 when a group of residents rebelled against the crime and vandalism wrecking their lives and took decisive action. They raised £10 million for a self-build scheme to answer two basic needs - decent housing and a steady job. Now, as Felicity Finch discovers in Quiet Revolution (11.0am, Radio 4) people are lining up to live there.

Peter Evans tries to cast a new light on one of mankind's oldest conundrums, what makes adolescents such a complete pain to everyone around them. Their behaviour is usually explained by the bubbling state of their hormones, but Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4) reports on research suggesting that incomplete brain development may be a more relevant factor. Some scientists now think the synaptic connections governing behaviour may not all have been completed in the teenaged brain.

fields.headline: Strictly speaking
fields.standfirst: Andrew Bovell, co-writer of Strictly Ballroom, tells  Michael Billington  why he loves British theatre
fields.trailText: Andrew Bovell, co-writer of Strictly Ballroom, tells Michael Billington why he loves British theatre
fields.body:
We complain about British theatre. But we forget we have a lot to be grateful for. Meeting Andrew Bovell, co-writer of Strictly Ballroom and author of Speaking in Tongues, which comes to Hampstead Theatre this week, I felt cheered by his affirmation of faith. He arrived on his first visit to Britain from Australia a month ago wondering whether his future lay in film. "What I've discovered," he says, "is a culture that still seems to celebrate the craft of the playwright. I'm going to go back home bursting to write."

Bovell was born in Kalgoorlie, a mining-town in Western Australia, and later studied drama in Melbourne. He started writing plays in the 80s for the Melbourne Workers Theatre - which was literally based in a train-maintenance depot.

"The workforce," he says, "was winding down but there was an incredibly rich fund of stories as people had to make decisions about their future. We'd perform in the depot to mechanics, metalworkers, electricians and cleaners.

"My generation," Bovell continues, "defined itself against what came before: people like Ray Lawler, David Williamson, Jack Hibberd. Their concerns were very specific: who are we? what kind of country do we want to be? Those aren't our preoccupations. We know who we are. The great cultural preoccupation of the moment is reconciliation between black and white. And there's a lot of energy coming from the artistic community on that subject because we have a government that pretends it doesn't exist."

Reconciliation between black and white is not the only issue. Bovell describes his play, Speaking in Tongues, as "part thriller, part conundrum about the nature of commitment, betrayal, the loss of trust between men and women. The audience is confronted by nine parallel stories and is left to fit the pieces together. If theatre is going to separate itself from film, it has to find new forms."

But film remains one of Bovell's passions: he points out that a writer can't sustain a career in Australian theatre. Unusually, he also started out by co-writing a global hit in the shape of Strictly Ballroom. "It began as a group-devised work at Nida (the Sydney drama school) where it was simply dance-sequences with dramatic tableaux. My task was to fill out the plot so that the love story of Scott and Fran became a metaphor for Australian multiculturalism. At the same time, Baz Luhrmann kept urging me to keep it simple: we looked at a lot of Hollywood 40s dance-musicals and used their boy-meets-girl structure. I thought we'd made a strange little film: Baz was convinced it would reach a wide audience. But, though I could have gone on to become part of his team, I broke away because I had too many stories to tell."

Since then Bovell has co-written a cult film called Head On about a young gay Greek-Australian and a much-admired play entitled Who's Afraid of the Working Class. But, having listened to siren-voices at home telling him the playwright is dead, his London exposure to plays like Blue/Orange and Dolly West's Kitchen has left him fired with new enthusiasm. It's a salutary reminder that our theatre's reputation still rests heavily on our dramatists. It sometimes takes a wayfarer from Oz to point that out.

Speaking in Tongues opens tomorrow at Hampstead Theatre, London (020-7722 9301).

fields.headline: Rock solid bohemians
fields.standfirst: More philosophy, less sex!  John O'Reilly  meets the Dandy Warhols
fields.trailText: More philosophy, less sex! John O'Reilly meets the Dandy Warhols who have a new album out
fields.body:
Thirteen Tales From Urban Bohemia is the new album from the Dandy Warhols. Tale one about the band is that their last album, Come Down, is a dreamy wash of psychedelic pop with more harmonies than a resort of Beach Boys. You might recall the catchy late 90s boredom of Not If You Were The Last Junkie On Earth: "I never thought you'd be a junkie because heroin is so passé."

It is early afternoon and singer and guitarist Courtney Taylor, bass and keyboard player Zia McCabe, guitarist Peter Holmstrom and new drummer Brent De Boer are physically in a Kensington restaurant, but are mentally occupying mid-west time. McCabe's confession that "I normally don't let the band members taste my Woo-Woo" refers to a cocktail that is designed for this conversational double entendre, but the Portland band are bored by their press billing as rock'n'roll orgiasts. Taylor winces: "The press around Come Down was all about 'crazy, wacky, randy, dandy, sex-crazed, drug' - like a bunch of fuckin' amateurs. It was embarrassing."

If their name is a flippant gesture to the king of the 60s art world, there are also musical tics to Andy Warhol's house band. You can hear echoes of the Velvet Underground in the Dandys' hypnotic song structure, and the faux-dry Lou Reed timbre of Taylor's vocals on tracks such as Solid.

Taylor describes the shift in sound on the new album as "hypnosis": "It seems so fucking easy for us to lay on 15 tracks of guitar. But with this album it was 'Can I do this with just the melody, without layering on harmonies?' There's not nearly as many harmonies on this record."

Compared to the Velvet Underground's tight roll-neck, loft-space psychedelia, the Dandys' psychedelia is big, warm and communal. Despite the weariness about rock'n'roll excess, the inspiration for their name came partly from Warhol's legendary parties at the Factory. Taylor reflects: "Our scene was pretty much exactly the same as the Factory, with film-makers, painters, musicians."

Whereas Warhol's parties were productions, the Portland scene is devoid of east coast self-consciousness. Taylor says: "We had parties but they were a lot more fun, a lot less strung out, and a lot more naked in the pool. In Portland it's not cool to be strung out but it's still cool to be beautiful, smart, and get naked with your friends." Taylor adds, in the self-mocking tone of their songs: "At least we made it fashionable for a while."

It has been three years since the last album which would normally mean a flurry of record company memos. But the band are relaxed about it, says Taylor: "The battles we fight with [the] label are about time and the resources. Time, genius, or money? Pick any two."

Listening to both Come Down and Thirteen Tales From Urban Bohemia you get the sense of a band playing out the history of rock. Every track seems like a hallucination of great pop hooks and melodies from the Byrds to the Stones and Nirvana. But the songs fool you into thinking you have heard them before simply because they sound like classic pop.

By definition, great pop is sexy and its basic formula is the reduction of sound to a singular irresistible feeling. Taylor explains his songwriting process: "Every song has one specific emotion with only enough movement to keep it maybe playing out into every corner of that room. You know that these chords, in that order with these melodies, produces this emotion."

And sex? "The thing about your music being sexual is that certain things like harmonies and the high-end open up the top of your head. What's happening in the low-mid range gives you that physical con stitution." The new album opens with the bitter Godless, a track filled with acoustic guitar, feedback and the Mariachi sound of a trumpet lament.

It is followed by the spooky falsetto and Gimme Shelter-guitar licks of Mohammed, and then the five-minute long Nietzsche, where west coast pop meets thumping Sturm and Drang over the graffiti philosophy "I wanna God who stays dead not plays dead".

Big themes? "Yeah they're a philosophy roll-call," says Taylor. The lyrics to Nietzsche confirm the fact that student toilets are the contemporary equivalent of Plato's Academy. As McCabe explains: "When Courtney said they were on the bathroom wall I thought he was speaking metaphorically but it really was on the bathroom wall."

There's more variety on the new album with songs like Big Indian, a piece of epic country pop sung by Taylor in the tones of Ray Davies, and the head shaking, body sway ing Bohemian Like You. So where does the title come from? "That's what all the lyrics are about, me writing about me or me writing about us," says Taylor. "Everything that happens in our lives is so fucking urban bohemian. We're so not suburban, and we're not urban chic at all, we're just a bunch of modern hippies."

The gossipy stories of the band's excess do communicate something about the Dandys. The bizarre X-rated panto of the music business is Warhol's Factory writ large and given their inspiration it would be surprising if the band did not have a take on it.

They put the ease into sleaze. Like the story of one of their label bosses who, Taylor says admiringly, "is a sleazy, sleazy man. He's the coolest guy in corporate rock. If we had 10 of him at Capitol our worries would be over."

Thirteen Tales From Urban Bohemia is out on Monday. The Dandy Warhols are currently on a UK tour.

fields.headline: The final frontier
fields.standfirst: What's your dream home? A 'flying saucer' in the Pembrokeshire hills? Or how about a mud hut? Space, a new BBC series on bizarre houses and their owners, has lessons for all of us.  Jeff Howell  explains
fields.trailText: What's your dream home? A 'flying saucer' in the Pembrokeshire hills? Or how about a mud hut? Space, a new BBC series on bizarre houses and their owners, has lessons for all of us. Jeff Howell explains
fields.body:
Our homes have become a fetishised leisure pursuit in which experts urge us to walk the holy grail to lifestyle perfection. Or, if you prefer: Architecture creates the backdrop to our city lives, making it the one art form in which each of us is daily implicated.

These aren't my words, you understand. They are screen captions from a new TV series about architecture. Of course, it has never occurred to 99% of the population that they might be lifestyle fetishists, or that their homes might implicate them in anything approaching an art form. After all, the message put across by the usual crop of TV building shows is that you live in it, you decorate it, and you might just try sticking up a few DIY cupboard units.

But Space comes as a welcome change. This three-part series explores a selection of modern homes and the people who live in them, and it does it well. The camera work, production and interviewing style are top-drawer, and the editing, in places, is very witty. This is just as well, because this sort of quality is needed to make up for the fact that the architectural subject matter can be rather tedious.

One of the problems with modern architecture is that the profession itself hijacked the term "modern" in the 1920s, leaving the rest of us to get confused about the differences between modernism and modernity. And of course anything more modern than modern is post-modern, if you get my drift. Modernism is also closely linked with minimalism and functionalism, which is why most people associate modern domestic architecture with uncluttered open-plan spaces, bare white walls and stainless steel staircases leading up to spartan sleeping platforms. Funnily enough, this stereotype does crop up remarkably frequently in Space. All spontaneous individual creations by the architects concerned, of course.

But some of the homes explored in the series are genuinely interesting. The first programme kicks off with Labour MP Bob Marshall-Andrews, who lives with his wife in a glass and concrete flying saucer snuggled into the Pembrokeshire coast. Their tranquil home life is disturbed only by the sound of screeching brakes, as passing tourists stop to gawp and take photographs.

Not far away is a different type of modern house, built from mud and logs by a solstice-worshipping drop-out from the civil service. Tony Wrench's break with the daily office grind came after his management appraisal interview. What do you see yourself doing in five years time, they asked him. Tony decided to take to the hills. This tale, and his frank description of how to use his composting toilet, are gems.

But most of the homes explored in the series are real modern modern, even those like Richard Rogers' London pad which has a new functionalist interior within the gutted shell of a Georgian terrace. Rogers is famous for the Pompidou Centre and the Lloyds Building, so when the local council granted him planning permission to remodel his house they asked if he wouldn't mind keeping the plumbing on the inside of the building.

John Young's functionalist London penthouse is so famous that it has become a shrine for worshipping architecture students. On an open day one admirer is waxing lyrical about the design: "one can live modern like this," he enthuses, "and this is today - and I think it's fun to be today". Cut to another visitor knocking himself almost unconscious on a protruding piece of stainless steel. Another gem.

John Young's colleagues rib him that if he ever sells the flat they'll be waiting outside to salvage all the bits that the new owners chuck into the skip. His wife couldn't stand it and moved out with their child.

In fact a dominant theme that emerges from the series is that modernist architecture really does seem to be a boy's thing. In the interviews the women are mostly absent or silent, or when they do speak it is to voice concerns, especially about the impracticalities of the designs in relation to their children. Some of the ordered modernist spaces shown in the series are not only free of clutter; they seem to be free of anything . Bare white walls and nothing else. Surely nobody can really live like that. Tell me they've tidied up specially for the cameras. But when there are children on the scene, there is no way of avoiding the mess, so where does that leave the concept of functionalism, exactly?

The last word in the series lies with John Pawson, described as the godfather of minimalism, and another architect whose home is a gutted Victorian terraced house with a plain white interior. His wife insisted on a sofa and a rug, but he still won't let her put her photographs up on the walls. He describes minimalism as a fight against the natural human instinct to collect things. Most people feel better when they cut down, he says, although it can be hard work. He makes it sound like giving up smoking. John's current project is designing a monastery.

Space, 9.50pm, BBC2

fields.headline: Great shot
fields.standfirst: When photographer Ravi Deepres goes to football matches he focuses on the fans, not the players. He talks to  Chris Arnot
fields.trailText: When photographer Ravi Deepres goes to football matches he focuses on the fans, not the players. He talks to Chris Arnot
fields.body:
Wembley in the summer of 1996: Gareth Southgate is stepping up to take that penalty. The one that seemed to take an eternity to roll across the turf. In reality it's a split second, during which Ravi Deepres reacts faster than the German goalkeeper. One eye takes in events on the pitch, while the other focuses on a section of the crowd. His camera catches them at the very moment where tension drains from their faces to be replaced by stunned disbelief.

Only a few minutes earlier he had photographed the same people celebrating England's penalty. "They were different from one another and I'm sure they hadn't known each other before the game," he recalls. "Yet all their movements are the same." All bar one. On the edge of the picture is a man in specs looking pensive. Obviously a German.

Paris in the summer of 1998: France have just won the World Cup and, on the Champs-Elysées, Deepres is trapped in a crush of humanity. For the first time in his photographic tour of major football events, he feels frightened. He sees cars being turned over and feels that the celebratory mayhem is being infiltrated by dark forces. "Some of the French hooligans put the fear of God into me," he admits. But he holds his video camera above his head long enough to capture the image he wants.

Safely back home, he fed it through the TV set and photographed it from the screen. "I wanted a coarse and grainy texture to disrupt the image," he says. "Then I processed it through a computer to make subtle manipulations." The result is similar to an impressionistic painting, conveying a sense of danger. Faces are indistinct. Clouds of smoke can be seen in the background while the foreground is dominated by that part of the French flag which is blood red.

Birmingham's Jewellery Quarter in the summer of 2000: Deepres is in the offices of Vivid, a production centre for media arts, trying to decide which of his images to show in a forthcoming exhibition. Vivid is showcasing 10 artists, but Deepres's work is likely to take centre stage. "We've moved the event back a week to the eve of Euro 2000," says the director, Yasmin Baig Clifford. "Ravi's images tie in with it so well."

His final show will probably be a triptych with a video screen at the centre, linking two still print images. The pre- and post-Southgate penalty photographs are contenders. So is the crowd scene on the Champs-Elysées, and a close-up of a French fan with face painted. It was taken outside St James' Park, Newcastle, during Euro 96. When Deepres approached with his camera, he was told in impeccable English, to "fuck off". He did. But from a safe distance, he used a zoom video lens.

"It gave me a degenerated, rough image which seemed appropriate," he says. "What intrigues me is that some fans dress normally for matches and others dress up and paint their faces to the point where their nationality takes over from their individuality. Their whole psychology changes and they become part of a mass for one day. I'm using football to explore the notion of identity."

What drew him to a particular section of the Wembley crowd during the England-Germany penalty shootout was a tall, rangy black man. To his left was a studious-looking youth, the red cross of St George underscoring his spectacles. To his right is a man with blue eyes and a receding hairline, wearing a check shirt. The black man, like everybody else, is punching the air to celebrate England scoring a penalty. Yet his white T-shirt is inscribed with "Jamaica".

No wonder Deepres was intrigued. His own identity might be considered even more confused. He was born in Liverpool 30 years ago, the son of an Indian sea captain and an English woman with a Flemish name. His father died when he was two and young Ravi moved around the country with his mother. She has now settled down as an organic farmer in Devon while he moves between homes in London and Birmingham. He is an occasional visiting lecturer in fine art photography at Newcastle University. As that is the city where he spent more of his childhood than anywhere else, he supports Newcastle United. England as well, despite having been at closer quarters with its hardcore fans longer than some of us might care to.

"I'm not saying that I'd go around with the Chelsea Headhunters. No way," he says. "You can usually tell when any trouble's about to start and make a sharp exit. Most of the fans are fairly good-natured. I usually tell them I'm doing pics for the paper and they're quite happy. They're drunk most of the time, and the Scottish supporters even more so."

He was at Wembley for two recent matches against England's old enemies - Germany in 1996 and Scotland last year. On both occasions there was no shortage of banter or bile on display. Yet some of his most memorable pictures from those great crowd-pulling events reveal no faces at all. One of the twin towers is reflected in the shimmering water of a leaf-strewn puddle. A St George's flag, illuminated with gold lights from using a long exposure, is unfurled like a knight's pennant to reveal the illustrious name of Bournemouth FC. Hand gestures aimed at the Germans are captured at a moment when they have an almost balletic gracefulness. Perhaps it is no coincidence that his other major interest is modern dance.

But football is his passion. "A few people making gestures can lead to anything up to 50,000 following suit. Large movements of fans intrigue me. It can be like a strong current of water, pushing and pulling you along." As he discovered in Paris, the current can sometimes run out of control. Undeterred, he is planning to head for the Low Countries after the Birmingham exhibition. Euro 2000 beckons.

Some of Ravi Deepres's football work will be on show at Vivid, Now! in the Big Peg in Warstone Lane, Birmingham (0121-233 4061) tomorrow and Friday.

webTitle: British open fire on Serbs in Kosovo clash

fields.headline: British open fire on Serbs in Kosovo clash
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: British troops yesterday fired into a crowd of Serb civilians, injuring three, after they surrounded Brigadier Richard Shireff, the commander of the British sector of Kosovo.
fields.body:
British troops yesterday fired into a crowd of Serb civilians, injuring three, after they surrounded Brigadier Richard Shireff, the commander of the British sector of Kosovo.

The incident, which is one of the worst since Nato-led troops entered Kosovo exactly a year ago, occurred as Serbs gathered to protest against a drive-by grenade attack at a crowded market in the monastery town of Gracanica, close to Pristina.

The grenade attack, which wounded five shoppers, touched off a melee. Serbs began stopping Albanian cars on the road through the town, setting five vehicles alight and injuring two drivers.

Hearing of the incident, Brig Shireff rushed to the scene but was almost set upon. The Nato spokesman, Captain Jo Butterfill, said his bodyguards had felt threatened and fired into the crowd.

Brig Shireff later met Father Sava Janjic, a leader of the moderate Serb faction, to try to ease tensions. Serbs said they began stopping vehicles after Swedish troops stationed in the town failed to block the car which carried out the grenade attack.

"It was thrown right in front of K-For [Nato peacekeepers]," said Dragan Stojanovic. "How come they weren't able to stop that car? Aren't they ashamed?"

The Serb national council said the grenade attack was only the latest "wave of organised Albanian terrorist groups seeking to expel Serbs from Kosovo".

"We have repeatedly told K-For that the market in Gracanica is a dangerous site ... but Nato has found no solutions for the problem," Fr Janjic told the private news agency, Beta.

Unlike most Serb communi ties in Kosovo which have been reduced to isolated enclaves, Gracanica straddles a key main road connecting the capital with the southeastern city of Gnjilane.

K-For maintains roadblocks for spot-checks on traffic, but the peacekeepers usually wave vehicles through without searching them. Serbs often set up their own roadblocks to deter Albanians from driving through the town.

The incident comes two days after the Serb national council walked out of the UN-led government of the province in protest at a spate of attacks on Serbs in the last fortnight. Eight Serbs, including a four-year-old boy, have been killed.

The increase in violence against Serbs comes as two Serbs have gone on trial in the town of Mitrovice, in northern Kosovo, accused of committing war crimes during the conflict last year. The men, one of whom is being tried in his absence, are accused of expelling Albanians from the province and burning their homes.

The international community agreed to speed up the trials of suspected war criminals after Serb prisoners staged a hunger strike to protest against their detention for weeks without trial.

At the height of the hunger strike as many as 1,000 local Serbs gathered outside the jail every day.

The top international official in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, was only able to break the deadlock over the hunger strike by giving in to almost all the prisoners' demands. He persuaded them to give up their protest in return for prompt trials before an international judge.

An international judge is presiding over the hearing, assisted by a panel of lay judges made up of two Serbs and two Albanians.

fields.headline: This side of paradise
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Michael White
fields.trailText: Last night's: Reputations/Can You Live Without Your Wife/The Horror Of...Flatmates
fields.body:
Well, what a surprise. Sir Anthony Eden (1897-1977) was just the kind of Tory politician - good-looking, posh, and a spectacular failure in the premiership - to whom you would expect the clever young men from the telly to give a good kicking, just to make sure he was properly dead.

In BBC2's Reputations series what we got instead was Maria Milne's respectful, rather superficial assessment of what was, until the disastrous 1956 invasion of Suez, a remarkable life, packed with drama.

Admittedly the film casually blamed Eden for sending 40,000 Russian prisoners who had fought for the Germans back to Stalin and death in 1945, and for not joining Europe in 1956, both unfairly. But all too often Joanna David's well-mannered narrative evoked the Bended Knee School of Biography. It lacked bite.

There were pleasing cameo portraits. Eden was a sartorial dandy, and you could tell from the grainy footage that women voters of all classes adored him ("peach skin and dancing eyes" recalled a lustful old constituent), an upmarket version of Cecil Parkinson. He looked as glamorous - the only word - as Douglas Fairbanks.

The late Alan Clark, a family friend, popped up to flash that vulpine smile and admit that the womanising Eden ("he always smelt delicious") took a crack at his own mother. But, despite the Military Cross at 20, the hard work and the 1938 resignation as Foreign Secretary over appeasement - or was it pique? - men always had their doubts.

So did Barbara Castle. She called Eden a Noel Coward character with no grit or judgement. Lord Bill Deedes mistrusted his weakness for double-breasted waistcoats ("so did my tailor"). Most damning of all, Milne's film reminded us that, on his last night in Downing St, the great Churchill had sat on his bed and declared: "You know, I don't think Anthony can do it." It took barely a year to find he couldn't.

Whichever way you slice it, this film was a case of lost opportunities. We all know Eden secretly colluded with France and Israel to invade Suez, the final fling of the doomed British Empire. But why did he try to deceive his friend Eisenhower in the week (unmentioned here) of the 1956 presidential election? And why did he think Nasser was another Hitler anyway?

Was it his illness, the pills he needed after the botched operation on his gall bladder? Vanity, the impatience of a crown prince eager to prove himself ? Or something deeper? As someone once quipped, Eden's trouble was that he was "half beautiful woman, half mad baronet", the child of privileged but spectacularly bad parenting.

Interesting, eh? But we hardly got a word of it from Reputations. Nor of the horror of the Flanders trenches which made the teenage officer a Tory liberal and paternalist, a vehement opponent of war. Odd that, because it had the opposite effect on Corporal Hitler, with whom Eden spoke at length in the 30s ("I rather liked [his] shyness") and may have shot at in 1916. (They fought in the same sector on the Somme.)

Sir Anthony would not have coped as well with the kids, the cooking and the washing machine as father-of-two Cliff Slades did when his wife, Julie, went to France for two weeks. In Can You Live Without Your Wife? (Channel 4) Cliff was shown just-about coping as Beth (12) and Mike (10) grappled with homework, hormones and Dad's curry.

It can hardly be claimed that the experience turned Cliff into a New Man, since he called his mum over as soon as he found he couldn't open the washing machine door. But he is clearly going to be more appreciative of Julie from now on. So the programme did no harm.

Jo Brand's overpowering presence, on the other hand, did harm The Horror Of... Flatmates (BBC2), another fly-on-the-wall series. Jo is rather a large fly and it would probably have been funnier to let her subjects talk direct to camera rather than buzz around them.

Still it was good to meet uptight Tom (24), a disciplinarian who charges his flatmates an extra fiver a night for guests, the Kiwis who pack 18 people into a four-bedroom house, and the two predatory twentysomethings who pick up the men whose skills match their flat renovation needs. Watch out fellas, they're looking for a plumber.

fields.headline: Doctor 'blundered three times'
fields.trailText: A nurse had to intervene on three occasions after a doctor's blunders in an accident and emergency department, the General Medical Council heard yesterday. Fiabema Adda Oruwari, 46, of Kentish   Town, north London, was working as a senior house officer at Stafford district general hospital when he made serious errors in the space of 48 hours, it was alleged.
fields.body:
A nurse had to intervene on three occasions after a doctor's blunders in an accident and emergency department, the General Medical Council heard yesterday. Fiabema Adda Oruwari, 46, of Kentish Town, north London, was working as a senior house officer at Stafford district general hospital when he made serious errors in the space of 48 hours, it was alleged.

One of the blunders involved a 10-year-old girl with a head injury. Dr Oruwari, who denies serious professional misconduct, did not appear to understand the seriousness of her condition, Sally Howes, representing the GMC, told its professional conduct committee.

Dr Oruwari is also alleged to have inadequately assessed a woman with serious facial cuts and to have failed to properly treat a man who had collapsed and had a fit.

He denies all the allegations. The hearing continues.

webTitle: Random views: What skateboarders are watching on TV

fields.headline: Random views: What skateboarders are watching on TV
fields.standfirst: Sin Pattenden talked to skateboarders in Regent's Park, London
fields.trailText: Sin Pattenden talked to skateboarders in Regent's Park, London
fields.body:
Shana Law: "I watch some TV on the weekends and things like that, but I don't really get time during the week because I'm at college and I have a bar job in the evenings. I'm Australian and I find a lot of the English sense of humour absolutely classic. I just love Brookside, do you know what I mean? I think that has to be the most disgusting accent on the planet, I think it's hilarious. And they all moan all the time and sit in that horrible bar. I'd like to see Bar Brookie's health and safety certificate, I would, because it doesn't look hygienic at all."

Tom Mitchell: "I'm an Aussie too but I don't like Neighbours, no I don't. Nor Home And Away. I think they're shallow pieces, really do. I like listening to music - a lot of classical stuff, actually. I sometimes watch that Art Zone thing on Sundays and I must say I haven't got into that much. Not enough opera. Did I see Music Live? Yeah, load of bollocks."

Andrew Haveling: "What are you talking about? TV? Yeah, I watch it all the time. No, I'm not usually rollerblading, this is the first time, and I'm crap. My mate persuaded me to do it. I think he's run off to get an ice cream because there's a girl he fancies at the stall. I watched EastEnders, but only when Bianca and Tiffany were in it, I liked them."

Paulo J: "I have been here for about, um, four days and I have not had a chance to see much TV, but I get it at home in Spain, on cable. I like The Simpsons very much, I like the Bart Simpson and the Maggi, I think I very much identify with them, hahahah! I am a baby! hahah! Difference in TV over here? I believe you have not so much pornography, which is a shame, hahahah! And in Spain there is bullfighting still on and that is very good, very good for the vegetarians. You have no proper food here. I am trying to get a job on Eurotrash, hahahahah! I'd like to meet the nice women and chat them up. I am good at that."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Who Wants To Marry A Multi-Millionaire?/Great Expectations/Contact/A Bronx Tale
fields.body:
Who Wants To Marry A Multi-Millionaire?

9pm, Living

The world's first game show marriage, featuring the most watched nuptials since Charles and Diana finally gets an airing in the UK. After trawling through thousands of hopefuls, 50 women tottered into Vegas for the chance to declare their undying devotion to Rick Rockwell's millions. A truly bizarre cattle-market, in which the multi-millionaire sits in a darkened booth watching the hopefuls waddle in front of him in swimsuits and little black dresses until he choses which one to buy, er, marry.

Great Expectations

(David Lean, 1946)

7am, Carlton Cinema

This is possibly the best screen Dickens. The eerie, gothic tone is set in the opening scene - Pip's graveyard encounter with Magwitch - and reaches through the film to abandoned Miss Havisham's embittered existence. The flawless cast includes John Mills and Valerie Hobson as the grown-up Pip and Estella, plus Martita Hunt, Jean Simmons and Alec Guinness.

Contact

(Robert Zemeckis, 1997)

2.05pm, Sky Premier

Jodie Foster (pictured) is an astronomer convinced that there must be aliens out there, and after much meditation, gets a chance to pilot her own space odyssey. Foster makes us feel the obsession, and Zemeckis, too, is committed to this serious exploration of the skies. Largely, it succeeds; although with Alien veterans Tom Skerritt and John Hurt on board, you might think at times that in space, no one can hear you yawn.

A Bronx Tale

(Robert De Niro, 1993)

10.20pm, FilmFour

De Niro walks the familiar mean streets of Scorsese-land in his accomplished directorial debut. In the Bronx of the early 60s, little Calogero (Francis Capra, and later Lillo Brancato) falls under the influence of local crime boss Sonny (played by Chazz Palminteri), while the boy's honest dad Lorenzo (De Niro) fights to keep his son on the straight and narrow. A rights-of-passage movie exploring issues of friendship and loyalty, it's impeccably shot - there's a richly evocative soundtrack too.

fields.headline: 'Victimised' banker settles case
fields.trailText: An RAF reserve officer who claimed he was a victim of racial discrimination when an international bank dismissed him has withdrawn his complaint.
fields.body:
An RAF reserve officer who claimed he was a victim of racial discrimination when an international bank dismissed him has withdrawn his complaint.

Sebastian Nokes's case against Credit Suisse First Boston has been settled, the Department of Trade and Industry said yesterday.

A preliminary hearing at Stratford, east London, in March, heard that Mr Nokes, 35, who worked in London, claimed he was forced out of his job after serving four months in Kosovo for the Royal Auxiliary Air Force. He said he would not have been sacked if he had been Swiss, and wanted reinstatement to his £75,000-a-year job.

A DTI spokesman said yesterday that the case had now been settled. "We received a letter from Mr Nokes on May 26 saying the two parties had come to an agreement." The bank declined to comment.

fields.headline: Woman obsessed with hospital life
fields.trailText: Social workers and doctors are trying to find a way of dealing with an obsessed but clinically sane woman who has been removed from a busy hospital 170 times in three months.
fields.body:
Social workers and doctors are trying to find a way of dealing with an obsessed but clinically sane woman who has been removed from a busy hospital 170 times in three months.

The 29-year-old mother is thought to have an unusual condition which impels her to make transitory friendships with strangers in a crowded place - like the Northern General hospital in Sheffield which is on her doorstep.

Security men have escorted her from the hospital up to seven times a day, after staff found her pretending to be a patient or wearing medical clothing. She has also been discovered napping in empty beds on wards and making snacks in the hospital's kitchens.

"She doesn't have a medical problem but it seems that she has a social problem which needs addressing," said Ron Little, spokesman for the Northern General which is the Yorkshire city's largest hospital and operates an open-campus policy.

"She has never been violent or made trouble but she does cause difficulties for our medical and security staff. By the nature of the work we do, we have to be open to the public, and on the rare occasions that this is abused, we have got to be vigilant."

The woman, whose parents also live locally, has been offered a range of support options by social services and voluntary agencies, but has either refused the help or failed to stick with it. She has also been seen recently by hospital psychiatrists and has been declared sane and not someone who could be detained under the compulsory section of the Mental Health Act.

webTitle: Holocaust recalled, Queen opens permanent exhibition

fields.headline: Holocaust recalled, Queen opens permanent exhibition
fields.trailText: The Queen was visibly moved yesterday after meeting a handful of Holocaust survivors when she opened a British exhibition dedicated to remembering those slaughtered by the Nazis.
fields.body:
The Queen was visibly moved yesterday after meeting a handful of Holocaust survivors when she opened a British exhibition dedicated to remembering those slaughtered by the Nazis.

The permanent exhibition, which took four years to put together, is housed in a new £17m wing of the Imperial War Museum in London.

It includes artefacts of the genocide, such as a cart used to collect the dead in the Warsaw ghetto, a 13-metre long model of Auschwitz, and filmed testimony of survivors.

Esther Brunstein, who lived through the horrors of Auschwitz and Belsen, told the Queen how the exhibition had transported her "back to a time when I lived on another planet when evil reigned supreme".

She said that for her the need to survive so she could tell of what happened in the concentration camps was what kept her alive.

"Just to survive one day in the camp and retain a sense of humanity was itself an act of resistance," Mrs Brunstein said.

"Yet atrocities go on in the world today and the tragedy is that we still haven't learned the lesson."

While the main part of the exhibition concentrates on the suffering of European Jews, the persecution and extermination of other groups such as Gypsies, Poles, homosexuals, Soviet prisoners of war, and disabled people is also documented.

fields.headline: Pub landlady 'killed regular with drink'
fields.trailText: A pub landlady and her husband killed a drunken customer by forcing him to drink a lethal cocktail of spirits during a bet, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A pub landlady and her husband killed a drunken customer by forcing him to drink a lethal cocktail of spirits during a bet, a court heard yesterday.

Teresa Browning, 34, and her husband Kevin, 36, are on trial at Winchester crown court jointly accused of the manslaughter of Barry Gates.

A jury was told how Gates, 44, collapsed and died after drinking from a pint glass filled with whisky, gin, vodka, bacardi and brandy.

Mrs Browning was licensee at the Kingston Tavern, Kingston Road, Portsmouth, when Gates died on June 7 last year.

fields.headline: Child 'killed and hidden under floor'
fields.trailText: A nine-year-old girl was lured to her death by a family friend who sexually assaulted, raped and killed her, and then hid her underneath his floorboards, Newcastle crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A nine-year-old girl was lured to her death by a family friend who sexually assaulted, raped and killed her, and then hid her underneath his floorboards, Newcastle crown court heard yesterday.

Colin Bainbridge, 35, self-employed, was decorating at Laura Kane's home in Tyne and Wear last August the day before she disappeared. The prosecution alleges he killed Laura at his home in Murton, Co Durham, after luring her there. At an earlier hearing he had pleaded not guilty to murdering and raping her.

John Milford QC, prosecuting, said: "He does not dispute that Laura was in his company when she died."

The defendant had been friendly with Laura's mother, Carol Kane, for a few years, the court heard. He played games with Laura and her siblings which sometimes involved tying them up, but he was not seen as a threat. On the day Laura disappeared, August 25, Mrs Kane had gone shopping. She returned to find Laura gone.

On September 4 police searching Mr Bainbridge's home were led by an unpleasant smell and flies in the sitting room to Laura's body. He said Laura had died when a tying-up game went wrong. The case continues.

fields.headline: Sviatoslav Fyodorov
fields.standfirst: Russian surgeon unable to translate medical success into politics
fields.trailText: Sviatoslav Fyodorov, who has died in a helicopter crash aged 72, was a rarity in the world of the new Russian business and political elite: a man who made his money through transparently legal means.
fields.body:
Sviatoslav Fyodorov, who has died in a helicopter crash aged 72, was a rarity in the world of the new Russian business and political elite: a man who made his money through transparently legal means.

A pioneering eye surgeon, who developed the technique of radial keratomy (making small incisions around the cornea) to cure short-sight, he was widely respected by Russians. His assembly-line operating theatres, and string of clinics, meant that there were few who did not know someone who had undergone the operation - and thrown away their spectacles for good.

But he failed to translate this reputation into political success; when he stood against Boris Yeltsin in the 1996 presidential elections, his programme of "democratic capitalism" - or employee profit-sharing - failed to win the necessary 5% vote to avoid elimination after the first round of polling.

Fyodorov's background is confused. He was born in the Ukraine, to a father he described as a Red Army commander who fell victim to Stalin's purges. But in one interview, he said his father, Nikolai, was a village blacksmith. His early career at the Rostov-on-Don flying academy ended after he had a leg amputated, following an accident, and he transferred to the medical institute. After post-graduate studies, he was appointed head of a regional eye institute.

In 1960, he performed the first artificial lens implantation in the Soviet Union, and worked on the production of crystalline lenses. In 1967, he moved to Moscow as head of the artificial lens implantation laboratory, working on surgical treatments for glaucoma.

By the early 1970s, Fyodorov had developed his surgical technique for correcting myopia, by making a series of small cuts into the cornea, which, when they heal, make the cornea contract and vision improve. His approach required less precision than similar operations performed in Japan in the 1940s, and thus allowed surgeons to be more certain of the outcome. At first, the work was denounced as anti-physiological, but by 1980 it was recognised both in the Soviet Union and abroad, and Fyodorov was appointed director of the Moscow institute of eye micro-surgery.

Unusually, he was allowed to keep the majority of his hard-currency earnings, using the money to buy hi-tech equipment from West Germany and develop a conveyor-belt technique for patients, who lay on operating tables which rotated from surgeon to surgeon - allowing the operation to be performed in little more than 15 minutes.

By 1986, growing economic liberalism under Gorbachev made it possible for Fyodorov to open his own string of independent clinics and fit out a passenger ship as a mobile operating theatre. At first he was seen as a figurehead for what could be possible under perestroika, but two years later became a focus of attacks from hardline communists.

Strange patients began turning up at his home, two of his surgeons were arrested on trumped-up bribery charges, and eventually a prominent Soviet politician demanded that he hand over 80% of his foreign currency earnings to the state. Fyodorov fought back, telling a pro-reform newspaper: "The fight for power is now the fight for property. If people get property, they will get power. If not, they will forever remain hired hands."

In 1989, he was elected to the Congress of People's Deputies and, as an advocate of privatisation, was offered the post of prime minister by Yeltsin in 1991, which he declined. He left the pro-Yeltsin Democratic party of Russia and joined the Party of Economic Freedom. His ideas of economic liberalisation trod a third way between the communists and Yeltsin's full-scale adoption of free-market capitalism.

What Fyodorov termed "democratic capitalism" or "popular socialism" was, he said, inspired by Deng Xiaoping in China and Ross Perot in the United States. In 1995, he formed the Party of Workers' Self Rule and was elected to the State Duma, remaining a deputy until his death.

Fyodorov's failure in the 1996 presidential election was indicative of the way that liberal economic ideas have failed to capture Russian voters. He also attracted criticism for an incautious remark about Hitler having done much to restore German pride. He did, however, remain in the public arena, giving his employees a share of the profits from his clinics, which expanded overseas, and branching out as a sharp and able businessman in other areas.

His last public statement reflected his aims as a surgeon and a politician. "We have one goal. To make it so that people live well, so that they see well . . . we are proving the potential of the Russian people, the potential of its talents, the potential of self-organisation, the potential of enterprises being self-sufficient, the potential of regions being self-sufficient."

Fyodorov married three times, and is survived by his wife and four daughters.

fields.headline: Japanese parents kill violent son
fields.trailText: Fresh evidence of the dangerous generation gap that is opening up in Japanese society emerged yesterday when a middle-aged couple admitted killing their son because they lived in terror of his violent and unpredictable temper.
fields.body:
Fresh evidence of the dangerous generation gap that is opening up in Japanese society emerged yesterday when a middle-aged couple admitted killing their son because they lived in terror of his violent and unpredictable temper.

The murder, which follows a series of brutal youth crimes, has added to fears that today's parents and teachers are losing control of teenage children, whose moods and values are increasingly the subject of worried media scrutiny.

Yuzo and Yumiko Kumagai told police that they strangled their 15-year-old son, Yuki, because they were afraid that he might kill someone.

Yuki, a tall, slim boy who was a member of his school basketball team, had reportedly beaten up his younger brother and smashed up the house the previous day. He had reportedly terrorised his parents for more than a year.

The case has an all too familiar ring in Japan, where the term "domestic violence" is just as likely to apply to tyrannical children who physically abuse their parents as vice versa.

According to sociologist Yuko Kawanishi of Temple University Japan, the situation has grown progressively worse during the past 20 years.

"Many parents are treated like slaves. Work-obsessed fathers are absent so often that they lose their authority and mothers can't handle the situation alone," she said. "This situation is made worse because families try to keep up appearances so nobody talks about the problem until it is too late."

While the murder is shocking, there is likely to be considerable sympathy for Mr and Mrs Kumagai. The Japanese public has been horrified in recent weeks by murders and assaults committed by teenagers, whose motives have been as shocking as the crimes.

Early last month, a 17-year-old boy hijacked a bus and killed one passenger with a butchers knife because, he said, "I wanted to do something that would make people sit up and take notice of me."

The same week, another teenager broke into a stranger's house and stabbed a housewife to death. "I wanted to experience murder," he explained to police.

Soon after, another 17-year-old took a hammer to the head of a sleeping commuter on a subway train, a crime he carried out to achieve notoriety.

With statistics confirming an overall rise in violent youth crime, the government has moved to take action against a generation that is increasingly seen as a threat. The juvenile law is to be tightened so that young offenders can be given stiffer punishment and the education ministry has set up a panel of psychiatrists and sociologists to assess the reasons for the apparent breakdown in values.

Many academics are already drawing disturbing conclusions. "Today's teens grew up with virtual reality, which has caused them to develop virtual personalities rather than fundamental human values," psychologist Yoshihisa Tanaka of Hosei University told one local newspaper. "They see others as mere instruments."

fields.headline: Johanna Peters
fields.standfirst: Operatic singer who breathed new life into teaching courses
fields.trailText: Johanna Peters, who has died at the age of 68, was one of the stalwarts of the British opera scene for more than 40 years. At first, she was a mezzo, who brought intelligence and character to a wide range of roles. Then, while continuing to sing occasionally, she devoted most of her energies to administration, direction and teaching.
fields.body:
Johanna Peters, who has died at the age of 68, was one of the stalwarts of the British opera scene for more than 40 years. At first, she was a mezzo, who brought intelligence and character to a wide range of roles. Then, while continuing to sing occasionally, she devoted most of her energies to administration, direction and teaching.

In her last appointment, she was wholly dedicated to her work as head of vocal studies at London's Guildhall School of Music, and previously had breathed new life into the opera course as head of opera. Earlier, she held similar posts at what was then the Birmingham School of Music. She could be a strict taskmaster; her high standards demanded complete dedication from her pupils. Two currently successful performers who benefited from her methods are the sopranos Janice Watson and Sophie Daneman.

Peters and her friend and companion, Anne Wood, herself a singer and administrator, kept their small company, Phoenix Opera, on the road for many travail-laden years with very little subsidy. They presented works in a true, traditional fashion, without resort to concepts or gimmicks.

Peters was born in Glasgow and studied at the National School of Opera in London. In 1958, she appeared as Jocasta in a performance by the Oxford University Opera Club of Stravinsky's Oedipus Rex. The following year she made her mark at Glyndebourne, where she gave her first professional performances, as Marcellina in Le nozze di Figaro, returning in the same part in 1962.

She sang Dame Carruthers in The Yeoman Of The Guard, at the Tower of London in Anthony Besch's staging of the Gilbert and Sullivan classic in 1962, and the same year took the title part in Arne's Artaxerxes at the St Pancras Festival, a performance that received glowing reviews.

When Britten's English Opera Group visited Russia, Peters undertook the role of the wise Bianca in The Rape Of Lucretia, and the eccentric Florence Pike in Albert Herring, both roles suited her ability to characterise a part. The same year, she appeared in London, as Mrs Baggott in Britten's Let's Make An Opera.

Her Mrs Peachum at the Bankside Globe in 1972, and her Nurse in Boris Godunov with Covent Garden in 1974, when Christoff was Boris, were both successes. For Phoenix Opera, she was a charming Nancy in a rare revival of Flotow's Martha in 1973. One of her last appearances was in Wolf-Ferrari's The School For Fathers, with Phoenix Opera at the Camden festival in 1983, where she was quite outrageous as the tetchy, tippling Margarita.

On radio, Peters took part in the first broadcast of Phyllis Tate's The Lodger. In concert, she was often heard to advantage in Monteverdi, Purcell and Handel. She also broadcast frequently as part of the lively duo she had formed with the soprano Patricia Clark.

Her voice was an unusual instrument with an individual timbre, particularly strong in the lower register, and she deployed it with real care, authority and artistry over a wide range of notes and roles. Later, from her pupils, she demanded a similar commitment - as she did when she acted as an adjudicator.

Peters loved to exchange views on the operatic situation, and expressed her own in strong language laced with a pronounced Glaswegian accent. She was always frank in her opinions, but her approach was consistent and constructive.

For many years, she and Anne Wood, who predeceased her, shared a home in St John's Wood, London, where they were always generous hosts. It was a place where opera was discussed ad infinitum. In the 1980s, they were trustees of the Peter Pears Singing Award, both having had close connections with Aldeburgh.

fields.headline: Merton Miller
fields.standfirst: US economist whose capital asset theory aided business
fields.trailText: The American economist Merton Miller, who has died aged 77, was hailed as the founder of modern finance after his pioneering work won him the Nobel prize for economics 10 years ago.
fields.body:
The American economist Merton Miller, who has died aged 77, was hailed as the founder of modern finance after his pioneering work won him the Nobel prize for economics 10 years ago. A member of the Chicago school of free-market economists who challenged Keynesian orthodoxy in the the 60s and 70s, he made his name by providing advice for corporations on how to cut taxation and finance investment more efficiently. He had recently fought a long battle against lymphoma.

An only child, Miller was born in Boston, Massachusetts, and followed in his father's footsteps to Harvard in 1940. Even at that early stage, he was interested in making money work more efficiently, describing once how he used to shuffle his account from bank to bank in order to be paid interest.

"You could get an interest-paying savings account in Harvard Square, providing there wasn't too much activity in your account," he recalled. "I would get my monthly allowance and put it in one of the local banks, making small withdrawals every day to pay expenses. After a while, I would get a notice from the bank saying that there was too much activity in my account and they were closing it out. So, I would walk my money across the street to one of the other banks. There were four of them, one on each corner. I just put the money in the next bank. That way, I managed to have a checking account without paying transaction fees."

After Harvard, Miller worked for the US government, first in the tax research division at the Treasury, and then in the research and statistics division of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve, America's central bank. In 1949, he decided to return to academic life, joining the graduate school at John Hopkins University, Baltimore.

After receiving his doctorate, Miller's first academic post was a one-year stint as a visiting assistant lecturer at the London School of Economics in 1952-53, and he subsequently spent eight years at the Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie-Mellon University) in Pittsburgh, then at the cutting edge of research-driven American business schools.

While at Carnegie, Miller began a long collaboration with fellow Nobel prizewinner Franco Modigliani, and the first of their so-called M&M papers on corporate finance was published in 1958. In 1961, he joined the graduate business school at Chicago, where, apart from a one-year spell as visiting professor at Louvain in Belgium, he worked until his retirement in 1993.

His Nobel prize, awarded in 1990, established a theory for the relationship between the structure of a firm's capital assets and its market value. Miller argued that managers looked after the best interests of their shareholders by maximising the firm's net wealth rather than worrying about their credit rating. "What counts is what you do with your money, not where it came from," he once said.

Asked to explain his complex theory in 10 seconds, Miller told the story of an interchange with reporters. "I said: 'If you take money out of your left pocket and put it in your right pocket, you're no richer.' Reporters would say, you mean they gave you guys a Nobel prize for something as obvious as that? And I'd add: 'Yes, but remember, we proved it rigorously.'"

The author of eight books, Miller also served as a public director of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. He is survived by his second wife, Katherine, and three daughters from his first marriage.

Merton Howard Miller, economist, born May 16 1923; died June 5 2000

A member of the Chicago school of free-market economists who challenged Keynesian orthodoxy in the the 60s and 70s, he made his name by providing advice for corporations on how to cut taxation and finance investment more efficiently. He had recently fought a long battle against lymphoma. An only child, Miller was born in Boston, Massachusetts, and followed in his father's footsteps to Harvard in 1940. Even at that early stage, he was interested in making money work more efficiently, describing once how he used to shuffle his account from bank to bank in order to be paid interest. "You could get an interest-paying savings account in Harvard Square, providing there wasn't too much activity in your account," he recalled. "I would get my monthly allowance and put it in one of the local banks, making small withdrawals every day to pay expenses. After a while, I would get a notice from the bank saying that there was too much activity in my account and they were closing it out. So, I would walk my money across the street to one of the other banks. There were four of them, one on each corner. I just put the money in the next bank. That way, I managed to have a checking account without paying transaction fees." After Harvard, Miller worked for the US government, first in the tax research division at the Treasury, and then in the research and statistics division of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve, America's central bank. In 1949, he decided to return to academic life, joining the graduate school at John Hopkins University, Baltimore. After receiving his doctorate, Miller's first academic post was a one-year stint as a visiting assistant lecturer at the London School of Economics in 1952-53, and he subsequently spent eight years at the Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie-Mellon University) in Pittsburgh, then at the cutting edge of research-driven American business schools. While at Carnegie, Miller began a long collaboration with fellow Nobel prizewinner Franco Modigliani, and the first of their so-called M&M papers on corporate finance was published in 1958. In 1961, he joined the graduate business school at Chicago, where, apart from a one-year spell as visiting professor at Louvain in Belgium, he worked until his retirement in 1993. His Nobel prize, awarded in 1990, established a theory for the relationship between the structure of a firm's capital assets and its market value. Miller argued that managers looked after the best interests of their shareholders by maximising the firm's net wealth rather than worrying about their credit rating. "What counts is what you do with your money, not where it came from," he once said. Asked to explain his complex theory in 10 seconds, Miller told the story of an interchange with reporters. "I said: 'If you take money out of your left pocket and put it in your right pocket, you're no richer.' Reporters would say, you mean they gave you guys a Nobel prize for something as obvious as that? And I'd add: 'Yes, but remember, we proved it rigorously.'" The author of eight books, Miller also served as a public director of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. He is survived by his second wife, Katherine, and three daughters from his first marriage. Merton Howard Miller, economist, born May 16 1923; died June 5 2000

fields.headline: Cardinal Sladkevicius
fields.trailText: The influence of Cardinal Vincentas Sladkevicius, who has died aged 79, would probably have been less if the Soviet authorities in Lithuania had left him alone.
fields.body:
The influence of Cardinal Vincentas Sladkevicius, who has died aged 79, would probably have been less if the Soviet authorities in Lithuania had left him alone.

Exile from his diocese, Kaisiadorys, to a remote village for 23 years - from 1959-82 - increased his hold over his people. He became a focal point for petitions by priests and laity, for religious liberty in general and for his reinstatement (together with that of Bishop Julijonas Steponavicius of Vilnius) in particular. His quiet determination and modest bearing united the people behind the common front of church and secular forces.

Sladkevicius was born into a humble farming family. The Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, followed by the Soviet invasion of 1940 and subjugation to the Germans a year later, produced a shock which hardened his young resolve. He studied at a Catholic school, entered the Kaunas seminary in 1939 and was ordained as a priest in March 1944.

Serious Soviet persecution of religion began soon after the end of the second world war, the Catholic church being (rightly) viewed as a bastion of Lithuanian nationalism. Sladkevicius managed to evade deportation by carrying out his priestly duties mainly in secret. His nomination in 1952 to a permanent post at the only Catholic theological seminary in the USSR (Kaunas) was followed by the death of Stalin and a slight hiatus in the anti-religious campaign.

His consecration as a bishop was carried out secretly by Bishop Teofilius Matulionis on Christmas Day, 1957. But by then, Khrushchev's persecution had begun. Sladkevicius was barred from the seminary, and, two years later, was exiled without accusation or trial to the remote village of Nemunelio Radviliskis.

Ironically, this move served only to heighten his profile. His actual living conditions were tolerable; at times, he could receive visitors, increasingly so as Lithuanian believers began raising his case internationally. Sladkevicius encouraged the compilation, translation into Russian and clandestine dispatch abroad of the Chronicle of the Lithuanian Catholic Church, which, from 1972, was one of the most influential samizdat publications.

Among its most reiterated themes was the demand for the return to diocesan administration of Sladkevicius himself. By the time the Soviet authorities allowed this, on June 8 1982, he was president of the Lithuanian Bishops' Conference. On his visit to Rome in May 1988, he was appointed Archbishop of Kaunas and the first Lithuanian cardinal for 400 years.

Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika policies had come later to Lithuanian Catholics than to the Russian Orthodox church, but when conditions did ease - with the reconsecration of Vilnius cathedral in February 1989 - church leaders, taking their cue from the cardinal, were as vocal as secular figures in calling for Lithuanian independence.

This came finally at the end of 1991, with the collapse of Soviet communism, by which time Sladkevicius was a sick man. The culmination of his life's work came when he received Pope John Paul II in Vilnius and Kaunas in September 1993. He retired in 1996, and was able to hand over a flourishing diocese to Archbishop Sigitas Tamkevicius, who himself had been released from prison only eight years earlier.
