fields.headline: Technical fault on derailed Eurostar
fields.trailText: A piece of equipment which became detached from below the leading coach could have led to the derailment of the London-bound Eurostar train in northern France, the Eurostar group said last night.
fields.body:
A piece of equipment which became detached from below the leading coach could have led to the derailment of the London-bound Eurostar train in northern France, the Eurostar group said last night.

The company said that the thick stick-like reaction arm had become loose and was "being considered as a possible factor in the incident". Eye witnesses in the first coach talked of a "hard piece of metal whizzing by outside the window".

This was described by investigators as part of the power transmission equipment. All Eurostar trains are being checked in Paris and London before entering service.

Eurostar, which is jointly operated by French railways, Belgian railways and Eurostar UK, said that four of the 24 wheel sets left the tracks.

The 501 passengers and 16 crew escaped serious injury when the 18 passenger carriages remained upright as the train, travelling at 150mph, skidded to a halt. There were four minor injuries.

Eurostar, which runs services from London's Waterloo station to Paris and Brussels, cancelled four of its trains yesterday and there were delays of up to 30 minutes on other Eurostar services.

French railways, on whose territory the accident occurred, said that a technical inquiry was under way, and that the French ministry of transport had called for an investigation. Safety checks on Eurostar's fleet are stringent. This is the first derailment of a Eurostar train since its introduction in November 1994.

Returning passengers to London from the Eurostar train gave accounts of the incident. Steve Nicholls, a mobile phone company manager, said: "There was a long sheet of orange flame all the way along the outside of the carriage. We all laid on the floor because we thought we were going to die." Lottie Stephenson, an art journalist, who is eight months pregnant, said: "I just thought of the Paddington rail disaster."

Mark Watts, Labour transport spokesman, said that there had to be a public inquiry in the three countries involved.

fields.headline: Hundreds sacked at 'Germany's Dome'
fields.trailText: Germany's Expo 2000 world fair is fast fulfilling fears that it could be the Teutonic equivalent of Britain's ill-fated Millennium Dome after it was revealed yesterday that more than 500 staff employed on the project had been sacked because of a drastic shortage of visitors.
fields.body:
Germany's Expo 2000 world fair is fast fulfilling fears that it could be the Teutonic equivalent of Britain's ill-fated Millennium Dome after it was revealed yesterday that more than 500 staff employed on the project had been sacked because of a drastic shortage of visitors.

The Adecco employment agency said 523 part-time staff it had engaged to work in bistros and souvenir shops at the Hanover fair had been handed their cards because the event had attracted only 360,000 visitors in its first four days - less than half the expected 760,000.

"This was inconsiderate. The expo is damaged when businesses panic like this," said Adecco spokesman Peter Fischer. A further 400 jobs at the fair were threatened, the agency said.

The layoffs were the latest in a series of embarrassing gaffes that have dogged the fair since it opened last Thursday.

The opening included the unedifying spectacle of the Polish president climbing on to a roof to escape being stuck in a lift.

The Expo's organisers said yesterday that they were doing their utmost to prevent a repeat of Sunday's mishap in which the fair's computer system broke down, causing the loss of some DM1.8m (£560,000) in takings.

But there were growing signs of dissent about how the event was being run. Klaus Zwickel, the leader of Germany's powerful IG Metall metalworkers' union and a member of the Expo board, demanded that the admission price of DM69 (£22) be lowered.

"The entry fee is definitely too high. Many employees wonder whether they can afford it," he said.

However, the organisers said they had no immediate plans to lower the entry fee.

Attendance problems have been compounded by the antics of radical "Expo No" demonstrators, who complain that the fair is a celebration of capitalism.

Germany's federal prosecutor has been called in to investigate the sabotage to high speed rail lines to Hanover on Monday by some of the protesters, which caused several train services to be suspended.

fields.headline: Search for victims
fields.standfirst: Growing death toll on Sumatra island in wake of earthquake
fields.trailText: Indonesian rescuers yesterday struggled to reach victims of a powerful earthquake that has killed more than 100 people and injured hundreds more on Sumatra island.
fields.byline: Staff and agencies, Beawiharta  in Bengkulu
fields.body:
Indonesian rescuers yesterday struggled to reach victims of a powerful earthquake that has killed more than 100 people and injured hundreds more on Sumatra island.

Police expect the death toll to rise because of the difficulty in contacting remote areas of Bengkulu province on Sumatra's west coast, the region worst affected by Sunday night's earthquake, which measured 7.9 on the Richter scale.

Bad weather, minimal electricity, damaged roads and the closure of Bengkulu airport have hampered rescue efforts, which were called off at nightfall yesterday.

"The quake caused several landslides in the south of the province and it is tough for rescuers to reach that area because some roads have been blocked by tonnes of earth," Police Sergeant Edy Somes said.

The earthquake's epicentre was 70 miles offshore from Bengkulu, and was felt as far away as Jakarta and Singapore.

Police yesterday put the death toll for Bengkulu town, the provincial capi tal, and nearby districts at 103. They had no figures for outlying areas.

Officials in Jakarta said preliminary reports estimated damage in the province at 50bn rupiah (£4m).

Aftershocks rippled across the province yesterday. "We are still living in trauma. Today there was a moderate quake and we can also feel other tremors, which puts everyone into a panic," said Awang, a telecommunications worker.

Many of the town's 260,000 residents prepared for another night in makeshift shelters.

Australia said yesterday it would provide A$500,000 (£190,000) in aid.

webTitle: Lennon looks to hook up with O'Neill

fields.headline: Lennon looks to hook up with O'Neill
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland midfielder Neil Lennon said yesterday he would like to follow Martin O'Neill to Celtic. Leicester City interviewed Joe Kinnear yesterday in their search for a new manager amid concerns that O'Neill's departure would lead to the team breaking up.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland midfielder Neil Lennon said yesterday he would like to follow Martin O'Neill to Celtic. Leicester City interviewed Joe Kinnear yesterday in their search for a new manager amid concerns that O'Neill's departure would lead to the team breaking up.

Lennon is on O'Neill's wish list, along with Matt Elliott and Stan Collymore, and the £6m-rated midfielder would relish a move to Parkhead.

"Were Celtic to make a bid for me and Leicester allowed me to talk to them it would become a very serious option," he said. "Myself and Martin were as close as it ever gets between a manager and a player and it's fair to say I was desperately disappointed when he left."

Kinnear spent only 40 minutes at Filbert Street, which may indicate that the former Wimbledon manager will have to wait a little longer to find himself an employer. Instead it seems likely that Leicester will attempt to find a manager in the Nationwide League, with Bolton's Sam Allardyce, Barnsley's Dave Bassett, Huddersfield's Steve Bruce, Gillingham's Peter Taylor and Tranmere's John Aldridge among those under discussion.

Steve Walsh and Tony Cottee tabled their joint bid during an hour-long interview yesterday in which they mooted the idea of installing the former West Ham manager John Lyall as director of football. "We were extremely pleased," said Cottee. "It went as well as we could have hoped."

 Hull City directors have offered £1.4m to buy Boothferry Park, after its owner David Lloyd locked the club out of their ground this month. "The price was basically my asking price plus £100,000, which is back rent, and I have accepted it," Lloyd said.
